cards.term: What are the reagents that can be used to test carboxylic acid? What are the corresponding observations?
cards.definition: Universal indicator - pH of weak acidReactive metal - hydrogen effervescenceMetal carbonate - carbon dioxide effervescence
Saturated organic compounds that contain carbon atoms and at least one halogen atoms.
Insoluble as C-H bonds are non-polar, not compensated for enough by C-X bond polarity.

cards.term: Do halogenoalkanes have a polar bond? Why?
cards.definition: Yes polar, as halogen has a higher electronegativity than C (halogen is \xce\xb4-, carbon is \xce\xb4+).

cards.term: What type of intermolecular forces do they have? Why?
cards.definition: Permanent dipole-dipole and London forces of attraction C-X bond polarity creates permanent dipoles.

cards.term: When would they have higher boiling points?
cards.definition: Increase Carbon chain length. Halogen further down group 7.

cards.term: How would the mass of a haloalkane compare with the mass of an alkane of the same chain length?
cards.definition: Greater as mass of halogen > mass of H

cards.term: What is the most important factor in determining halogen reactivity?
cards.definition: The strength of carbon halogen bond.

cards.term: What would bond polarity suggest the order of reactivity would be?
cards.definition: C-F would be most reactive as most polar bond.

cards.term: What would bond enthalpies suggest the order of reactivity would be?
cards.definition: C-I would be most reactive as lowest bond enthalpy.
The halogen atom is present at the end of the chain.
Electron pair donor.
:OH-:CN-:NH3
A reaction where a nucleophile donates a lone pair of electrons to \xce\xb4+ C atom, \xce\xb4\xe2\x88\x92 atom leaves molecule (replaced by nucleophiles).
A reaction where water is a reactant.

cards.term: What reactant often produces hydroxide ions for hydrolysis?
cards.definition: Water

cards.term: What is the functional group of an alcohol?
cards.definition: Hydroxyl group -OH

cards.term: What is the general formula of an alcohol?
cards.definition: CnH2n+1OH

cards.term: How do you name alcohols (one prefix, one suffix)?
cards.definition: Hydroxyl- OR -ol.

cards.term: What kind of intermolecular forces do alcohols have? Why?
cards.definition: Hydrogen bonding, due to the electronegativity difference in the OH bond.

cards.term: How do alcohols\xe2\x80\x99 melting point and boiling point compare to other hydrocarbons\xe2\x80\x99 of similar C chain lengths? Why?
cards.definition: Higher, because they have hydrogen bonding (strongest type of intermolecular force) \xe2\x86\x92 stronger than London forces.

cards.term: Are alcohols soluble in water? Why does solubility depend on chain length?
cards.definition: Soluble when short chain - OH hydrogen bonds to hydrogen bond in water.Insoluble when long chain - non-polarity of C-H bond takes precedence.
C bonded to OH is only bonded to one other C atom.
C bonded to OH is bonded to two other C atoms.
C bonded to OH is bonded to three other C atoms.

cards.term: Write an equation for the combustion of ethanol.
What forms if you partially oxidise a primary alcohol?
cards.definition: An aldehyde.

cards.term: What conditions are needed to partially oxidise a primary alcohol?
cards.definition: Dilute sulphuric acid, potassium dichromate (VI), distill product as it\xe2\x80\x99s produced, gentle heating.

cards.term: Write an equation for the partial oxidation of ethanol.
cards.definition: CH3CH2OH (l) + [O] \xe2\x86\x92 CH3CHO (g) + H2O (l)

cards.term: What forms if you fully oxidise a primary alcohol?
cards.definition: A carboxylic acid.

cards.term: What conditions are needed to fully oxidise a primary alcohol?
cards.definition: Concentrated sulphuric acid, potassium dichromate (VI), reflux, strong heating.
Unsaturated hydrocarbons that contain at least one C=C bond made up of a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8b bond and a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8e bond.

cards.term: What is the general formula of alkenes?
cards.definition: CnH2n
Electrons in the adjacent p orbitals overlap above and below the carbon atoms. They can only be made after a \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8e bond is formed.

cards.term: What bond restricts the rotation of carbon atoms?
cards.definition: \xf0\x9d\x9c\x8b bond

cards.term: What is the angle and shape of a double bond?
cards.definition: Trigonal planar: 120\xc2\xb0

cards.term: Are they more or less reactive than alkanes? Why?
cards.definition: More reactive due to high electron density of double bond and the fact the pi-bond is slightly easier to break.

cards.term: What intermolecular forces of attraction do they have?
cards.definition: Only London forces due to non-polar bonds.

cards.term: Are they soluble in water? Why?
cards.definition: No, non-polar bonds.

cards.term: What are the types of isomers that can be formed using alkenes?
cards.definition: E/Z isomers - due to the restricted rotation.Cis-trans isomers - if two of the same substituents are attached to each carbon.
Species that are electron pair acceptors.

cards.term: What is the most stable type of carbocation intermediate? Why?
cards.definition: Alkyl groups have a positive inductive effect, so the most stable carbocation is the one bonded to the most other carbon atoms. i.e. A tertiary carbocation.

cards.term: Major products will be formed from which kinds of carbocations?
cards.definition: Tertiary (or the most stable available)

cards.term: What conditions are needed for the electrophilic addition of H2O to an alkene? What is this type of reaction called?
cards.definition: Steam in the presence of an acid catalyst, usually phosphoric acid. Reaction is called hydration.

cards.term: What are the product(s) of the hydration reaction?
cards.definition: An alcohol.

cards.term: What conditions are needed for the electrophilic addition of a hydrogen halide to an alkene?
cards.definition: Hydrogen halide gases must be at room temperature.
A saturated hydrocarbons containing C-H bonds only.

cards.term: What is the general formula of an alkane?
cards.definition: CnH2n+2

cards.term: Are alkane bonds polar? Why/why not?
cards.definition: Nonpolar because carbon and hydrogen have similar electronegativities.

cards.term: What is the shape and angle of an alkane?
cards.definition: Tetrahedral: 109.5\xc2\xb0
The sigma bond is a covalent bond which has a direct overlap of the electron clouds of the bonding atoms.

cards.term: What type of intermolecular forces do alkanes have? Why?
cards.definition: London force \xe2\x86\x92 induced dipole-dipole interaction, because the bonds are nonpolar.

cards.term: What happens to the boiling point as alkane chain length increases? Why?
cards.definition: The boiling point increases because there is more surface area and so more number of induced dipole- dipole interaction. Therefore more energy required to overcome the attraction.

cards.term: Does a branched molecule have lower or higher boiling point compared to equivalent straight chain? Why?
cards.definition: The branched molecule has a lower boiling point because they have fewer surface area and hence less induced dipole -dipole interactions.

cards.term: Are alkanes soluble in water? why?
cards.definition: Insoluble because hydrogen bonds in water are stronger than alkanes\xe2\x80\x99 London forces of attraction.
Very unreactive.
Combustion and reaction with halogens.

cards.term: What type of reaction is combustion?
cards.definition: Oxidation reaction
Combustion that occurs with plentiful supply of air.

cards.term: What are the products of complete combustion when alkanes are used?
cards.definition: Carbon dioxide and water.

cards.term: What is the colour of the bunsen burner flame during complete combustion?
cards.definition: Blue Flame
The system used for naming organic compounds.

cards.term: What does the term empirical formula mean?
cards.definition: Simplest whole number ratio of atoms in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term molecular formula mean?
cards.definition: It provides the actual number of atoms of different elements in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term displayed formula mean?
cards.definition: It shows every atom and every bond in a molecule.

cards.term: What does the term structural formula mean?
cards.definition: It shows the arrangement of atoms in a molecule without showing every bond.
A type of formula which is drawn as lines with each vertex being a carbon atom. Carbon atoms not drawn, assumed each C atom has all unspecified bonds as C-H.
A series of organic compounds having the same functional group but with each successive member differing by CH2.
A group of atoms responsible for characteristic reactions of a compound.
Hydrocarbon with carbon atoms joined together in a straight line or branched chain.
Hydrocarbons arranged in non aromatic rings with or without side chains.
Hydrocarbon that contains at least one benzene ring.

cards.term: Give the suffixes for:a) No double bondsb) At least one double bondc) An alcohold) An aldehydee) A ketonef) A carboxylic acid
cards.definition: a) No double bonds -aneb) At least one double bond -enec) An alcohol -old) An aldehyde -ale) A ketone -onef) A carboxylic acid -oic acid

cards.term: Give the prefixes for:a) CH3 groupb) C2H5 groupc) C3H7 groupd) C4H9 groupe) Cl groupf) Br groupg) I group
cards.definition: a) CH3 group methyl-b) C2H5 group ethyl-c) C3H7 group propyl-d) C4H9 group butyl-e) Cl group chloro-f) Br group bromo-g) I group iodo-

cards.term: What is the general formula of alkanes?
cards.definition: CnH2n+2

cards.term: What is the general formula of alkenes?
cards.definition: CnH2n

Alcohols contain an -OH group and follow the general formula CnH2n+1OH. They can be produced via two main methods of fermentation or hydration.Alcohols are named according to IUPAC rules and have the suffix -ol.Alcohols can be primary (1o), secondary (2o) or tertiary (3o), depending on the position of the hydroxyl group.
Hydrogen bonds are a much stronger intermolecular force than van der Waals forces so more energy is required to overcome them.
When burned in air, alcohols react with oxygen to form carbon dioxide and water. Alcohols make good fuels by reacting in this way as lots of energy is also released.
PCl5 is used to produce chloroalkanes.
Alkenes can be formed from the dehydration of alcohols, where a molecule of water is removed from the molecule. In order to do this, the alcohol is heated with concentrated phosphoric acid.
Primary and secondary alcohols can be oxidised to produce various products but tertiary alcohols are not easily oxidised.
A nucleophile is an electron pair donor. These species are \xe2\x80\x98positive liking\xe2\x80\x99. They contain a lone electron pair that is attracted to \xe2\x88\x82+ regions of molecules.

cards.term: Some of the most common nucleophiles.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f CN:-\xe2\x97\x8f :NH3\xe2\x97\x8f -:OH

Nucleophilic substitution is the reaction mechanism that shows how nucleophiles attack haloalkanes. Aqueous potassium hydroxide is used to produce alcohols, potassium cyanide is used to produce nitriles and ammonia is used to produce amines.

Reflux apparatus is used to continually heat the contents of the flask to allow reactions like the oxidation of primary alcohols to proceed all the way to the formation of carboxylic acids. The condenser helps ensure the vapours condense and return to the flask for further heating. This ensures the product vapours can not escape.

Distillation apparatus is used to separate liquids with different boiling points. The round-bottomed flask is heated and the liquid with the lower boiling point will evaporate first. It rises out of the flask and into the attached tubing which is surrounded by a condenser. The condenser causes the vapour to cool and condense back into a liquid, which is then collected in a separate flask.
A separating funnel is used to separate two liquids with different densities.
Subsequent distillations can be carried out to obtain a purer product.

A compound can be dried by the addition of an anhydrous (contains no water) salt. The anhydrous salt will absorb moisture and water present, thus drying and purifying the compound. Common anhydrous salts used for drying are magnesium sulphate and calcium chloride.

Synthetic routes are the routes which can be used to produce a certain product from a starting organic compound. It is important that you understand the different methods and conditions required to convert compounds to other products.

Organic chemistry mainly concerns the properties and reactions of hydrocarbons, compounds that contain only carbon and hydrogen atoms. Hydrocarbons form series of compounds with similar structures and formulas that can be represented in many different ways
Nomenclature is the set of rules that outline how different organic compounds should be named and how their formulas are represented.

Compounds are named according to rules laid out by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC). This ensures each compound is universally named the same - which helps to avoid potentially dangerous confusion.
The simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element in a compound.
The true number of atoms of each element in a compound.
The simplest algebraic formula of a member of a homologous series. All members of a homologous organic series follow the general formula.
- The minimal detail that shows the arrangement of atoms in a molecule.- The carboxyl group will be represented as COOH and the ester group as COO.
- The relative positioning of atoms and the bonds between them. Shows every atom and every bond in an organic compound.

- The simplified organic formula of just a carbon skeleton and functional groups.- Shows only the bonds in a compound and any non-carbon atoms.- Vertices are carbon atoms.- Hydrogen is assumed to be bonded to them unless stated otherwise.
- These compounds are represented by the symbols below.- Benzene can be represented in two equivalent ways.
A homologous series is a series of organic compounds with the same functional group but with each successive member differing by CH2.
Organic compounds are often part of a homologous series, in which all members follow a general formula and react in a very similar way.

An alkyl group is a hydrocarbon chain with the general formula CH\xe2\x82\x82\xe2\x82\x8a\xe2\x82\x81. Sometimes R may be used to represent alkyl groups, as well as other fragments of organic compounds not involved in reactions.
An aliphatic compound is a compound containing carbon and hydrogen joined together in straight chains, branched chains or non-aromatic rings.
An alicyclic compound is an aliphatic compound arranged in non-aromatic rings, with or without side chains.
A compound containing carbon and hydrogen only.
Has single bonds only.
Contains carbon-carbon multiple bonds.
A series of organic compounds having the same functional group but with each successive member differing by a CH2.
Part of molecule largely responsible for molecule\xe2\x80\x99s chemical properties.
Carbon atoms joined in unbranched/branched chains, or non aromatic rings.
An aliphatic compound arranged in non-aromatic ring, with without branches.
Some/all carbon atoms found in a benzene ring.
Contains at least one triple carbon-carbon bond.
Shows number of + type of atoms of each element in a molecule.e.g. C2H6O.
Simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present in a compound.e.g. C4H8 \xe2\x86\x92 CH2
Simplest algebraic formula for any member of a homologous series.
Shows relative positioning of all the atoms in a molecule and the bonds between them.
Uses the smallest amount of detail necessary to show the arrangement of atoms in a molecule.
Compounds with same molecular formula but different structural formula, can have same functional group at different point/different functional group.
An aliphatic compound that is arranged in non-aromatic rings (with or without side chains).
A compound containing carbon and hydrogen atoms joined in straight or branched chains or in non-aromatic rings.
A homologous series with the general formula CnH2n+2.
A group with the general formula CnH2n+1.
An organic compound containing a benzene ring.
Shows the movement of a pair of electrons. Curly arrows must start from a bond, a lone pair of electrons or a negative change.
A partial charge on an atom which is caused by the differing electronegativities of atoms in a covalent bond.
The relative positions of atoms and the bonds between them.
The simplest whole number ratio of atoms of each element present in a compound.
A group of atoms responsible for the characteristic reactions of a compound.
The simplest algebraic formula of a member of a homologous series. E.g. Alkane: CnH2n+2.
When a covalent bond breaks, one bonding atom receives both electrons from the bonded pair.
A series of organic compounds containing the same functional group with successive members differing by -CH2.
When a covalent bond breaks, each bonding atom receives one electron from the bonding pair, forming 2 radicals.
International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry.

topics.title: Module 5: Physical Chemistry and Transition Elements

cards.definition: A d block element that forms at least one stable ion with partially filled d subshel.

cards.term: Where are the transition metals located in the periodic table?
cards.definition: In the middle block from Ti to Cu.

cards.term: What are the 2 elements in d block that are not considered as transition metals?
cards.definition: Scandium and zinc.

cards.term: Why is scandium and zinc not considered as transition metals?
cards.definition: Scandium only forms Sc ^3+ , where the d orbitals are empty.Zinc only forms Zn^2+ where the d orbitals are full.

cards.term: Which electrons do transition metals lose first when forming ions?
cards.definition: 4s

cards.term: What are some characteristic physical properties of transition metals?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Metallic\xe2\x97\x8f High density\xe2\x97\x8f High melting and boiling point\xe2\x97\x8f Shiny\xe2\x97\x8f Good conductors of heat and electricity

cards.term: What are the characteristic chemical properties of transition metals (4)?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Variable oxidation states \xe2\x86\x92 take part in many redox reactions\xe2\x97\x8f Coloured compounds/ions in solution\xe2\x97\x8f Good catalysts\xe2\x97\x8f Form complex ions

cards.term: In potassium manganate (VII), what is the oxidation number of Mn?
cards.definition: Mn = +7

cards.term: What are the 2 main ways in which transition metals act as an effective catalyst?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f They provide a surface on which reaction can take place.\xe2\x97\x8f They change oxidation states to form intermediates required for pathways with lower activation energy.

cards.term: Give some examples of transition metal catalysts and the processes/reactions they catalyse (4)?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Iron - Haber process\xe2\x97\x8f Vanadium (V) oxide - contact process\xe2\x97\x8f Nickel - hydrogenation of alkenes\xe2\x97\x8f Manganese (IV) oxide - decomposition of hydrogen peroxide\xe2\x97\x8f Copper sulfate - hydrogen production
Transition metal ion bonded to one or more ligands by coordinate bonds.
Molecule or an ion that can donate a pair of electrons to the metal to form a coordinate bond.
A bond in which one of the atom provides both the electrons required for bonding, also known as dative bonding.

cards.term: What does the coordination number indicate?
cards.definition: The number of coordinate bonds formed between the metal ion and its ligands.
A ligand that forms one co-ordinate bond to the central metal ion (one lone pair to donate).
A species that is reduced in a reaction and causes another species to be oxidised.
A species that is oxidised in a reaction and causes another species to be reduced.
- Loss of electrons.- An increase in the oxidation number.
- Gain of electrons.- Decrease in the oxidation number.

cards.term: What happens in a redox reaction?
cards.definition: Electrons are transferred from one species to another. One element is oxidised whilst the other is reduced.
The E.M.F. of a half cell compared with a standard hydrogen half cell measured at 298 K with solution concentration of 1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm^-3 and a gas pressure of 100 kPa.

cards.term: What happens when a rod of a metal is dipped into a solution of its own ions?
cards.definition: An equilibrium is set up between the solid metal and the aqueous metal ions.

cards.term: Write a half-equation for zinc (s) to zinc (II).
cards.definition: Zn (s) \xe2\x87\x8c Zn^2+ (aq) + 2e^-

cards.term: Write a half-equation for copper (II) to copper (III).
cards.definition: Cu^2+ (aq) \xe2\x87\x8c Cu^3+ (aq) + e^-

cards.term: What is a standard hydrogen half cell made of?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Hydrochloric acid 1 mol\xe2\x80\xa2dm^-3\xe2\x97\x8f Hydrogen gas at 100 kPa\xe2\x97\x8f Inert platinum electrode

cards.term: Why is hydrogen half cell used as a standard half cell?
cards.definition: Easy to control its purity and reproducibility.

cards.term: How to make a simple salt bridge?
cards.definition: Soak a piece of filter paper in an aqueous solution of KNO3 or NH4NO3.
To complete the circuit by connecting the two solutions. This enables charge to be transferred between the half cells. They do not react with the electrodes.

cards.term: Why might you use other standard electrodes occasionally?
cards.definition: They are cheaper/easier/quicker to use and can provide just as good a reference. Platinum is expensive.

cards.term: If an E\xc2\xb0 value is more negative, what does it mean in terms of oxidising/reducing power?
cards.definition: Better reducing agent (easier to oxidise).
A measure of the dispersal of energy in a system which is greater when the system is more disordered.

cards.term: What is the symbol of entropy?
cards.definition: S

cards.term: Solid or gas, which is more disordered?
cards.definition: Gas

cards.term: What is the unit of standard entropy?
cards.definition: J\xe2\x80\xa2K^-1\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-1
The greater temperature particles have more energy and move more. Thus the arrangement of particles become more random.More random arrangement = Higher entropy

cards.term: When a solid ionic lattice is dissolved in solution what happens to entropy?
cards.definition: Entropy increases because the ions are more disordered.

cards.term: How does change in number of gas molecules in a reaction affect entropy?
cards.definition: Increase in number of gas molecules = Increase in entropyDecrease in number of gas molecules = Decrease in entropy

cards.term: For a reaction to occur spontaneously \xce\x94G must be positive or negative?
cards.definition: Negative

cards.term: What are the limitations of the predictions of feasibility made by using \xce\x94G?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Reaction may have high activation energy\xe2\x97\x8f Rate of reaction may be very slow
Formation of 1 mole of ionic lattice from gaseous ions under standard conditions.

cards.term: What does a more exothermic lattice enthalpy mean?
cards.definition: More exothermic = More stronger ionic bonds

cards.term: Why is it not possible to measure lattice enthalpy directly?
cards.definition: It is not possible to form 1 mole of ionic solid from its gaseous ions.
Enthalpy change that takes place when 1 mole of a solute is completely dissolved in water under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change that takes place when dissolving one mole of gaseous ions in water.

cards.term: What are the factors that impact the size of lattice enthalpy?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Size of ions involved\xe2\x97\x8f Charges on the ions\xe2\x97\x8f Ionic bond strength

cards.term: Which ions have more negative lattice enthalpy values? smaller / larger ions?Why?
cards.definition: Smaller ions because they can get closer hence more stronger attraction.
When a ionic lattice is broken the ions become part of the solution.Positive ions get attracted towards slightly negative oxygen and negative ions get attracted towards slightly positive hydrogen.

cards.term: What are the factors that impact the magnitude of the enthalpy of hydration?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Size of the ion\xe2\x97\x8f Charge on the ions
Proton donor.
Proton acceptor.
Electron pair donor.
Electron pair acceptor.

cards.term: What ion causes a solution to be alkaline?
cards.definition: -OH (hydroxide ion)

cards.term: Write an equation for the ionisation of water.
cards.definition: 2H2O (l) \xe2\x87\x8c H3O + (aq) + -OH (aq)OR H2O (l) \xe2\x87\x8c H + (aq) + -OH (aq)

cards.term: Give example of a monobasic acid.
cards.definition: HCl

cards.term: Give example of a dibasic acid.
cards.definition: H2SO4

cards.term: Give example of a tribasic acid.
cards.definition: H3PO4
Acids dissociate completely.

cards.term: Give some examples of strong acids.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Hydrochloric acid\xe2\x97\x8f Sulfuric acid\xe2\x97\x8f Nitric acid

cards.term: What is the difference between concentrated and strong?
cards.definition: Concentrated means many mol per dm3, strong refers to amount of dissociation.
Acids that only partially dissociate.

cards.term: Give some examples of weak acid.
cards.definition: Methanoic acid, any organic acid.

cards.term: What is constant that is used to measure the extent of acid dissociation called?
cards.definition: Acid dissociation constant.

cards.term: What does it mean when a reaction is at equilibrium?
cards.definition: The rate of forward and reverse reactions are equal.

cards.term: What are the methods that can be used to measure equilibrium?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Measure change in colour or colour intensity using colorimeter.\xe2\x97\x8f Use pH probe.\xe2\x97\x8f Measure electrical conductivity.\xe2\x97\x8f Titration - used when equilibrium is slow so that titration can be completed before there is much change in equilibrium mixture.
The amount of a given component in a given reaction mixture.

cards.term: Write the equation used to calculate mole fraction.
cards.definition: Mole fraction = number of moles of substance A / total number of moles of all substances
The pressure exerted by a single species in a reaction vessel.

cards.term: What is the symbol for partial pressure?
cards.definition: P

cards.term: Write the equation used to calculate partial pressure.
cards.definition: Partial pressure = Mole fraction x total pressure

cards.term: What is the relationship between concentration of a substance and its partial pressure?
cards.definition: Concentration of a substance is proportional to its partial pressure.

cards.term: What are the 3 common units of pressure used in chemistry?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Pascals\xe2\x97\x8f Atmospheres\xe2\x97\x8f Newtons per square metre

cards.term: What type of brackets are used in Kc expressions?
cards.definition: Square Brackets

cards.term: What type of brackets are used in Kp expressions?
cards.definition: Round Brackets

cards.term: How do you calculate the units for Kp?
cards.definition: Write out the units for the partial pressures in the same arrangement as the Kp equation and cancel out/multiply together. Usually in Pa, kPa, atm etc. DO NOT CHANGE UNITS.

cards.term: What is the symbol of equilibrium constant?
cards.definition: K

cards.term: What does it mean when K is greater than 1?
cards.definition: Reaction favours product.

cards.term: What does it mean when K is lesser than 1?
cards.definition: The reaction favours reactants.
Change in concentration of a reactant or a product per unit time.

cards.term: At a given instant, how could you calculate the rate of reaction?
cards.definition: Rate of reaction = Change in concentration of reactants or products / Time

cards.term: If the order is zero with respect to a reactant, what does that mean?
cards.definition: Changing the concentration of the reactant has no effect on the rate.

cards.term: What is the effect on rate in a first order reaction?
cards.definition: Rate is directly proportional to the concentration.

cards.term: What is the effect on rate in a second order reaction?
cards.definition: Change in rate = Change in concentration squared

cards.term: Write a generic rate equation and state what each term means.
cards.definition: Do zero order reactants appear on rate equation? Why?

cards.term: Do zero order reactants appear on rate equation? Why?
cards.definition: No, because they don\xe2\x80\x99t have an effect on the rate.

cards.term: How is overall order of a reaction calculated?
cards.definition: Sum of individual orders.

cards.term: When the overall order is 3, what would be the units for rate constant?
cards.definition: dm^6\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-2\xe2\x80\xa2s^-1

cards.term: How could you measure the rate of reaction experimentally (different methods)?
cards.definition: Use a colorimeter at suitable intervals if there is a colour change.If gas is evolved, use a gas syringe to collect volume of gas evolved, or measure the change in mass of the reaction mixture.
The time taken for concentration of a reactant to decrease by half.

cards.term: What is the symbol for half life?
What is the relationship between first order reactions and half life?
cards.definition: First order reactants have constant half lifes.

cards.term: What is the equation that is used to determine rate constant using half life in a first order reaction?
How would you draw a rate concentration graph?
cards.definition: Plot [A] against time, draw tangents at different values \xe2\x86\x92 draw a secondary graph of rate against [A]

The transition metals are elements in the d-block of the periodic table that form one or more stable ions with a partially filled d-orbital. Transition metals lose electrons to form positive ions, with the s-orbital electrons being removed first.
Copper and chromium are exceptions to the rule that the 4s subshell is filled before the 3d subshell.

A ligand is a molecule or ion with a lone electron pair that is able to form a dative (coordinate)bond to the central metal ion by donation of this electron pair. Common ligands include:\xe2\x97\x8f Cl-\xe2\x97\x8f H2O\xe2\x97\x8f NH3
Monodentate ligands each form one coordinate bond.Examples: H2O, Cl-, NH3.
Bidentate ligands each form two coordinate bonds. Example: NH2CH2CH2NH2.

The coordination number of a transition metal complex is the total number of coordinate bonds formed with the central metal ion. Silver complexes have a coordination number of 2 and platinum complexes commonly have a coordination number of 4. The coordination number determines the shape of the complex ion.

Some metal ions and complexes are colourless. Colour arises when some wavelengths of light are absorbed while others are reflected. This involves the excitation of electrons. Ions and complexes where there are no available electrons to excite cannot absorb light and are therefore colourless.
Transition metal complexes with H2O and NH3 ligands commonly form octahedral complexes with a bond angle of 90\xc2\xb0. Octahedral complexes are formed when there is six-fold coordination.
When complexes form with larger ligands such as Cl-, they form tetrahedral complexes with a bond angle of 109.\xc2\xb0 and 4 ligands coordinated. Tetrahedral complexes can show optical isomerism.
Platinum and nickel complexes form in a square planar shape. This consists of four coordinate bonds with a bond angle of 90\xc2\xb0.
Optical isomerism is seen in some octahedral complexes with bidentate ligands. These complexes have non-superimposable mirror images.

In ligand substitution reactions, a positive entropy change is favourable as it means a more stable complex is being formed. Therefore, it is favourable to have more moles on the right of the reaction than on the left. This is achieved by substituting monodentate ligands with bidentate or polydentate ligands. This is known as the chelate effect.

The enthalpy change (\xe2\x88\x86H) for ligand substitution reactions is very small as the bonds being formed are very similar to the bonds that were broken. Therefore, overall enthalpy change isnear to zero.
The most stable oxidation states of iron are Fe^2+ and Fe^3+.
The most stable oxidation states of copper are Cu^+ and Cu^2+.
Lattice enthalpies are used for ionic substances. Lattice enthalpy is a measure of the strength of ionic bonding in a giant ionic lattice.
The enthalpy change when one mole of a solid ionic compound is completely dissociated into its gaseous constituent ions under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of a solid ionic compound is formed from its gaseous constituent ions under standard conditions.
The energy required for the formation of one mole of gaseous atoms from an element under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is added to a mole of gaseous atoms to form one mole of gaseous 1- ions under standard conditions.
Born-Haber cycles are similar to the cycles used with Hess\xe2\x80\x99s Law.
The enthalpy change when one mole of ionic solid is dissolved in water to infinite dilution so that the ions no longer interact under standard conditions.
The enthalpy change when one mole of gaseous ions is dissolved in water to form one mole of aqueous ions under standard conditions.
1. Balance all atoms except for oxygen and hydrogen.2. Add H2O to balance oxygens (if needed).3. Add H+ ions to balance hydrogens (if needed).4. Add e- to balance charges (if needed).

Electrochemical cells use redox reactions since the electron transfer between products creates a flow of electrons. This flow of charged particles is an electrical current that flows between electrodes in the cell. A potential difference is produced between the two electrodes which can be measured using a voltmeter.

The standard hydrogen electrode is the measuring standard for half-cell potentials. It has a cell potential of 0.00V, measured under standard conditions. These conditions are:\xe2\x97\x8f Solutions of 1.0 mol dm^-3 concentration\xe2\x97\x8f A temperature of 298K\xe2\x97\x8f 100 kPa pressure
There are limitations to both calculating a standard cell potential using the SHE and using the calculated value to determine reaction feasibility.
Electrochemical cells can be a useful source of energy for commercial use. They can be produced to be non rechargeable, rechargeable or fuel cells.

Fuel cells are a type of electrochemical cell which continuously produces a voltage when supplied with a fuel and oxygen. The fuel donates electrons at one electrode and oxygen gains electrons at the other electrode. The energy released is used to generate a voltage.
Lithium ion batteries are a commonly used example of an electrochemical cell. They are rechargeable, however, their benefits are counteracted by risks of toxicity and fire.
The rate of a reaction shows how fast reactants are converted into products. It depends on the concentrations of the reactants and the rate constant.

The rate constant for a reaction is constant when the reaction temperature is constant. The rate constant relates the concentrations of the species that affect the rate of a reaction to the overall rate of reaction. The rate constant, k, can be calculated by rearranging the rate equation for that reaction.
Using the initial rate of reactions is one way the order of a reaction can be determined. This involves varying the concentrations of reactants and measuring the initial rate of the reaction.
No change to the initial rate.
Initial rate doubles.
Initial rate quadruples (2^2).

If a gas is produced by a reaction, then the mass of the reaction mixture will decrease as the reaction proceeds. Plotting a mass-time graph and drawing a tangent to the curve can be used to find the rate of reaction.

If a gas is produced by a reaction, the rate of reaction can be found by measuring the volume of gas produced over the course of the reaction, and plotting a graph of volume evolved against time. A gas syringe or an underwater upside down measuring cylinder can be used to collect the gas.

Small samples of a reaction mixture can be removed at regular intervals throughout a reaction. These samples can then be titrated to determine the concentration of a given reactant or product at that time. A concentration-time graph can then be plotted.

Colorimetry can be used to determine the rate of reaction for a reaction that involves the formation or depletion of a coloured species. A colorimeter is a device that measures the amount of light that is absorbed by a solution. The amount of light absorbed by the solution is proportional to the concentration of the coloured species.
A mole fraction shows the proportion that a molecule accounts for of the total moles present. It is calculated by dividing moles of substance A by the total moles present.

K_c is the equilibrium constant of a reversible reaction. Kc is equal to the concentration of the products divided by the concentration of the reactants at equilibrium. The concentration terms are raised to a power of the same value as the number of moles of that substance.

Kp is the equilibrium constant used for gaseous equilibria. Kp is calculated from gaseous reactants and products. If all reactants and products are in the gaseous state, the system is said to be homogeneous.
A Br\xc3\xb8nsted-Lowry acid is a proton donor. For example, ammonium ions (NH4+).
A Br\xc3\xb8nsted-Lowry base is a proton acceptor. For example, hydroxide ions (OH-).
pH increases rapidly on the addition of a small volume of base. acid/base concentration is similar.
Continuous measurements taken during the course of a reaction.
Instantaneous rate at the start of a reaction when time=0, found by measuring.
A convenient way of obtaining initial rate with single measurement.
Electrode (dipped into solution), connected to meter displaying reading.
The volume of one solution that exactly reacts with the volume of the other solution (at the centre of the vertical section).
Weak acid with distinctively different colour to conjugate base (e.g. methyl orange: weak acid is red, conjugate base is yellow, end point colour between two so orange).
The enthalpy change that accompanies the formation of one mole of an ionic compound from its gaseous ions under standard conditions (always exothermic).
Dispersal of energy within the chemicals making up the chemical system (units J\xe2\x80\xa2K^-1\xe2\x80\xa2mol^-1).
The entropy of one mole of a substance under standard conditions (+ve).
Whether a reaction is able to happen and is energetically feasible.
Overall energy change during a chemical reaction. Made up of enthalpy change and entropy change.
Converts chemical energy into electrical energy. Made by connecting 2 different half cells, allowing electrons to flow (not made by mixing cells- would produce heat energy.
Contains the species present in a redox half equation.
Phase boundary where metal in contact with its ions, equilibrium is set up.
A reaction in which the time taken for an abrupt visible change to occur is measured. The abrupt change typically indicates the formation of the product.

A technique used to measure the amount of light absorbed by a solution, used to determine the rate of a reaction. Typically, a calibration curve is plotted and used to relate the absorbance recorded by the colorimeter to the concentration of the solution.
A graph in which concentration is plotted on the y axis and time on the x axis. The gradient of the line is equal to the rate of reaction.
During a rate experiment, continuous measurements are taken as the reaction progresses. The results can then be plotted on a concentration-time graph.
Doubling the concentration of a first order reactant will double the rate (if all other conditions remain the same).
Change in y \xc3\xb7 Change in x
The rate of a reaction at t = 0.
A number that relates the rate of a reaction to the concentrations of each reactant.
The sum of the orders with respect to each reactant.

A constant value that relates the rate of a reaction at a given temperature to the concentrations of the reactants. For a first order reaction, this can be determined using the relationship k = ln 2/t_1/2.
A graph that has concentration plotted on the x-axis and rate on the y-axis.
The slowest step of a reaction.
Relates rate to the concentrations of the reactants multiplied by the rate constant. Each concentration is raised to the power of the order with respect to that reactant.
A measure of how quickly a reactant is used up / a product is formed.
A step-by-step sequence of the individual reactions that make up the overall reaction.
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance

cards.term: What are the basic principles of NMR?
cards.definition: You can find the structures of complex molecules by placing them in a magnetic field and applying EM waves of radio frequency to them. If radio waves of the right frequency are absorbed, the nuclei flips from parallel to applied magnetic to field to anti-parallel. This energy change can be monitored and recorded. Uses the resonance of nuclei with spin.
MRI scans

cards.term: On a low resolution spectrum, what peaks would you expect to see for H NMR?
cards.definition: One peak for each set of inequivalent H atoms (each chemical environment shows 1 peak).
A stepped line that makes it easier to measure the area under the curve (height of line = area under that peak).

cards.term: What are other advantagesof using TMS?
cards.definition: Inert, non-toxic, easy to remove from the sample (as relatively volatile).
If there are n inequivalent 1 H atoms on the neighbouring carbon then the peak will split into (n+1) smaller peaks

cards.term: Why must solvents used for 1H NMR not contain any hydrogen atoms?
cards.definition: Signals from the solvent would swamp signals from the sample, as there is much more solvent than sample.
Deuterated solvents: CDCl3, D2O, C6D6CCl4 -tetrachloromethane

cards.term: Why does the peak from O-H bonds disappear if D 2 O is used as a solvent?
cards.definition: O-D bond is formed in preference to O-H due to labile protons that move/swap from one molecule to another.

cards.term: What are the basic principles of all kinds of chromatography?
cards.definition: A family of separation techniques that depend on the principle that a mixture is separated if it is dissolved in a solvent and this mobile phase is passed over a solid (the stationary phase).
Carries the soluble components of the mixture.

cards.term: What relationship between a sample and the mobile phase makes the sample move faster?
cards.definition: More soluble components / components with more affinity to the solvent move faster.

cards.term: What does the stationary phase do?
cards.definition: Holds back components of the mixture that are attracted to it.

cards.term: What relationship between a sample and the stationary phase that makes the sample move slower? What kind of bonding does this often involve?
cards.definition: More affinity for the stationary phase means that a component moves slower; often attracted by hydrogen bonding.

cards.term: How are substances separated by chromatography?
cards.definition: If suitable stationary/mobile phases are chosen, the balance between affinity for the mobile phase and affinity for the stationary phase is different for each component of the mixture. Thus, they move at different rates and are separated over time.

cards.term: Why will different substances show different Rf values?
cards.definition: They are bonded differently and have different polarities - more polar bonds mean longer retention time or smaller R f value, since hydrogen bonding/dipoles are attracted more strongly to the stationary phase.
Thin Layer Chromatography.

cards.term: What are the advantages of TLC over paper chromatography?
cards.definition: Runs fasterSmaller amounts of a mixture can be separatedTLC plates are more robust that paper

cards.term: How can you observe colourless spots?
cards.definition: Shine UV light on them. Or spray with a developing agent (e.g. ninhydrin turns amino acid spots from colourless to purple, so they can be seen) (heating needed with ninhydrin).

cards.term: How do you calculate the Rf value?
cards.definition: Measure the distance from the initial line (that the mixture was spotted onto) to the solvent front, and the distance from the initial line to the spot. Calculate R f using: Rf = distance moved by spot \xe2\x9e\x97 distance moved by solvent front.

cards.term: What does Rf value stand for?
cards.definition: Retention factor; a measure of the rate of movement of a component through the chromatography apparatus; a ratio between the rate of movement of the solvent and that component

cards.term: How could you confirm the identity of a substance from its Rf value?
cards.definition: Compare your Rf value to accepted values Rf for that substance run in the same solvent and set-up; if they match, then identity is confirmed.

cards.term: What is the stationary phase in gas-liquid chromatography?
cards.definition: Powder, coated with oil. Packed into a long, thin, capillary tube (100m long, 0.5mm diameter). Coiled and placed in an oven, the temperature of which can be varied.

cards.term: What is the mobile phase in gas-liquid chromatography?
cards.definition: Carrier gas, inert e.g. N2 or He.

cards.term: When purifying by recrystallisation, why is the minimum volume of hot solvent used?
cards.definition: So that a saturated solution is created, so that as many crystals will fall out of solution as possible when it is cooled.

cards.term: Why is the solution filtered hot when purifying by recrystallisation?
cards.definition: To remove insoluble impurities and ensure that the crystals do not form in the filter paper.

cards.term: Why is the solution cooled in an ice bath when purifying by recrystallisation?
cards.definition: To ensure that as many crystals as possible fall out of solution - yield is higher.

cards.term: Why are the crystals washed with cold water when purifying by recrystallisation?
cards.definition: To remove soluble impurities.

cards.term: How would you separate the crystals from the reaction mixture when purifying by recrystallisation?
cards.definition: Filter under reduced pressure using a Buchner funne.

cards.term: Why might percentage yield be below 100% (practical reasons)?
cards.definition: Product is lost during filtration, drying and weighing - spills, not all transferred from one piece of apparatus to the other. Product is left dissolved in the solution - some does not crystallise. Some left on filter paper. Sample still wet.

cards.term: Describe how Quickfit apparatus is connected.
cards.definition: Grease the joints using some petroleum jelly on the inside of the joints before connecting the pieces together.

cards.term: In a distillation setup, why is it necessary to have a continuous water flow around the condenser?
cards.definition: So that the water remains cool in order for the mixture to be distilled.

cards.term: Describe a method that can be used to separate immiscible liquids.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Pour the mixture into a separating funnel and some distilled water\xe2\x97\x8f Add the stopper and invert the flask to mix the mixture\xe2\x97\x8f Equalise the pressure by opening the stopper as required\xe2\x97\x8f Continue shaking until there is no \xe2\x80\x98whistle\xe2\x80\x99 sound\xe2\x97\x8f To collect the water in the lower layer, open the stopper and place a beaker under the spout\xe2\x97\x8f Use another beaker to collect the desired organic layer\xe2\x97\x8f Shake the liquid with some drying agent
Magnesium sulphate and Calcium chloride.

cards.term: How is a drying agent used?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Add a selected drying agent to the organic product\xe2\x97\x8f If the drying agent forms clumps add some more until they are moving freely\xe2\x97\x8f Use gravity filtration to collect the dry product.\xe2\x97\x8f Filtrate is the product
When a liquid is purified by using multiple distillations.

cards.term: What are the three key steps to purify an organic solid?
cards.definition: 1. filtration under reduced pressure2. recrystallisation3. measurement of melting points

cards.term: What type of mechanism is involved in the reaction between haloalkanes and cyanide ions?
cards.definition: Nucleophilic substitution

cards.term: What type of reaction is involved in the reaction between carbonyl compounds and cyanide ions?
cards.definition: Nucleophilic addition

cards.term: How can you form a carboxylic acid from a nitrile?
cards.definition: Acid hydrolysis

cards.term: What type of catalyst is used for a Friedel-Crafts reaction?
cards.definition: A halogen carrier (e.g.AlCl3).

cards.term: How could you use a Friedel-Crafts mechanism to add a methyl group to a benzene ring?
cards.definition: Use a halogenoalkane and AlCl3 to create an electrophile that can attack benzene.

cards.term: What is condensation in terms of polymers?
cards.definition: Small molecule eliminated (usually H2O) to form a larger molecule.

cards.term: How many monomers are condensation polymers usually formed from?
cards.definition: Two (2)

cards.term: What properties do these monomers forming condensation polymers have?
cards.definition: Each has two functional groups.
PolyestersPolyamidesPolypeptides

cards.term: What molecule is eliminated in formation of a polyester?
cards.definition: H2O

cards.term: What are the two monomers which form a polyester (generic names and structures)?
cards.definition: Diol and dicarboxylic acid or a molecule with both alcohol and a carboxylic acid functional groups.
As a fibre for making clothes.

cards.term: Which molecule is eliminated when a polyamide is formed?
cards.definition: H2O

cards.term: What are the two monomers used to form a polyamide (generic names and structures)?
cards.definition: Diamine and dicarboxylic acid.
Nylon, Kevlar

cards.term: If you are making Nylon in the lab, what monomers would you use and why? What molecule is eliminated?
cards.definition: Use hexane-1,6-diacyl chloride as the rate of reaction is much faster. HCl is eliminated.
In body armour (bullet proof vests, stab vests), helmets (e.g. F1 drivers\xe2\x80\x99), oven gloves.
Non-polar C-H and C-C bonds.

cards.term: Why is it bad to burn poly(alkenes)?
cards.definition: Releases CO2, CO, C (soot) and other toxicchemicals from monomers.

cards.term: Where do most poly(alkenes) end up?
cards.definition: Landfill Sites

cards.term: What are the two functional groups of amino acids?
cards.definition: NH2 and COOH (amine and carboxylic acid).
Yes, one carbon has 4 different substituents.Except glycine, where R = H.
Ions which have both a permanent positive and negative charge, but are neutral overall.

cards.term: What property must a carbon atom have for the molecule to display optical isomerism about that carbon atom?
cards.definition: 4 different substituents attached to one carbon atom.

cards.term: What are the similarities and differences between two optical isomers?
cards.definition: Same atoms and bonds, but they are non-superimposable mirror images of one another. NOT IDENTICAL in chemical properties necessarily.Differ in the way they rotate plane polarised light - rotate plane of polarisation by the same angle but in different directions.

cards.term: What word is used to describe optically active molecules?
cards.definition: Chiral
-amine or amino-
The lone pair of electrons on the Nitrogen - due to polar N-H bond.

cards.term: What shape are amines around the N? Bond angle?
cards.definition: What shape are amines around the N? Bond angle? Trigonal pyramidal, 107\xc2\xb0 due to lone pair on N.

cards.term: What kind of intermolecular forces do they have? Why?
cards.definition: Hydrogen bonding due to polar N-H bond and lone pair of electrons on N atom.

cards.term: Do amines have intermolecular forces which are stronger than or weaker than alcohols? Why?
cards.definition: Weaker, as N has a lower electronegativity than O \xe2\x86\x92 Weaker hydrogen bonding

cards.term: How can/when do amines act as bases?
cards.definition: The lone pair on the nitrogen atom accepts a proton.

cards.term: How can/when do amines act as nucleophiles?
cards.definition: When they bond with an electron-deficient C atom (donate lone pair from N).

cards.term: In order to be the strongest base, what must a particular amine have (out of a set of amines)?
cards.definition: Greatest electron density around the N atom, making it a better electron pair donor (attracts protons more).

cards.term: What effect do alkyl groups have (on electron density and base strength)?
cards.definition: Positive inductive effect - increase electron density around N \xe2\x86\x92 stronger base

cards.term: How can primary amines then form 2\xc2\xb0, 3\xc2\xb0 amines and 4\xc2\xb0 ammonium ions?
cards.definition: Multiple substitutions; primary amine is a nucleophile that attacks the original haloalkane etc.

cards.term: What are the problems with this method?
cards.definition: Not efficient as low yield of 1\xc2\xb0 amine due to multiple substitution.

cards.term: How would you maximise the yield of the primary amine?
cards.definition: Use excess ammonia.

cards.term: What type of mechanism is the reaction of a haloalkane with a cyanide ion?
cards.definition: Nucleophilic substitution

cards.term: What conditions does this reaction require? What is the product formed?
cards.definition: Ethanol as a solvent. A nitrile is formed.

cards.term: How do you get from a nitrile to a primary amine? (name of reaction type and reagents/catalysts).
cards.definition: Reduction using Nickel / Hydrogen catalyst.

cards.term: What is the functional group of a carboxylic acid?
cards.definition: -COOH (C=O and C-OH)

cards.term: How do you name carboxylic acids?
cards.definition: -oic acid

cards.term: Are carboxylic acids soluble in water? Why? What influences their solubility.
cards.definition: Yes. Acid group can form hydrogen bonds with water molecules.

cards.term: What are the intermolecular forces in carboxylic acids?
cards.definition: Hydrogen bonds in solid state - very strong.

cards.term: What are esters (what are they formed from)? Functional group, general formula?
cards.definition: Formed from carboxylic acids and alcohols. RCOOR\xe2\x80\x99 (C=O, C-O-C)
Start with the alcohol group that has replaced the hydrogen, then acid part e.g. propyl (from alcohol) ethanoate (from  carboxylic acid).

cards.term: What characteristic physical properties do esters have?
cards.definition: Volatile, pleasant fruity smells e.g. apple, pear drops.

cards.term: What are some uses of esters?
cards.definition: Flavourings, perfumes (both for longer chains), solvents (short chains), plasticisers.

cards.term: How could you distinguish carboxylic acids from other -OH containing compounds?
cards.definition: Add NaHCO3 , acids will produce sodium salt, water and carbon dioxide.

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction of ethanoic acid with NaOH.
cards.definition: CH3COOH + NaOH \xe2\x86\x92 H2O + CH3COO- Na+

cards.term: Write an equation for the reaction of ethanoic acid with calcium oxide
cards.definition: 2CH3COOH + CaO \xe2\x86\x92 (CH3COO)2 Ca + H2O

cards.term: What catalyst is needed for the formation of esters from alcohols and carboxylic acids?
cards.definition: Concentrated strong acid. e.g. H2SO4

cards.term: What catalyst is needed for the hydrolysis of esters?
cards.definition: Dilute strong acid. e.g. H2SO4

cards.term: What is an alternative method of hydrolysis?
cards.definition: Base hydrolysis

cards.term: What are the advantages of base hydrolysis?
cards.definition: Reaction goes to completion due to neutralisation by base - more product in the mixture than acid catalysed hydrolysis.
C=O

cards.term: What is the functional group and general formula for an aldehyde?
cards.definition: RCHO (C double bonded to O, single bond to H and R).

cards.term: What is the functional group for a ketone?
cards.definition: RCOR\xe2\x80\x99 (C double bonded to O).
-al suffix (C=O is on the end of a chain).
-one suffix (designate number for which carbon C=O is on).

cards.term: What kind of intermolecular forces do molecules with the carbonyl group have? Why?
cards.definition: Permanent dipole-dipole due to the polar C=O bond (O is \xe2\x88\x82-).

cards.term: How soluble are they in water? What influences solubility?
cards.definition: Yes - form hydrogen bonds between water molecules and oxygen of C=O. As C chain length increases, solubility decreases.

cards.term: Which bond in carbonyl compounds is usually involved in reactions? Why?
cards.definition: C=O, due to the polarity of the bond (large difference in electronegativity between C and O).

cards.term: What is the strongest bond in carbonyl compounds?
cards.definition: C=O

cards.term: Why is the addition of HCN important?
cards.definition: Increases the length of the carbon chain by one carbon atom allowing more useful molecules to be made.

cards.term: Will the product of HCN added to a carbonyl compound have optical isomers? Why?
cards.definition: Yes they will. In the aldehyde/ketone, the carbonyl carbon is planar, so the :CN - can attack from either above or below, forming two enantiomers.

cards.term: What is the name of the product when HCN is added to a carbonyl compound?
cards.definition: Hydroxynitriles (have OH and CN groups).

cards.term: What is Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s solution? What colour is it?
cards.definition: Copper complex ions, blue.

cards.term: What happens when an aldehyde is added to Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s solution?
cards.definition: Reduced to Cu + ions \xe2\x86\x92 colour change to brick red ppt.

cards.term: What happens when a ketone is added to Fehling\xe2\x80\x99s solution?
cards.definition: No visible change \xe2\x86\x92 stays blue

cards.term: What is the empirical formula of Benzene?
cards.definition: CH

cards.term: What is the state of benzene at room temperature?
cards.definition: Liquid

cards.term: What is the bond angle of benzene?
cards.definition: Bond angle = 120\xc2\xb0

cards.term: What are the 3 features of benzene that don\xe2\x80\x99t support Kekule\xe2\x80\x99s model?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Benzene is resistant to addition reactions\xe2\x97\x8f Enthalpy change of hydrogenation of benzene is more stable than predicted\xe2\x97\x8f All the carbon bonds are same length

cards.term: What technique was used to find the bond lengths of benzene?
cards.definition: X ray diffraction

cards.term: What happens to the 4th electron in the p-orbital of each carbon atom in benzene?
cards.definition: It delocalises to form rings of electron density above and below the hexagon, forming rings of delocalised electron density above/below the hexagon.

cards.term: How do the rings of electron density affect the stability of Benzene?
cards.definition: Makes benzene very stable, even though it is unsaturated (aromatic stability).

cards.term: Why does benzene have a relatively high melting point?
cards.definition: Close packing of flat hexagonal molecules when solid.

cards.term: Is benzene soluble in water? Explain why?
cards.definition: No because it is non polar.

cards.term: Dangers of benzene - why it is not used in schools?
cards.definition: It is a carcinogen.

cards.term: How do you name compounds containing a benzene ring?
cards.definition: -benzene, or phenyl- ; can designate position on ring using numbers if there is more than one substituent.

cards.term: Why is benzene attacked by electrophiles?
cards.definition: High electron density above/below ring due to delocalised electrons.

cards.term: Nitration of benzene is what type of reaction?
cards.definition: Electrophilic substitution reaction.

cards.term: What is the catalyst in nitration of benzene?
cards.definition: Sulfuric acid

cards.term: What type of catalyst is used for a Friedel-Crafts reaction?
cards.definition: A halogen carrier (e.g. AlCl 3)

Chromatography is an analytical technique used to separate and identify component molecules of a mixture. Separation of the mixture depends on distribution between a mobile phase and a stationary phase.

The mobile phase is a fluid that allows molecules to move over or through the stationary phase. It can be in the form of a liquid or a gas depending on the type of chromatography being carried out. Species that are more soluble in the mobile phase move further and/or faster within the mobile phase.

The stationary phase is a substance that has affinity to molecules in the mixture being analysed. The greater the affinity of a molecule to the stationary phase, the shorter the distance and/or the slower it moves within the mobile phase.

An Rf value is a retention factor that is unique to each different component molecule in the mixture being analysed. This is because different molecules within the mixture will have different affinities for the mobile and stationary phase and so will move at different rates within the mobile phase. It is calculated by comparing the distance moved by the component molecule to the distance moved by the mobile phase.

In TLC chromatography, a metal plate is coated with a thin layer of silica and the sample being analysed is dotted on the plate. These initial samples must be placed above the level of the solvent in the container.

In gas chromatography, a thin coiled tube is packed with a solid, powdered substance that acts as the stationary phase. Instead of a solvent, a high pressure gas is passed through this tube and acts as the mobile phase. This method is used to separate mixtures of volatile liquids which are fed into the gas chromatography machine as vapours. The analysis machine records a retention time for each component in the mixture, allowing them to be identified.

Carbon-12 is the most common isotope of carbon but is not detected by NMR spectroscopy. This is why carbon-13 is used, however, carbon-13 only has an abundance of roughly 1.1%, so a greater quantity of sample will be needed to obtain a well resolved spectra.
The process of hydrogen/deuterium exchange can be used to identify N-H and O-H peaks in an NMR spectra.
The analytical techniques covered throughout the course can be used together to predict the structure of unknown compounds.
This is an analytical technique used to identify different molecules and find the overall relative molecular mass.

High resolution mass spectrometry is a much more sensitive form of mass spectrometry which allows the Mr of a substance to be determined to several decimal places. Precise atomic masses can then be used to calculate the molecular formula of the compound being tested.
Infrared spectroscopy is an analytical technique that uses infrared (IR) radiation to determine the functional groups present in organic compounds.

Amines react with water to form an alkaline solution. The lone pair of electrons on the amine\xe2\x80\x99s nitrogen atom can accept a hydrogen from a water molecule, therefore acting as a base. This releases OH- ions into the solution.
Amines react with acids to form an ammonium salt. Again, the amine acts as a base and accepts a proton to form a quaternary ammonium salt.

Aliphatic amines can be produced from the nucleophilic substitution reaction between a halogenoalkane and ammonia in a sealed tube. One mole of halogenoalkane reacts with two moles of ammonia, producing a primary amine and an ammonium salt (ammonium ion bonded to a halide ion).
Aliphatic amines can also be produced by the reduction of nitriles by hydrogenation. This reduction requires a combination of hydrogen with a nickel catalyst (catalytic hydrogenation).
Aromatic amines can be produced from the reduction of nitrobenzene using concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl) and a tin catalyst. Aromatic amines consist of an amine group and a benzene ring.

Zwitterions are dipolar ions with a positive charge in one part of the molecule and a negative charge in another part of the molecule. The zwitterionic form of an amino acid is the state in which the amine group has a positive charge (+NH3) and the carboxyl group has a negative charge (COO-).Zwitterions form at the isoelectric point, which is the pH at which the overall charge of the molecule is zero.
Amines can also undergo nucleophilic addition-elimination reactions with acyl chlorides to produce amides and N substituted amides.
Secondary amides are also known as N-substituted amides. They have an additional carbon chain bonded to the nitrogen atom.
A chiral centre is a carbon atom with four different groups bonded around it, so that the molecule has no line of symmetry.

Optical isomerism is a type of stereoisomerism where molecules have the same molecular formula but a different spatial arrangement of atoms. The presence of a chiral centre leads to two possible isomers that are non-superimposable mirror images of each other. These are called optical isomers.
Condensation polymers form when a water molecule is removed from the species of a reaction. Polyesters and polyamides can be formed in this way.
Polyesters are formed when a dicarboxylic acid and a diol react together, producing an ester linkage, -COO-.
Terylene (PET) is a common polyester made from ethane-1,2 diol and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid.
Polyamides are condensation polymers generally formed in a reaction between a dicarboxylic acid and a diamine. A molecule of water is removed, producing an amide linkage.
Kevlar is another common polyamide made from benzene-1,4 dicarboxylic acid and 1,4-diaminobenzene.
Arenes are aromatic compounds that contain a benzene ring as part of their structure.
Benzene is an arene consisting of a ring of six carbon atoms each bonded to one hydrogen atom, giving it the molecular formula C6H6.

X-ray diffraction experiments have shown that all the bond lengths between carbon atoms in benzene are the same. If the cyclohexatriene structure was correct, three of the bond lengths would be the length of a single carbon bond and three would be the length of a double carbon bond. In reality, each bond in the benzene ring has an intermediate length in between that of a double and single bond.

Benzene is resistant to electrophilic addition reactions, such as bromination, which other compounds with carbon-carbon double bonds, such as alkenes, readily undergo. Benzene does not undergo electrophilic addition since this would involve breaking up the stable delocalised ring of electrons. Benzene instead undergoes electrophilic substitution reactions.
Halogenation is a type of electrophilic substitution reaction in which benzene reacts with halogens in the presence of a catalyst, such as iron(III) bromide (FeBr3).

Nitration is a form of electrophilic substitution, where the electrophile is an NO2 + ion. This is a reactive intermediate, produced in the reaction of concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4) with concentrated nitric acid (HNO3). Sulfuric acid behaves as a catalyst since it is not used up in the reaction.
The delocalised electron ring in benzene can also act as a nucleophile, leading to their nucleophilic attack on acyl chlorides. This reaction is known as Friedel-Crafts acylation.

The test for unsaturation would be expected to work for benzene like it does for alkenes, however, benzene is resistant to bromination. This is due to the delocalised electron density of the \xcf\x80-system in benzene compared with the localised electron density of the \xcf\x80-bond in alkenes. The delocalised model makes benzene relatively stable and hence not reactive enough to decolourise bromine water.

Phenols are organic compounds containing a benzene ring with an OH alcohol group. This makes them aromatic alcohols. Phenols are weak acids. They can be neutralised in a reaction with NaOH but will not react with carbonates.

Phenol, an aromatic compound with the formula C6H5OH, is produced in electrophilic substitution reactions with benzene. Phenol can react with bromine water via multiple substitutions to produce 2,4,6-tribromophenol which forms as a white precipitate with a distinct smell of antiseptic. This reaction decolourises bromine water.

Electron donating groups such as OH and NH\xe2\x82\x82 direct electrophiles to substitute at the 2- and 4- positions. Electron-withdrawing groups such as NO\xe2\x82\x82 are 3-directing in electrophilic substitution of aromatic compounds. These effects occur to favour the most stable charged intermediate.
Directing effects can be used to predict substitution products. This is very important in organic synthesis as it allows you to control the structure of the products.
Carbonyl compounds are organic compounds containing a carbonyl group, C=O. This gives them the functional group -CO. The most common carbonyl compounds are aldehydes and ketones.

Aldehydes are produced from the initial oxidation and distillation of primary alcohols. Aldehydes have a carbonyl group on a carbon atom at the end of the carbon chain (only attached to one other carbon atom).

Ketones are recognised by the functional group -C=O, a carbonyl group. They are produced from the oxidation of secondary alcohols with acidified potassium dichromate(VI). Ketones have a carbonyl group on a carbon atom that is attached to two other carbon atoms.
The breaking of a covalent bond when one of the bonded atoms takes both of the electrons.
The breaking of a covalent bond when each of the bonded atoms takes one electron.
Two reactants join together to form one product.
Two reactants where one atom or group of atoms replaces another set of atoms.
A reaction which involves the removal or a small molecule from a larger one.
An atom or compound that are electron pair acceptors.
An atom or compound that are electron pair donors.
A compound containing at least one benzene ring.

The p-orbitals of the 6 carbon atoms overlap to form a delocalised \xcf\x80 system. This model is supported by experimental evidence: all the C-C bond lengths in benzene are the same, the enthalpy change of hydrogenation is less exothermic than would be expected for cyclohex-1,3,5-triene and the benzene does not undergo addition reactions.

A representation of the probability of finding an electron at a specific point around an atom/ molecule. Benzene has a lower electron density than an alkene. In benzene, the electron density is delocalised into the \xcf\x80 system across 6 carbon atoms while in an alkene, the pair of electrons is localised between 2 carbon atoms in a \xcf\x80 bond.

Groups which donate electrons into the aromatic ring when they are attached to a carbon in the ring. OH, an electron donating group, is 2- and 4-directing, meaning that substituents will be substituted at positions 2 and 4 during an electrophilic substitution reaction.

Groups which pull electron density away from the delocalised \xcf\x80 system of benzene. NO2, an electron withdrawing group, is 3-directing meaning that substituents will be substituted at carbon 3 during an electrophilic substitution reaction.
A reaction in which an electrophile (an electron pair acceptor) reacts with another compound to replace an atom / group of atoms.
An organic compound containing a halogen atom (F/Cl/Br/I) bound to an alkyl chain.

A Lewis acid that can bind to a halogen molecule, weakening the halogen bond and allowing the halogen to function as an electrophile and attack electrons in an aromatic ring. Examples of halogen carriers include iron, iron halides and aluminium halides.
A model of benzene which contains alternating C=C double and C-C single bonds in a hexagonal ring, with each carbon atom bound to one hydrogen atom.

A weak acid that reacts with NaOH but not carbonates. Phenol has an aromatic ring with an OH group attached. Phenol can undergo electrophilic substitution reactions more easily than benzene as the lone pair in the p-orbital of oxygen is donated into the \xcf\x80 system of phenol, increasing its electron density. As a result of this electron donation, phenol is more susceptible to electrophilic attack than benzene.

Also known as Brady\xe2\x80\x99s reagent, this compound forms an orange precipitate in the presence of aldehydes and ketones. The melting point of the 2,4-DNP derivative of a carbonyl can be used to identify the carbonyl compound.
The C=O group. Aldehydes and ketones are carbonyl compounds.
An electron pair donor.

A reaction in which an electrophilic \xcf\x80 bond reacts with a nucleophile, breaking the \xcf\x80 bond and forming 2 new \xcf\x83 bonds. Examples include carbonyl compounds reacting with NaBH4 to form alcohols or with HCN to form hydroxynitriles.
The loss of electrons/ increase in oxidation number.

cards.term: What is a flywheel?What is a flywheel designed to store as much energy as possible called?What are 3 ways to increase the RKE of a flywheel?
cards.definition: A heavy wheel with a high moment of inertia in order to resist changes to its rotational motion.A flywheel batteryMake it1. Heavier - more mass increases I2. Spoked - more mass concentrated further from centre of wheel increases I3. Spin faster - greater \xcf\x89

cards.term: Why can you only increase the RKE of a flywheel to a certain extent?What are modern flywheels generally made of instead of steel? Why?What are 3 ways to decrease a flywheel's energy losses to air resistance and friction between flywheel and bearings it spins on.
cards.definition: If flywheel gets too big and heavy, it'll take up too much space and slow down a vehicle. If angular speed gets too high, centrifugal force can increase to a point where flywheel starts breaking.Carbon fibre - it is less dense than steel, but has a much stronger strength-to-weight ratio and can be spun much faster.1. Lubricate flywheel to reduce friction between bearings and wheel.2. Levitate flywheel with superconducting magnets so there's no contact between bearings and wheel.3. Operate in vacuums or sealed cylinders so there's no air resistance.

cards.term: How does a flywheel smooth torque and angular velocity?How is a flywheel used to smooth out torque when the force a system can exert can vary?List 5 uses of a flywheel.
cards.definition: When force supplied to a system varies, flywheels use each spurt of power to charge up and then deliver RKE smoothly to the system smoothly.When load torque is too high, flywheel decelerates, releasing energy to top up the system. When engine torque is higher than load torque, flywheel accelerates and stores spare energy until it's needed.1. Potter's wheels2. Regenerative braking3. Power grids4. Wind turbines (and other intermittent power sources)5. Riveting machines

cards.term: How is a flywheel used in regenerative braking?How is a flywheel used in a riveting machine?
cards.definition: When brakes are applied in a car, instead of lots of KE being lost to heat by work done against friction between brakes and wheels, flywheel charges up without energy being lost.Electric motor charges up flywheel, which rapidly transfers a burst power as the machine presses down on the rivet and fixes two sheets of material together. This stops rapid changes of power going through the motor, which could cause it to stall, and means less powerful motors can be used.

cards.term: List 5 advantages of flywheelsList 4 disadvantages of flywheels
cards.definition: 1. They're very efficient2. They last a long time without degrading3. Recharge time is short4. They can react and discharge quickly5. They are environmentally friendly (don't rely on chemicals to store energy)1. They're much larger and heavier than other storage methods2. The wheel could break apart at high speeds (safety risk) - protective casing to protect against this involves in extra weight3. Energy lost through friction4. If used in moving objects, they can oppose changes in direction, which can be problematic for vehicles

A closed system does not.Q = \xe2\x88\x86U + W. Q is heat supplied to the system, \xe2\x88\x86U is the increase in the system's internal energy and W is the work done by the system (the work the gas is doing).

cards.term: What are non-flow processes?What do you assume when applying the first law to non-flow processes?Why is pV/T constant for a closed system? What equation can be derived from this consistency?

cards.definition: One in which no heat is lost or gained by the system.Q=0, so \xe2\x88\x86U=-Wp1V1^\xce\xb3 = p2V2^\xce\xb3, where \xce\xb3 is the adiabatic constant.

topics.title: AQA A Level Physics Practical Skills

cards.definition: A measurement result is considered accurate if it is judged to be close to the true value.
Marking a scale on a measuring instrument.This involves establishing the relationship between indications of a measuring instrument and standard or reference quantity values, which must be applied.
Information, either qualitative or quantitative, that has been collected.
The difference between a measured value and the true value.
These are values in a set of results which are judged not to be part of the variation caused by random uncertainty.

These cause readings to be spread about the true value, due to results varying in an unpredictable way from one measurement to the next.Random errors are present when any measurement is made, and cannot be corrected.

cards.term: How can the effect of random errors be reduced?
cards.definition: The effect of random errors can be reduced by making more measurements and calculating a new mean.
These cause readings to differ from the true value by a consistent amount each time a measurement is made.

cards.term: What are the sources of systematic errors?
cards.definition: Sources of systematic error can include the environment, methods of observation or instruments used.

cards.term: How are systematic errors dealt with?
cards.definition: Systematic errors cannot be dealt with by simple repeats. If a systematic error is suspected, the data collection should be repeated using a different technique or a different set of equipment, and the results compared.
Any indication that a measuring system gives a false reading when the true value of a measured quantity is zero, eg the needle on an ammeter failing to return to zero when no current flows.

cards.term: What may a zero error result in?
cards.definition: A zero error may result in a systematic uncertainty.
Data which has been shown to be valid.
A fair test is one in which only the independent variable has been allowed to affect the dependent variable.
A proposal intended to explain certain facts or observations.

cards.term: Explanation of how a transformer works
cards.definition: \xe2\x80\xa2 a changing current in primary coil\xe2\x80\xa2 produces a changing flux in the transformer core\xe2\x80\xa2 producing a changing flux linkage in the secondary coil\xe2\x80\xa2 which from Faraday's Law\xe2\x80\xa2 induces an emf in the secondary coil
Transformers only work with alternating current. Direct current does not produce a changing magnetic field in primary coil.
Increases voltage (decreases current)more turns on secondary than on primary
Decreases voltage (increases current)less turns on secondary than on primary

ac in primary and secondary coils - Coils have an electrical resistance resulting in heating and hence energy loss - fix by lower R of wire by increasing area, ie thicker wire, as P=I^2R, and R=pL/Aac in primary magnetises, de-magnetises and re-magnetises the core -energy needed to do this, so energy lost as heat - fix by using magnetically soft material eg iron (NOT steel)changing flux in core -causes eddy currents to flow, energy is lost as heat - fix by using a laminated core, as eddy currents are smallerpoor design of transformer- Not all of the flux from primary coil links with secondary coil, energy is lost - fix by putting coils next to eachother
