cards.term: What is the resistance of an ideal ammeter?
cards.definition: Zero.
At any point in a circuit the sum of the currents entering that point is equal to sum of the currents leaving.
A force produces an extension of the object.
A force that reduces the length of an object.
Force is proportional to extension so long as the elastic limit is not exceeded.
When an object will return to its original shape when the load is removed.
A permanent change in shape that remains once the load is removed.

cards.term: What is k in F = kx
cards.definition: The force constant.

cards.term: What are the units of force constant (k)
cards.definition: Nm\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What is represented by the area under a force-extension graph?
cards.definition: The work done stretching the object.

cards.term: What is meant by an elastic material?
cards.definition: A material which can be significantly deformed and will return to it's original shape.
The force applied per unit cross sectional area.
The fractional change in length of an object.
A material which ccan be drawn into a wire of hammered into thin sheets.

cards.term: What is the limit of proportionality of a material?
cards.definition: The point at which a material stops obeying Hooke's Law

cards.term: What is the elastic limit of a material?
cards.definition: The point at which a material starts to plastically deform.

cards.term: What is the yield point of a material?
cards.definition: The point at which the material starts to extend rapidly as stress increases.

cards.term: What determines the energy of a photon?
cards.definition: The frequency/wavelength
A quantum of energy of electromagnetic radiation

cards.term: How do you calculate the energy of a photon?
cards.definition: E = hf OR E =hc/\xce\xbb
The energy gained or lost by an electron passing through a potential difference of 1V

cards.term: How do convert from eV to J?
cards.definition: multiply by 1.6x10^-19

cards.term: How do convert from J to eV?
cards.definition: divide by 1.6x10^-19

cards.term: What is the threshold p.d. of an LED?
cards.definition: The minimum potential difference required for the LED to produce light.

cards.term: How can the threshold p.d. of an LED be used to find photon energy?
cards.definition: The energy transferred by the electrons (e x V) is equal to the energy of the photons produced (hf).

cards.term: What is meant by wave particle duality?
cards.definition: It describes how all matter can display both wave and particle properties.

cards.term: What is the key piece of evidence for wave particle duality?
cards.definition: When an electron beam passes through polycrystaline graphite it produces a diffraction and interference pattern pattern.

cards.term: What does the De Broglie wave equation apply to?
cards.definition: Everything

cards.term: What is the relationship between momentum and wavelength?
cards.definition: Inverse proportionality
The emission of electrons from a metal surface when illuminated with light.

cards.term: What is the atomic structure of a metal?
cards.definition: A lattice of positive ions surrounded by a sea of free electrons.
An electron that has been removed from a metal by absorbing a photon
When two objects at the same temperature so no heat flows between them.
The temperature at which the internal energy of a system is at its lowest possible value

cards.term: What is the relationship between absolute temperature and the average KE of particles in a substance?
cards.definition: Absolute temperature is proportional to average kinetic energy of the particles in a substance.

cards.term: What is the triple point of a substance?
cards.definition: The temperature and pressure at which a substance can exist in all three phases in thermal equilibrium.

cards.term: Describe the kinetic model of a solid.
cards.definition: A regular arrangement of particles that are strongly attracted to each other. Particles vibrate but can't change positions in the structure.

cards.term: Describe the kinetic model of a liquid.
cards.definition: Particles are attracted to each other but are free to move around.

cards.term: Describe the kinetic model of a gas.
cards.definition: Particles are far apart and there are no forces of attraction between them.

cards.term: What is the internal energy of a substance?
cards.definition: The sum of the randomly distributed kinetic and potential energy of the particles in an object

cards.term: Why doesn't the temperature of a substance change whilst it is changing state?
cards.definition: The electrostatic potential of the particles is changing rather than the kinetic energy.

cards.term: Why is the electrostatic potential energy of liquids and solids negative?
cards.definition: Energy must be supplied to the substance to break the bonds between particles.

cards.term: What effect does increasing the temperature have on the particles in a substance?
cards.definition: It increases their average kinetic energy.

cards.term: What is the specific heat capacity (c) of a material?
cards.definition: The energy needed to raise the temperature of 1kg of the material by 1 degree Celsius/Kelvin without any change of state.

cards.term: What are the units of specific heat capacity (c)
cards.definition: J kg\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9 K\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9
Thermal energy gained (or lost if negative) by an object (provided no change in state).

cards.term: How many radians are there is 360 degrees?
cards.definition: 2 pi

cards.term: What are the SI units of angular velocity?
cards.definition: Radians per second.

cards.term: What is the definition of angular velocity?
cards.definition: The rate of change of angle.

cards.term: How do you calculate angular velocity from time period (T)?
cards.definition: Angular velocity = 2 pi / T

cards.term: How do you calculate angular velocity from frequency (f)?
cards.definition: Angular velocity = 2 pi f

cards.term: What is required for uniform circular motion?
cards.definition: A force that always acts perpendicular to velocity.

cards.term: Why doesn't a centripetal force do any work on an object in circular motion!
cards.definition: The force has no component in the dircetion of motion/is always perpendicular to motion.

cards.term: How do you calculate linear velocity from the time period (T) of an object in circular motion?
cards.definition: v = 2 pi r / T

cards.term: How do you calculate linear velocity from angular velocity?
cards.definition: v = angular velocity x radius

cards.term: How is it possible for an object to experience an acceleration but travel at a constant speed?
cards.definition: If acceleration is perpendicular to velocity, the velocity will change direction whilst speed is constant.

cards.term: What provides the centripetal force for a car turning a corner?
cards.definition: Friction from the road on the tyres.

cards.term: What provides the centripetal force on the moon?
cards.definition: The gravitational attraction of the Earth.

cards.term: Apart from friction what contributes to the centripetal force on a banked track?
cards.definition: The horizontal component of the normal reaction.

cards.term: If a mass on a string is swung in a vertical circle where is the tension greatest?
cards.definition: At the bottom of the circle.

cards.term: If a mass on a string is swung in a vertical circle where is the tension least?
cards.definition: At the top of the circle.
A region in which a mass will experience a gravitational force.
The force per unit mass exerted on test mass at that point in the field.

cards.term: What are the units of gravitational field strength?
cards.definition: N kg\xe2\x81\xbb\xc2\xb9

cards.term: What does the direction of a gravitational field line show?
cards.definition: The direction of force on a test mass at that point in the field.

cards.term: What is represented by the spacing of field lines in a field line diagram?
cards.definition: Field strength.

cards.term: What is a radial gravitational field?
cards.definition: A gravitational field produced by a spherical (or point) mass in which the field lines all point towards the centre of mass of the object causing the field.

cards.term: What is a uniform gravitational field?
cards.definition: A region in which the gravitational field strength is constant.

cards.term: How is a uniform gravitational field shown in a field line diagram?
cards.definition: Parallel, equally spaced field lines.
A idealised mass with zero size. The field outside a spherical mass can be modelled as the field around a point mass.
The gravitational attraction between two objects is proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the sqaure of the distance between their centres of mass
A planet's orbit is an ellipse with the Sun at one of the two foci
The point in an orbit when an object is furthest from the sun and travelling slowest.
The point in an orbit when an object is closest to the sun and travelling fastest.
A line segment joining the planet to the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal time intervals.
For planets in the solar system the square of the orbital period is proportional to the cube of the average orbital radius.
Everything that exists.
A large cloud of gas (mainly hydrogen) and dust in space
A hot dense sphere of gas prior to the ignition of nuclear fusion in the core that creates a star

cards.term: What provides the energy required for a protostar to begin fusion?
cards.definition: Gravitation energy is transferred to thermal energy.
The fusing of light nuclei to produce heavier nuclei releasing energy in the process.

cards.term: What is required for nuclear fusion to occur?
cards.definition: Extremely high temperatures and pressures.

cards.term: What prevents gravity from causing stars to collapse?
cards.definition: The radiation and gas pressure pushing outward.

cards.term: Why do large stars tend to remain stable for less time than smaller starts?
cards.definition: The pressure and temperature in the core is higher so they fuse hydrogen more quickly.

cards.term: What is radiation pressure in a star?
cards.definition: Pressure from the photons created by fusion in the core of a star.

cards.term: What is the gas pressure in a stars?
cards.definition: Pressure of the nuclei in the star's core pusing outwards.

cards.term: What is a main sequence star?
cards.definition: A stable star fusing hydrogen in helium.

cards.term: What causes a star to leave the main sequence?
cards.definition: It runs low on hydrogen, affecting the stability of the star.
The stage after the main sequence for a star with insufficient mass to go supernova.

cards.term: Describe the structure of a red giant.
cards.definition: An inert core surronded by shells fusing elements heavier then Hydrogen.
The very hot, dense remnant core of a red giant star.
Moving charges and permanent magnets.

cards.term: What is shown by the direction of a magnetic field line?
cards.definition: The direction of force on a free north pole.

cards.term: Which direction do magnetic field lines flow in?
cards.definition: From north to south.

cards.term: How is a uniform magnetic field represented by field lines?
cards.definition: Parallel

cards.term: What does the spacing of magnetic field lines show?
cards.definition: Magnetic field strength/flux density.

cards.term: How do you find the direction of the field lines around a current?
cards.definition: Using the right hand grip rule.

cards.term: How is a field line or current running into the paper shown?
cards.definition: \xe2\x8a\x97

cards.term: How is a field line or current running out of the paper shown?
cards.definition: . in a circle

cards.term: Why does a current experience a force in a magnetic field?
cards.definition: The current's magnetic field interacts with the external one.

cards.term: What is represented by the thumb in Fleming's Left Hand rule.
cards.definition: (Direction of) force

cards.term: What is represented by the first finger in Fleming's Left Hand rule.
cards.definition: (Direction of the) magnetic field

cards.term: What is represented by the second finger in Fleming's LHR?
cards.definition: (Direction of) current

cards.term: When is Fleming's Left Hand Rule used?
cards.definition: To find the direction of a current/moving charge in a magnetic field.

cards.term: When is the equation F = BIL sin\xce\xb8 used?
cards.definition: To find the magnitude of force on a wire (carrying current) in a magnetic field.

cards.term: What is represented by \xce\xb8 in the equation F = BIL sin\xce\xb8?
cards.definition: The angle between the current and the field direction.
Group of organisms of the same species in the same habitat at the same time
A collection of all organisms of different species in the same place at the same time
The interaction of different communities between each other and their habitat
major ecosystems of the world
Hollow sphere where biomes are found

- Progressively less energy available for the next trophic level- Energy lost through respiration, maintaining body temperature (endotherms) & death, decay, indigestible material e.g. cellulose cell walls, fur, bones which pass their energy to saprophytic organisms e.g. fungi and bacteria
Total amount of light energy fixed by PHS (in a given time & given area) units: KJ/m2/y
Amount of light energy fixed by photosynthesis available to the next trophic levelGPP- Respiratory losses

cards.term: Population estimate: Plants and sessile organisms
cards.definition: In area, create axes and generate random coordinates.Place quadrats randomlyRepeat & find mean number of organisms per quadratFind total field size/ quadrat sizeTotal population estimate = mean organism per quadrate x total number of quadrats in the total area

(Capture, mark & release) Capture a percentage (S1) of the total population (P)Mark the same, marking must be visible, not easily removed and must not hinder the organism in terms of breeding or predationRelease sample so they are equally distributed back into total population (P)Capture a second sample (S2) and count the number that are marked (M)S1/P = M/S2Therefore total population = (S1 x S2)/M

cards.term: Pyramid of numbers: (Area equivalent to number of organisms, must be symmetrical) Pros and cons
cards.definition: Pros: Quick and easy to carry out, minimal equipment requiredCons: Assumes all organism have the same ecological impact and does not take into account difference in size. Therefore instead of the expected pyramid, it can be inverted e.g. parasitic environment or a single large producer

cards.term: Pyramid of biomass: Pros and cons (Area of bar = Population estimate x mean dry mass of organism)
cards.definition: Pros: More accurate than pyramid of numbersCons: requires dry mass which involves killing several organismsDoesn't take into account time of yearAssumes 1g of one organism contains the same amount of energy as 1g in another organism

cards.term: Pyramid of energy: Pros and cons (Area of bar = population estimate x energy passed onto next trophic level using calorimetry)
cards.definition: Pros: Calculates exact energy flow between trophic levelsCons: Doesn't take into account large percentage mass of indigestible material in organisms such as tortoises and treesAlso average must be taken, so requires killing large amount of organisms

- Nitrogen fixation of inert nitrogen in are either by energy from lighting or nitrogen fixing bacteria in root nodules of legumes to form nitrates- Nitrates in soil can be absorbed by plants to form amino acids- Animals eat plants and they are used in building animal proteins- As plants and animals decay, they are broken down and their death and nitrogenous waste are released as ammonium compounds-These ammonium compounds undergo nitration by two nitrifying bacteria causing the formation of nitrites and then nitrates-Denitrifying bacteria converts nitrates back to inert nitrogen in the air
the process by which the communities of organisms colonising an area change over time
Maintenance of a state of dynamic equilibrium
Constant internal environment, including constant temperature water potential and pH

cards.term: Why must temperature and pH be regulated?
cards.definition: For optimum enzyme activity

cards.term: Why must water potential be regulated?
cards.definition: To avoid negative osmotic effects which could damage a cell e.g lysis, shrinkage and disruption of metabolic reactions
Ensures that any departure from an ideal state results in a return to the ideal stateCounteracts changes in internal conditions to maintain dynamic equilibrium

cards.term: What is the process of negative feedback?
cards.definition: 1. Change occurs in internal environment2. Change is detected by receptors3. Receptors lead to activation of a mechanism that reverses the change4. Conditions return to ideal and the mechanism is switched off

cards.term: What is the process of positive feedback?
cards.definition: 1. Change occurs in the internal environment2. This change is detected by receptors3. Receptors lead to activation of a mechanism that continues the change
Causes a departure from a starting condition to lead to further departure

cards.term: What are the two main modes of action in hormones?
cards.definition: 1. Hormones attach to receptor sites and trigger the release of a second messenger by a series of membrane bound reactions. The second messenger activates enzymes in the cell e.g. adrenaline2. Hormones enter the cell through the cell membrane and bind to transcription factors e.g oestrogen and steroid hormones
Secrete hormones directly into blood which signal proteins
Chemical messengers released by cells in the immune system that stimulate other cells in the immune system
Chemicals released at the ends of neurones that stimulate their target cells
Cells with receptor proteins on their cell surface membrane complimentary to the chemical
Regions of actively dividing cells e.g. roots and shoots
promote cell division of stem and promote growth of lateral buds

topics.title: Topic Eight - Origins of Genetic Variation

cards.definition: A source of new variation
sections of DNA are exchanged between homologous chromosomes
New combinations of alleles- recombination
The different possible combinations of maternal and paternal chromosomes
Introduces variation because the combination of gametes that fuse to form a zygote is random
The alleles present in a cell
The observable characteristics of an organism
An individual with two identical alleles for a characteristic
The two alleles in an individual are different for a characteristic
A characteristic that always shows an effect in the phenotype
A characteristic that is only expressed if the gene is homozygous
The alleles are equally dominant
When there are more than two possible alleles for a gene
Only one or a small number of nucleotides are inserted, substituted or deleted.
A change in position of genes on a chromosome
Nitrogen base + sugar (ribose or deoxyribose) and phosphate group joined by a condensation reaction with TWO water molecules released.

cards.term: What is the role of a nucleotide?
cards.definition: - provide the building blocks for the mechanism of inheritance in the form of DNA and RNA.

cards.term: What are the pentose sugars in DNA and RNA and what is the difference between the two.
cards.definition: DNA = deoxyriboseRNA = riboseDeoxyribose contains one fewer oxygen atoms than ribose

cards.term: What are the the most common purine and pyrimidine bases?
cards.definition: Purine = adenine and guaninePyrimidine = cytosine, uracil and thymine

cards.term: What is the effect of the phosphate group on a nucleotide?
cards.definition: - makes nucleotide molecules acidic- is the reason nucleotides carry a negative charge

cards.term: What is a nucleic acid? How does it create proteins?
cards.definition: Also called a polynucleotide, they are polymers made of nucleotide monomer units. They carry information needed to form new cells, with this information stored in DNA. This is then copied into RNA, used to produce proteins that build a cell and control its actions.

cards.term: What is genetic information stored in eukaryotic cells?
cards.definition: chromosomes in the nucleus

cards.term: Where is the genetic information stored in prokaryotic cells?
cards.definition: a single length of DNA floating freely in the cytoplasm
- nucleotides are joined through phophodiester bonds between the sugar of one nucleotide and the phosphate of the next formed through condensation reactions.

cards.term: How many nucleotides are in a nucleic acid?
cards.definition: sometimes millions

cards.term: What groups are at the end of each polynucleotide?
cards.definition: A hydroxyl group at one end and a phosphate group at the other

cards.term: What is the difference between the formation of DNA and RNA?
cards.definition: DNA is a nucleotide contain A, G , T and C nut RNA has A, U, G and C.They are also composed of different sugars; DNA - deoxyribose, RNA - ribose.

cards.term: What does a polynucleotide look like? Explain it and draw.
cards.definition: - single polynucleotide strand that can fold into complex shapes held in place by hydrogen bond or remain thread like- DNA has two polynucleotides twisted around each other.

DNA has two polynucleotides twisted around each other. Sugars and phosphates form the backbone, pointing inwards from the sugar-phosphate backbones, the bases pair up in specific ways. Purine bases always bond with pyrimide bases, leading to the double helix. The two strands are held by hydrogen bonds between bases.

cards.term: Where do hydrogen bonds form in DNA's double helix?
cards.definition: Between the bases. These form between the amino and carbonyl groups of the purine and pyrimide bases of opposite strands. There are three bonds between C and G but only two between A and T.

cards.term: How do you produce an aseptic culture?
cards.definition: Provide organisms with appropriate nutrientsUse a sterile mediumUse an inoculating loop to transfer pathogenPrevent contamination from air (convection current)Pass bottle through flameOnly open lids partway

cards.term: Why must aseptic techniques be used?
cards.definition: To prevent potentially harmful microorganisms escaping from culture to airTo prevent microorganisms from the air contaminating the culture

cards.term: What are the different types of culture media?
cards.definition: Liquid (broth)Solid (grows cultures with discrete colonies)Non-selective (allows broad range of microorganisms to grow)Selective (allows only a narrow range of microorganisms to grow)

cards.term: How do you isolate a singular microorganism from a culture?
cards.definition: streak plating

cards.term: What are the steps of streak plating?
cards.definition: 1. Flame inoculating loop2. Dip loop in culture3. Make three streaks on sterile plate4. Turn the plate 90 degrees and streak again, overlapping last streaks5. Turn and streak again6. use isolated colonies to prepare a second plate

cards.term: How do you make a serial dilution?
cards.definition: 1. Start with 10cm^3 of undiluted culture2. Add 1cm^3 of first tube into 9 cm^3 of sterile saline3. Continue to add 1cm^3 from previous tubes to form serial dilutions

cards.term: Why is an appropriate dilution a compromise when diluting a culture?
cards.definition: Must have a low enough number of microorganisms to count and a high enough number to provide a reliable sample of the culture

cards.term: What are the two types of cell count?
cards.definition: Total count: All cells in the culture, dead or aliveViable count: Only the living cells in the culture

cards.term: What is the lag phase of bacterial growth?
cards.definition: First phase after inoculation when microorganisms are adjusting to their environment so the population is only increasing very slowly

cards.term: What is the log phase of bacterial growth?
cards.definition: exponential growth

cards.term: What is the stationary phase of bacterial growth?
cards.definition: population reaches maximum due to limiting nutrients and a build up of toxic substances

cards.term: What is the death phase of bacterial growth?
cards.definition: A lack of nutrients and increase of toxic products cause death of microorganism

cards.term: How is a direct cell count calculated?
cards.definition: A haemocytometer (a glass slide with a grid etched on) is placed on a slideBacteria cells=number counter x1064 per cm^3Only counts viable cells

cards.term: How is an indirect cell count used to measure dry mass of cells?
cards.definition: 1. Filter a sample of known dilution through a pore2. Remove water by evaporation3. subtract final mass from initial mass (including filter paper) to calculate mass of dry microorganisms

cards.term: How is an indirect cell count used to measure turbidity of a diluted culture?
cards.definition: The cloudiness of a sample can be calculated using a simple colorimeter to measure absorbance or transmission. Use a haemocytometer to produce a calibration curve that relates to absorbance or transmission to the the actual number of cells.

topics.title: Topic Five - Energy for Biological Processes

cards.definition: process by which food is broken down to yield ATP, which is used as a source of energy for metabolic reactions
the substance oxidised during cellular respiration
cellular respiration that takes place in the mitochondria in the presence of oxygen.
structures where ATP production takes place on the inner mitochondrial membrane
addition of electrons to a substance, e.g. by the addition of hydrogen or removal of oxygen
removal of electrons from a substance, e.g. by the addition of oxygen or removal of hydrogen

NAD that has accepted a hydrogen atom in a metabolic pathway

the right upper chamber of the heart that receives blood from the vena cava
pumps deoxygenated blood to the lungs
valve between the right atrium and the right ventricle
Attached to walls of the ventricle, stop valves turning inside out.
One of two large vessels (superior and inferior) that return deoxygenated blood to the right atrium of the heart.
Valve with flaps resembling a half moon located between the ventricles and their attached blood vessels. (ex: pulmonary and aortic valves)
Carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs
one of two pairs of vessels carrying oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium of the heart
receives oxygenated blood from the lungs
between left atrium and left ventricle
pumps oxygenated blood to the body
The large arterial trunk that carries blood from the heart to be distributed by branch arteries through the body.
Divides the right and left chambers of the heart
epicardium, myocardium, endocardium
inner lining of the heart
plants and animals
autotrophic and stationary
heterotrophic and motile

cards.term: Why did they stop using the 2 kingdom system?
cards.definition: Fungi - heterotrophic but plant likebacteria - prokaryotic
Animalia, Plantae, Fungi, Protista, Prokaryotae (monera)
kingdom of multicellular eukaryotic heterotrophs whose cells do not have cell walls
Kingdom of multicellular photosynthetic autotrophs that have cell walls containing cellulose
Kingdom composed of heterotrophs; many obtain energy and nutrients from dead organic matterchitin cell wall and mycelium
one celled organism with no distinct nucleus
Kingdom composed of eukaryotes that are not classified as plants, animals, or fungi - defined by exclusion
plant-like protists
animal-like protists
Bacteria, Archaea, Eukarya
Prokaryotes, cell walls have peptidoglycan, can be autotrophic or heterotrophic
Prokaryotic, single-celled, live in extreme environments, hetero and autotrophic
chloroplast, mitochondria, nucleus
To increase contrast only stains specific parts of the cellmaking them more visible
mitochondria
ribosomes
full= nucleustrace = mitochondria / chloroplast
lysosomes
The degree to which the size of an image is larger than the object itselfnumerically - image size/actual size
The degree to which it is possible to distinguish between two points that are close together.
A series of lines on a microscope which can be used to calculate the size of objects.
1 marking1000/ magnification
eyepiece x objective

cards.term: What is the difference in function between RER and SER?
cards.definition: RER = isolate and transport proteins (digestive enzymes and hormones) made at the ribosomes. SER = synthesis and transport of lipids and steroids

cards.term: Describe the internal structure of mitochondria.
cards.definition: Double membrane, cristae, matrix

cards.term: State the surrounding membrane of the vacuole.
cards.definition: Tonoplast

cards.term: Explain the difference between proviral latency and episomal latency.
cards.definition: EL = viral nucleic acid remains inactive but free in the cytoplasm or nucleus of the infected cell. PL = viral nucleic acid becomes incorporated into the DNA of the infected host cell. It is now termed a provirus but the viral nucleic acid can be reactivated at any time.

cards.term: What biological molecule is an enzyme?
cards.definition: protein

cards.term: What is the substance called that an enzyme works on?
cards.definition: Substrate

cards.term: Where do substrates enter an enzyme?
cards.definition: Active site

cards.term: Why does only one enzyme work on one substrate?
cards.definition: Active site is specific and only complementary to 1 substrate

cards.term: Describe the shape of an enzyme
cards.definition: \xe2\x80\xa2Enzymes are proteins\xe2\x80\xa2Enzymes are 3D\xe2\x80\xa2Enzymes have an active site\xe2\x80\xa2Active site is specific

cards.term: Explain the shape of an enzyme
cards.definition: \xe2\x80\xa2Enzymes have a tertiary structure because the secondary has folded\xe2\x80\xa2The sequence of amino acids determines the shape because bonds (H, I or DS) are formed between the different R-groups\xe2\x80\xa2Enzymes are specific because a different primary structure will cause different bonding and folding because there is a different sequence of R-groups
is a substance that increases the rate of reaction but remains chemically unchanged
to ensure vital reactions do occur under normal temperatures, pH and pressure
\xe2\x80\xa2Do not change the nature of the reaction\xe2\x80\xa2Effective in small amounts\xe2\x80\xa2Remain chemically unchanged after reaction
In anabolic reactions enzymes bring the substrate molecules together. (Build Up)
In catabolic reactions the enzyme active site affects the bonds in substrates so they are easier to break (break down)
Synthesis of proteins from AASynthesis of polysaccharides from simple sugars
Digestion of complex foodsBreakdown of sugar in respiration
anabolism + catabolism

cards.term: What is needed for a reaction?
cards.definition: \xe2\x80\xa2successful collisions between two molecules\xe2\x80\xa2Right angle\xe2\x80\xa2Right velocity

topics.title: Module 1 - Development of Practical Skills in Biology

cards.term: Outline the procedure to investigating the effect of exercise on heart rate.
cards.definition: 1. Measure the resting heart rate.2. Do some gentle exercise, such as stepping on and off a step for 5 minutes. Immediately afterwards, measure the heart rate again.3. Return to the resting position. Measure the heart rate every minute until it returns to the resting state.4. Record the time taken to return to normal.5. Repeat the experiment for different people (e.g. 8 people).
Place your fingers on your forearm. Count the number of beats in 15 seconds and multiply that by 4 to get the number of beats per minute.

cards.term: Which test can be used to test if the effect of exercise is significant, and why?
cards.definition: T-test, because it is comparing 2 means.
The orientation of a plant in response to light.

cards.term: What should be the controlled variables when investigating phototropism?
cards.definition: Temperature, nutrient concentration, humidity, light intensity

cards.term: How should the shoots be prepared?
cards.definition: 1: Cover tips with foil 2: Cover base with foil 3: Leave without foil
The growth of plants in response to gravity.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to investigating geotropism.
cards.definition: 1. Line three petri dishes with moist cotton wool.2. Space out 10 cress seeds on the surface of the wool. Press them down in the wool slightly.3. Put a lid on each dish. Wrap the dishes in foil to prevent light reaching the seeds. Leave the dishes where the temperature is constant and warm.4. Set up the dishes so they\xe2\x80\x99re placed at different angles: 90, 45, 0 degrees.5. Leave the seeds for 4 days.6. After 4 days, unwrap each dish and note the direction of the shoot and root growth of cress seedlings. Record in a table.

cards.term: What are the controlled variables for investigating geotropism?
cards.definition: Volume of water providedMass of cotton wool Number of seeds Exposure to light Species of seed Temperature Time allowed for growth

cards.term: What is the function of auxin in plants?
cards.definition: It stimulates cell elongation for growth, and has a role in apical dominance.
Where the main stem inhibits the growth of lateral buds.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to investigate the effect of auxin.
cards.definition: 1. Select 30 plants similar in height, mass and age. Count the number of side shoots growing from the main stem.2. Apply a paste with auxin to 10 plants, apply a past without auxin to another 10 plants, and leave the remaining 10 as they are.3. Allow 6 days for the plants to grow.4. Count the number of side shoots that have grown from the main stem.

cards.term: What are the controlled variables of this practical?
cards.definition: Age, height, mass of plant Species of plant Temperature Light intensityWater

cards.term: What is the role of gibberellins in plants?
cards.definition: They have a role in germination and stem elongation.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to find the effect of gibberellin on plant stem elongation.
cards.definition: 1. Select 40 plants of similar height, age and mass.2. Leave 20 to grow, and water the other 20 with a dilute gibberellin solution.3. Leave the plants to grow for 28 days.4. Measure the length of the stem of the plants every 7 days. Calculate the mean stem length.

cards.term: What is the function of a spirometer?
cards.definition: Measures breathing and respiration.

cards.term: How is tidal volume found using a spirometer?
cards.definition: It is the distance from peak to trough when the participant is breathing normally.

cards.term: How is vital capacity found using a spirometer?
cards.definition: The distance from peak to trough when the participant takes a forced deep breath.

cards.term: What does an upward slope on the spirometer trace indicate?
cards.definition: Person breathing in.

cards.term: What does a downward slope on the spirometer trace indicate?
cards.definition: Person breathing out.
Protein.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to a Biuret test.
cards.definition: 1. Add sodium hydroxide solution.2. Add copper (II) sulphate solution.3. If the colour changes from blue to purple, protein is present.
Starch.

cards.term: What is the colour change for a positive iodine test?
cards.definition: Brown to blue-black.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to the emulsion test.
cards.definition: 1. Add ethanol.2. Pour solution into water.3. A white emulsion forms.

cards.term: What does Benedict\xe2\x80\x99s reagent test for?
cards.definition: Reducing sugars.

cards.term: Outline the test for reducing sugars.
cards.definition: 1. Add equal volume or excess Benedict\xe2\x80\x99s reagent to a sample and boil.2. If positive, colour changes from blue tored, with a brick-red precipitate.

cards.term: Outline the test procedure for non-reducing sugars.
cards.definition: 1. Add dilute HCl and boil.2. Neutralise with sodium hydrogen carbonate.3. Add Benedict\xe2\x80\x99s reagent and boil.4. If positive, colour changes from blue to red, with brick-red precipitate.

cards.term: What is a method to test for glucose specifically?
cards.definition: Dip the pad of a glucose test strip into the sample. Colour change will occur if glucose is present.Concentration can be found by comparing colour to a colour standard chart.

cards.term: State 2 factors that affect the permeability of cell membranes.
cards.definition: TemperatureConcentration of solvents (ethanol)

cards.term: How is beetroot used to measure the permeability of cell membranes?
cards.definition: The higher the permeability, the more red pigment that leaks out into the surrounding solution within a given time. A colorimeter can be used to determine the absorbance, hence concentration of pigment.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to investigate the effect of temperature on permeability of cell membrane.
cards.definition: 1. Cut beetroot into 6 identical cubes with a scalpel.2. Place each cube in a different test tube with equal volumes of distilled water.3. Place each test tube into water baths ranging from 30-80\xc2\xb0C. Leave for 20 minutes.4. Filter each solution out into a cuvette and measure the absorbance.

cards.term: What are the safety hazards involved in testing the effect of ethanol concentration on membrane permeability?
cards.definition: Ethanol is an irritant and is flammable, keep away from naked flames, wear eye protection.Keep sharp scalpel away from fingers. Handle hot liquid with care.

cards.term: What is the effect of temperature on membrane permeability?
cards.definition: Increasing temperature results in increase membrane permeability.

cards.term: What is the effect of ethanol concentration on membrane permeability?
cards.definition: Increasing ethanol concentration leads to increased membrane permeability, as ethanol causes gaps to form in the membrane.

cards.term: Outline the materials used to measure the rate of diffusion.
cards.definition: Make agar jelly mixed with phenolphthalein. Place in HCl and measure the time taken for the agar jelly to turn colourless.Change the factor and repeat eg. concentration of HCL, surface area of agar jelly.

cards.term: What is the effect of concentration on the rate of diffusion?
cards.definition: Increasing concentration increases the steepness of the concentration gradient, hence increasing the rate of diffusion (decreasing the time taken for the agar jelly to decolourise).

cards.term: What is the effect of surface area on the rate of diffusion?
cards.definition: Increased surface area to volume ratio increases the rate of diffusion.

\xe2\x97\x8f Wash your hands and disinfect your work area.\xe2\x97\x8f Have Bunsen Burner on nearby to sterilise the air and prevent air-borne microorganisms settling.\xe2\x97\x8f When opening the bottle of broth, pass the neck over the Bunsen Burner flame to prevent the microorganisms in the air entering the bottle.\xe2\x97\x8f Only open a petri dish enough to allow you to introduce your desired organisms.\xe2\x97\x8f All equipment should be sterilised by passing it over the flame before and after use.
To prevent the growth of pathogens (harmful bacteria), which occurs at higher temperatures.

cards.term: Why are petri dishes incubated upside down?
cards.definition: To prevent condensation from forming on the lid and dripping down onto the bacteria.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to find the effect of antibiotics on bacteria growth.
cards.definition: 1. Using a sterile pipette, add the same volume of each antibiotic to a different Petri dish.2. Dip an inoculating loop in the broth. Recap the broth bottle.3. Spread a streak of broth over the agar surface, then close the Petri dish, and tape it shut. Repeat for the remaining Petri dishes. Label each petri dish.4. Place the petri dishes in a warm incubator. Leave all the plates for the same amount of time (e.g. a day) then observe the results.5. Count the number of colonies that have formed on each plate and record results in a table. Calculate the mean number of colonies formed for each antibiotic.

cards.term: How should the controls be set up for this practical?
cards.definition: Two petri dishes with no antibiotic and two uncultured petri dishes.

cards.term: State the hazards and precautions of this practical.
cards.definition: Naked flame: keep away from flammable materials, tie hair up, wear gogglesBacteria is a biohazard, use disinfect and wash hands, dispose of bacteria safelyDisinfectant is flammable, keep away from naked flame.

cards.term: Why should the lid not be completely taped to the petri dish?
cards.definition: To allow oxygen to enter the petri dish, preventing the growth of harmful anaerobic bacteria.

cards.term: What is the purpose of chromatography?
cards.definition: To separate different components in a sample.

cards.term: State the factors affecting the rate of migration of different pigments.
cards.definition: Solubility MassAffinity to the paper

cards.term: What is the formula of the RF value?
cards.definition: Distance moved by pigment / Distance moved by solvent

cards.term: What is the purpose of finding the RF value of a pigment?
cards.definition: Experimental RF value can be compared to a standard value in a database to identify the pigment.The standard value should be using the same paper and solvent.

cards.term: Outline the procedure of using chromatography to separate photosynthetic pigments.
cards.definition: 1. Draw a pencil line 1cm above the bottom of the filter paper.2. Add some acetone and use the mortar and pestle to grind up the leaf sample and release the pigments.3. Use a capillary tube to transfer the pigment onto the pencil line.4. Suspend the paper in the solvent so that the level of the liquid does not lie above the pencil line and leave until the solvent has run up the paper to near the top.5. Remove the paper from the solvent and draw a pencil line marking where the solvent moved up to.6. Calculate the Rf value for each spot.

cards.term: State the hazards and precautions in this practical.
cards.definition: Solvents are irritant and flammable. Keep away from naked flame, wear eye protection and avoid contact with skin.Leaf extract may be a biohazard. Wash hands after use.

cards.term: Why should the final locations of the pigments be marked?
cards.definition: The pigments may also disappear as the solvent dries.

cards.term: How can chromatography be used to separate amino acids?
cards.definition: Same method as leaf extract, except spray the chromatography paper after the solvent had run with ninhydrin solution to stain each residue purple.

cards.term: What is the purpose of gel electrophoresis?
cards.definition: To separate fragments of DNA. It can be used for DNA fingerprinting.

It separates DNA fragments by their length. Due to the negative charge of the phosphate groups in DNA, it is attracted to the positive electrode (anode), and shorter fragments move at faster rates. Hence, the fragments move different distances within a given time.

cards.term: What are controlled variables in this practical?
cards.definition: Voltage applied Thickness of agarose gel TemperatureTime allowed for DNA to run Restriction enzymes used
They are a type of enzyme derived from bacteria that cuts DNA into fragments at specific restriction sites.

cards.term: Outline the procedure of gel electrophoresis.
cards.definition: 1. Use restriction enzymes to cut the DNA sample.2. Load into wells near the cathode of the agarose gel, along with buffer.3. Apply an electric current and allow the fragments to separate. Stop the current before the DNA reaches the end of the gel.

cards.term: Other than DNA, which molecules can be tested using electrophoresis?
cards.definition: Protein, RNA.
Absorbance/transmission.The paler the solution, the lower the absorbance and higher the transmission, as more light can pass through the sample.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to find an unknown concentration of reducing sugar.
cards.definition: 1. Carry out a Benedict\xe2\x80\x99s test on a range of standard solutions of reducing sugar.2. Using the colorimeter, measure the percentage transmission for each sample.3. Plot a graph of transmission against reducing sugar concentration.4. Carry out a Benedict\xe2\x80\x99s test on the unknown solution and measure the transmission using the colorimeter.5. Plot the transmission on the calibration curve, and read off the x axis (reducing sugar concentration) for the concentration of the unknown solution.

cards.term: What indicates a higher reducing sugar concentration?
cards.definition: Higher absorbance, lower transmission.

cards.term: What is the function of a potometer?
cards.definition: A device used to measure the rate of water uptake of a plant, and hence the rate of transpiration.

cards.term: Which factors affect the rate of transpiration?
cards.definition: Temperature Water supplyHumidity Surface areaWind speed Presence of cuticle Light intensity

cards.term: Why must the leafy shoot be cut underwater?
cards.definition: To prevent air bubbles from forming in the vascular tissue.

cards.term: Why should the cut of the shoot be slanted?
cards.definition: To increase the surface area available for water uptake.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to this practical.
cards.definition: 1. Set up the potometer.2. Clamp the capillary tube into the stand. Place the bottom of the capillary tube into the beaker of water.3. Smear petroleum jelly around the join to maintain airtight conditions.4. Leave for 5 minutes for a bubble to be drawn into the capillary tube.5. Measure the movement of the bubble along the capillary tube in a certain length of time.6. Repeat the experiment and change the abiotic variable

cards.term: How is the rate of transpiration calculated?
cards.definition: Measure the distance travelled by the bubbles in the capillary and the radius of the capillary.Find the volume of water taken up by using \xcf\x80r2. Divide the volume by time.
By changing the distance between the lamp and the potometer.

cards.term: How can wind speed be controlled?
cards.definition: By placing a fan near the potometer with different speeds.
By wrapping a plastic bag around the plant to maintain a humid environment.

cards.term: What are some limitations of this method?
cards.definition: Not all of the water taken up is transpired, some is used to maintain turgidity and for photosynthesis.The plant is dying when the stem is cut, rate of water uptake is lower than normal.

cards.term: What are the four factors affecting rate of enzyme reaction?
cards.definition: Enzyme concentration Substrate concentration Temperature pH

cards.term: How can you measure the rate of reaction using hydrogen peroxide and catalase?
cards.definition: Measure the volume of oxygen gas produced in a given time

cards.term: State the word equation for the action of catalase.
cards.definition: Hydrogen peroxide \xe2\x86\x92 Oxygen + Water

cards.term: What are the controlled variables of this practical?
cards.definition: Enzyme volume and concentration Substrate volume and concentration pH

cards.term: State the hazards and safety precautions involved in this practical.
cards.definition: Hydrogen peroxide is an irritant. Wear eye protection and avoid contact with skin.Take care in handling hot water baths, and wash hands after handling peas/ source of catalase.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to find the effect of enzyme concentration on rate of reaction using amylase.
cards.definition: 1. Put drops of iodine solution into each well of a spotting tile.2. Make a serial dilution of amylase to produce several concentrations.3. Add the same concentration and volume of starch to the first boiling tube. At the same time, start the timer.4. Use a dropping pipette to put a drop of this mixture into one of the wells containing the iodine solution at regular intervals.5. Time how long it takes for the colour to no longer turn blue-black.6. Repeat at least 2 more times and calculate the mean time taken.7. Repeat the experiment for each concentration of amylase.

cards.term: What are the controlled variables of this practical?
cards.definition: Temperature pHSubstrate volume and concentration Volume of enzyme added
Light intensity HumidityTemperature Wind speedWater supply Day length Nutrient supply Rainfall
Competition for resources PredationDiseaseanimalsplantsfungibacteria
Use a quadrat with squares. Count how many squares the required species is present in. Only count a square is more than half of the square is covered.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to this practical.
cards.definition: 1. Choose an area to take samples from. Use a random number generator to generate 10 sets of random coordinates.2. Use two tape measures to create a set of axes off which coordinates can be read.3. Place the quadrat at each of the coordinates, placing the bottom left corner on the coordinate every time.4. Record the percentage cover for the chosen species.5. At each coordinate, a measure of the independent variable should be taken. Eg. record light intensity using a photometer at each location

cards.term: How can the results be used to determine the relationship between the chosen factor and the percentage cover?
cards.definition: Use a statistical test eg. Pearson\xe2\x80\x99s linear correlation, Spearman\xe2\x80\x99s rank
Number of different species in a community and the relative abundance of each population.

cards.term: What is the advantage of random sampling?
cards.definition: Prevents selective sampling from causing bias.

cards.term: Outline the procedure of using a transect for systematic sampling.
cards.definition: 1. Use a measuring tape to make a transect over the area you wish to sample.2. Place quadrats at given intervals along the tape measure (e.g. every 5 metres). The bottom left-hand corner of each quadrat should be touching the relevant metre mark, and the left-hand edge runs along the tape measure3. Identify the different species in each quadrat using a key and count the number of each present. Calculate the percentage cover.

cards.term: Which type of graph is used to represent the distribution of a species along a transect?
cards.definition: A kite diagram.

cards.term: What can be observed when feeling the walls of the 4 chambers of the heart?
cards.definition: The walls of the atria are thinner than the ventricles, and the wall of the left ventricle is thicker than the right ventricle.

cards.term: State an observable difference between veins and arteries.
cards.definition: The walls of arteries are thicker, veins have valves and a larger lumen.

cards.term: Why are plant tissues stained before they are observed?
cards.definition: So that different tissues can appear as different colours to be more easily identified.

cards.term: What is the function of a stage micrometer?
cards.definition: To calibrate an eyepiece graticule so that it can be used to make measurements.

cards.term: How is an eyepiece graticule calibrated?
cards.definition: Select the desired magnification and objective. Place the stage micrometer on the stage.Line up the scales of the micrometer and the eyepiece graticule.Count the number of divisions on the eyepiece graticule equivalent to each division on the stage micrometre.Calculate the length of one division of the eyepiece graticule.

cards.term: Outline the procedure to preparing a slide.
cards.definition: Stain the sample with an appropriate dye.Mount the sample on the slide.Place a cover slip carefully on the slide, avoiding air bubbles.
Magnification = Size of image / Size of object

cards.term: State what the cell cycle is and outline its stages.
cards.definition: Regulated cycle of division with intermediate growth periods.1. interphase2. mitosis or meiosis (nuclear division)3. cytokinesis (cytoplasmic division)

G1: cell synthesises proteins for replication e.g. tubulin for spindle fibres & cell size doubles.S: DNA replicates = chromosomes consist of 2 sister chromatids joined at a centromere.G2: Organelles divide.

cards.term: What is the purpose of mitosis?
cards.definition: Produces 2 genetically identical daughter cells for:\xe2\x97\x8f growth\xe2\x97\x8f cell replacement/ tissue repair \xe2\x97\x8f asexual reproduction
1. Prophase2. Metaphase3. Anaphase4. Telophase

1. Chromosomes condense, becoming visible. (X-shaped: 2 sister chromatids joined at centromere).2. Centrioles move to opposite poles of cell (animal cells) & mitotic spindle fibres form.3. Nuclear envelope & nucleolus break down = chromosomes free in cytoplasm.
Sister chromatids line up at cell equator, attached to the mitotic spindle by their centromeres.

Requires energy from ATP hydrolysis1. Spindle fibres contract = centromeres divide.2. Sister chromatids separate into 2 distinct chromosomes & are pulled to opposite poles of cell. (looks like \xe2\x80\x98V\xe2\x80\x99 shapes facing each other).3. Spindle fibres break down.
1. Chromosomes decondense, becoming invisible again.2. New nuclear envelopes form around each set of chromosomes = 2 new nuclei, each with 1 copy of each chromosome.
1. Cell membrane cleavage furrow forms.2. Contractile division of cytoplasm.

cards.term: How is the cell cycle regulated?
cards.definition: Checkpoints regulated by cell-signalling proteins ensure damaged cells do not progress to next stage of cycle.Cyclin-dependent kinase enzymes phosphorylate proteins that initiate next phase of reactions.

cards.term: Describe what happens at each key checkpoint in the cell cycle.
cards.definition: Between G1 & S, cell checks for DNA damage (e.g. via action of p53). After restriction point, cell enters cycle.Between G2 & M, cell checks chromosome replication.At metaphase checkpoint, cell checks that sister chromatids have attached to spindle correctly.
A form of cell division that produces four genetically different haploid cells (cells with half the number of chromosomes found in the parent cell) known as gametes.

1. Homologous chromosomes pair to form bivalents.2. Crossing over (exchange of sections of genetic material) occurs at chiasmata.3. Cell divides into two. Homologous chromosomes separate randomly. Each cell contains either maternal or paternal copy.
Pair of chromosomes with genes at the same locus. 1 maternal & 1 paternal.Some alleles may be the same while others are different.
1. Independent segregation of sister chromatids.2. Each cell divides again, producing 4 haploid cells.

cards.term: Describe the fluid mosaic model of membranes.
cards.definition: Fluid: phospholipid bilayer in which individual phospholipids can move = membrane has flexible shape.Mosaic: extrinsic & intrinsic proteins of different sizes and shapes are embedded.

cards.term: Explain the role of cholesterol & glycolipids in membranes.
cards.definition: Cholesterol: steroid molecule in some plasma membranes; connects phospholipids & reduces fluidity to make bilayer more stable.Glycolipids: cell signalling & cell recognition.

cards.term: Explain the functions of extrinsic and transmembrane proteins in membranes.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Binding sites/ receptors e.g. for hormones & drugs\xe2\x97\x8f Antigens (glycoproteins)\xe2\x97\x8f Bind cells together\xe2\x97\x8f Involved in cell signalling

cards.term: Explain the functions of intrinsic transmembrane proteins in membranes.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Electron carriers (respiration/photosynthesis).\xe2\x97\x8f Channel proteins (facilitated diffusion).\xe2\x97\x8f Carrier proteins (facilitated diffusion / active transport).

cards.term: Explain the functions of membranes within cells.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Provide internal transport system.\xe2\x97\x8f Selectively permeable to regulate passage of molecules into / out of organelles or within organelles.\xe2\x97\x8f Provide reaction surface.\xe2\x97\x8f Isolate organelles from cytoplasm for specific metabolic reactions.

cards.term: Explain the functions of the cell-surface membrane.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Isolates cytoplasm from extracellular environment.\xe2\x97\x8f Selectively permeable to regulatetransport of substances.\xe2\x97\x8f Involved in cell signalling / cell recognition.

cards.term: Name and explain 3 factors that affect membrane permeability.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Temperature: high temperature denatures membrane proteins / phospholipid molecules have more kinetic energy & move further apart.\xe2\x97\x8f pH: changes tertiary structure of membrane proteins.\xe2\x97\x8f Use of a solvent: may dissolve membrane.

cards.term: Outline how colorimetry could be used to investigate membrane permeability.
cards.definition: 1. Use plant tissue with soluble pigment in vacuole. Tonoplast & cell-surface membrane disrupted = \xe2\x86\x91 permeability = pigment diffuses into solution.2. Select colorimeter filter with complementary colour.3. Use distilled water to set colorimeter to 0. Measure absorbance / % transmission value of solution.4. High absorbance/ low transmission = more pigment in solution.
Water diffuses across semi-permeable membranes from an area of higher water potential to an area of lower water potential until a dynamic equilibrium is established.
\xe2\x97\x8f Pressure created by water molecules measured in kPa\xe2\x97\x8f \xce\xa8 of pure water at 25\xe2\x84\x83 & 100 kPa: 0\xe2\x97\x8f More solute = \xcf\x88 more negative

cards.term: How does osmosis affect plant and animal cells?
cards.definition: osmosis INTO cell:plant: protoplast swells = cell turgidanimal: lysisosmosis OUT of cell:plant: protoplast shrinks = cell flaccidanimal: crenation

Passive process requires no energy from ATP hydrolysis.Net movement of small, lipid-soluble molecules directly through the bilayer from an area of high concentration to an area of lower concentration (i.e. down a concentration gradient).

Passive process.Specific channel or carrier proteins with complementary binding sites transport large and/ or polar molecules/ ions (not soluble in hydrophobic phospholipid tail) down concentration gradient.

cards.term: Explain how channel and carrier proteins work.
cards.definition: Explain how channel and carrier proteins work. Channel: hydrophilic channels bind to specific ions = one side of the protein closes & the other opens.Carrier: binds to complementary molecule = conformational change releases molecule on other side of membrane; in facilitated diffusion, passive process; in active transport, requires energy from ATP hydrolysis.

Active process: ATP hydrolysis releases phosphate group that binds to carrier protein, causing it to change shape.Specific carrier protein transports molecules/ ions from area of low concentration to area of higher concentration (i.e. against concentration gradient).

Proteins that act as biological catalysts for intra & extracellular reactions to determine structure & function. Therefore affect metabolism of cells & whole organism.Specific tertiary structure determines shape of active site, complementary to a specific substrate.Formation of enzyme-substrate (ES) complexes lowersactivation energy of metabolic reactions.

cards.term: Give an example of an enzyme that catalyses intracellular reactions.
cards.definition: Catalase: catalyses decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (which causes oxidative stress) into water + oxygen.

cards.term: Give 2 examples of enzymes that catalyse extracellular reactions.
cards.definition: Amylase: carbohydrase catalyses digestion of starch to maltose in saliva/ small intestine lumen.Trypsin: pancreatic endopeptidase catalyses hydrolysis of peptide bonds in small intestine lumen.

cards.term: Explain the induced fit model of enzyme action.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Shape of active site is not directly complementary to substrate & is flexible.\xe2\x97\x8f Conformational change enables ES complexes to form when substrate adsorbs.\xe2\x97\x8f This puts strain on substrate bonds, lowering activation energy. Bonds in enzyme-product complex are weak, so product desorbs.

cards.term: Explain the lock and key model of enzyme action.
cards.definition: Suggests that active site has a rigid shape determined by tertiary structure so is only complementary to 1 substrate. Formation of ES complex lowers activation energy.Bonds in enzyme-product complex are weak, so product desorbs.

cards.term: Name 5 factors that affect the rate of enzyme-controlled reactions.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f enzyme concentration\xe2\x97\x8f substrate concentration\xe2\x97\x8f concentration of inhibitors\xe2\x97\x8f pH\xe2\x97\x8f temperature

cards.term: How does substrate concentration affect rate of reaction?
cards.definition: Given that enzyme concentration is fixed, rate increases proportionally to substrate concentration.The rate levels off when maximum number of ES complexes form at any given time.

cards.term: How does enzyme concentration affect rate of reaction?
cards.definition: Given that substrate is in excess, rate increases proportionally to enzyme concentration.Rate levels off when maximum number of ES complexes form at any given time.

cards.term: How does temperature affect the rate of enzyme-controlled reactions?
cards.definition: Rate increases as kinetic energy increases & peaks at optimum temperature.Above optimum, ionic & H-bonds in 3\xc2\xb0 structure break = active site no longer complementary to substrate (denaturation).
Q10 measures the change in rate of reaction per 10\xe2\x84\x83 temperature increase.Q10 = R2 / R1 (where R represents rate)

cards.term: How does pH affect rate of reaction?
cards.definition: Enzymes have a narrow optimum pH range.Outside range, H+/ OH- ions interact with H-bonds & ionic bonds in 3\xc2\xb0 structure = denaturation.
Bind to active site since they have similar shape to substrate. Temporarily prevent ES complexes from forming until released.Increasing substrate concentration decreases their effect.
Bind at allosteric binding site.Trigger conformational change of active site.Increasing substrate concentration has no impact on their effect.
One of the products of a reaction acts as a competitive or non-competitive inhibitor for an enzyme involved in the pathway.Prevents further formation of products.

Permanently prevent formation of ES complexes.Heavy metal ions e.g. mercury, silver cause disulphide bonds in tertiary structure to break.Bind to enzymes by strong (covalent) bonds e.g. cyanide binds to cytochrome c.

cards.term: Draw the structure of a nucleotide.
cards.definition: Name the pentose sugars in DNA & RNA.
Describe how polynucleotide strands are formed and broken down.

cards.term: Condensation reactions between nucleotides form strong phosphodiester bonds (sugar-phosphate backbone). Hydrolysis reactions use a molecule of water to break these bonds.Enzymes catalyse these reactions.
cards.definition: Describe the structure of DNA.

cards.term: Molecule twists to form double helix of 2 deoxyribose polynucleotide strands (so there are 2 sugar-phosphate backbones).H-bonds form between complementary base pairs (AT & GC) on strands that run antiparallel.
cards.definition: Name the purine bases and describe their structure.

cards.term: Name the pyrimidine bases and describe theirstructure.
cards.definition: Name the complementary base pairs in DNA and RNA.

cards.term: DNA: 2 H-bonds between adenine (A) + thymine (T)RNA: 2 H-bonds between adenine (A) + uracil (U)Both have 3 H-bonds between guanine (G) + cytosine (C)
cards.definition: Why is DNA replication described as semiconservative?

cards.term: Strands from original DNA molecule act as templates.New DNA molecule contains 1 old strand & 1 new strand (specific base pairing enables genetic material to be conserved accurately).
cards.definition: Explain the role of DNA helicase in semiconservative replication.

cards.term: Breaks H-bonds between base pairs to form 2 single strands, each of which can act as a template.
cards.definition: How is a new strand formed during semiconservative replication?

cards.term: 1. Free nucleotides from nuclear sap attach to exposed bases by complementary base pairing.2. DNA polymerase joins adjacent nucleotides on new strand in a 5\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x86\x92 3\xe2\x80\x99 direction via condensation reactions to form phosphodiester bonds.3. H-bonds reform.
cards.definition: Identify features of the genetic code.

cards.term: \xe2\x97\x8f Non-overlapping: each triplet is only read once.\xe2\x97\x8f Degenerate: more than one triplet codes for the same amino acid (64 possible triplets for 20 amino acids).\xe2\x97\x8f Universal: same bases and sequences used by all species.
cards.definition: How does a gene determine the sequence of amino acids in a protein?

cards.term: Consists of base triplets that code for a specific amino acids.
cards.definition: Describe how DNA can be purified by precipitation.

cards.term: Add ethanol & a salt to aqueous solution. Nucleic acids precipitate out of solution.Centrifuge to obtain pellet of nucleic acid. Wash pellet with ethanol & centrifuge again.
cards.definition: What does transcription produce and where does it occur?
Outline the process of transcription.

cards.term: 1. RNA polymerase binds to promoter region on a gene.2. Section of DNA uncoils into 2 strands with exposed bases. Antisense strand acts as template.3. Free nucleotides are attracted to their complementary bases.4. RNA polymerase joins adjacent nucleotides to formphosphodiester bonds.
How do hydrogen bonds form between water molecules?
cards.definition: Water is polar: O more electronegative than H, so attracts electron density in covalent bond more strongly. Forms O \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbf- (slightly negative) & H \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbf+ (slightly positive).There are intermolecular forces of attraction between a lone pair on O \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbf- of one molecule & H \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbf+ on an adjacent molecule.

cards.term: State 7 biologically important properties of water.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f reaches maximum density at 4\xe2\x84\x83\xe2\x97\x8f high surface tension\xe2\x97\x8f incompressible\xe2\x97\x8f metabolite/ solvent for chemical reactions in the body\xe2\x97\x8f high specific heat capacity\xe2\x97\x8f high latent heat of vaporisation\xe2\x97\x8f cohesion between molecules

cards.term: Why is the incompressible nature of water important for organisms?
cards.definition: Provides turgidity to plant cells.Provides hydrostatic skeleton for some small animals e.g. earthworms.

cards.term: Explain why ice floats on water. Why is this important for organisms?
cards.definition: Ice is less dense than water because H-bonds hold molecules in fixed positions further away from each other.Insulates water in arctic climates so aquatic organisms can survive. Water acts as a habitat.

cards.term: Why is the high surface tension of water important for organisms?
cards.definition: Slows water loss due to transpiration in plants.Water rises unusually high in narrow tubes, lowering demand on root pressure.Some insects can \xe2\x80\x98skim\xe2\x80\x99 across the surface of water.

cards.term: Why is water an important solvent for organisms?
cards.definition: Polar universal solvent dissolves & transports charged particles involved in intra & extracellular reactions e.g. PO4 3- for DNA synthesis.

cards.term: Why are the high specific heat capacity and latent of vapourisation of water important for organisms?
cards.definition: Acts as a temperature buffer which enables endotherms to resist fluctuations in core temperature to maintain optimum enzyme activity.Cooling effect when water evaporates from skin surface as sweat/ from mouth when panting.

cards.term: Define monomer and polymer. Give some examples.
cards.definition: monomer: smaller units that join together to form larger molecules\xe2\x97\x8f monosaccharides (glucose, fructose, galactose, ribose)\xe2\x97\x8f amino acids\xe2\x97\x8f nucleotidespolymer: molecules formed when many monomers join together\xe2\x97\x8f polysaccharides\xe2\x97\x8f proteins\xe2\x97\x8f DNA/ RNA

cards.term: What happens in condensation and hydrolysis reactions?
cards.definition: Condensation: chemical bond forms between 2 molecules & a molecule of water is produced.Hydrolysis: a water molecule is used to break a chemical bond between 2 molecules e.g. peptide bonds in proteins, ester bonds between fatty acids & glycerol in lipids.

cards.term: Name the elements found in carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and nucleic acids.
cards.definition: carbohydrates & lipids: C, H, O proteins: C, H, O, N, Snucleic acids: C, H, O, N, P
both hexose monosaccharides (6C) with ring structure.

\xe2\x97\x8f Small & water soluble = easily transported in bloodstream.\xe2\x97\x8f Complementary shape to antiport for co-transport for absorption in gut.\xe2\x97\x8f Complementary shape to enzymes for glycolysis = respiratory substrate.
pentose monosaccharide (5C) ring structure.

cards.term: What type of bond forms when monosaccharides react?
cards.definition: (1,4 or 1,6) glycosidic bond\xe2\x97\x8f 2 monomers = 1 chemical bond = disaccharide.\xe2\x97\x8f Multiple monomers = many chemical bonds = polysaccharide.

cards.term: Name 3 disaccharides. Describe how they form.
cards.definition: Condensation reaction forms glycosidic bond between 2 monosaccharides.\xe2\x97\x8f maltose: glucose + glucose\xe2\x97\x8f sucrose: glucose + fructose\xe2\x97\x8f lactose: glucose + galactoseall have molecular formula C12H22O11

cards.term: Outline how a student could prepare a temporary mount of tissue for a light microscope.
cards.definition: 1. Obtain thin section of tissue e.g. using ultratome or by maceration.2. Place plant tissue in a drop of water.3. Stain tissue on a slide to make structures visible.4. Add coverslip using mounted needle at 45\xc2\xb0 to avoid trapping air bubbles.

1. Lenses focus rays of light and magnify the view of a thin slice of specimen.2. Different structures absorb different amounts and wavelengths of light.3. Reflected light is transmitted to the observer via the objective lens and eyepiece.

cards.term: Describe how a transmission electron microscope (TEM) works.
cards.definition: 1. Pass a high energy beam of electrons through a thin slice of specimen.2. More dense structures appear darker since they absorb more electrons.3. Focus image onto fluorescent screen or photographic plate using magnetic lenses.

cards.term: Describe how a scanning electron microscope (SEM) works.
cards.definition: 1. Focus a beam of electrons onto a specimen\xe2\x80\x99s surface using electromagnetic lenses.2. Reflected electrons hit a collecting device and are amplified to produce an image on a photographic plate.

cards.term: Describe how a laser scanning confocal microscope works.
cards.definition: 1. Focus a laser beam onto a small area on a sample\xe2\x80\x99s surface using objective lenses.2. Fluorophores in the sample emit photons.3. Photomultiplier tube amplifies the signal onto a detector. An image is produced pixel by pixel in the correct order.

cards.term: How should the field of view in microscopy be recorded?
cards.definition: Draw a diagram with a sharp pencil. Do not use sketchy lines or shading.Include a scale bar. Annotate visible structures.

cards.term: State an equation to calculate the actual size of a structure from microscopy.
cards.definition: actual size = image size / magnification
Magnification: factor by which the image is larger than the actual specimen.Resolution: smallest separation distance at which 2 separate structures can be distinguished from one another.

cards.term: Why do samples need to be stained for light microscopes?
cards.definition: Coloured dye binds to the structures.Facilitates absorption of wavelengths of light to produce image. Differential staining: contrast between heavily & lightly stained areas distinguishes structures.

cards.term: State the magnification and resolution of a compound optical microscope.
cards.definition: magnification: x 2000 resolution: 200 nm

cards.term: State the magnification and resolution of a TEM.
cards.definition: magnification: x 500 000resolution: 0.5 nm

cards.term: State the magnification and resolution of an SEM.
cards.definition: magnification: x 500 000resolution: 3 - 10 nm

cards.term: Explain how to use an eyepiece graticule and stage micrometer to measure the size of a structure.
cards.definition: 1. Place micrometer on stage to calibrate eyepiece graticule.2. Line up scales on graticule and micrometer. Count how many graticule divisions are in 100\xce\xbcm on the micrometer.3. Length of 1 eyepiece division = 100\xce\xbcm / number of divisions.4. Use calibrated values to calculate actual length of structures.

cards.term: Describe the structure of the nucleus.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Surrounded by a nuclear envelope, a semipermeable double membrane.\xe2\x97\x8f Nuclear pores allow substances to enter/exit.\xe2\x97\x8f Dense nucleolus made of RNA & proteins assembles ribosomes.

cards.term: Describe the function of the nucleus.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Contains DNA coiled around chromatin into chromosomes.\xe2\x97\x8f Controls cellular processes: gene expression determines specialisation & site of mRNA transcription, mitosis, semiconservative replication.
An organelle found in the head of sperm cells which is specialised to digest the outer coating of an egg cell during fertilisation.
The third stage in mitosis where the chromosomes are pulled apart to the poles of the cell by the spindle fibres.
The third stage of meiosis where the chromosomes that make up the bivalent are pulled apart to the poles of the cell by the spindle fibres.
The seventh stage of meiosis where the chromatids are pulled apart to opposite poles of the cell.
A type of cell which does not have a nucleus.
The production of genetically identtical offspring from one parent through the process of mitosis.
A pair of homologous chromosomes.
A type of epithelium which has many fine protrusions known as cilia and is specialised for sweeping dirt and debris out of the body.
The exchange of genetic material between two chromosomes in a bivalent.
The division of the cytoplasm at the end of mitosis to produce two new daughter cells.
The process where a cell develops certain features so that it is specialised to carry out a certain function.
Cells with two copies of each chromosome.
An anucleate cell specialised to carry oxygen from the lungs around the body (commonly referred to as a red blood cell).
The first checkpoint in the cell cycle which occurs just before the end of G1 phase and commits the cell to division under favourable conditions.
The first growth phase in interphase where the cell synthesises proteins and RNA, duplicates its organelles and increases in size before DNA replication in S phase.
The active movement of substances from a low concentration to a higher concentration (up their concentration gradient) with the use of energy in the form of ATP.
A molecule with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts.
The bursting of a cell, particularly after the uptake of too much water into an animal cell through osmosis.
A mostly hydrophobic molecule that sits in the hydrophobic portion of the membrane and regulates membrane fluidity.
The shrinking of a cell when placed in a hypertonic solution due to large amounts of water moving out of the cell through osmosis.
The bulk uptake of substances into a cell by invagination of the membrane to form a vesicle trapping the substances inside the cell with the use of energy in the form of ATP.
The bulk transport of substances out of a cell using a vesicle that fuses with the plasma membrane using energy in the form of ATP.
The net movement of substances from a high concentration to a lower concentration (down their concentration gradient) through transport proteins without the use of energy.
A model that describes membrane structure as a sea of mobile phospholipids studded with various proteins.
A molecule which is attracted to water
A molecule which repels water.
A type of protein bound to the membrane with strong interactions.
The net movement of water molecules across a partially permeable membrane from a region of high water potential to a region of lower water potential without the use of energy.
A type of protein that is weakly bound to the surface of the membrane.
The ingestion of solid material (particularly pathogens and foreign material) by phagocytic cells.
The amount of energy needed for a reaction to happen.
A specific region on an enzyme where the substrate binds and the reaction takes place.
An enzyme that catalyses the extracellular breakdown of starch.
An enzyme that catalyses the intracellular breakdown of hydrogen peroxide into oxygen and water.
A type of cofactor that is bound loosely to an enzyme with weak interactions.
A non-protein molecule that is needed for the effective functioning of an enzyme.
A molecule which binds to the active site of an enzyme and prevents the substrate from binding.
A metabolic poison which acts as an irreversible inhibitor of cytochrome oxidase and hence preventing respiration.
A method of enzyme inhibition where the product of an enzyme controlled reaction can bind to the enzyme and prevent it from working.
A biological catalyst used to speed up the rate of biochemical reactions without being used up or permanently altered.
The temporary complex formed after the enzyme has catalysed the reaction but before the products have left the active site of the enzyme.
The temporary complex formed when the substrate binds to the active site of the enzyme.
A reaction that occurs outside of cells
An inactive form of an enzyme that cannot carry out its function until it is activated.
A model of enzyme action that describes how once a specific substrate binds to the active site, the enzyme undergoes subtle conformational changes to fit the substrate better.
A nucleotide consisting of a molecule of ribose joined to the nitrogenous base adenine and three phosphate groups.
A term used to describe the fact that some amino acids can be coded for by multiple different codons.
A double stranded polynucleotide that contains the genetic material of an organism and is made up of deoxyribonucleotide monomers joined together by phosphodiester bonds.
The monomer that makes up DNA and consists of deoxyribose, a nitrogenous base and a phosphate group.
An enzyme that catalyses the formation of phosphodiester bonds between nucleotides during the synthesis of a new DNA strand.
An enzyme that catalyses the formation of phosphodiester bonds between nucleotides during the synthesis of a new RNA strand.
An enzyme that catalyses the unwinding and unzipping of DNA in many processes like replication and transcription.
A type of RNA that carries genetic information from the DNA in the nucleus to the ribosomes for translation.
A term used to describe the fact that each base is only part of one codon and that each codon is read one at a time in order.
The monomer from which nucleic acids are made that consists of a pentose sugar, nitrogenous base and phosphate group.
A type of bond that joins nucleotides together to create polynucleotides.
A class of nitrogenous bases which are made up of two rings that adenine and guanine are members of.
A class of nitrogenous bases which are made up of a single ring that cytosine, thymine and uracil are members of.
A type of RNA that makes up ribosomes.
The monomer that makes up RNA and consists of ribose, a nitrogenous base and a phosphate group.
A property of water molecules that creates an attraction between them and surfaces that they are in contact with.
The monomers containing an amino group (NH2), a carboxyl group (COOH) and a variable R group that make up proteins.
