A branched polysaccharide made up of alpha glucose monomers joined by \xce\xb1-1,6 glycosidic bonds that makes up starch along with amylose.
An unbranched polysaccharide made up of alpha glucose monomers joined by \xce\xb1-1,4 glycosidic bonds that makes up starch along with amylopectin.
An ion with a negative charge.
A biochemical test used to detect the presence of a reducing sugar in a solution and distinguish between solutions of different reducing sugar concentrations.
A biochemical test that produces a purple colour when it is added to a solution containing protein.
An ion with a positive charge.
A linear polysaccharide that is the main component of the cell wall in plants and is made up of many beta glucose molecules joined by \xce\xb2-1,4 glycosidic bonds.
A technique used to separate different molecules in a solution by their different properties.
A property of water molecules that creates an attraction between them which causes them to stick together.
A type of fibrous protein that provides strength to many different cell types and makes up connective tissues.
A type of reaction that joins two molecules together with the formation of a chemical bond involving the elimination of a molecule of water.
A protein with a prosthetic group bound to it.
A type of fibrous protein that allows tissues and structures like blood vessels to stretch and return to their original shape.
Structures found in the cytoplasm made of microtubules that produce the spindle fibres during mitosis.
Organelles found in plants and algae that are the site of photosynthesis.
Small hair-like structures that project from the surface of cells
A type of microscopy that uses lasers to scan a specimen point by point to produce an image.
A mesh of protein fibres found in the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells used for structural support and intracellular transport.
Using multiple different stains to distinguish different parts of a specimen.
A type of cell that contains a nucleus along with membrane bound organelles.
A whip-like structure found on bacterial cells that is used for cell movement.
An organelle found in eukaryotic cells that is involved in the modification and packaging of proteins.
A type of microscope that uses a series of lenses to magnify the visible light reflecting off a specimen.
Membrane-bound vesicles found in the cytoplasm that contain a hydrolytic enzyme called lysozyme.
How much bigger an image appears compared to the original object calculated using the following formula:Image size = Actual size x Magnification
An organelle found in eukaryotic cells that is the site of aerobic respiration.
A double membrane that surrounds the nucleus.
A structure found inside the nucleus that contains proteins and RNA and is involved in synthesising new ribosomes.

cards.term: Why do plants require a transport system?
cards.definition: To ensure all cells receive a strong supply of the nutrients they require. Especially important as a plant must be able to transport substances up their stem (against gravity).

cards.term: Relate the structure of xylem to its function.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Long, continuous columns made of dead tissue, allowing transportation of water.\xe2\x97\x8f Contain pits, allowing water to move sideways between vessels.\xe2\x97\x8f Thickened with a tough substance, providing structural support.

cards.term: Relate the structure of phloem to its function.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Sieve tube elements transport sugars around the plant.\xe2\x97\x8f Companion cells designed for active transport of sugars into tubes.\xe2\x97\x8f Plasmodesmata allow flow of substances between cytoplasm of different cells.

cards.term: Describe the structure and function of the vascular system in the roots.
cards.definition: Consists of xylem and phloem. Xylem arranged in an X shape to provide resistance against force. Surrounded by endodermis, a water supply.

cards.term: Describe the structure and function of the vascular system in the stem.
cards.definition: Consists of xylem and phloem. Xylem on the inside of the bundle to provide support and flexibility, phloem on the outside. Layer of meristem cells that produce new xylem and phloem tissue when required.

cards.term: Describe the structure and function of the vascular system in the leaves.
cards.definition: Consists of xylem and phloem, forms the midrib and veins. Involved in transport and support.
\xe2\x97\x8f The evaporation of water from the leaves of a plant.\xe2\x97\x8f Consequence of gaseous exchange;occurs when the plant opens the stomata to exchange oxygen and CO2.

cards.term: Name factors that affect the rate of transpiration.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Increased light increases transpiration.\xe2\x97\x8f Increased temperature increases transpiration.\xe2\x97\x8f Increased humidity decreases transpiration.\xe2\x97\x8f Increased air movement increases transpiration.\xe2\x97\x8f Waxy cuticle prevents transpiration.

cards.term: How can we measure transpiration rate?
cards.definition: Potometer. Plant cutting is placed in a water-filled tube that contains an air bubble. Rate of transpiration is calculated by measuring the movement of the air bubble over time.

cards.term: Define water potential as a mechanism of movement in plants.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Water potential= the tendency of water to move by osmosis, from high water potential to low. Pure distilled water has the highest water potential of 0.\xe2\x97\x8f This is the basis by which water moves to the areas it is needed within plants.

cards.term: Explain what is meant by the apoplastic pathway.
cards.definition: A method of osmosis through the root hair cells, where water moves through the cell walls and intercellular spaces. This pathway can only be used until water reaches the Casparian strip.

cards.term: Explain what is meant by the symplastic pathway.
cards.definition: A method of osmosis through the root hair cells, where water moves through the cytoplasm via plasmodesmata. To begin this pathway, water must be actively transported into cells.

Water molecules form hydrogen bonds with each other, causing them to \xe2\x80\x98stick\xe2\x80\x99 together (cohesion). The surface tension of the water also creates this sticking effect. Therefore as water is lost through transpiration, more can be drawn up the stem from the roots.

cards.term: Give adaptations of xerophytes that allow them to live in dry conditions.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Small/rolled leaves\xe2\x97\x8f Densely packed mesophyll\xe2\x97\x8f Thick waxy cuticle\xe2\x97\x8f Stomata often closed\xe2\x97\x8f Hairs to trap moist air

cards.term: Give adaptations of hydrophytes that allow them to live in wet conditions.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Thin or absent waxy cuticle\xe2\x97\x8f Stomata often open\xe2\x97\x8f Wide, flat leaves\xe2\x97\x8f Air spaces for buoyancy

cards.term: Why do multicellular organisms require transport systems?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Large size (small surface area to volume ratio), subsequently high metabolic rates.\xe2\x97\x8f Demand for oxygen is high, so need a specialised system to ensure a strong supply to all respiring tissues.

cards.term: Summarise the different types of circulatory system.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Open= blood can diffuse out of vessels e.g. insects\xe2\x97\x8f Closed= blood confined to vessels e.g. fish, mammals\xe2\x97\x8f Single= blood passes through pump once per circuit of the body\xe2\x97\x8f Double= blood passes through heart twice per circuit of the body

cards.term: Relate the structure of arteries to their function.
cards.definition: Thick, muscular walls to handle high pressure without tearing. Elastic tissue allows recoil to prevent pressure surges. Narrow lumen to maintain pressure.

cards.term: Relate the structure of veins to their function.
cards.definition: Thin walls due to lower pressure. Require valves to ensure blood doesn\xe2\x80\x99t flow backwards. Have less muscular and elastic tissue as they don\xe2\x80\x99t have to control blood flow.

cards.term: Relate the structure of capillaries to their function.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Walls only one cell thick; short diffusion pathway.\xe2\x97\x8f Very narrow, so can permeate tissues and red blood cells can lie flat against the wall, effectively delivering oxygen to tissues.\xe2\x97\x8f Numerous and highly branched, providing a large surface area.

cards.term: Relate the structure of arterioles and venules to their function.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Branch off arteries and veins in order to feed blood into capillaries.\xe2\x97\x8f Smaller than arteries and veins so that the change in pressure is more gradual as blood passes through increasingly small vessels.
A watery substance containing glucose, amino acids, oxygen, and other nutrients. It supplies these to the cells, while also removing any waste materials.

cards.term: What types of pressure influence formation of tissue fluid?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Hydrostatic pressure= higher at arterial end of capillary than venous end.\xe2\x97\x8f Oncotic pressure= changing water potential of the capillaries as water moves out, induced by proteins in the plasma.
As blood is pumped through increasingly small vessels, hydrostatic pressure is greater than oncotic pressure, so fluid moves out of the capillaries. It then exchanges substances with the cells.

cards.term: How does tissue fluid differ from blood and lymph?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Tissue fluid is formed from blood, but does not contain red blood cells, platelets, and various other solutes usually present in blood.\xe2\x97\x8f After tissue fluid has bathed cells it becomeslymph, and therefore this contains less oxygen and nutrients and more waste products.

cards.term: Draw a diagram of the human heart, including names of chambers, vessels, and valves.
cards.definition: Describe what happens during cardiac diastole.

cards.term: The heart is relaxed. Blood enters the atria, increasing the pressure and pushing open the atrioventricular valves. This allows blood to flow into the ventricles. Pressure in the heart is lower than in the arteries, so semilunar valves remain closed.
cards.definition: Describe what happens during atrial systole.

cards.term: The atria contract, pushing any remaining blood into the ventricles.
cards.definition: Describe what happens during ventricular systole.

cards.term: The ventricles contract. The pressure increases, closing the atrioventricular valves to prevent backflow, and opening the semilunar valves. Blood flows into the arteries.
cards.definition: How do you calculate cardiac output?

cards.term: Cardiac output = heart rate x stroke volume
Why do multicellular organisms require specialised gas exchange surfaces?
cards.definition: Their smaller surface area to volume ratio means the distance that needs to be crossed is larger and substances cannot easily enter the cells as in a single-celled organism.

cards.term: How is surface area to volume ratio calculated?
cards.definition: Ratio = Surface area / Volume

cards.term: Name three features of an efficient gas exchange surface.
cards.definition: 1. Large surface area, e.g. root hair cells.2. Thin/short distance, e.g. alveoli.3. Steep concentration gradient, maintained by blood supply or ventilation, e.g. gills.

cards.term: Describe the trachea and its function in the mammalian gaseous exchange system.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Wide tube supported by C-shaped cartilage to keep the air passage open during pressure changes.\xe2\x97\x8f Lined by ciliated epithelium cells which move mucus, produced by goblet cells, towards the throat to be swallowed, preventing lung infections.\xe2\x97\x8f Carries air to the bronchi.

cards.term: Describe the bronchi and their function in the mammalian gaseous exchange system.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Like the trachea they are supported by rings of cartilage and are lined by ciliated epithelium cells and goblet cells.\xe2\x97\x8f However they are narrower and there are two of them, one for each lung.\xe2\x97\x8f Allow passage of air into the bronchioles.

cards.term: Describe the bronchioles and their function in the mammalian gaseous exchange system.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Narrower than the bronchi.\xe2\x97\x8f Do not need to be kept open by cartilage, therefore mostly have only smooth muscle and elastic fibres so that they can contract and relax easily during ventilation.\xe2\x97\x8f Allow passage of air into the alveoli.

cards.term: Describe the alveoli and their function in the mammalian gaseous exchange system.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Mini air sacs, lined with epithelium cells, site of gas exchange.\xe2\x97\x8f Walls only one cell thick, covered with a network of capillaries, 300 million in each lung, all of which facilitates gas diffusion.

cards.term: Explain the process of inspiration and the changes that occur throughout the thorax.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f External intercostal muscles contract (while internal relax), pulling the ribs up and out.\xe2\x97\x8f Diaphragm contracts and flattens.\xe2\x97\x8f Volume of the thorax increases.\xe2\x97\x8f Air pressure outside the lungs is therefore higher than the air pressure inside, so air moves in to rebalance.

cards.term: Explain the process of expiration and the changes that occur throughout the thorax.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f External intercostal muscles relax (while internal contract), bringing the ribs down and in.\xe2\x97\x8f Diaphragm relaxes and domes upwards.\xe2\x97\x8f Volume of the thorax decreases.\xe2\x97\x8f Air pressure inside the lungs is therefore higher than the air pressure outside, so air moves out to rebalance.
Used to measure lung volume. A person breathes into an airtight chamber which leaves a trace on a graph which shows the volume of the breaths.
The maximum volume of air that can be taken in or expelled from the lungs in one breath. Can be calculated from the spirometer graph by finding the maximum amplitude.
The volume of air we breathe in and out during each breath at rest. Can be calculated from the spirometer graph by finding the amplitude at rest.
The number of breaths we take per minute. Can be calculated from the spirometer graph by counting the number of peaks in one minute.

cards.term: Name and describe the two main features of a fish\xe2\x80\x99s gas transport system.
cards.definition: Gills = located within the body, supported by arches, along which are multiple projections of gill filaments, which are stacked up in piles.Lamellae = at right angles to the gill filaments, give an increased surface area. Blood and water flow across them in opposite directions (countercurrent exchange system).

cards.term: Explain the process of gas exchange in fish.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Buccal cavity volume increased to enable water to flow in, reduced to increase pressure.\xe2\x97\x8f Water is pumped over the lamellae by the operculum, oxygen diffuses into the bloodstream.\xe2\x97\x8f Waste carbon dioxide diffuses into the water and flows back out of the gills.

The process by which hydrogen ions are actively pumped out of companion cells using ATP, before diffusing down a concentration gradient, back into the cells via co-transporter proteins, whilst carrying sucrose.
The formation of hydrogen bonds between carbohydrates in the xylem vessel walls and water molecules. This contributes to the capillarity of water and transpiration pull.
One of two pathways by which water and minerals move across the root. Water moves through intercellular spaces between cellulose molecules in the cell wall.
A waterproof strip surrounding the endodermal cells of the root that blocks the apoplast pathway, forcing water through the symplast route.
The formation of hydrogen bonds between water molecules. This contributes to the capillarity of water and transpiration pull.
The model that explains the movement of water from the soil to the leaves, in a continuous stream.

The active cells of the phloem located adjacent to the sieve tube elements. They retain their nucleus and organelles, producing ATP for metabolic processes in both themselves and the sieve tube elements.
Plants that produce seeds that contain two cotyledons. They have two primary leaves.
Plant that are adapted to live and reproduce in very wet habitats, e.g. water lilies.
A living plant transport vessel responsible for the transfer of assimilates to all parts of the plant. The phloem consists of sieve tube elements and companion cells.
Small pores between adjacent sieve tube elements and companion cells that allow communication and the exchange of materials.
An apparatus used to measure water uptake from a cut shoot.
Specialised cells responsible for the uptake of water and minerals from the soil. They have long hair-like extensions known as root hairs, which are adapted as exchange surfaces.
The perforated end walls of sieve tube elements that allow plant assimilates to flow between cells unimpeded.
The main cells of the phloem. They are elongated cells laid end-to-end with sieve plates between. They contain few organelles.
The tendency of one substance to bind with another substance.
The artery that takes oxygenated blood away from the heart to the body.
A type of blood vessel that connects the arteries and capillaries. The walls of the arterioles contain large amounts of smooth muscle, some elastic fibres and some collagen.
A type of blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart to the tissues, under high pressure. The walls of the arteries contain collagen, smooth muscle and elastic fibres.
An arrhythmia that involves the rapid contraction of the atria, preventing complete ventricular filling.
The stage of the cardiac cycle in which the atria contract, pushing blood into the ventricles. The AV valves are pushed open fully and the atria are emptied of blood.
A group of cells located between the atria that slow down the wave of excitation and pass it between the ventricles, along the bundle of His.
The valves found between the atria and ventricles. They prevent the backflow of blood from the ventricles into the atria. There are two types of atrioventricular valves: bicuspid and tricuspid.
The atrioventricular valves found between the left atrium and left ventricle.
The transport medium in the mammalian circulatory system. It consists of plasma, red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets.
The loss of affinity of haemoglobin for oxygen as the partial pressure of carbon dioxide increases.
A slow resting heart rate below 60 bpm.
A collection of Purkyne fibres which run from the AVN down to the apex of the ventricles.

Microscopic blood vessels that form a large network through the tissues of the body and connect the arterioles to the venules. They are the site of exchange of substances between the blood and the tissues.
An enzyme that catalyses the reversible reaction between water and carbon dioxide to produce carbonic acid.
Tiny air sacs that serve as the primary gaseous exchange surface. They consist of a thin epithelial cell layer, collagen and elastic fibres.
The number of breaths per minute.
Divisions of the trachea that lead into the lungs. They are small tubes supported by incomplete rings of cartilage.
Many small divisions of the bronchi. They contain smooth muscle to restrict airflow to the lungs but do not have cartilage. They are lined with a thin layer of ciliated epithelial cells.
Strong, flexible connective tissue that supports the walls of the trachea and bronchi, preventing collapse. It is found in an incomplete ring shape.
Specialised cells with tiny hair-like cilia found lining the trachea that waft bacteria-containing mucus up to the back of the throat, where it is swallowed.
An adaptation for gaseous exchange in bony fish. Blood in the gill filaments and water moving over the gills flow in opposite directions, maintaining a steep oxygen concentration gradient.
Fibres of elastin that allow the alveoli to stretch as air is drawn in and recoil back to normal size, expelling air. They are also found in the trachea, bronchi and bronchioles.

A surface over which materials are exchanged from one region to another. An effective exchange surface has a large surface area, thin layers, a good blood supply, and ventilation to maintain a steep diffusion gradient.

During expiration (exhalation) the diaphragm relaxes and reverts to a dome. The external intercostal muscles relax, moving the ribs down and in. The volume of the thorax decreases and thoracic pressure exceeds air pressure. Air moves out of the trachea.
The main site of gaseous exchange in fish, over which water flows. They are found in large stacks, known as gill plates, and have gill lamellae which provide a large surface area for exchange.
The fine branches of the gill filaments. They are adapted for gaseous exchange by having a large surface area and good blood supply.
Large stacks of gill filaments.
The organs of gaseous exchange in fish. They are contained in a gill cavity and are made up of gill lamellae, gill filaments and gill plates.
Specialised cells that secrete mucus onto the trachea lining. The mucus traps harmful substances and microorganisms, preventing their entry into the lungs.
The process of naming and organising organisms into groups based on their characteristics.

cards.term: Name the eight groups an organism can be classified into, from largest to smallest.
cards.definition: Domain \xe2\x86\x92 kingdom \xe2\x86\x92 phylum \xe2\x86\x92 class \xe2\x86\x92 order \xe2\x86\x92 family \xe2\x86\x92 genus \xe2\x86\x92 species

cards.term: What are the two components to a binomial name?
cards.definition: Generic name = the genus the organism belongs to. Two closely related species will share the same genus.Specific name = the species the organism belongs to.

cards.term: What is the advantage of the binomial naming system?
cards.definition: It is universal; an organism\xe2\x80\x99s binomial name is the same everywhere in the world.

cards.term: Name the five kingdoms and three domains.
cards.definition: Kingdoms = Prokaryote, Protoctista, Fungi, Plantae, AnimaliaDomains = Bacteria, Archaea, Eukaryota

cards.term: How are organisms classified into a kingdom?
cards.definition: Based on similarities in observable characteristics.

cards.term: How was the domain system of classification developed?
cards.definition: By analysing molecular differences between organisms to determine their evolutionary relationships (phylogeny).

cards.term: What is the difference between classification and phylogeny?
cards.definition: Classification is simply sorting organisms into groups. Phylogeny investigates the evolutionary relationships between organisms.

cards.term: Explain how natural selection results in evolution.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Random mutations result in new alleles.\xe2\x97\x8f Some alleles provide an advantage against selection pressures, making an individual more likely to survive and reproduce.\xe2\x97\x8f Their offspring receive the new allele, and are said to have \xe2\x80\x98evolved\xe2\x80\x99 a new characteristic.

cards.term: How did Darwin and Wallace contribute to the theory of evolution?
cards.definition: Observed that birds have many different beak shapes. Concluded that birds with beak shapes most suited to the food they eat are more likely to survive and therefore pass this beak shape onto their offspring.

cards.term: Give other evidence for the theory of evolution.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Fossils= allows us to compare extinct organisms to today\xe2\x80\x99s organisms.\xe2\x97\x8f Genomic DNA= sequencing of genomes have shown how closely related we are to primates.\xe2\x97\x8f Molecular= proteins are composed of the same 20 amino acids in all organisms.
\xe2\x97\x8f Genetic= mutations, random fertilisation, etc.\xe2\x97\x8f Environmental= climate, diet, culture, etc.

cards.term: Differentiate between intraspecific and interspecific variation.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Intraspecific= variation within the same species.\xe2\x97\x8f Interspecific= variation between different species.

cards.term: Differentiate between continuous and discontinuous variation.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Continuous= variation exists as gradual changes over a range e.g. height, root length.\xe2\x97\x8f Discontinuous= variation exists as distinct categories e.g. blood group, bacteria shape.

cards.term: Why might we calculate a Spearman\xe2\x80\x99s rank correlation coefficient?
cards.definition: To measure correlation between two variables, i.e. the extent to which changing one variable affects the other variable.

The variety of living organisms. It can be measured in terms of species diversity (number of species in a community), habitat diversity (range of different habitats) and genetic diversity (variety of alleles within a species).

cards.term: Differentiate between species richness and species evenness.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Species richness= the number of species in an area.\xe2\x97\x8f Species evenness= whether species have similar numbers.

\xe2\x97\x8f Random= no particular system, however aim is still to be representative.\xe2\x97\x8f Opportunistic= those that are encountered first are chosen.\xe2\x97\x8f Stratified= population divided into smaller groups based on a characteristic, then sampled.\xe2\x97\x8f Systematic= follows a particular pattern.
We cannot study the whole population as it is impractical. Using a representative sample instead allows us to investigate the population easily.

cards.term: Describe how Simpson\xe2\x80\x99s Index of Diversity is used.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f A measurement of the total number of organisms compared to the total number of organisms of each species.\xe2\x97\x8f A high index of diversity means several different species are equally abundant, whereas a low index means one or two species dominate over others.

cards.term: How can we assess genetic diversity?
cards.definition: Proportion of polymorphic gene loci = number of polymorphic gene loci / total number of loci
\xe2\x97\x8f Population growth\xe2\x97\x8f Deforestation for agriculture\xe2\x97\x8f Climate change affecting habitats
\xe2\x97\x8f Ecological= protecting species, maintaining resources.\xe2\x97\x8f Economic= reducing soil depletion.\xe2\x97\x8f Aesthetic= protecting landscapes.
The protection and management of species and habitats, in order to maintain biodiversity. Can be in-situ (in an organism\xe2\x80\x99s habitat) or ex-situ (outside an organism\xe2\x80\x99s habitat).
\xe2\x97\x8f Marine conservation zones\xe2\x97\x8f Wildlife reserves
\xe2\x97\x8f Seed banks\xe2\x97\x8f Botanic gardens\xe2\x97\x8f Zoos

cards.term: Give some agreements made with the aim of protecting species and habitats.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES).\xe2\x97\x8f Rio Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD).\xe2\x97\x8f Countryside Stewardship Scheme (CSS).

cards.term: Name 4 groups of pathogens that can cause communicable diseases.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f bacteria\xe2\x97\x8f fungi\xe2\x97\x8f protoctista\xe2\x97\x8f viruses

cards.term: How does Mycobacterium tuberculosis cause disease?
cards.definition: 1. Triggers inflammatory response by infecting phagocytesin lungs.2. Infected phagocytes are sealed in waxy-coated tubercles so bacteria remain dormant. First infection has no symptoms.3. If another factor weakens immune system, bacteria become active & destroy lung tissue.

cards.term: How does HIV result in the symptoms of AIDS?
cards.definition: 1. Attachment proteins bind to complementary CD4 receptor on TH cells.2. HIV particles replicate inside TH cells, killing or damagingthem.3. AIDS develops when there are too few TH cells for the immune system to function.4. Individuals cannot destroy other pathogens & suffer from secondary diseases/ infections. May cause death.

cards.term: How does the tobacco mosaic virus cause disease?
cards.definition: Affects plants. Mainly transmitted via infected sap.Contains ssRNA, which is directly transcribed by host cell to assemble new virions.Virions enter other cells via plasmodesmata then enter xylem & phloem.Causes stunted growth & mottled leaves.

cards.term: How does the influenza virus cause disease?
cards.definition: Transmitted via: droplet infection, contact with mucus containing virus, zoonotic infection, contact with fomites.Injects viral RNA into ciliated epithelial cells of throat & lungs. Viral RNA hijacks cell biochemistry to produce new virions. Cell lysis releases virions.5-7 days of headache, coughing, sneezing, sore throat, vomiting, fever, muscular/joint pain.

Female Anopheles mosquito acts as vector for Plasmodium spp. protoctista when it transfers saliva to another organism during feeding.Parasite reproduces asexually in red blood cells in liver, causing lysis.

cards.term: What causes potato/ tomato late blight? What causes ring rot of potatoes?
cards.definition: Blight: The protoctista Phytophthora infestans behaves similarly to a fungus. Mainly transmitted via spores.Ring rot: Sepedonicus subspecies of the bacterium Clavibacter michiganensis. Mainly transmitted by planting infected seeds/ contact with fomites.Plant-to-plant transmission is rare.

Often meningococcal bacteria A, B, C, W, X, Y, Z. Also caused by pneumococcal bacteria & Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria. Affects meninges (protective membranes around brain).Transmitted by droplet infection & direct contact with salivae.g. kissing. Usually spread by carriers of the bacteria who are not ill & occasionally by individuals with meningitis.

The sac fungus Mycosphaerella fijiensislack causes the leaf-spot disease black sigatoka in banana plants.About 40 types of fungi cause ringworm. Transmitted by contact with fomites, zoonotic infection, direct contact with infected individuals. Particularly affects cattle.Athlete\xe2\x80\x99s foot in humans (tinea pedis) is caused by a range of fungi which can also affect hands or nails.

cards.term: How are communicable pathogens transmitted directly?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Inhalation (droplet infection).\xe2\x97\x8f Skin-to-skin contact or exchange of fluids.\xe2\x97\x8f Penetrate skin actively using enzymes or passively through wounds, hair follicles or sweat glands.

cards.term: How are communicable pathogens transmitted indirectly?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Consumption of contaminated food & drink.\xe2\x97\x8f Via a vector e.g. mosquitoes transmit Plasmodium parasite.\xe2\x97\x8f Spores.

cards.term: How do living conditions affect disease transmission?
cards.definition: Overcrowding increases direct transmission.Climate determines which organisms can survive e.g. malaria is more prevalent in tropical countries, where mosquitoes (the vector) can breed.Social factors influence how quickly people are treated, which can increase/ decrease direct transmission.

cards.term: Name 4 physical barriers to pathogen entry in plants.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f cellulose cell walls\xe2\x97\x8f lignified layer\xe2\x97\x8f waxy upper cuticle\xe2\x97\x8f old vascular tissue is blocked to prevent pathogens from spreading inside the plant

cards.term: Describe 2 mechanical responses to infection in plants.
cards.definition: Guard cells close stomata.The thick polysaccharide callose is produced & deposited between the cell wall & plasma membrane to increase entry distance/ limit spread.
Injury activates intracellular enzymes in plants that kill cells near the site of infection to prevent pathogen from spreading.Necrosis of woody tissue is known as canker.
A feature of an organism that increases its chance of survival in its environment. An adaptation may be anatomical, physiological or behavioural.
A line along a sampled area upon which quadrats are placed at intervals to determine the abundance and distribution of organisms in an ecosystem.
The universal system of naming organisms. It is made up of two parts; the first gives the genus and the second, the species e.g. Homo sapiens.
The variety of living organisms in an ecosystem.
The scientist who developed the theory of evolution by natural selection.
The organisation of organisms into groups.
All of the populations of different species living together in a habitat.
The maintenance of ecosystems and biodiversity by humans in order to preserve the Earth\xe2\x80\x99s resources.
When a characteristic can have any value within a given range e.g. height, mass, heart rate.
A treaty that promotes the sustainable use of and maintenance of biodiversity. One of three Rio Conventions.

cards.term: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES)
cards.definition: A treaty that regulates the trade of plants and wild animals across international borders.
The process by which unrelated species evolve similar traits due to exposure to similar environments or selection pressures.
A scheme in England (1991-2014) that aimed to provide financial incentives to farmers to enhance and conserve the environment. Replaced by the Environmental Stewardship Scheme (ESS).
When a characteristic can only take certain values e.g. sex, eye colour, blood group.
The highest taxonomic rank. There are three domains; Archaea, Bacteria and Eukaryota.
Specialised white blood cells that engulf and destroy pathogens. There are two types: neutrophils and macrophages.
The process by which phagocytes engulf and destroy pathogens.
A vesicle within a phagocyte formed by the fusion of a phagosome and lysosome.
The vacuole inside a phagocyte in which a foreign particle is engulfed.
B lymphocytes that produce antibodies specific to a particular antigen.

A disease caused by the fungi-like protoctist Phytophthora infestans whose hyphae penetrate host cells, causing the collapse and decay of the leaves, fruit and tubers. Also known as tomato blight or late blight.
The response of the immune system to a pathogen when it is first encountered. A small number of antibodies are produced slowly.
A group of eukaryotic, single-celled microorganisms that may cause disease. They digest cells and use the cell contents to reproduce.
A bacterial disease in tomatoes, potatoes and aubergines that results in damage to the leaves, fruit and tubers. It is caused by the Clavibacter michiganensis bacterium.
A fungal disease that affects mammals, causing grey-white, circular, crusty lesions on the skin.

cards.term: A fungal disease that affects mammals, causing grey-white, circular, crusty lesions on the skin.
cards.definition: The response of the immune system to a pathogen when it is encountered for a second (third, fourth\xe2\x80\xa6etc.) time. Immunological memory gives a rapid production of a large number of antibodies.
The design and construction of new biological entities, as well as the reconstruction of pre-existing natural biological systems.
T lymphocytes with CD4 receptors on the cell surface membrane. These bind to antigens on antigen-presenting cells and secrete interleukins.
T lymphocytes that produce perforin, destroying pathogens with a specific antigen.
Lymphocytes that mature in the thymus gland. There are four main types: T helper cells, T killer cells, T memory cells and T regulatory cells.
Resistance in an organism that has developed through the production of specific antibodies in response to a pathogen. It provides long-lasting immunity as memory cells are produced.
Chemicals that cause pathogens to aggregate together, aiding phagocytosis. Antibodies can act as agglutinins.
A chemical or compound produced by a living organism that kills or prevents the growth of bacteria.
Bacteria that mutate to become resistant to an antibiotic, survive and reproduce very rapidly, passing on their antibiotic resistance.
Immunoglobulins produced by B-lymphocytes in response to a specific antigen, triggering an immune response.
A chemical present on the surface of a cell that induces an immune response.
A macrophage that displays foreign antigens.
Chemicals produced by white blood cells that neutralise toxins released by pathogens.
The production of antibodies by the immune system following the exposure to a weakened, attenuated or dead pathogen, e.g: by vaccination.
The immunity acquired from the administration of specific antibodies from another organism, e.g: by vaccination.
A form of ringworm in humans that affects the feet, resulting in cracking and scaling of the skin.
A condition in which the immune system attacks and destroys healthy body tissue, e.g: arthritis, lupus.
Prokaryotic cells that have cell walls but lack organelles. Some bacteria are pathogenic, producing toxins that damage host cells.

A severe form of meningitis caused by bacterial infection of the meninges. Complications of bacterial meningitis include septicaemia; a symptom of this is a rash of purple discolouration that does not fade when a glass is pressed against it.
A type of B lymphocyte that divides to form plasma cells.

cards.term: Why do organisms need to respire?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Produces ATP as energy currency for:a) active transport against concentration gradients e.g. to absorb nutrients from small intestine/soil.b) metabolic reactions e.g. to form peptide bonds in protein synthesis.c) muscle contraction.\xe2\x97\x8f Releases heat energy for thermoregulation.

cards.term: Describe the structure of a mitochondrion.
cards.definition: Surrounded by double membrane.Folded inner membrane forms cristae: site of electron transport chain.Fluid matrix: contains mitochondrial DNA, respiratory enzymes, lipids, proteins.

cards.term: Name the 4 main stages in aerobic respiration and where they occur.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Glycolysis: cytoplasm.\xe2\x97\x8f Link reaction: mitochondrial matrix.\xe2\x97\x8f Krebs cycle: mitochondrial matrix.\xe2\x97\x8f Oxidative phosphorylation via electron transfer chain: membrane of cristae.

1. Glucose is phosphorylated to hexose bisphosphate by 2x ATP.2. Hexose bisphosphate splits into 2x triose phosphate (TP).3. 2x TP is oxidised to 2x pyruvate.Net gain of 2x reduced NAD & 2x ATP per glucose.

cards.term: Draw a flowchart to represent what happens during glycolysis.
cards.definition: How does pyruvate from glycolysis enter the mitochondria?
What happens during the link reaction?

cards.term: 1. Oxidation of pyruvate to acetate. per pyruvate molecule: net gain of 1xCO2 (decarboxylation) & 2H atoms (used to reduce 1xNAD).2. Acetate combines with coenzyme A (CoA) to form Acetylcoenzyme A.
cards.definition: Give a summary equation for the link reaction.

cards.term: pyruvate + NAD + CoA \xe2\x86\x92 Acetyl CoA + reduced NAD + CO2
cards.definition: What happens in the Krebs cycle?

cards.term: Series of redox reactions produces:\xe2\x97\x8f ATP by substrate-level phosphorylation\xe2\x97\x8f reduced coenzymes\xe2\x97\x8f CO2 from decarboxylationBegins when acetyl group from Acetyl CoA (2C) reacts with oxaloacetate (4C). Cycle regenerates oxaloacetate.
cards.definition: Outline the stages of the Krebs cycle.

cards.term: Names of the circled compounds:4C: oxaloacetate 6C: citrate
cards.definition: What is the electron transfer chain (ETC)?

cards.term: Series of carrier proteins embedded in membrane of the cristae of mitochondria.Produces ATP through oxidative phosphorylation via chemiosmosis during aerobic respiration.
cards.definition: What happens in the electron transfer chain (ETC)?

cards.term: Electrons released from reduced NAD & FAD undergo successive redox reactions.The energy released is coupled to maintaining proton gradient or released as heat.Oxygen acts as final electron acceptor.
cards.definition: How does chemiosmosis produce ATP during aerobic respiration?

cards.term: Some energy released from the ETC is coupled to activetransport of H+ ions (protons) from mitochondrial matrix into intermembrane space.H+ ions move down concentration gradient into mitochondrial matrix via channel protein ATP synthase.ATP synthase catalyses ADP + Pi \xe2\x86\x92 ATP
cards.definition: State the role of oxygen in aerobic respiration.

cards.term: Final electron acceptor in electron transfer chain. (produces water as a byproduct)
cards.definition: Name the stages in respiration that produce ATP by substrate-level phosphorylation.

cards.term: How are photosynthesis and respiration related?
cards.definition: CO2 & H2O are the raw materials for photosynthesis and the products of respiration.O2 & glucose are the raw materials for photosynthesis and the products of respiration.

cards.term: Describe the structure of a chloroplast.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Usually disc-shaped.\xe2\x97\x8f Double membrane (envelope).\xe2\x97\x8f Thylakoids: flattened discs stack to form grana.\xe2\x97\x8f Intergranal lamellae: tubular extensions attach thylakoids in adjacent grana.\xe2\x97\x8f Stroma: fluid-filled matrix with high enzyme & substrate concentration & own loop of DNA.

cards.term: Where do the light-dependent & light-independent reactions occur in plants?
cards.definition: Light-dependent: in the thylakoids of chloroplasts.Light-independent: stroma of chloroplasts.

cards.term: What is the role of photosynthetic pigments? Name the 2 main groups.
cards.definition: Embedded within thylakoid membrane. Absorb different wavelengths of light to maximise rate of photosynthesis.\xe2\x97\x8f Primary pigment: chlorophyll (made of chlorophyll a & chlorophyll b) found in photosystems.\xe2\x97\x8f Accessory pigments: carotenoids (carotene & xanthophylls) found in light-harvesting systems.

cards.term: Name the processes in the light-dependent reaction.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f photoionisation\xe2\x97\x8f electron transfer chain\xe2\x97\x8f chemiosmosisnon-cyclic only:\xe2\x97\x8f reduction of NADP\xe2\x97\x8f photolysis of water

cards.term: Explain the role of light in photoionisation.
cards.definition: Chlorophyll molecules absorb energy from photons of light.This \xe2\x80\x98excites\xe2\x80\x99 2 electrons (raises them to a higher energy level), causing them to be released from the chlorophyll.

cards.term: What happens in the electron transfer chain (ETC)?
cards.definition: Electrons released from chlorophyll move down a series of carrier proteins embedded in the thylakoid membrane & undergo a series of redox reactions, which releases energy.

cards.term: How does chemiosmosis produce ATP in the light-dependent stage?
cards.definition: Some energy released from the ETC is coupled to active transport of H+ ions from stroma into thylakoid space.H+ ions move down concentration gradient from thylakoid space into stroma via transmembrane channel protein ATP synthase.ATP synthase catalyses ADP + Pi \xe2\x86\x92 ATP

Uses Photosystems \xe2\x85\xa0 & \xe2\x85\xa1. Excited electrons enter ETC to produce ATP. NADP acts as final electron acceptor & is reduced. Water is photolysed to release electrons to replace those lost from PS \xe2\x85\xa1.Purpose is to produce ATP & reduced NADP for Calvin cycle to produce biological compounds.

Uses only Photosystem \xe2\x85\xa0. Excited electrons enter ETC to produce ATP then return directly to photosystem (so no reduction of NADP & no water needed to replace lost electrons).Purpose is to produce additional ATP to meet surplus energy demands of cell.

cards.term: What happens in photolysis of water?
cards.definition: Light energy splits molecules of water 2H2O \xe2\x86\x92 4H+ + 4e- + O2

cards.term: What happens to the products of the photolysis of water?
cards.definition: H+ ions: move out of thylakoid space via ATP synthase & are used to reduce the coenzyme NADP.e-: replace electrons lost from chlorophyll.O2: used for respiration or diffuses out of leaf as waste gas.

cards.term: How and where is reduced NADP produced in the light-dependent reaction?
cards.definition: NADP + 2H+ (from photolysis of water) + 2e- (from acting as final electron acceptor in ETC) \xe2\x86\x92 reduced NADP.Catalysed by dehydrogenase enzymes. Stroma of chloroplasts.

cards.term: Name the 3 main stages in the light-independent reaction.
cards.definition: 1. Carbon fixation2. Reduction3. Regeneration
Reaction between CO2 & ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP) catalysed by ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase (RuBisCo).Forms unstable 6C intermediate that breaks down into 2 x glycerate 3-phosphate (GP).
Non-living environmental factor that could harm a plant e.g. mineral deficiency, drought, depleted oxygen supply, pollution.

cards.term: How do plants respond to abiotic stress and herbivory?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f May produce antifreeze enzymes.\xe2\x97\x8f May contain bitter-tasting tannins.\xe2\x97\x8f May contain bitter-tasting nitrogen compounds called alkaloids.\xe2\x97\x8f Release cell-signalling pheromones to trigger defensive responses in other organisms.

cards.term: How does Mimosa pudica respond to being touched?
cards.definition: Seismonasty (touch sensitivity) causes leaves to fold.

directional growth response of plants\xe2\x97\x8f phototropism: response to light\xe2\x97\x8f geotropism: response to gravity\xe2\x97\x8f hydrotropism: response to water\xe2\x97\x8f thermotropism: response to temperature\xe2\x97\x8f thigmotropism: response to touching a surface or object

cards.term: How is leaf loss (leaf abscission) in deciduous plants controlled?
cards.definition: 1. As leaf ages, cytokinin & auxin levels lower, ethene level increases.2. Triggers production of cellulase enzymes, which weaken leaves by breaking down cell walls in abscission layer.3. Leaves break from branch. Below abscission layer, suberin layer forms to prevent entry of pathogens.
Stimulate:\xe2\x97\x8f germination\xe2\x97\x8f elongation at cell internodes\xe2\x97\x8f fruit growth\xe2\x97\x8f rapid growth/ flowering

1. Seed absorbs water, activating embryo to secrete gibberellins.2. Gibberellins diffuse to aleurone layer, which produces amylase.3. Amylase diffuses to endosperm layer to hydrolyse starch.4. Hexose sugars act as respiratory substrate to produce ATP as \xe2\x80\x98energy currency\xe2\x80\x99.

\xe2\x97\x8f Involved in trophic responses e.g. IAA.\xe2\x97\x8f Control cell elongation.\xe2\x97\x8f Suppress lateral buds to maintain apical dominance.\xe2\x97\x8f Promote root growth e.g. in rooting powders.

cards.term: Explain why shoots show positive phototropism.
cards.definition: 1. Indoleacetic acid (IAA) diffuses to shaded side of shoot tip.2. As IAA diffuses down shaded side, it causes active transport of H+ ions into cell wall.3. Disruption to H-bonds between cellulose molecules & action of expansins make cell more permeable to water. (acid growth hypothesis)4. Cells on shaded side elongate faster due to higher turgor pressure.5. Shoot bends towards light.

cards.term: Explain why roots show positive gravitropism.
cards.definition: 1. Gravity causes IAA to accumulate on lower side of the root.2. IAA inhibits elongation of root cells.3. Cells on the upper side of the root elongate faster, so the root tip bends downwards.

cards.term: How do hormones stimulate stomata to close?
cards.definition: 1. Abscisic acid binds to complementary receptors on guard cell membrane, causing Ca2+ ion channels on tonoplast to open. Ca2+ ions diffuse from vacuole into cytosol.2. Positive feedback triggers other ion channels to open. Other ions e.g. K+ diffuse out of guard cell.3. Water potential of guard cell becomes more positive. Water diffuses out via osmosis.4. Guard cells become flaccid so stomata close.
Phenomenon where during the growth of the shoot, the growth of side shoots does not take place. Maintained by the action of auxin, abscisic acid & cytokinins.

cards.term: Explain the experimental evidence that auxins maintain apical dominance.
cards.definition: Auxin production in apex maintains high levels of abscisic acid. Inhibits growth of side shoots.When apex is removed:a) Auxin levels drop, causing abscisic acid levels to drop.b) Cytokinins (initially concentrated near auxin reserve in bud) diffuse evenly to promote bud growth in other parts of plant= lateral buds.

cards.term: Explain the experimental evidence that gibberellins control stem elongation and germination.
cards.definition: Stem elongation: Tall plants have higher gibberellin concentration than dwarf plants.Germination: Mutant seeds with non-functional gibberellin gene do not germinate unless gibberellin is applied externally. Inhibitors of gibberellin production prevent germination.

cards.term: How are auxins and cytokinins used commercially?
cards.definition: Auxins: rooting powder, growing seedless fruit, herbicides, low concentrations prevent leaf & fruit growth, high concentrations promote fruit drop.Cytokinins: prevent yellowing of lettuce leaves, promotes shoot growth.

Specialised glands secrete hormones into bloodstream.Circulatory system carries hormone to target cell/ tissue.Lipid-soluble steroid hormones diffuse into cell & bind to complementary receptor in cytoplasm. Peptide hormones bind to complementary receptor on cell-surface membrane.

cards.term: Describe the structure of the adrenal glands.
cards.definition: Located above kidneys.

cards.term: What hormone does the medulla secrete?
cards.definition: Adrenaline in response to danger, stress or excitement as part of the fight or flight response.

cards.term: Which hormones does the cortex secrete?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Mineralocorticoids e.g. aldosterone, which targets kidney & gut to control concentration of Na+ & K+ ions in blood.\xe2\x97\x8f Glucocorticoids e.g. cortisol & corticosterone, which stimulate an increase in blood glucose concentration.

cards.term: Describe the histology of the pancreas.
cards.definition: Why is it important that blood glucose concentration remains stable?

cards.term: \xe2\x97\x8f Maintain constant blood water potential: prevent osmotic lysis/ crenation of cells.\xe2\x97\x8f Maintain constant concentration of respiratory substrate: organism maintains constant level of activity regardless of environmental conditions.
cards.definition: Define negative feedback.

cards.term: Self-regulatory mechanisms return internal environment to optimum when there is a fluctuation.Different mechanisms are responsible for dealing with an increase/ decrease in normal level for greater control.
cards.definition: Define glycogenesis, glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

cards.term: Glycogenesis: liver converts glucose into the storage polymer glycogen.Glycogenolysis: liver hydrolyses glycogen into glucose which can diffuse into blood.Gluconeogenesis: liver converts glycerol & amino acids into glucose.
cards.definition: Outline the role of glucagon when blood glucose concentration decreases.

cards.term: 1. \xf0\x9d\x9e\xaa cells in Islets of Langerhans in pancreas detect decrease & secrete glucagon into bloodstream.2. Glucagon binds to surface receptors on liver cells & activates enzymes for glycogenolysis & gluconeogenesis.3. Glucose diffuses from liver into bloodstream.4. \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbc cells detect that blood glucose concentration has returned to optimum & stop producing glucagon. (negative feedback).
cards.definition: Use the secondary messenger model to explain how glucagon works.

cards.term: 1. Hormone-receptor complex forms.2. Conformational change to receptor activates G-protein.3. Activates adenylate cyclase, which converts ATP tocyclic AMP (cAMP).4. cAMP activates protein kinase A pathway.5. Results in glycogenolysis.
cards.definition: Outline what happens when blood glucose concentration increases.

cards.term: 1. \xf0\x9d\x9d\xb1 cells in Islets of Langerhans in pancreas detect increase & secrete insulin into bloodstream.2. Insulin binds to surface receptors on target cells to:a. increase cellular glucose uptake.b. activate enzymes for glycogenesis (liver & muscles).c. stimulate adipose tissue to synthesise fat.
cards.definition: Describe how insulin leads to a decrease in blood glucose concentration.

cards.term: \xe2\x97\x8f Increases permeability of cells to glucose.\xe2\x97\x8f Increases glucose concentration gradient.\xe2\x97\x8f Triggers inhibition of enzymes for glycogenolysis.
cards.definition: How is insulin secretion controlled?

cards.term: 1. \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbd cells have K+ & Ca2+ ion channels to maintain p.d. -70mV.2. As glucose concentration increases, glucose enters \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbd cells via facilitated diffusion.3. Respiration of glucose produces ATP. ATP-gated K+ ion channels close, so K+ ions no longer diffuse out of cell.4. P.d. in cell becomes more positive = depolarisation. Ca2+ ion channels open. Ca2+ triggers exocytosis of insulin.
cards.definition: Describe the exocrine function of the pancreas.

cards.term: Secretes digestive enzymes e.g. amylase, trypsin & lipase to the duodenum via the pancreatic tract.
cards.definition: Explain the causes of Type 1 diabetes mellitus and how it can be controlled.

cards.term: Body cannot produce insulin e.g. due to autoimmune response which attacks \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbd cells of Islets of LangerhansTreat by injecting insulin from animal source or genetically modified bacteria. Possible future treatment: use stem cells to produce new \xf0\x9d\x9b\xbd cells.
What features are common to all sensory receptors?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Act as energy transducers which establish a generator potential.\xe2\x97\x8f Respond to specific stimuli.

cards.term: Describe the basic structure of a Pacinian corpuscle.
cards.definition: Single nerve fibre surrounded by layers of connective tissue which are separated by viscous gel and contained by a capsule.Stretch-mediated Na+ channels on plasma membrane.Capillary runs along base layer of tissue.

cards.term: What stimulus does a Pacinian corpuscle respond to? How?
cards.definition: 1. Pressure deforms membrane, causing stretch-mediated Na+ ion channels to open.2. If influx of Na+ raises membrane to threshold potential, a generator potential is produced.3. Action potential moves along sensory neurone.

cards.term: Describe the features of all neurones.
cards.definition: Cell body: contains organelles & high proportion of RER.Dendrons: branch into dendrites which carry impulses towards the cell body.Axon: long, unbranched fibre carries nerve impulses away from cell body.

cards.term: Describe the structure and function of a sensory neurone.
cards.definition: Usually unipolar.Transmits impulses from receptors to CNS.

cards.term: Describe the structure and function of a relay neurone.
cards.definition: Usually bipolar.Transmits impulses between neurones.

cards.term: Describe the structure and function of a motor neurone.
cards.definition: Usually multipolar.Transmits impulses from relay neurones in the CNS to effectors.

cards.term: Describe the additional features of a myelinated neurone.
cards.definition: Schwann cells: wrap around axon many times.Myelin sheath: made from myelin-rich membranes of Schwann cells.Nodes of Ranvier: very short gaps between neighbouring Schwann cells where there is no myelin sheath.

cards.term: Name 3 processes Schwann cells are involved in.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f electrical insulation\xe2\x97\x8f phagocytosis\xe2\x97\x8f nerve regeneration

cards.term: Explain why myelinated axons conduct impulses faster than unmyelinated axons.
cards.definition: Saltatory conduction: Impulse \xe2\x80\x98jumps\xe2\x80\x99 from one node of Ranvier to another. Depolarisation cannot occur where myelin sheath acts as electrical insulator.So impulse does not travel along whole axon length.

cards.term: Where are myelinated and non-myelinated neurones found in the body?
cards.definition: Myelinated: most neurones in central & peripheral nervous systems e.g. those involved in spinal reflex.Non-myelinated: group C nerve fibres involved in transmitting secondary pain.
Potential difference (voltage) across neurone membrane when not stimulated (-50 to -90 mV, usually about -70 mV in humans).

1. Membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+.2. Sodium-potassium pump actively transports 3Na+ out of cell & 2K+ into cell.establishes electrochemical gradient: cell contents more negative than extracellular environment.

cards.term: Name the stages in generating an action potential.
cards.definition: 1. Depolarisation2. Repolarisation3. Hyperpolarisation4. Return to resting potential

1. Stimulus \xe2\x86\x92 facilitated diffusion of Na+ into cell down electrochemical gradient.2. p.d. across membrane becomes more positive.3. If membrane reaches threshold potential (-50mV), voltage-gated Na+ channels open. (positive feedback mechanism).4. Significant influx of Na+ ions reverses p.d. to +40mV.
Process of removing metabolic wastes e.g. carbon dioxide & nitrogen-based byproducts to maintain metabolism.Enables organisms to maintain pH balance & regulate osmotic pressure.

cards.term: Describe the gross structure of the mammalian liver.
cards.definition: Liver lobules (cylinders of hepatocytes arranged in rows & connected at the centre) are connected to:hepatic vein takes deoxygenated blood away from the liver & is attached to \xe2\x86\x92 hepatic portal vein: contains products of digestion & hepatic artery: supplies oxygenated blood via Sinusoid capillaries.And bile duct: transports bile to gall bladder for storage.

cards.term: Describe the histology of the mammalian liver.
cards.definition: Outline the functions of the mammalian liver.

cards.term: \xe2\x97\x8f Site of gluconeogenesis, glycolysis, glycogenesis.\xe2\x97\x8f Stores glycogen.\xe2\x97\x8f Deaminates excess amino acids, forming ammonia & organic acids. Acids can be respired or converted into glycogen. Ammonia is detoxified by addition of CO2 in ornithine cycle.\xe2\x97\x8f Detoxifies chemicals e.g. converts alcohol to ethanal then acetic acid.
cards.definition: Describe the gross structure of the mammalian urinary system.

cards.term: A: kidneyB: renal vein C: renal arteryD: ureter E: urethra F: bladder
cards.definition: Describe the gross structure of a mammalian kidney.

cards.term: Fibrous capsule: protects kidney.Cortex: outer region consists of Bowman\xe2\x80\x99s capsules, convoluted tubules, blood vessels.Medulla: inner region consists of collecting ducts, loops of Henle, blood vessels.
cards.definition: Describe the structure of a nephron.

cards.term: A: glomerulusB: Bowman\xe2\x80\x99s capsuleC: proximal convoluted tubule D: collecting ductE: afferent arteriole F: efferent arteriole G: loop of HenleH: distal convoluted tubule
cards.definition: Describe the blood vessels associated with a nephron.

cards.term: Wide afferent arteriole from renal artery enters renal capsule & forms glomerulus: branched knot of capillaries which combine to form narrow efferent arteriole.Efferent arteriole branches to form capillary networkthat surrounds tubules.
cards.definition: Describe the histology of the kidney.
Describe the sections of a nephron.

cards.term: Bowman\xe2\x80\x99s capsule at start of nephron: cup-shaped, surrounds glomerulus, inner layer of podocytes.Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): series of loops surrounded by capillaries, walls made of epithelial cells with microvilli.Loop of Henle: hairpin loop extends from cortex into medulla. Distal convoluted tubule : similar to PCT but fewer capillaries. Collecting duct: DCT from several nephrons empty into collecting duct, which leads into pelvis of kidney.
cards.definition: Describe the process of ultrafiltration.

cards.term: Occurs in Bowman\xe2\x80\x99s capsule.High hydrostatic pressure in glomerulus forces small molecules (urea, water, glucose, mineral ions) out of capillary fenestrations AGAINST osmotic gradient.Basement membrane acts as filter. Blood cells & large molecules e.g. proteins remain in capillary.
cards.definition: How are cells of the Bowman\xe2\x80\x99s capsule adapted for ultrafiltration?

cards.term: \xe2\x97\x8f Fenestrations between epithelial cells of capillaries.\xe2\x97\x8f Fluid can pass between & under folded membrane of podocytes.
cards.definition: State what happens during selective reabsorption and where it occurs.

cards.term: Useful molecules from glomerular filtrate e.g. glucose are reabsorbed into the blood.Occurs in proximal convoluted tubule.
cards.definition: Outline the transport processes involved in selective reabsorption.

cards.term: How does the kidney produce urine?
cards.definition: After selective reabsorption, filtrate passes through Loop of Henle, which acts as countercurrent multiplier & then through distal convoluted tubule, where water & mineral ions are reabsorbed.More water is reabsorbed in collecting duct. Remaining fluid (urine) contains only waste materials & water.

cards.term: Why do multicellular organisms need communication systems?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f To respond when their internal & external environment changes.\xe2\x97\x8f To coordinate organ function.

Communication between cells: electrical signals carried by neurones or chemical signals as hormones.\xe2\x97\x8f Long-distance endocrine signalling.\xe2\x97\x8f Paracrine signalling between adjacent cells occurs directly or aided by extracellular fluid.\xe2\x97\x8f In autocrine signalling, cell releases signals to stimulate its own receptors & triggers a response within itself.
Internal environment is maintained within set limits around an optimum.

Negative feedback: self-regulatory mechanisms return internal environment to optimum when there is a fluctuation.Positive feedback: a fluctuation triggers changes that results in an even greater deviation from the normal level.
Receptors: specialised cells located in sense organs that detect a specificstimulus.Effectors: usually muscles or glands which enable a physical response to a stimulus.

Organism that cannot increase its respiration rate to increase the internal production of heat.Relies on external sources to regulate its body temperature. Responds to temperature changes behaviourally e.g. may orient body to minimise/ maximise sun exposure.
Organism that can regulate its body temperature independently of external sources. Thermoreceptors send signals to the hypothalamus, which triggers a physiological or behavioural response.

cards.term: Outline behavioural methods endotherms use to regulate their body temperature.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f basking in the sun\xe2\x97\x8f pressing against warm surfaces\xe2\x97\x8f digging burrows\xe2\x97\x8f hibernation/ aestivation\xe2\x97\x8f panting (heat lost as water evaporates from mouth)

cards.term: How does the autonomic nervous system enable endotherms to thermoregulate?
cards.definition: Negative feedback. Peripheral thermoreceptors detect changes in skin temperature. Thermoreceptors in hypothalamus detect changes in blood temperature.Hypothalamus sends impulses to effectors in skin (vasodilation/ constriction, piloerection, sweating) & muscles (shivering).

cards.term: Explain the role of the skin in thermoregulation.
cards.definition: Vasodilation/ constriction of arterioles supplying skin capillaries controls heat loss to skin surface.Hair erector muscles contract & follicles protrude to trap air for insulation.Evaporation of sweat cools skin surface.
A protein complex consisting of a light-harvesting system and reaction centre, that is involved in the absorption of light and transfer of electrons in photosynthesis.

A three-carbon molecule produced in glycolysis. In the link reaction of aerobic respiration, it is oxidised to acetate. During fermentation, it is converted to lactate (animals) or ethanol and carbon dioxide (plants and microorganisms).
The region of a photosystem where energy is funneled and photosynthetic reactions take place. It contains two chlorophyll a molecules.

A set of metabolic reactions that take place in organisms and break down respiratory substances, such as glucose, into smaller inorganic molecules, like water and carbon dioxide. This is linked to the synthesis of ATP.
The ratio of carbon dioxide produced to oxygen consumed during respiration. Calculated using:RQ = CO2 produced / CO2 consumed
An organic molecule that can be broken down via the respiratory pathways to produce ATP.
A device used to determine respiration rate in living organisms by measuring the change in volume of oxygen or carbon dioxide.
Calculated using the equation:Rf = Distance travelled by component / Distance travelled by solvent
A five-carbon compound that reacts with carbon dioxide in the light-independent stage of photosynthesis, forming two molecules of GP.
An enzyme that catalyses the reaction of RuBP and carbon dioxide in the light-independent stage of photosynthesis.
The fluid interior of chloroplasts that contains the enzymes required for the light-independent reaction.
The synthesis of ATP by the transfer of a phosphate group from a phosphorylated intermediate to ADP.

A technique used to separate photosynthetic pigments by their rate of movement when carried by a solvent, across an inert surface. Differences in rate arise due to varying solubilities in the mobile phase and interactions with the stationary phase.
A series of flattened membrane-bound compartments in chloroplasts. They are stacked to form grana and contain the chlorophyll and other molecules needed for the light-dependent reaction.

A three-carbon compound formed in glycolysis and the light-independent stage of photosynthesis. It may serve as a starting material for the formation of organic molecules or be used to regenerate RuBP.
A two-carbon molecule formed in oxidative decarboxylation when an acetyl group is bound by coenzyme A. It is oxidised in the Krebs cycle.
The universal energy carrier found in all living cells.
A form of cellular respiration that takes place in the presence of oxygen and produces carbon dioxide, water and ATP. Overall:C6H12O6 + 6O2 \xe2\x86\x92 6CO2 + 6H2O
A type of fermentation that takes place in plant root cells and yeast cells, and produces ethanol and carbon dioxide.
A form of cellular respiration that takes place in the absence of oxygen. It produces less ATP than in aerobic respiration.
An enzyme found embedded in cellular membranes that phosphorylates ADP to form ATP as protons flow through it.
See \xe2\x80\x98Light-independent reaction\xe2\x80\x99.
The synthesis of ATP through the movement of protons down their concentration gradient across a semipermeable membrane, catalysed by ATP synthase.
A photosynthetic pigment located in the thylakoids of chloroplasts that absorbs light energy. There are two main types, chlorophyll a and chlorophyll b.
An organelle found in plants and algae that is the site of photosynthesis.
A six-carbon molecule formed in the first stage of the Krebs cycle from the reaction of acetyl coenzyme A and oxaloacetate.
A coenzyme that binds an acetyl group to form acetyl coenzyme A during oxidative decarboxylation of aerobic respiration.
Molecules that help enzymes carry out their function e.g. NAD, FAD, coenzyme A and NADP.
Folds of the inner mitochondrial membrane that provide a large surface area for oxidative phosphorylation.
The formation of ATP involving photosystem I only.
Each repeating unit of striations between adjacent Z-lines.
The cytoplasm shared by muscle fibres. It consists of a high concentration of mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum.
Cells that form the myelin sheath around nerve cells in the peripheral nervous system.
The mechanism by which a hormone (e.g. adrenaline or glucagon) has an effect inside a cell by triggering the production of a second messenger such as cAMP.
The selective reuptake of useful substances along the kidney nephron using membrane transport proteins.
A neurone that carries nerve impulses from the receptors to the CNS.
A type of vessel found in the liver which is formed from the convergence of the hepatic artery and the hepatic portal vein.
A voluntary muscle responsible for movement. It makes up the majority of body muscle and is attached to the skeleton by tendons.

The mechanism by which a muscle contracts. During contraction, myosin filaments pull actin filaments to the centre of the sarcomere. The actin filaments slide along the myosin filaments. The sarcomere is shortened and the muscle length is reduced.
An involuntary muscle under the control of the autonomic nervous system. It is found in the walls of the blood vessels, digestive tract and organs.
A branch of the nervous system that carries impulses to the skeletal muscles. It controls voluntary activities.
The combination of many impulses that can cumulatively stimulate the generation of an action potential in a postsynaptic neurone.
A branch of the autonomic nervous system that is active under stressful conditions. It stimulates effectors, speeding up activity.
The junction between two nerve cells or a nerve cell and an effector.
Secretory vesicles located in the presynaptic neurone that store neurotransmitters. Upon fusion with the presynaptic membrane, their contents are released into the synaptic cleft.
The main vein which takes deoxygenated blood away from the liver back to the heart.
Maintaining a constant internal environment around an optimum despite external change.
Hormones such as synthetic dicot auxins that alter plant metabolism, promoting rapid growth that is unsustainable.

Cell signalling molecules produced by endocrine glands and released into the blood. They travel to target cells and bind to specific receptors, initiating a response. The effects of hormones are usually long-lasting.
The drop in membrane potential below the resting potential after repolarisation due to open potassium ion channels.

The region of the brain that serves as the control centre for the autonomic nervous system. It is responsible for production of hormones, the regulation of the water potential of body fluids and the control of behavioural patterns.
The lighter region in the centre of each A band.
An impulse which inhibits the next neurone from generating an action potential.
Regions of the pancreas which contain \xce\xb1 and \xce\xb2 cells.
The lighter bands in a myofibril, which consist of non-overlapping actin and myosin filaments.
A type of spinal reflex commonly tested by doctors. It involves the sudden involuntary movement of the lower leg when the patella is tapped.
A specialised type of macrophage which is located within the sinusoids of the liver and removes pathogens and dead cells.
A large hairpin shaped loop found in the kidney tubule used to regulate the water and salt concentration of the blood.
The growth of a plant away from a stimulus.
Chemicals that are used for communication between neurones and their target cells. Neurotransmitters are stored in synaptic vesicles in the presynaptic neurone and released into the synaptic cleft.
A plant hormone that stimulates stomatal cloning, maintains seed dormancy and triggers cold protective responses.
The shedding of leaves in plants.
A type of neurotransmitter that is used for communication between neurones.
A type of protein filament found in myofibrils. It forms thin filaments consisting of two long twisted chains.
A site on actin that is normally blocked by tropomyosin. During muscle contraction, it becomes exposed, allowing a myosin head to attach.
The cross-bridge formed when a myosin head attaches to the myosin binding site on an actin filament.
An enzyme that catalyses the conversion of ATP to cAMP.
Glands which are located on the top of the kidneys and produce adrenaline and steroid hormones.
A hormone that is secreted by the adrenal glands under stressful conditions. It serves as a \xe2\x80\x98primary messenger\xe2\x80\x99, activating adenylyl cyclase.
The larger diameter arteriole which carries blood to the glomerulus for ultrafiltration.
A group of nitrogenous compounds found in plants. They are bitter-tasting and affect the metabolism of animals or insects that take them in.
The principle that describes how any generator potential which reaches or exceeds the threshold potential will produce an action potential of equal magnitude.
Cells found in the pancreas which secrete glucagon into the blood to raise glucose concentration.
The darker bands in a myofibril, which consist of overlapping actin and myosin filaments.
A class of performance enhancing drugs that are structurally similar to testosterone and used illegally by athletes to promote muscle growth.

All the living organisms found in one area, and the non-living aspects of their environment.Can range in size e.g. rock pool, tree, field. Known as \xe2\x80\x98dynamic\xe2\x80\x99 as they depend on interactions between biotic and abiotic factors.

cards.term: Describe biotic and abiotic factors, giving examples.
cards.definition: Biotic= living features of an ecosystem e.g. predators, disease.Abiotic= non-living features of an ecosystem e.g. light, temperature.

cards.term: What is biomass and how is it transferred? How can we measure this?
cards.definition: The total weight of living matter in a certain area, transferred up trophic levels through consumption. Can be measured in terms of mass of carbon, or dry mass of tissue.

cards.term: Give the formula for efficiency of biomass transfer.
cards.definition: Efficiency = (biomass transferred / biomass intake) x 100

cards.term: How can human activities affect biomass transfer?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Light, water, temperature maximised.\xe2\x97\x8f Increased nutrients in soil.\xe2\x97\x8f Pests and weeds removed.\xe2\x97\x8f Growth rates boosted through steroids, selective breeding, etc.

cards.term: Outline the roles of microorganisms in the nitrogen cycle.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Nitrogen-fixing bacteria e.g. Rhizobium inroots and Azotobacter in soil, convert gaseous nitrogen into ammonia.\xe2\x97\x8f Nitrifying bacteria e.g. Nitrosomonas convert ammonium compounds into nitrites. Nitrobacter then convert nitrites to nitrates.

cards.term: Outline the role of organisms in the carbon cycle.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Respiration of plants and animals add carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.\xe2\x97\x8f Photosynthesis of plants removes carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.\xe2\x97\x8f Decomposers (microorganisms) decay plant and animal material into carbon dioxide.

cards.term: What is meant by primary succession?
cards.definition: Where an area previously devoid of life is colonised by a community of organisms.

cards.term: Summarise the process of primary succession.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Pioneer species, able to survive harsh conditions, colonise the area.\xe2\x97\x8f They die, decompose, and add nutrients to the ground.\xe2\x97\x8f Over time, this allows more complex organisms to survive.

cards.term: What is the climax community and how is it reached?
cards.definition: The final stage of succession, where the ecosystem is balanced and stable. It is reached when the soil is rich enough to support large trees or shrubs, and the environment is no longer changing.
Where succession is interrupted, usually by human interference.
Selecting a group of individuals that will represent the whole target population.Allows us to measure the distribution and abundance of organisms.

cards.term: Give methods of sampling and explain how they are used.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Quadrats = used in small areas. Randomly or regularly placed across habitat. Frequency or % cover calculated.\xe2\x97\x8f Transects = used in larger areas. Sample taken along a line that crosses the habitat. Can be combined with quadrats in the form of a belt transect.
The maximum population size that a habitat can support, defined by the presence of limiting factors.

cards.term: Give factors that limit the maximum size of a population.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Food\xe2\x97\x8f Water\xe2\x97\x8f Light\xe2\x97\x8f Oxygen\xe2\x97\x8f Nesting sites\xe2\x97\x8f Shelter\xe2\x97\x8f Parasites\xe2\x97\x8f Predators

cards.term: How can we produce natural clones of plants?
cards.definition: Vegetative propagation. Part of a plant is separated, then develops into a new plant genetically identical to the original. English Elm does not produce viable seed, so naturally self-propagates using its roots.

cards.term: How should a plant cutting be taken for cloning?
cards.definition: Stem is cut between the leaf and nodes. Replanted and allowed to grow, sometimes with the use of plant hormones.

cards.term: How can we produce artificial clones of plants?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Tissue culture; sample placed on various nutrient-containing mediums to encourage cell division and shoot growth.\xe2\x97\x8f Micropropagation; material produced from tissue culture is rapidly multiplied to produce large numbers of plants.

cards.term: Evaluate the use of artificial plant cloning in agriculture.
cards.definition: + Large number of plants can be produced regardless of weather conditions.- Reduces genetic variation, making them susceptible to disease.

cards.term: Give an example of natural cloning in animals.
cards.definition: Monozygotic twins; embryo splits during development to produce two genetically identical individuals.

cards.term: How can we produce artificial clones of animals?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Somatic cell nuclear transfer; differentiated cell from parent fused with an enucleated egg cell. The cell develops into an embryo and can be implanted into a womb.\xe2\x97\x8f Embryo splitting; same process by which twins form, performed artificially.

cards.term: Give arguments surrounding cloning in animals.
cards.definition: + Quick process suited to the growing population of Earth.+ Can preserve endangered species.- Cloned animals often suffer from health problems.- Low genetic diversity.

cards.term: Why are microorganisms suited for use in biotechnological processes?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Rapid growth in a variety of environmental conditions.\xe2\x97\x8f Can be genetically engineered.\xe2\x97\x8f Reduces use of chemicals, beneficial to the environment.

cards.term: Give some ways microorganisms are used in biotechnological processes.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Food; baking, brewing, yogurt, cheese\xe2\x97\x8f Medicine; penicillin, insulin\xe2\x97\x8f Environmental; removing pollution (bioremediation)

cards.term: Give advantages of using microorganisms to produce food for human consumption.
cards.definition: + Production rate easily varied+ Not dependent on climate+ Long-lasting+ Uses waste products

cards.term: Give disadvantages of using microorganisms to produce food for human consumption.
cards.definition: - Lack of flavour.- Proteins must be isolated and purified.- Contains different amino acids to animal proteins.

cards.term: Describe the technique that should be used to culture microorganisms.
cards.definition: Aseptic technique; everything must be kept completely sterile so that no unwanted microorganisms are present in the culture.

cards.term: Summarise the three steps of growing microorganisms.
cards.definition: 1. Sterilisation; part of the aseptic technique.2. Inoculation; microorganism introduced to agar plate by streaking, seeding, or spreading.3. Incubation; placed in warm environment for 24-48 hours to grow.

cards.term: Differentiate between batch and continuous fermentation.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Batch= closed environment, competition for resources, maintains culture in stationary phase, easy to set up, less efficient.\xe2\x97\x8f Continuous= products continually removed, maintains culture in log phase, difficult to set up, more efficient.

cards.term: How are the growth conditions manipulated to maximise yield?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Temperature maintained at optimum.\xe2\x97\x8f Sufficient nutrient supply.\xe2\x97\x8f Aerobic conditions to prevent products of anaerobic respiration.\xe2\x97\x8f pH kept constant to maximise enzyme activity.
Identifying the base sequence of a DNA fragment.
