cards.term: How have sequencing methods changed over time?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Used to be a manual process, however now it has become automated.\xe2\x97\x8f Entire genomes can now be read.

cards.term: Give some benefits of genome-wide comparisons.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Comparing between species allows us to determine evolutionary relationships.\xe2\x97\x8f Comparing between individuals of the same species allows us to tailor medical treatment to the individual.

cards.term: How can DNA sequencing be used in synthetic biology?
cards.definition: Knowing the sequence of a gene allows us to predict the sequence of amino acids that will make up the polypeptide it produces.This in turn allows for development of synthetic biology.
Identifying the unique areas of a person\xe2\x80\x99s DNA, in order to create a profile that is individual to them.

\xe2\x97\x8f Forensics= DNA obtained during crime investigations can be compared to that of victims or suspects.\xe2\x97\x8f Medicine= to screen for a particular base sequence in order to identify heritable diseases.

cards.term: How can we amplify DNA fragments in order to sequence them?
cards.definition: Using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Makes millions of a copies of a fragment, which are then cut at different lengths in order to be sequenced.

cards.term: Describe the reaction mixture in the first stage of PCR.
cards.definition: Contains the DNA fragment to be amplified, primers that are complementary to the start of the fragment, free nucleotides to match up to exposed bases, and DNA polymerase to create the new DNA.

cards.term: Summarise the process of amplifying DNA fragments using PCR.
cards.definition: 1. Heated to break apart the DNA strands.2. Cooled to allow primers to bind.3. Heated again to activate DNA polymerase and allow free nucleotides to join.4. New DNA acts as template for next cycle.

cards.term: How is gel electrophoresis used in DNA profiling?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f DNA fragments of varying lengths are placed at one end of a slab of gel.\xe2\x97\x8f Electric current is applied; DNA fragments move towards the other end of the gel.\xe2\x97\x8f Shorter fragments travel further. The pattern of bands created is unique to every individual.

cards.term: What is meant by genetic engineering?
cards.definition: Where a DNA fragment from one organism is inserted into the DNA of another organism, sometimes across different species. This is done through use of a vector and a host cell.

cards.term: Summarise the process of isolating a DNA fragment.
cards.definition: Restriction enzymes (RE) cut DNA at specific sequences. Different REs cut at different points, but one RE will always cut at the same sequence. Therefore using particular REs allows you to cut out a certain gene of interest.

cards.term: Summarise the process of inserting a DNA fragment into a vector.
cards.definition: A plasmid (circular DNA from bacteria) is used as the vector, and is cut using the same restriction enzymes as the DNA, so that the ends are complementary. DNA ligase joins the fragment and plasmid together.

cards.term: Summarise the process of inserting a vector into a host cell.
cards.definition: The host cells (bacteria) are mixed with the vectors in an ice-cold solution, then shocked to increase the permeability of the cell membrane (electroporation) which encourages the cells to take up the vectors.

cards.term: Give some ethical issues around genetic engineering.
cards.definition: + Insect resistance can be introduced to crops.+ GE animals used to produce pharmaceuticals (pharming).+ GE pathogens can be produced for research- GE seeds would be hard to acquire for poorer farmers.
The expression of an organism\xe2\x80\x99s genetic constitution e.g. low metabolism, combined with its interaction with the environment e.g. diet.

cards.term: How can meiosis bring about genetic variation?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Random arrangement of chromosomes during lining up.\xe2\x97\x8f Crossing over of chromatids before thefirst division.

cards.term: How does random fertilisation bring about genetic variation?
cards.definition: Gametes are haploid cells, meaning they only contain half of a person\xe2\x80\x99s DNA. As this is determined by meiosis, every gamete contains different DNA. Therefore the same two individuals can produce genetically different offspring.
Where one phenotypic characteristic is controlled by a single gene.

cards.term: Draw a genetic diagram for monogenic inheritance.
cards.definition: Define dihybrid inheritance.

cards.term: Where two phenotypic characteristics are determined by two different genes present on two different chromosomes at the same time.
cards.definition: Draw a genetic diagram for dihybrid inheritance.
Where an allele is located on one of the sex chromosomes, meaning its expression depends on the sex of the individual.

cards.term: Draw a genetic diagram for sex-linked inheritance.
cards.definition: What is meant by multiple alleles?

cards.term: A gene with more than two alleles.
cards.definition: Draw a genetic diagram for multiple allelic inheritance.

cards.term: What is meant by codominant alleles?
cards.definition: Two dominant alleles that both contribute to the phenotype, either by showing a blend of both characteristics, or the characteristics appearing together.

cards.term: Draw a genetic diagram for codominant inheritance.
cards.definition: What is meant by autosomal linkage?

cards.term: Where two or more genes are located on the same (non-sex) chromosome. In this case, only one homologous pair is needed for all four alleles to be present. For genes that aren\xe2\x80\x99t linked, two homologous pairs are needed.
cards.definition: What is meant by epistasis?

cards.term: Where two non-linked genes interact, with one gene either masking or suppressing the other gene.

cards.definition: An alteration to the DNA base sequence. Often arise spontaneously during DNA replication.

cards.term: What are addition and deletion mutations?
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f Where one or more nucleotides (bases) are either inserted or deleted from the DNA sequence.\xe2\x97\x8f More likely to be either harmful or beneficial, due to frame shift which means the entire amino acid sequence will be different.
\xe2\x97\x8f When a nucleotide in the DNA sequence is replaced by another.\xe2\x97\x8f More likely to be a neutral mutation,meaning no change occurs in the amino acid sequence.

cards.term: How is gene expression regulated at the transcriptional level?
cards.definition: Transcription factors. These are proteins that can either initiate or inhibit the transcription of genes, so that only certain parts of the DNA are expressed.

cards.term: Describe the function of the lac operon in low lactose concentrations.
cards.definition: \xe2\x97\x8f E.coli can use lactose as a respiratory substrate, via use of an enzyme.\xe2\x97\x8f When lactose concentration is low, the lac operon binds to the gene that makes this enzyme and inhibits its expression.

cards.term: Describe the function of the lac operon in high lactose concentrations.
cards.definition: Lactose binds to the operon, causing it to change shape and unattach from the gene. Allows RNA polymerase to bind and the gene to be expressed.

cards.term: How is gene expression regulated at the post-transcriptional level?
cards.definition: Splicing. Primary mRNA contains both coding regions (exons) and non-coding regions (introns). The introns are removed to produce mature mRNA ready for translation.

cards.term: How is gene expression regulated at the post-translational level?
cards.definition: Activation of proteins, such as adrenaline. When adrenaline binds to a receptor, an enzyme is activated which converts ATP to cyclic AMP. Prompts further enzyme reactions, which activates the protein.

cards.term: How is development controlled by homeobox genes?
cards.definition: Code for transcription factors that activate genes when they\xe2\x80\x99re needed during development of a zygote. Their sequences are similar in plants, animals, and fungi.

cards.term: How is development controlled by mitosis?
cards.definition: Mitosis (cell replication) is the primary mechanism of growth. Genes regulating mitosis respond to various stimuli, both internal and external, in order to control rate of growth.

cards.term: How is development controlled by apoptosis?
cards.definition: Programmes the death of cells. It is highly controlled and keeps cell division at a constant rate so as to prevent cancer.
The non-living aspects of an ecosystem e.g. light, temperature, water availability, oxygen availability and soil pH.
The number of individuals per species in a specific area at any given time.
The production of ammonium compounds when decomposers feed on organic nitrogen-containing molecules.
A type of nitrogen-fixing bacteria that lives freely in the soil.
A line along a sampled area upon which quadrats are placed at intervals to determine the abundance and distribution of organisms in an ecosystem.
The total mass of organic material, measured in a specific area over a set time period. This can be calculated in terms of dry mass.
The living components of an ecosystem e.g. food availability, pathogens, predators and other species.
The cycle through which carbon (in the form of carbon dioxide) moves between living organisms and the environment, involving respiration, photosynthesis and combustion.
The maximum population size that can be indefinitely supported by an environment.
The stable community of organisms that exists at the final stage of ecological succession.
The maintenance of ecosystems and biodiversity by humans in order to preserve the Earth\xe2\x80\x99s resources.
Organisms that feed on other organisms to obtain energy.
Organisms that release enzymes which catalyse the breakdown of dead plant and animal material into simpler organic matter.
Changes to the natural flow of succession due to human activity that result in a stable community known as a plagioclimax.
The conversion of nitrate ions to nitrogen gas by denitrifying bacteria.
The artificial production of monozygotic twins from the manual splitting of the early embryo.
A range of techniques used to culture microorganisms under sterile conditions in order to minimise contamination.
An industrial method of fermentation that runs for a set period of time. The culture broth is not removed until the fermentation is complete.
The use of microorganisms to remove soil and water pollution.
The field of biology involving the use of living systems to produce or transform materials. Applications include agriculture, medicine and food science.
The production of beer from the steeping of barley in water, and the fermentation of the resulting product with yeast.
The genetically identical offspring produced as a result of cloning.
A method of producing genetically identical offspring by asexual reproduction.
An industrial method of fermentation in which culture broth is continuously removed and extra nutrient medium is added. The fermentation conditions remain relatively constant.
The growth of living matter in vitro in suitable conditions.
A small section of the root or stem of an adult plant that is used in horticulture to produce natural clones.
The removal of the nucleus.
A type of anaerobic respiration that does not involve an electron transport chain.
An immobilised enzyme that is used to produce pure samples of L-amino acids.
Enzymes which are attached to an inert, insoluble material over which the substrate passes and the reaction takes place.
A form of cell division that produces two genetically identical diploid daughter cells. Mitosis is important for growth, increasing the number of cells.
The determination of a trait by the inheritance of a single gene.
When a gene has more than two potential alleles.
A chemical, biological or physical agent that increases the rate of gene mutations above normal level.
A group of genes that are expressed together and controlled by the same regulatory mechanism.
An organism\xe2\x80\x99s observable characteristics. Due to interactions of the genotype and the environment.
An in vitro technique used to rapidly amplify fragments of DNA.
The level of gene regulation in which primary mRNA can be modified, controlling translation.
The level of gene regulation in which proteins can be modified post-synthesis.
The product of transcription before any post-transcriptional regulation.
Describes an allele that is only expressed in the absence of a dominant allele. Represented by a small letter.
A combination of DNA from two different organisms
A gene that codes for the production of proteins involved in DNA regulation. The expression of regulatory genes is influenced by internal and external stimuli.
A protein that binds to the operator, altering the transcription rate.
Enzymes that cut DNA molecules at recognition sequences, creating sticky ends.
A version of a gene.
A form of speciation that occurs when two populations become geographically isolated due to a physical barrier.
Programmed cell death. This is important for pruning surplus cells and tissues in development.
See \xe2\x80\x98selective breeding\xe2\x80\x99.
When two or more genes are positioned on the same autosome. They are unlikely to be separated by crossing over during meiosis so are often inherited together.
A chromosome that is not an X or Y chromosome.
The development of the computer tools and software required to organise and analyse unprocessed biological data.
A statistical test used to determine whether a pattern of inheritance is statistically significant.
A condition in which plant leaf cells produce insufficient chlorophyll, resulting in pale or yellow coloured leaves. This may be due to mineral deficiencies, lack of light, or viral infections.
When both alleles for a gene in a heterozygous organism equally contribute to the phenotype.
The use of computational techniques to analyse large amounts of biodata and build theoretical models of biological systems.
A type of variation that cannot be categorised e.g. skin colour, height. It produces a continuous range in which a characteristic can take any value. Multiple genes influence continuous variation.
The number of categories minus one
A form of gene mutation in which one or more nucleotide bases are removed from a DNA sequence. This may lead to a frameshift mutation, changing every successive codon.
The determination of a trait by the inheritance of two genes
A definition of abnormality by Jahoda, whoproposed that the absence of 6 indicators of ideal mental health are a sign of "dysfunction". This is the way in which physical health is assessed.

- Positive self attitude- Self-actualisation- Autonomy- Resisting stress- Accurate perception of reality- Environmental mastery: abnormality is failure to meet criteria such as autonomy, resisting from stress, environmental mastery.

cards.term: Evaluation of the validity of the deviation from ideal mental health definition
cards.definition: It is subjective as it relies on self-report, unlike the measurement of physical health.It is over-demanding as at a given moment, most people would not meet all of the ideals.It is not cross culturally generalisable, as in collectivist cultures "autonomy" is not seen as a desirable trait to have.It is subject to change over time e.g. in the 13th century, seeing visions was seen as desirable (a sign of religious commitment).

Rosenhan and Seligman argued that a "dysfunctional" person is one whose behaviour suggests they can\'t cope with everyday life.This definition focuses on the individual\'s experience, and permits judgement by others via observable/measurable behaviour.E.g. the DSM definition of depression states that the symptoms must cause distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

cards.term: 7 features of failing to function adequately
cards.definition: - Personal distress, -Maladaptive behaviour, -Unpredictability, -Irrationality, -Observer discomfort,-Violation of moral standards & -Unconventionality.

cards.term: Evaluation of the validity of the failure to function adequately definition
cards.definition: It doesn\'t take into account times when it\'s normal to suffer distress e.g. mourning.It doesn\'t take into account how behaviour may not cause an individual distress, even though it may cause others discomfort.It doesn\'t take into account conditions where people maintain their success e.g. psychopaths, who can commit murder to lead successful lives (e.g. Dr Harold Shipman).It doesn\'t take into account the fact that some so called "dysfunctional" behaviour may actually be personally rewarding e.g. an eating disorder may bring with it affection and attention.

A definition of abnormality: abnormality is behaviour which violates the often unwritten rules for acceptable behaviour which society sets.Once identified, social deviants can then be helped.E.g. Antisocial personality disorder (psychopathy) is defined by the DSM as a "failure to conform to social norms with respect to lawful behaviours as indicated by repeatedly performing acts that are grounds for arrest".

cards.term: Evaluation of the validity of the deviation from social norms definition
cards.definition: It is subject to change over time e.g. homosexuality was classified as abnormal until relatively recently.It can label eccentric people as abnormal, even though their behaviour may cause no problems or, actually be beneficial e.g. the Suffragettes.It is subjective as it\'s based on the opinions of the elite, who can then use the label of "dysfunctional" to discriminate against people who don\'t conform.It may be affected by culture bias and therefore lead to discrimination of ethnic minorities as they don\'t conform to western norms: e.g. black people are diagnosed more often with schizophrenia than white/Asian people in the UK.

A person\'s behaviour is classified as dysfunctional if it is statistically unusual. This definition requires clarification of how rare behaviour needs to be before we class it as abnormal.E.g. as many traits in the population demonstrate a normal distribution curve, the 2% that are at either end of the curve could be considered "dysfunctional".This works on characteristics which can be quantified such as IQ- 96% of all people fall within 30 IQ points of the mean (100).

cards.term: Evaluation of the validity of the statistical infrequency definition
cards.definition: It doesn\'t take into account the desirability of behaviour, just its frequency e.g. having an IQ of 150 is rare, but highly desirable.There is no objectively defined cut off point when a behaviour becomes rare enough to be classified as "dysfunctional"- any decision will be arbitrary.Some disorders that are considered psychologically abnormal are quite common e.g. mild depression.Some disorders may appear rare in a culture simply because they are not reported due to the stigma surrounding it e.g. few mental illnesses are reported in India.

Irresistible and repetitive physical or mental actions that people feel compelled to carry out (compulsions). Time consuming nature of repeating actions leads to hindrance of performing everyday functions/conducting relationships.
Extreme anxiety/ guilt/ disgust caused by intrusive thoughts (obsessions).Sense of urgency to complete compulsion, followed by temporary relief, then distress
Recurrent and intrusive thoughts/ideas/images/impulses(obsessions). Selective attention towards source of obsessionRealisation of irrationality of thoughts/behaviour

OCD is inherited through genetic transmission. e.g. The COMT gene is associated with the production of dopamine. One variation of the COMT gene results in higher levels of dopamine and this variation is more common in patients with OCD vs. people without OCD.e.g. A second gene which has been implicated in OCD is the SERT gene which affects the transport of the serotonin, causing lower levels of serotonin which is associated with OCD.It is unlikely that single genes cause OCD, more that it is a combination of genes that determines an individuals level of vulnerability to develop the disorder.

cards.term: Twin study evidence for biological explanation of OCD.
cards.definition: Nestadt et al review: on average, if one of a pair of identical (MZ) twins had OCD, the other had a 68% of having it too. Non-identical twins have a lower "concordance" for OCD at 31%. As MZ twins share more genes than DZ twins (100% vs 50%), this supports that genetics are influential in the development of OCD.

cards.term: Gene mapping evidence for biological explanation of OCD.
cards.definition: Taylor: review of gene mapping studies to find the genes which OCD patients display more often than non-OCD controls. There are up to 230 such "candidate genes", particularly ones which control the action of neurotransmitters in the brain such as dopamine and serotonin. This suggests that there are multiple specific genes which are involved in the development of OCD.

cards.term: Evaluation of genetic explanation of OCD
cards.definition: X MZ concordance for OCD is not 100% = cause of OCD isn\'t solely genetic e.g. they may be some environmental influence too.X Some argue MZ twins are treated more similarly than DZ twins = could b an EV in twin study data e.g. it may be this rather than a higher proportion of shared genes which cause MZ concordance to be higher than DZ for OCD...X Evidence suggests that childhood OCD/ obsessions relating to contamination/ aggression & compulsions relating to washing/ ordering/ are more likely to be genetic than others = the influence of genes may vary depending on the age of onset and pattern of OCD symptoms demonstrated...

OCD may be caused by abnormalities in the brain. This may involve neuroanatomical (brain structure) abnormalities in the "worry circuit" of the brain. The orbitofrontal cortex converts sensory information into thoughts and actions. Damage to the caudate nucleus (which usually inhibits impulses from the OFC relating to environmental stimuli) may lead to hyperactivation of the OFC. This increases the conversion of sensory information to actions i.e. compulsions in OCD. Additionally, the brains of OCD patients may have higher levels of dopamine/ lower levels of serotonin.

cards.term: Evidence for neural explanation of OCD (neuroanatomical)
cards.definition: Saxena and Rauch: review of studies that used neuroimaging techniques e.g. PET and MRI. Across all studies, there was a consistent correlation between high levels of activity in the OFC and OCD symptoms. This is evidence that the caudate nucleus is damaged, with could otherwise regulate OFC activity.

cards.term: Evidence for neural explanation of OCD (neurochemical)
cards.definition: Antidepressant drugs which increase levels of serotonin in the brain have been found to be effective in treating the symptoms of OCD.This suggests that OCD is associated with low baseline levels of serotonin.

cards.term: Evaluation of neural explanation of OCD
cards.definition: X The evidence for the neural explanations is correlational = cause and effect cannot be established e.g. does abnormal neural activity cause OCD, or does OCD cause abnormal brain activity, or are the 2 related to an underlying 3rd variable?...X Not all sufferers of OCD respond well to serotonin enhancing drugs = not all P\'s OCD symptoms are related to low levels of serotonin...X Biological explanations don\'t take into account the person\'s environment =they are reductionist e.g. in some cases OCD is known to be a response to trauma..
SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors). A type of antidepressant e.g. fluoxetine. An alternative drug treatment is antipsychotic drugs which reduce dopamine levels in the brain.

SSRIs block the serotonin receptors on the pre-synaptic neurone which usually allow serotonin to be reabsorbed, so serotonin stays in the synapse longer, allowing it to stimulate the post-synaptic neurone for longer. SSRIs affect the neurones in the orbitofrontal cortex, causing the activity of this area to become closer to normal. They are usually taken for 12-16 weeks.

cards.term: Evidence for SHORT TERM effect of drug treatments for OCD
cards.definition: Soomro et al: reviewed 17 studies involving 3,097 adult patients comparing the effectiveness of drugs vs placebos. All studies showed SSRIs to be more effective than placebos up to 3 months after the treatment. This suggests that SSRIs can reduce the symptoms of OCD in the short term.

cards.term: Evidence for LONG TERM effect of drug treatments for OCD
cards.definition: Simpson et al:Up to 45% of patients treated with clomipramine (another SSRI) relapsed back into the disorder within 12 weeks of finishing the medication, compared to 12% of those who\'d been receiving psychological therapy. This suggests that SSRIs are merely a quick fix, and don\'t constitute a cure as effectiveness doesn\'t extend to the long term.

cards.term: Evaluation of drug therapy for OCD
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 Drugs are cost effective and non-disruptive = a practical treatment e.g. they are cheaper to prescribe than talking therapy, and can fit into Ps daily routine with ease.X Drugs can produce unpleasant side effects = the risk of non-adherence to treatment is increased because of their impact on wellbeing e.g. nausea, headaches, anxiety, blurred vision, loss of sex drive...IN ADDITION...X Most patients report improvement rather than cessation of symptoms = drugs are not a cure e.g. increasing serotonin may not be tackling the underlying cause of OCD...X Not all SSRIs are effective in treating all OCD patients- around 70% will improve significantly. = the underlying cause of all OCD patients\' symptoms cannot be reduced to low levels of serotonin...X There is controversy attached to the sponsorship by drug companies of research to support the use of drug treatments = evidence for drug treatments may be unreliable e.g. it could be the case that such companies suppress evidence that does not support the effectiveness of certain drugs to maximise their economic gain.
Reduced levels of energyIncreased or need for sleepIncrease/ decrease in appetite
SadnessLoss of pleasure in normal activities Irritability/ aggression
Low self-esteemAttending to/dwelling on negative aspects of a situationNegative beliefs about the selfPoor concentration/ memoryThoughts of death

cards.term: The cognitive approach to explaining depression
cards.definition: This approach focuses on people\'s beliefs rather than their behaviour. Depression results from systematic negative bias in thinking processes.

cards.term: Becks\' cognitive explanation (cognitive explanation of depression 2)
cards.definition: 3 factors create a \'cognitive vulnerability\' to depression:a) Negative Self-Schemas: Mental structures which help us organise/ interpret information relating to ourselves. This may lead to biased info. processing if a person\'s self-schema contains negative beliefs because of frequent experiences of criticism... b) Faulty Information Processing: A person will readily process info. which confirms negative beliefs, whilst ignoring evidence against them- e.g. "magnification and minimisation" (overestimating the extent of failure whilst underestimating success).c)The Cognitive Triad: Negative thoughts will be in relation to the self, world and future.

cards.term: Ellis\' ABC model (cognitive explanation of depression 1)
cards.definition: The cause of depression is way in which we process information:  Activating event \xe2\x86\x92 Beliefs \xe2\x86\x92 ConsequenceThe beliefs (B) we hold cause the emotional response (C) we have to events rather than the events themselves (A).

cards.term: Evidence for the cognitive explanation of depression
cards.definition: 1) Beck gave the dysfunctional attitude scale (DAS) to depressed and non-depressed people. Those with depression scored higher on the DAS, showing that they thought more negatively about events and situations than non-depressed people.However it is not clear from this study that negative thoughts CAUSED depression. In contrast...2) Alloy et al identified students as either "optimistic" or "hopeless" thinkers. They were interviewed regularly over 2\xc2\xbd years. 1% of O thinkers developed depression compared to 17% of the H thinkers,suggesting that negative thinking precedes the development of depression.

cards.term: Evaluation of the cognitive explanation of depression
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 Practical applications = knowledge of how depression develops can be used to help Ps change their behaviour e.g. by teaching them new thinking patterns using CBT...X Doesn\'t take biological factors into account = it is a reductionist theory e.g. particularly as it is known that drugs which increase serotonin levels also improve symptoms, suggesting depression is associated with low levels.X Much of the evidence for the explanation is correlational = impossible to establish a cause effect relationship e.g. do negative thoughts cause depression, or does depression lead to negative thinking?...X Client is blamed rather than the situation = ethical issues with the explanation e.g. failing to acknowledge that the P may have developed thought patterns which reflect negative life experiences...
Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), tackling the negative thoughts of depressed Ps in order to change their behaviour

Education phase: Involves teaching P about the link between thoughts and emotions.Behavioural activation: P is encouraged to do activities which they find enjoyable in order to improve mood.Cognitive factors are now addressed: the Ps beliefs about themselves are identified and challenged.Hypothesis testing: Ps are set HW tasks which will provide evidence against their faulty beliefs, therefore causing them to change.

cards.term: Evidence for the effectiveness of CBT vs no treatment for depression
cards.definition: Embling: 38 patients receiving 12 CBT sessions/ 2 months vs. control group. CBT mean depression score reduced over time (although Ps with certain traits e.g. perfectionism didn\'t improve) vs. control groups\' stayed the same, suggesting that except for a subset of Ps, CBT improves the condition of Ps.

cards.term: Evidence for the effectiveness of CBT vs drugs for depression
cards.definition: Hollon et al: Moderate to severely depressed Ps treated for 16 weeks with CBT , drugs or a placebo.Over the next 6 months 40% of CBT group relapsed vs. 45% of drug group vs 80% of placebo group suggesting that in contrast to drugs, CBT tackles the underlying cause of depression rather than merely masking symptoms.

cards.term: Evaluation of CBT to treat depression
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 CBT is relatively quick to administer = more practical than previous talking therapies e.g. psychoanalysis for depression takes years rather than 2 months to improve symptoms...X CBT is more effective with articulate, motivated Ps = its effectiveness may not generalise to all subgroups e.g. Ps need to be able to express themselves well and engage fully in the homework tasks...X CBT is more effective with skilled therapists. Th= administering CBT isn\'t guaranteed to lead to improvements e.g. if 2 therapists have received different training, the outcomes they achieve with patients may not be consistent... X CBT ignores the context of the P = may demotivate people to change their situation e.g. in some cases apparently "pessimistic" thought patterns may be realistic assessments of the P\'s impoverished/ abusive living circumstances.
Altering behaviour to avoid feared stimulus.Freezing in the presence of the feared stimulus.Attempts to escape from the feared stimulus.
Anxiety in anticipation of being in the presence of the feared stimulus.Anxiety in the presence of the feared stimulus.
Irrational beliefs about the stimulus.Difficulty concentrating due to preoccupation with irrational thoughts.Awareness that anxiety levels are out of proportion to the stimulus.

cards.term: The behavioural approach to explaining phobias
cards.definition: Phobias are learned through conditioning: the 2 process model.
The perception of phobias as acquired through classical conditioning, with their maintenance upheld through operant conditioning
When a naturally feared stimulus (UCS) becomes associated with a neutral stimulus, making the NS a conditioned stimulus producing fear (CR)

cards.term: Evidence for the role of classical conditioning in the acquisition of phobias
cards.definition: Watson & Rayner exposed Little Albert to a loud noise & a white rat at the same time. He consequently developed a phobia of rats & other white furry objects. This suggests phobias can be learned by C.C. if a previously NS becomes associated with a fear producing UCS. In this case the phobia is acquired because the rat became a CS for the CR of fear.
The reduction in fear from avoiding or escaping from a feared object/ situation acts as negative reinforcement, maintaining the phobia.

cards.term: Evidence for the role of operant conditioning in the maintenance of a phobia
cards.definition: DiGallo: It was found that around 20% of people who had experienced a traumatic car accident developed a phobia of travelling in cars, especially travelling at speed. Many then avoided making car journeys in future. This suggests that avoiding a CS leads to negative reinforcement of the escape behaviour by making fear subside, thus maintaining the fear.

cards.term: Evaluation of the behavioural explanation of phobias
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 Practical applications= knowledge of how phobias are acquired can be used to help Ps "unlearn" their fear response e.g. providing experiences to allow new associations to form with the CS/ preventing escape from the CS...X Conditioning isn\'t necessary to develop phobias = phobias occur without Ps having any bad experience with the CS e.g. DiNardo found only 60% relate their dog phobia to a traumatic experience...X Conditioning isn\'t sufficient to develop phobias = it is possible to have a bad experience with a stimulus without developing a phobia e.g. DiNardo found 60% of a non-phobic control group had also had a traumatic experience with a dog...X The behavioural explanation doesn\'t take into account evolutionary factors = it\'s a reductionist explanation e.g. humans appear to be predisposed to form fear associations with stimuli which posed a threat to survival in our evolutionary history such as snakes and spiders more readily than cars...
Systematic desensitisationFlooding

P has relaxation training.They construct an anxiety hierarchy.They experience gradual exposure to the anxiety hierarchy whilst practising relaxation, and only move on once the fear at that stage has subsided.

cards.term: Evidence for systematic desensitisation to treat phobias
cards.definition: Jones used SD to eradicate "Little Peter\'s" phobia of white fluffy objects. The 3 year old boy was first presented to a rabbit in a cage as he ate his lunch in his play pen, and built up from there. After 40 sessions he would stroke the rabbit and other, similar white fluffy objects. This suggests that that S.D is an appropriate treatment to use to extinguish the fear response in childhood phobias.
P has direct full exposure to the feared stimulus.They are prevented from escaping until they are calm and fear is extinguished.

cards.term: Evidence for flooding to treat phobias
cards.definition: Wolpe forced his female patient into a car and drove her around for 4 hours until her hysteria at being in the car was eradicated. This removed the girl\'s phobia of being in cars. This suggests that flooding can successfully eradicate a phobia preventing reinforcing escape behaviour.

cards.term: Evaluation for the behavioural approach in treating phobias
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x93 Treatments are quick to administer = practical treatments e.g. in contrast to talking therapies, the improvement in symptoms is much more immediate...\xe2\x9c\x93Treatments require little input from Ps = are suitable for a wide range of patients e.g. children, people with learning difficulties...X Treatments are most effective for specific phobias acquired from personal experience = effectiveness doesn\'t generalise to every case e.g. they are less helpful for general phobias such as agoraphobia and ones with an evolutionary advantage...X Therapies pose ethical issues, esp. flooding e.g. preventing Ps from leaving a feared situation/ causing distress...X The effectiveness may not generalise to real life = improvements seen in the clinical setting are not valid indicator of the being "cured" e.g. symptoms often reappear in a less controlled context...
A two-way, enduring, emotional bond to a specific other person

A batch of fertilised eggs was split into an experimental group (saw Lorenz after they hatched) and the control group (saw the mother goose as soon as they hatched). Lorenz then labelled the goslings, placed them all together then released them at once.

The goslings separated according to which group they had been in. (In follow up experiments, this was only shown to occur if they saw him in the first 13-16 hours after hatching. After 32 hours it was very unlikely to occur.)

Goslings innately attach as a result of mere exposure (imprinting), suggesting it is a strategy which has evolved to ensure offspring stay close to an attachment figure who can provide food and protection. The exposure to the attachment figure must occur in a critical period within 16 hours.

X Geese are less complex than humans = behaviour may not be generalisable to human infants e.g. geese are precocial, which means they are mobile from birth and so have greater need to stay close.HOWEVER\xe2\x9c\x93 Human infants do show the greatest separation anxiety in relation to the primary attachment figure when they begin to become mobile = imprinting may be present in a modified form in humans.\xe2\x9c\x93 Field experiment= high ecological validity e.g. it is likely that the attachment behaviour of the goslings reflected their attachment behaviour in real life.
8 infant rhesus monkeys taken from their mothers and kept in a cage with two substitute mothers : a cloth and a wire mother (incorporating a feeding bottle) for 165 days.

-Infant monkeys spent most time clinging to the cloth mother/only a short time on the wire mother, when feeding. -When frightened, they would run to the cloth mother. -When returned to other monkeys, they were aggressive, unable to form relationships and attacked monkeys that tried to mate with them. -If they had offspring, they were poor, neglecting mothers.
a) Contact comfort is a more important factor than food in leading to attachment. b) Early attachments lead to the development of an internal working model on which to base future attachments.

x Monkeys are less complex than humans = role of comfort/effects of privation may not be generalisable to human infants e.g. processes involved in human attachment formation/the effects of privation may be different in humans.HOWEVER\xe2\x9c\x93 Humans and monkeys are evolutionarily related = may be appropriate to generalise the findings to some extent e.g. we share common ancestors from whom the behaviour patterns seen may have been inherited.\xe2\x9c\x93 Ethical and practical advantages to studying non-human animals= wider range of hypotheses that can be tested using animals than humans e.g. it is easier to access and accommodate animals, a greater range of interventions can be used on animals, and the effects of an intervention can be seen quicker as they mature quicker.

-60 babies (5-23 weeks at the start of the investigation) from working class area of Glasgow observed/ mothers interviewed to gather data on their attachments. -Data collected every month for the infants\' first year, then again at 18 months. -Strength of attachment measured in terms of separation anxiety when away from the main caregiver and stranger anxiety.

-Attachments develop in 4 stages- Attachments were most likely to form with the person who most accurately responded to the babies\' needs (carers high in "sensitive responsiveness"), not just the person that spent most time with them (in 39% of cases it wasn\'t the mum).

cards.term: Evaluation of Schaffer and Emerson- strengths
cards.definition: Naturalistic observation= behaviour is likely to have high validity e.g. the children were observed in their own homes and so are likely to have been demonstrating natural behaviour.Longitudinal study= likelihood of the validity of the data being affected by individual differences was reduced e.g. in a snap-shot study with different children at each age, the development of the individual babies\' attachments couldn\'t be observed in the same way.

cards.term: Evaluation of Schaffer and Emerson- limitations
cards.definition: Interview techniques= reduce the validity of the evidence e.g. parents\' self report may have been biased by the desire to appear to be "good parents".Babies all from the same cultural group= the stages of attachment may be specific to that group e.g. they may represent the outcome of the parenting style common in the working class Glaswegian community and not generalise to the wider population. It has been found that multiple attachments are more common earlier on in collectivist cultures.
Asocial, indiscriminate, specific, multiple
First few weeks in which similar responses produced in response to objects and people. Towards the end of the period they show a preference for human-like stimuli (faces and eyes)
2 to 7 months, in which babies can tell people apart and prefer familiar adults, but can be easily comforted by anyone. No fear of strangers.
7m+ at which point babies begin to show separation anxiety when a primary caregiver leaves them. Fear of strangers is demonstrated.
By 1 year, in which the baby shows attachment behaviour towards several different people e.g. siblings, grandparents, child-minders.

cards.term: Bowlby\'s argument on multiple attachments inc. role of the father
cards.definition: An infant forms one special "primary" attachment (usually with the mother) which determines the child\'s development. All "secondary" attachments are of minor importance.

cards.term: 2 x studies to support Bowlby\'s argument on multiple attachments/ role of father
cards.definition: 1) Geiger: fathers\' play interactions are more exciting and pleasurable, whilst mothers are more nurturing and affectionate, suggesting that the role of mothers and fathers to infant development are fundamentally different.2) Hrdy: fathers were less able than mothers to detect low level infant distress, suggesting fathers may not have the same innate abilities as mothers to allow them to nurture an infant.

cards.term: Rutter\'s argument on multiple attachments inc. role of the father
cards.definition: All attachments are equivalent in the role they play in the child\'s development.

cards.term: 2 x studies to support Rutter\'s argument on multiple attachments/ role of father
cards.definition: 1) Field: filmed 4 m olds interacting with primary caregiver mothers/ secondary caregiver fathers/ primary caregiver fathers. Both primary caregiver mothers and fathers spent more time smiling/ imitating/ holding infants than secondary caregiver fathers, suggesting that parenting skills can develop if fathers are placed in the role of primary caregiver.2)Children with secure attachments to their fathers have better relationships with peers/less problem emotional and behavioural problems. Children who grow up without any father do less well at school and show more risk taking and aggressive behaviour (especially male children), suggesting that fathers play a crucial role in normal development of a child.

cards.term: Evaluation of research on multi attachments/ role of father: limitations
cards.definition: -Individual differences between father= over-simplistic to classify all fathers in the same way e.g. \xe2\x80\xa2 more secure attachments likely with sensitive father, more marital intimacy between father and co-parent, more support from their co-parent.-Research is correlational = it is impossible to establish the direction of cause and effect e.g. does father\'s characteristics determine his ability to form an attachment, or does attachment allows a father\'s characteristics to develop.-Research into the role of fathers may be confounded by researcher bias= validity of the research may be reduced e.g. preconceptions about how fathers behave may lead researchers to unintentionally interpret their behaviour to fit their expectations.

cards.term: Evaluation of research on multi attachments/ role of father: strength
cards.definition: There are practical applications of the research.e.g.\xe2\x80\xa2 development of parenting classes training for males to develop skills they may not demonstrate spontaneously.\xe2\x80\xa2 increase the paternity leave men are entitled to after their child has been born.\xe2\x80\xa2 the research can determine whether men are as capable as women in careers involving childcare, potentially reducing the stigma surrounding men caring for childre

cards.term: Evaluation of research on multiple attachments/role of the father: economic implications
cards.definition: \xe2\x98\xb9 There are economic implications of the research. E.g. if more fathers remain at home they will contribute less to the economy consequently, and funding of new legal requirements for paternity leave costs the government money OR \xf0\x9f\x98\x8amore mothers returning to work will contribute to the economy and the gender pay gap may be reduced if parental roles are regarded as more equal.

cards.term: 3 aspects of caregiver-infant interactions which help to develop and maintain attachment
cards.definition: Skin to skin contactInteractional synchronyReciprocity

cards.term: Evidence on the role of skin to skin contact in attachment formation
cards.definition: Klaus and Kennel: 28 new-borns...Group 1: only had contact with mother during feeding in the first 3 days (normal practice),Group 2: extended contact with mother lasting several hours a day One month later mothers in 2 cuddled babies\' more/made greater eye contact etc. Effects still noticeable a year later suggesting that skin to skin in a critical period plays a role in the formation of attachments.

cards.term: Evaluation of evidence on skin to skin contact
cards.definition: -The research has practical application = useful e.g. it led to hospitals encouraging mother & infants to room together.-The results of the study may lack population validity= the sample was not representative e.g. most Ps were unmarried teenagers from disadvantaged backgrounds who may have been responding to the extra attention they received from the researchers.-Replications have shown small effects or no effect at all = research is not reliable i.e. the importance of skin to skin contact hasn\'t been demonstrated consistently.
How a caregiver and infant\'s behaviour become finely synchronised to produce simultaneous, co-ordinated sequences of movements/ communication/ emotion.

cards.term: Evidence on the role of interactional synchrony in attachment formation
cards.definition: Murray & Trevarthen: After a period of real-time interaction between mothers and their new-borns via a video monitor, a pre-recorded tape of the mother was played. The babies became acutely distressed, grimaced and averted their gaze. Older children become more distressed & attempted to draw the mother back into interaction, suggesting the baby is an active and intentional partner in the communication, not just a passive responder; demonstrating a need to be in interactional synchrony with their caregiver.

cards.term: Evaluation of evidence on interactional synchrony
cards.definition: X Interactional synchrony appears to not be necessary in the formation of attachments. This means attachments can form when synchronised interaction doesn\'t occur e.g. LeVine et al showed that mothers in Kenya rarely cuddle and interact closely with their babies, although they are attentive and have secure attachments.
Interactions between adult and infant that result in mutual behaviour, where individuals motivate responses from each other.

cards.term: Evidence on the role of reciprocity in attachment formation
cards.definition: Melzoff & Moore: presented2-3 week olds with facial expressions. After the behaviour shown, dummies removed and immediate response recorded to be assessed by independent judges for likeness to the behaviours.Independent ratings showed an association between the model\'s and child\'s behaviour i.e. the babies imitated specific facial or hand movements suggesting children are innately social beings and take an active, intentional part in forming the attachment from the start by demonstrating reciprocity, before they have been reinforced for it.

x There are problems with testing infant behaviour = decreases validity of findings e.g. the behaviour of babies has to be interpreted by researchers, and this be biased by researchers\' expectations. (HOWEVER, Melzoff and Moore overcame this issue by using independent judges).x Jacobsen found babies responded similarly way to inanimate object = reciprocity may be a reflex to any visual stimulus, and not a specifically intentionally social behaviour e.g. responding in the same way to an approaching pen as a human.\xe2\x9c\x93 The role of reciprocity appears to be important in the formation of attachments = the concept has predictive validity e.g. Heimann found infants who demonstrate more reciprocity from birth have a better quality attachment at 3 months.

cards.term: General evaluation of research on caregiver-infant interaction
cards.definition: X Conclusions from research may be socially sensitive = it has implications for the way people live their lives e.g. if research suggests mothers need to be with babies, returning to work may be discouraged.XThere are practical issues with conducting research = reduced validity of data e.g. babies are often asleep or being fed, meaning data is incomplete.

cards.term: How does caregiver-infant interaction lead to attachment formation?
cards.definition: The behaviours make contact more enjoyable so that interaction is reinforcing for both parties, so that interaction increases, and in turn, a stronger attachment is formed.
Developed a the Strange Situation method for measuring attachment type of infants

\xe2\x80\xa2A controlled observation of 100 middle class US mother/child pairs. During a period of 25 minutes, infants went through sequence of 3 minute episodes e.g. infant & mother enter room, stranger enters, mother leaves infant & stranger, child left alone, mother returns. \xe2\x80\xa2Important variables are separation anxiety, stranger anxiety, & reunion behaviour.
15% babies were type A, 70% type B, 15% type C
Indifferent to mum/plays independently, low separation anxiety when mum leaves, can be comforted by stranger as much as by mum, low level stranger anxiety.
Infants are happy with mum, distressed when she leaves, comforted at reunion & wary of stranger.
Anxious resistant: Tearful and doesn\'t play easily, the most distressed without mum, seeks comfort at reunion but resists it, resists stranger.

\xe2\x80\xa2There are different types of attachment that we can differentiate between on the basis of observable attachment behaviours. \xe2\x80\xa2"The Maternal Sensitivity Hypothesis": Type of attachment is based on mother\'s sensitivity & responsiveness to the child.

\xe2\x80\xa2 A controlled observation was used with clearly defined behavioural categories = it\'s been possible to test the reliability of the findings in many replications e.g. the 3 types have consistently emerged as the most important types of attachment, and there has been found to be a 94% agreement between observers in classifying children.\xe2\x80\xa2 Type of attachment has been shown to influence later development = results have predictive validity e.g. attachment type at 18m can predict social confidence at nursery age 3; empathy and independence at age 5.

\xe2\x80\xa2 The indicators of each attachment type may not be valid = behaviours demonstrated by the babies was subject to interpretation e.g. "proximity seeking" and "maintenance of proximity" are used as indicators of a secure attachment, but they could equally demonstrate insecurity.\xe2\x80\xa2 The Type A/B/C categorisation system may be over-simplistic = individual differences aren\'t fully accounted e.g. Main and Solomon led to the identification of a 4th type of attachment, which they called disorganised, common in children who have been abused.
Aimed to investigate whether Ainsworth\'s findings were replicated in other cultures.
A meta-analysis of Strange Situation data from 32 studies in 8 countries.

German infants had highest percentage of anxious-avoidant attachments.Israeli & Japanese infants had highest percentage of anxious-resistant attachments. The most common form of attachment in all cultures was secure.

The SS is a useful tool for measuring attachment, with differing child rearing norms between cultures leading to varying percentages of types of attachment e.g. German parents are more likely to encourage independence, whereas Japanese and Israeli babies are rarely left alone.

\xe2\x9c\x93A meta-analysis was used = data from a large range of studies was used, increasing the reliability of the findings.X Using the Strange Situation to make judgements on children raised in other cultures is "imposing an etic" = it demonstrates ethnocentrism , with a bias towards western cultures e.g. US child rearing is are more likely to result in a so-called "secure attachment", assumed to be the "best" type to be.X Results showed around one-and-a-half times the variation within countries as between countries = cross cultural variation may have been exaggerated e.g. there are more individual differences demonstrated within babies of the same country than between countries, as within any country there are cultural differences (e.g. urban vs rural).
1) Learning Theory2) Bowlby\'s monotropic theory
The theorythat attachments develop through conditioning processes
When a response produced naturally by an UCS becomes associated with a NS, not usually associated with that particular response.

cards.term: How classical conditioning relates to attachment
cards.definition: Food (UCS) produces positive feelings (UCR). If the caregiver (NS) is consistently paired with food (UCS), they become a CS, producing the CR of positive emotion towards the caregiver.
learning occurring via reinforcement of behaviour, thus increasing the chances of the behaviour occurring again

cards.term: How operant conditioning relates to attachment
cards.definition: Infants are positively reinforced with food for approaching caregiver, and negatively reinforced by the subsequent reduction in hunger. Reinforcement increases likelihood of the of the behaviour being repeated, making the formation of an attachment more likely.

cards.term: 4 features of Bowlby\'s monotropic theory of attachment
cards.definition: Innate mechanismsCritical periodMonotropyInternal working model

Bowlby argued humans evolved attachment bonds though natural selection: offspring that stayed close to caregivers were more likely to survive. Behaviours that evolved to enable this to happen are called "social releasers" e.g. smiling.

Bowlby argued children should receive continuous care from the primary attachment figure for the first 30 months of life- the \'critical period\'. If an attachment doesn\'t form in this time, there will be long term consequences in how they will be able to form relationships in the future.

Bowlby argued that the first attachment to form acts as a template for all future attachments- an "internal working model". This means that there is continuity from infancy to adulthood in terms of emotional "type".
Bowlby argued children have an innate need to form single and exclusive attachment to one primary attachment figure (usually the mother).

cards.term: Evidence to use for Bowlby\'s concept of innate mechanisms
cards.definition: Lorenz\'s study supports this concept.Melzoff and Moore\'s study supports this concept.

cards.term: Evidence to use for Bowlby\'s concept of a critical period
cards.definition: Genie case study supports this concept.Czech twins case study refutes this concept.

cards.term: Evidence to use for Bowlby\'s concept of monotropy
cards.definition: Schaffer and Emerson\'s study refutes this concept

cards.term: Evidence to use for Bowlby\'s concept of an internal working model
cards.definition: Harlow\'s study supports this concept.Bowlby\'s juvenile thieves study supports this.

-Use of evidence to support refute individual concepts + evaluation of this evidence-Bowlby\'s theory can/has been applied to real life = practically useful...e.g.WORKING MOTHERS have been encouraged not to return to work until after the critical period is over.e.g.SOCIAL/WELFARE POLICY changed to place children with foster parents rather than children\'s homes to facilitate monotropy.e.g.HEALTHCARE POLICY changed to allow parents to stay with children when hospitalised to prevent disrupting the critical period.
The theory that there is consistency between early emotional experiences and later relationships.

cards.term: Evidence from CHILDHOOD RELATIONSHIPS for the internal working model/continuity hypothesis
cards.definition: Lieberman: Secure children go on to be more socially skilled in their friendships.Hartup et al: Children with more secure attachments are more popular at nursery and engage in more social interactions with other children.Moore: Secure teens were less likely to engage in risky sexual activity but were more likely to have had sex.Myron Wilson & Smith: Avoidant children were more likely to be victims of bullying, whilst resistant children were most likely to be bullies.Feeny and Noller: Avoidant university students were most likely to split up from their partners.All of the above evidence suggests that early attachment type continues into later childhood.

cards.term: Evidence from ADULT RELATIONSHIPS for the internal working model/continuity hypothesis
cards.definition: Hazan & Shaver: The "love quiz" was published in a newspaper. Part 1 assessed the relationship of the P with parents and part 2 assessed current beliefs about romantic love.59% of Ps categorised as secure, 25% avoidant and 19% resistant. There was a correlation between early and adult relationships...e.g. \xe2\x80\xa2 adults secure as infants had no trouble getting close to others and were happy to depend on others/be depended on.\xe2\x80\xa2 adults anxious-avoidant as infants demonstrated difficulties in developing intimacy and lacked trust in their partners.\xe2\x80\xa2 adults who anxious-resistant as infants demonstrated intense desire for closeness and were scared of rejection/ abandonment.Conclusion: early attachment type continues into adulthood in romantic relationships.

cards.term: Evaluation of research on the influence of early attachment on childhood/adult relationships
cards.definition: X Most studies assess early attachment type retrospectively = reduces reliability of evidence e.g. it is unrealistic to suppose that adults have a clear memory of their parents\' behaviour towards them as children.X Most studies assess attachment type through self-report = reduced validity of the evidence e.g. social desirability bias may affect individuals\' report of their own behaviour within a relationship.X Evidence is correlational because continuity hypothesis can\'t be ethically tested experimentally= it can only be concluded that there is a relationship (not cause and effect) between early and late attachment styles e.g. there may be intervening EVs which underlie the relationships such as temperament.X The IWM is deterministic = pessimistic e.g. children with insecure attachments as infants will not be able to form secure attachments in future (HOWEVER some evidence shows that attachment type can change, so pessimism may be unjustified).
When a child has had a secure relationship or bond which has been broken or lost e.g. due to bereavement/divorce/hospitalisation.
Deprivation of attachment during the critical period will cause LONG TERM emotional, physical, social and intellectual underdevelopmente.g. "affectionless psychopathy"
An inability to form relationships and a disregard for the feelings of others), which can in turn, lead to antisocial behaviour

cards.term: Evidence for LONG TERM effects of deprivation
cards.definition: Bowlby: 44 Juvenile Thieves Studyto investigate the link between maternal deprivation and later antisocial behaviour.44 juvenile thieves compared to a law-abiding but emotionally disturbed control group. Boys interviewed about themselves, their behaviour & childhood experiences. Members of family were interviewed about family history.Results: 17 of the delinquent group had experienced frequent separations before age 2. 12 of these were diagnosed as "affectionless psychopaths". 2 of the control group had experienced prolonged deprivation.Conclusion: The anti-social behaviour in thief group was related to the higher incidence of maternal deprivation.

cards.term: Evaluation of evidence for LONG TERM effects of deprivation
cards.definition: X Conclusions are based on data gathered retrospectively = reduces reliability of evidence e.g. it is unrealistic to suppose that the juveniles/ caregivers had a clear memory of the boys\' early childhoods.X Bowlby assessed the boys as "affectionless psychopaths". This means the conclusions are based on biased data i.e. his assessments of the boys may have been influenced by his expectations.

cards.term: Overall evaluation for Bowlby\'s maternal deprivation hypothesis
cards.definition: Some argue that Bowlby was incorrect about the long term effects of deprivation e.g. and that he was failing to distinguish between deprivation and privation (maybe the extreme effects he predicted are more relevant to privation than deprivation).

cards.term: Evidence that Bowlby\'s maternal deprivation hypothesis IS appropriate to predict the effect of privation rather than deprivation.
cards.definition: Genie: found at 13 after 12 yrs of extreme privation. She was almost entirely mute, with a vocabulary of about 20 words and a few short phrases. She constantly sniffed, spat and clawed. She made some improvements after being given specialist treatment inc. limited language and social skills. However, after poor maintenance of the treatment she lost many of the skills she had gained.This suggests that privation in the critical period results in irreversible effects on development, as a child fails to develop an internal working model.

cards.term: Evidence that Bowlby\'s maternal deprivation hypothesis ISN\'T appropriate to predict the effect of privation rather than deprivation.
cards.definition: Czech twins: between 18m-7yrs they were locked in a cellar and physically abused. The twins were moved into care at 7, then fostered at 9.At 7 the twins had no speech, were suffering from malnutrition, totally lacking in social ability and were easily frightened by others. As adults they good social skills and loving relationships with their foster parents and extended family etc This suggests that even the effects of privation in the critical period CAN be reversed with adequate aftercare.

cards.term: Discussion of the contradictory evidence on Bowlby\'s maternal deprivation.
cards.definition: The circumstances of the case studies had many key differences, leading to contradictory findings e.g. in contrast to the twins, Genie was suspected early on to have learning difficulties, she experienced privation for longer than the twins and had disrupted aftercare.
Never having formed an attachment.
Being reared in a residential organisation.
Conducted the Romanian orphan studies on the effects of institutionalisation.
111 Romanian orphans compared to a control group of British adopted children (adoption occurred before 6 months) on several measures until age 4.

At the start, half the Romanians had showed intellectual deficits and most were underweight (vs. none of the controls). 4 years later there were no significant intellectual or physical differences. Romanian children who\'d arrived in the UK before 6 months showed most improvement.
The effects of institutionalisation in infancy can be reversed (this is contradicted by follow up studies).

cards.term: Rutter: findings for follow up of orphans age 6
cards.definition: 8.9% Romanian children adopted before 6 months vs 26.1% Romanian children adopted after 6 months showed "marked disinhibition" in their attachments (vs. 3.8% of UK controls). Also, inattention/overactivity; autistic-like social difficulties; and cognitive impairment, especially in those who had been adopted later.

cards.term: Rutter: findings for follow up of orphans age 11
cards.definition: As in the age 6 follow up, plus elevated levels of emotional difficulties

cards.term: Rutter: findings for follow up of orphans age 15
cards.definition: Emotional, conduct and peer-relationship problems had emerged. One third of the Romanian children placed for adoption after the age of six months experienced problems that warranted the intervention of professional educational, psychological or psychiatric services.

cards.term: Rutter: conclusion from follow up studies
cards.definition: The effects of institutionalisation in infancy can be reversed HOWEVER not if attachments aren\'t formed until after 6m (this seems to be a critical period)

-Large sample= results are likely to provide a reliable picture of the effects of institutionalisation e.g. in contrast to the previous studies of privation which were one off case studies.-The findings can be applied to real life= useful in shaping policy e.g. the recommendation that adoption occur before 6m whenever possible.-The study was carried out longitudinally= increases validity of the findings e.g. the individual differences between children are controlled for.

The age at which a child was adopted may not have been decided randomly = extraneous factors may have influenced conclusions on the age related effects of adoption e.g. children who naturally demonstrated more alertness and sociability may have been picked for adoption sooner than those who were already less developed.

-mental retardation/low IQ -delayed language development -quasi-autism -disinhibited attachment -disorganised attachment -delayed physical development, eg restricted growth-impaired adult relationships
Yielding to majority influence pressure
Internalisation, compliance, identification

cards.term: What is the weakest form of conformity?
cards.definition: Compliance
An individual maintains their private views but goes along with the majority publicly in order to gain approval
Conformity to a social role
An individual changes their public and private views to conform with a majority
NSI and ISI
An explanation for internalisation: the motivational force to look to others for guidance in order to be correct

cards.term: What situation does ISI usually occur?
cards.definition: Occurs in unfamiliar/ambiguous situations
Sherif
Ps were shown a still point of light in the dark and estimated how far it moved (it appears to move because of the autokinetic effect). There was no right answer.
When alone, Ps developed their own estimates. In the group, judgements gradually became closer and closer until a group norm developed (an estimate they agreed on) because of ISI.
An explanation for compliance: the motivational force to change behaviour in tbe accepted by the group
Asch

cards.term: What was the aim of Asch\'s Study?
cards.definition: The investigate the degree to which individuals would conform to the majority who gave obviously wrong answers

cards.term: What was the procedure for Asch\'s Study?
cards.definition: -123 American Male Student Volunteers- 1 naive P in a group of 7/8-An unambiguous test to match a standard line with A,B or C-12/18 trials were critical-Real PP answered last or next to last
In critical trials participants conformed to majority 37% of time. 75% conformed at least once. This is a demonstration of compliance.
-Artificial task- Unrepresentative sample-Demand characteristics-Ethical issues (deception. protection of participants)

cards.term: Factors effecting conformity studied by Asch
cards.definition: -Group Size-Unanimity-Task Difficulty-Anonymity

cards.term: What happens to conformity rates as the task difficulty increased and why?
cards.definition: When stimulus and comparison lines made closer in length the conformity rate increased, as ISI increases.

cards.term: What happens to conformity rates as the majority size decreased and why?
cards.definition: Conformity decreases below the 37% level as no. confederates decreases: 3= 32%, 2= 13%, 1= 3%. Fewer confederates= reduced NSI.

cards.term: What happens to conformity rates when unanimity is broken and why?
cards.definition: if the na\xc3\xafve P had one supporter conformity reduced to 5.5%ans the presence of a supporter decreased NSI.

cards.term: What happens to conformity rates when Ps can give answers anonymously and why?
cards.definition: When the incorrect majority called out their answers but the na\xc3\xafve participant wrote his down privately, conformity dropped to just over 12% as anonymity decreases NSI.

cards.term: What are the cross cultural differences in conformity rates and why?
cards.definition: In a meta-analysis of Asch replications Smith and Bond found that the average conformity rate in collectivist countries was 37% vs 25% in in individualistic.

cards.term: What are the individual differences in conformity rates and why?
cards.definition: Perrin and Spencer found a conformity of 0.25% amongst science and engineering students vs youths on probation who had similar rates to the original study. Greater confidence/higher IQ= decreased ISI.

\xe2\x98\xb9 They are difficult to demonstrate separately because the resultant conformity differs only in terms of in terms of whether there is private dis/agreement which cannot be observed. \xe2\x98\xb9 NSI and ISI don\'t explain all cases of conformity. This means they aren\'t the only reasons for conformity e.. identification and Social Identity Theory are more appropriate in some cases...\xe2\x98\xb9For NSI: There are individual differences in how much people want to be liked by others (need for affiliation (N-Affil)). This means noteveryone will conform due to this desire e.g. the behaviour seen in Asch can\'t be generalised to all individuals...
Features of an environment the affect the degree to which individuals yield to group pressures
Personal characteristics that affect the degree to whcih individuals yield to group pressures
Zimbardo\'s Stanford Prison experiment

cards.term: What were the aims of Zimbardo\'s experiment?
cards.definition: The extent to which people conform to roles of guard/prisoner in a simulation of prison life.

cards.term: What was the sample in Zimbardo\'s study?
cards.definition: 75 male university student volunteers

cards.term: What happened to the Zimbardo\'s prisoners after around 36 hours?
cards.definition: The participants in the study started to cry and have a mental breakdown

cards.term: How many days did it take for Zimbardo\'s study to be over?
cards.definition: 6 days

cards.term: Positive evaluation points for Zimbardo\'s study
cards.definition: -Prison reforms which occurred afterwards-Ethical issues: avoided by gaining informed consent, choosing emotionally stable Ps, calling of study early.

cards.term: What are the negative evaluation points for Zimbardo\'s Study?
cards.definition: -Zimbardo\'s dual role reduced his objectivity in terms of calling off the experiment & his own behaviour affected the way in which events unfolded, thus the validity of the findings could be questioned-Demand characteristics: the majority of a group of students who hadn\'t heard of the study could accurately guess what it was about/ what happened from the procedure-Results having been replicated e.g. Reicher and Haslam 20016, so poor temporal validity.
Complying with the demands of an authority figure

cards.term: What was the sample for Milgram\'s study?
cards.definition: 40 Male 20-50 volunteers

cards.term: What were the people who volunteered for Milgram\'s study told?
cards.definition: They were told it was a memory test
Yale University

cards.term: What was the punishment system in Milgram\'s study?
cards.definition: Increasing electric shocks given to the learner by the teacher if they gave an incorrect answer15 to 450 volts

cards.term: How did Milgram authenticate his study to participants?
cards.definition: The teacher was given a 45 volt electric shot

cards.term: How many participants in Milgrams study went to 300 volts?
What percentage of participants in Milgrams study went to 450 volts?
What were the conclusions for Milgrams experiment?
cards.definition: People will obey orders that distress us or go against thier moral code

cards.term: What were the ethical issues with Milgram\'s study?
cards.definition: -Psychological harm e.g. 1 had a seizure.-Right to Withdraw reduced by having verbal prompts to continue.-Deception: told it was memory and Learning test/ shocks were real

cards.term: What are the ethical counterarguments for Milgram\'s study?
cards.definition: -Ends justify the means?Most said they were glad to have taken part.-35% did leave before the end.-Presumptive consent had been gained from psychiatrists who deemed it acceptable.

cards.term: What were the methodological criticisms of Milgram\'s study?
cards.definition: -Unrepresentative sample-Giving electric shocks is an artificial task-Demand characteristics- Ps may have guessed it was fake.

cards.term: What were the counterarguments to the methodological criticisms of Milgram\'s study?
cards.definition: -Women have been shown to have even higher rates, and cross culturally rates are universally high.-Hofling demonstrated 21/22 nurses would obey in a natural hospital setting when asked to give a potentially nurses asked to give a potentially lethal dose of meds.-Ps reported they believed they had been giving real shocks.

cards.term: What were the situational factors in Milgram\'s experiment?
cards.definition: Proximity LocationUniform
A situational explanation for obedience. We move between 2 states: the autonomous state & agentic state. In the agentic state, our sense of responsibility is shifted to the authority figure.
A mental state where we feel no personal responsibility for our behaviour because we believe ourselves to be acting for an authority figure. i.e as an agent
They are free to behave to their own principles and therefore feel a sense of responsibility for their own actions

A situational explanation for obedience: we are more likely to obey orders perceived as legitimate from people who we perceive to have a legitimate authority over us, justified by their position within an legitimate system.

The presence of these is a situational explanation for obedience. They prevent a person from acknowledging the consequences of their actions, so it becomes easier to perform actions which otherwise seem "out of character".

cards.term: What is the evidence for agency theory as an explanation of obedience?
cards.definition: In Milgram\'s 2 teacher condition (when P paired with another teacher (confederate) who delivered shocks), obedience rose to 93% as their presence allowed them to shift responsibility and therefore remain in the agentic state.In the social support condition (when 2 other \'teachers\' (confederates) refused to obey) obedience dropped to 10%, as their presence made it difficult for Ps to remain in the agentic state.

cards.term: What is the evidence for legitimacy of authority as an explanation of obedience?
cards.definition: In the shift of setting condition  (Milgram\'s experiment moved to run-down offices rather than Yale University) obedience dropped to 48% because perceived legitimacy of system reduced.In the absent experimenter condition (when the experimenter left and gave instructions by telephone) obedience dropped to 20% as perceived legitimacy of the authority figure reduced.

cards.term: What is the evidence for buffers as an explanation of obedience?
cards.definition: In the proximity condition (when the learner was in the same room as the teacher) obedience dropped to 40%.In the touch proximity condition (when the teacher had to force the learner\'s hand down onto the shock plate) obedience dropped to 30%.Both conditions removed buffers so Ps had to acknowledge the consequences of their actions.

cards.term: What is a dispositional explanation of obedience?
cards.definition: Personality (The Authoritarian personality) is the cause of obedience rather than the situation.
A type of personality that Adorno argued saying that they were susceptible to obey people who are in authority.
They are especially obedient to authority. Extreme respect for authority figures. They show contempt for people with inferior social status.

cards.term: What is the cause of having an Authoritarian personality?
cards.definition: Strict parenting
F scale

cards.term: What is the evidence for the Authoritarian Personality as an explanation for obedience?
cards.definition: Elms and Milgram (66) conducted a follow up study using 20 obedient and 20 defiant Ps. Ps who gave the HIGHEST shock level had stronger authoritarian characters, and blamed THE LEARNER rather than THEMSELVES for the obedience.

cards.term: What are the evaluation points for the Authoritarian personality explanation?
cards.definition: -Politically biased, being associated with right wing beliefs.-Measurement of AP using the F scale may be invalidated by response bias in answering the questions which are all in the same direction.-Can\'t explain how whole societies become obedient.-Evidence is correlational (levels of education may be confounding)

cards.term: What is resistance to social influence?
cards.definition: Non-conformity with a majority or disobedience to an authority

cards.term: What are the explanations for resistance to social influence?
cards.definition: Social supportLocus of control

cards.term: What is the evidence for social support as an explanation for resistance to OBEDIENCE?
cards.definition: Social support condition of Milgram\'s study: when two other \'teachers\' (confederates) refused to obey, obedience dropped from 65% to 10%, as Ps are shifted to their autonomous state.

cards.term: What is the evidence for social support as an explanation for resistance to CONFORMITY?
cards.definition: Asch (1951) found that if the na\xc3\xafve participant had one supporter they were less likely to conform. Asch found that a break in unanimity by just one person reduced conformity from 37% to 5.5%, as social support decreases NSI.

cards.term: Evaluation points for social support as an explanation for resistance to social influence.
cards.definition: Link the evaluation of the evidence (Asch/Milgram) to the question.
A stable aspect of the personality, relating to the individual\'s beliefs about the causes of successes/failures.It is measured along a dimension of "high internal" to "high external".

cards.term: What is meant by high Internal LOC?
cards.definition: The belief that things happen as a results of choices and decisions. Having a high Internal LOC is believed to make individuals more resistant to social pressures.
