cards.term: What is meant by High External LOC?
cards.definition: The belief that things happen as a result of luck, fate or other external forces. Linked to reduced resistance to social influence.

cards.term: What\'s the evidence for LOC as an explanation for resistance to CONFORMITY?
cards.definition: Shute (75) exposed undergraduates to peers who expressed either a conservative or liberal attitude towards alcohol and drug taking. The conformity of the students with internal and external LOC was measured.Undergraduates with an internal LOC conformed less to expressing pro-drug attitudes.

cards.term: What\'s the evidence for LOC as an explanation for resistance to OBEDIENCE?
cards.definition: Oliner and Oliner (88) interviewed two groups of non-Jewish people who had lived through the Holocaust in Nazi Germany. They compared 406 people who had protected and rescued Jews from the Nazis and 126 people who had not done this on a measure of their locus of control.The group that rescued the Jews had scores demonstrating an internal locus of control.

cards.term: Evaluation for LOC as an explanation for resistance to social influence.
cards.definition: -There\'s a significant correlation between LOC and predisposition towards NSI BUT NOT ISI. -LOC is only important in new situations ( in familiar situations, habits were more important for predicting behaviour)-Analyses of obedience/ conformity studies show that people have become more independent over the past 40 years whilst also showing an increase in external LOC which contradicts the theory.-LOC is assessed using self- report measuring beliefs out of context= reduces validity.
A type of social influence that motivates individuals to reject established majority group norms.

cards.term: What factors are key to a persuasive message in order to achieve minority influence?
cards.definition: -Consistency-Flexibility-Commitment

cards.term: What is Consistency in terms of Minorty SI?
cards.definition: Repeating the minority group opinion repeatedly, in the same way. This needs to occur between people in the minority group (synchronic consistency) and over time (diachronic consistency).

cards.term: What is Flexibilty in terms of Minority SI?
cards.definition: Members of the minority must be seem to be accepting of reasonable and valid counterarguments, or else put the majority off by appearing to be dogmatic.

cards.term: What is Commitment in terms of Minority SI?
cards.definition: Minorities can engage in extreme activities to draw attention to their vision and persuade the majority of their deep belief (the augmentation principle).

cards.term: What was the procedure for Moscovici\'s study?
cards.definition: Participants placed into 32 groups of 6 with two confederates in each group. They were all shown 36 blue slides, which varied in intensify. Consistent condition: Confederates said that all the slides were green.Inconsistent condition: Said 24 were green and 12 were blue

cards.term: What were the findings and conclusions for Mocovici\'s study?
cards.definition: Consistent condition: 8.2% agreement rate, 32% agreed at least onceInconsistent condition: 1.28%

cards.term: Which aspect of minority influence does Moscovici\'s study demonstrate?
cards.definition: Consistency.

cards.term: Which study supports the importance of flexibility to minority Influence?
cards.definition: Nemeth

Groups of 4 (3 real participants and 1 confederate) had to decide how much compensation to pay the victim of a ski-lift accident. The confederate was instructed to act as a minority by arguing for a low amount in one of 2 conditions a) where he refused to change his position at all b) where he demonstrated compromise by offering a slightly higher amount than he did to start with.
An inflexible confederate In condition had no effect on the majority, whereas when flexible the Ps changed their opinion to a lower amount.

cards.term: What are the evaluation points on the research on minority influence?
cards.definition: - When Moscovici allowed Ps to be anonymous their agreement with the minority was greater, showing consistency to be more important in influencing the majority than first shown.-Many tasks in MI use artificial tasks, unlike real life scenarios e.g. political views, which the phenomenon of MI may be applied to.-Use of small groups means that the level of MI demonstrated may not reflect that in real life situations e.g. the minority of 2/6 is a significant proportion of the group. -In real life maj/minority are hard to identify, esp as other factors such as power are also important It\'s difficult to replicate this.
This occurs when whole societies, rather than individuals, adopt new attitudes, beliefs and ways of doing things.

cards.term: What are the stages for minority influence to create social change?
cards.definition: -Drawing your attention to an issue-Cognitive Conflict-Consistency-Augmentation Principle-Snowball effect -Social Cryptoamnesia
Atkinson and Shiffrin

cards.term: 3 components of the Multistore Model of Memory are...
cards.definition: 1) Sensory register, 2) STM, 3) LTM

cards.term: In the MSM what enters the sensory register?
cards.definition: Environmental stimuli

cards.term: In the MSM how does information pass from the SR to the STM?
cards.definition: Paying attention

cards.term: In the MSM how does information pass from the STM to the LTM?
cards.definition: Rehearsal

cards.term: In the MSM how is information maintained in the STM?
cards.definition: Rehearsal

cards.term: 2 roles of rehearsal in the MSM
cards.definition: 1) Maintenance of info in the STM2) Storage in LTM

cards.term: In the MSM what is it called when information is recalled?
cards.definition: Retrieval

cards.term: How is info coded in the SR?
cards.definition: Modality specifically

cards.term: What is the capacity of the SR?
cards.definition: All sensory data

cards.term: What is the duration of on memory traces in the SR?
cards.definition: 1/4 second approx (depends on the sense)

cards.term: How is info coded in the STM?
cards.definition: Acoustically (words which sound the same get confused)

cards.term: What is the capacity of the STM?
cards.definition: 7 +/- 2 chunks (shown using immediate recall of increasingly long digit sequences in the "digit span" technique)

cards.term: What is the duration of on memory traces in the STM?
cards.definition: 18-30 seconds (tested using an increasingly long recall interval for trigrams whilst conducting a distractor task to prevent rehearsal)

cards.term: How is info coded in the LTM?
cards.definition: Semantically (words which mean the same are confused)

cards.term: What is the capacity of the LTM?
cards.definition: Unlimited (Waagener showed this, testing himself on thousands of diary entries over 6 years)

cards.term: What is the duration of on memory traces in the LTM?
cards.definition: Unlimited (Bahrick tested Ps aged 17-74 on highschool yearbook names/photos, with very high recall even in the oldest Ps)

cards.term: Case study evidence for the MSM
cards.definition: Milner et al: HM had his hippocampus removed to reduce the symptoms of epilepsy. Although his STM remained normal he could not retain any info about family, world events, or remember new people he met. He could remember most things from before the op.This supports the MSM as it demonstrates that STM and LTM are distinct stores.

Murdock: Ps given 15-20 letters to remember in 90 secs. Several items from the beginning and end are recalled, but those from the middle are less likely to be recalled. The primacy effect is caused by info. at the start of a list passing into LTM as it\'s rehearsed whilst the recency effect is a result of the last 5-9 items being present in STM. This supports the MSM as it demonstrates STM and LTM are separate.

Makes clear predictions about memory, therefore falsifiable e.g. Murdock\'s experiment, gathering objective evidence to support, or refute, the model...The MSM inspired a lot of research. This means it has been an influential model e.g. although some evidence has refuted the model, it has been used as a basis from which more recent models such as the WMM were developed from...

Oversimplistic: other researchers have found evidence for different types of STM (KF study) and LTM (Corkin study on HM)"Flashbulb memories" exist, where people have a very vivid memory for emotional events without rehearsal.= must be alternative routes to LTM other than those originally shown...
An active store, where info. is maintained and manipulated for everyday tasks (previously known as the STM)

cards.term: What are the VSS, PL and EB known as?
cards.definition: Slave systems
\xe2\x88\x99 Attention control system\xe2\x88\x99 Coordinates slave systems\xe2\x88\x99 Very limited capacity (can\'t store info.)\xe2\x88\x99 Process information in any sensory form
The "sound system"
-Inner ear-Holds/ processes acoustically coded memory traces (inc. sub-vocal speech)-Limited capacity
-Stores integrated information from other stores to form a single memory-Maintains time sequencing.
-Inner voice-Subvocally rehearses information-Limited capacity (depends on time to say something rather than no. items- approx. 2 seconds)
-Inner eye-Holds visual and spatial information (what things look like and their physical relationship to other things)-Limited capacity (4 items)

Shallice & Warrington: KF suffered brain damage- his short-term forgetting of verbal stimuli (sound) was much greater than his forgetting of visually presented letters and digits heard.= there are separate components of the WM which can be damaged independently of each other (PL was damaged whilst VSS remained intact).

Gathercole & Baddeley: P\'s had to do 2 tasks simultaneously- a visual tracking task & another visual task (describing the letter F) OR a verbal task.Visual tracking task performance was impaired by the 2nd visual task but not by the verbal task.= there are separate components to the WM, each with a limited capacity: 2 tasks can be done simultaneously if they use separate components (e.g. PL and VSS), but if they use the same one (e.g. VSS), performance will be impaired.

-STM viewed as active rather than passive = increased validity of the model in comparison to the MSM i.e. reflects how the WM is responsible for a range of tasks such as verbal reasoning, comprehension, reading, problem solving and visual and spatial processing... -PET brain scans have showed that different areas of the brain are active when undertaking verbal and visual tasks = biological evidence for WMM i.e. it supports that the hypothetical stores of the model exist in different areas of the brain...

-Little is known about the central executive= model is vague e.g. unclear what the CE is, its exact role in attention etc, despite it being the most important part of the model...- Brain damaged patients have demonstrated their ability to both succeed and fail at tasks which are assumed to be controlled by the CE= model is too simplistic e.g. it is likely that the CE itself should be further divided into separate components...
episodic, semantic, procedural
A type of long-term memory that involves the recollection of specific events, situations and experiences.
A type of long-term memory of how to perform different actions and skills.
A type of LTM for knowledge about the world

cards.term: Differences between episodic vs procedural memory
cards.definition: -E is declarative, so can be consciously recalled and verbally expressed vs P is non-declarative so is unconsciously recalled and difficult to verbally express- E is more likely to be affected by amnesia than P-Stored in different brain regions

cards.term: Differences between semantic vs procedural memory
cards.definition: -S is declarative, so can be consciously recalled and verbally expressed vs P is non-declarative so is unconsciously recalled and difficult to verbally express-Stored in different brain regions

cards.term: Differences between episodic and semantic memory
cards.definition: -E memory is personal to the individual vs S is general knowledge-E is "time-stamped" vs S is not.

cards.term: Evidence for different types of LTM: Tulving
cards.definition: Tulving injected himself with radioactive gold, and used a scanner to monitor blood flow as he thought about semantic memories (e.g. historical facts) or episodic memories (e.g. childhood holidays). Blood flow increased to either the back or front of the brain depending on the task.This supports that there are different forms of LTM, stored in physically distinct areas of the brain.

cards.term: Evidence for different types of LTM: Corkin
cards.definition: Corkin trained HM over several days on a motor task. His performance improved with practice. Several days later, despite having no conscious memory of the training session, he was as good at the task as he had been at the end of his training. This supports that there are different forms of LTM, as it is possible to damage episodic memory whilst procedural memory remains intact.
Interference and retrieval failure

The way in which 2 memories compete, resulting in forgetting of 1 of the memories.This is an explanation of forgetting of information that was stored in LTM. This is more likely to occur when the 2 memories are similar to each other. T
Proactive and retroactive
The disruptive effect of prior learning on the recall of new information
The disruptive effect of new learning on the recall of old information

Underwood:-Ps asked to learn word lists (1 - 15+). -Recall of the last list was tested 24 hours later.-Ps who had learned 15 or more word lists had recall of 20% for the last list vs 80% if they hadn\'t learned any earlier lists, recall was 80%.= previously learned information can disrupt memory for more recently learned information.

Baddeley and Hitch (1977)-Rugby players were asked to recall the names of teams they played earlier in the season. Players had played in varying no.s of games due to injury.-Whether a team was correctly recalled was related to the number of intervening games played rather than the time that had passed since the game.=subsequently learned information can disrupt memory for previously learned information.

-Real life evidence that supports the theory = increased ecological validity of the theory e.g. interference can explain why memory for street names of one\'s childhood neighbourhood is worse when an individual has subsequently moved house more...-Practical applications= understanding of the explanation can be exploited e.g. advertisers may choose to position TV ads at the end of a sequence in order to prevent the effect of proactive interference from other brands.

-Most evidence is from lab experiments= may lack ecological validity e.g. it is very rare in real life for people to have to learn word lists of purposely similar words as in Underwood\'s study...-The theory is very descriptive; however it doesn\'t explain why similar info. Interferes with each other e.g. there is no cognitive or biological explanation of the mechanism which causes interference...-Doesn\'t explain all cases of forgetting: SEE RETRIEVAL FAILURE
This is when information is stored in memory, but can\'t be accessed due to the absence of a suitable cue. This is an explanation of forgetting of information that is stored in LTM.
Context dependent forgetting.State dependent forgetting.
State of recall is different to that at coding, so internal cues are absent.
Context of recall is different to that at coding, so external cues are absent.

Bower:-Happy/sad moods were induced in Ps by hypnosis. -They were tested on recall of word lists, personal experiences, and childhood experiences. -Recall was improved when emotional content of the memory matched the induced mood.= SDF: memory was worse when the lack of internal cues present at learning were absent at the time of retrieval.

Goddon & Baddeley-Deep sea divers learned lists of words either on land or in water, then were tested in the same or different context.-Memory was 30% worse when the learning and recall context were mismatched, compared to when it was the same.=CDF: where memory was worse when the lack of external cues present at learning were absent at the time of retrieval.

-Practical applications: This means understanding of the explanation can be exploited e.g. students can use colour coded notes to provide external cues for when they are being examined on the content/ use of context reinstatement in the cognitive interview to provide external cues.

-Most evidence is from lab experiments. This means it may lack ecological validity e.g. it is very rare in real life for people to have to learn strings of wordlists, in contexts design to vary as extremely as underwater vs dry land...-The findings only occur when Ps are asked to do free recall, not recognition= it can\'t explain all types of forgetting e.g. if an individual fails to recognise an item in spite of receiving the cue, their forgetting can\'t be explained by retrieval failure...-Doesn\'t explain all cases of forgetting: SEE INTERFERENCE

cards.term: Factors affecting accuracy of eyewitness testimony
cards.definition: 1) Misleading information. 2) Anxiety.
This is post-event information which can retroactively interfere with the original memory for the event.
1) Leading questions2) Post event discussion

Loftus & Palmer-Students were shown clips of car accidents and then asked questions inc. a critical qu.: "about how fast were the cars going when they *** each other?". -When the word was "smashed" av. estimate=40.3, vs. "contacted"= 31.8mph. The smashed group were also more likely to false remember seeing glass on the video than the contacted group.=Leading question can reduce the reliability of EWT, providing suggestions about the event which distorts and adds to the original memory.

Gabbert et al: -Each P of a pair saw a video of the same crime filmed from a different point of view.-Ps discussed what they\'d seen then individually completed a recall test.-71% of Ps recalled things they didn\'t see, but had picked up from the discussion vs. 0% of the control group.=Post event discussion reduces the reliability of EWT. Ps make "source monitoring errors"- misattributing the origin of the information they have recalled.

cards.term: Strengths of research on misleading information
cards.definition: -Practical applications: suggestions arise from the conclusions as to how EWT can be enhanced e.g. use open questions and prevent witnesses talking to each other after an event...

cards.term: Limitations of research on misleading information
cards.definition: -Most evidence is from lab experiments=1) artificial settings= results may lack ecological validity e.g. in a real crime scene the increased arousal of the Ps may have an additional effect on memory which is not shown in the lab with videos as the stimuli (However, this is done for ethical reasons...)2) ...so results may have been affected by demand characteristics = Ps may report the misinformation because they believe they are supposed to, although they may be able to remember what originally happened too. (HOWEVER, even when Ps have been offered money to recall the original information, they have still recalled the post event info, suggesting the original memory has been altered)-The effects may be less important than first believed = Loftus may have exaggerated the prevalence of the effect on EWT e.g. the effects have been shown to be most noticeable regarding peripheral details suggested a long time after the original event...
An unpleasant state of emotional arousal (or stress), usually accompanied by physiological symptoms (e.g. pounding heart). It is triggered by stressors in the environment.

cards.term: Evidence that anxiety enhances EWT accuracy
cards.definition: Yuille & Cutshall:-Re-interviewed 13 EWs 5 months after they a real life shooting, comparing account to original interview.-Memory was v. accurate, and 2 misleading questions inserted by the research team had no effect on accuracy. =This suggests that memory of EWs may be enhanced if they are experiencing arousal at the time of witnessing a crime.

cards.term: Evidence that anxiety deceases EWT accuracy
cards.definition: Loftus et al:-Ps heard a discussion in an adjoining room. Grp. 1- a man emerged holding a pen with grease on his hands. Grp. 2- the discussion was more heated and a man emerged carrying a knife covered in blood. -Ps in grp. 1=49% accurate in identifying the man later from 50 photos, vs. to 33%.=This suggests that memory of EWs may be less reliable if they are experiencing arousal at the time of witnessing a crime

- The seemingly contradictory findings can be explained: The Yerkes Dodson curve shows how anxiety can enhance memory up to an optimum level, after which it has a detrimental effect i.e. in the studies where memory by is enhanced by arousal it may be because Ps were below the optimum level of arousal, vs above optimum where it decreased performance...-There are 2 proposed mechanisms to explain the decrease in performance after the optimal level of stress. \xe2\x80\xa2e.g.1 It could be that anxiety prevents Ps from encoding details of the crime scene in the first place. This would be likely if the a weapon was present, causing the witness to focus on the weapon, neglecting their surroundings a s a result (weapon focus).\xe2\x80\xa2e.g. 2 Alternatively, it could be that anxiety prevents retrieval. This would be the case is an anxiety producing event were pushed into the unconscious mind through a process of repression to protect the conscious mind.

cards.term: How police aim to improve accuracy of EWT
cards.definition: The Cognitive Interview

cards.term: 4 strategies used in the cognitive interview
cards.definition: 1) Perspective change2) Context reinstatement3) Report everything4) Recall in a different order

cards.term: How perspective change and report everything work
cards.definition: By going through a \'different route\' into memory, more information may be accessed.

cards.term: How context reinstatement and recall in a different order work
cards.definition: New cues can trigger retrieval of other details

Geiselman et al: In a lab expt. Ps viewed a video of a violent crime, and were interviewed 48 hours later. The no. correctly recalled facts was recorded. \xe2\x80\xa2a) standard interview : 29\xe2\x80\xa2b) interview using hypnosis: 38 \xe2\x80\xa2c) cognitive interview: 41A follow up showed that P\'s also less susceptible to misinformation when using the CI.This suggests that the CI is superior to the traditional interviewing techniques and therefore should be implemented by the police force.

Interview procedure that includes various principles of social dynamics in addition to the memory retrieval principles used in the original cognitive interview:\xe2\x80\xa2 language tailor to suit the witness\xe2\x80\xa2 witness should speak slowly and be encouraged to relax.\xe2\x80\xa2 judgemental comments should be avoided.\xe2\x80\xa2 the witness\' descriptions should be reviewed.

- May lead to poorer recall in some groups = limited to those with whom its effectiveness has been demonstrated e.g. it should be avoided for interviewing children under 6...- Effectiveness decreases over time= practical implications for use i.e. it should used as soon after the event as possible...-doesn\'t enhance memory for all aspects of EWT= limited in terms of its application e.g. although it can enhance EWT for details of events, it doesn\'t improve person identification...-The usefulness may have been exaggerated. This means that the extra info gained from its use isn\'t necessarily important e.g. it is mainly the recall of peripheral details are increased, which may not be that useful for solving crime...-Takes extra training and time to complete = practical limitations to using the CI e.g. police forces may have not the money and time to conduct the CI properly...
A complex network of nerve cells that carries messages to and from the brain and spinal cord to different parts of the body. It allows different parts of the body to communicate with each other.
A nerve cell; the basic building block of the nervous system.
Transmits impulses from the CNS to muscles/glands
A type of neurone, found in the spinal cord and brain, linking sensory/motor/other relay neurones.
Transmits impulses from the sense organs/receptors to the CNS
Contains the nucleus (containing genetic material) of the neurone.
The branching extensions of a neurone.
A long projection of a neurone that conducts electrical impulses known as action potentials away from the nerve cell body.
Small knobs at the end of axons that secrete chemicals called neurotransmitters.
A layer of fatty tissue encasing the fibers of many neurons; enables greater transmission speed of electrical impulses.
A junction where information is transmitted from one neuron to the next/ the gap between two neurones.
Small membrane-bound sac that stores neurotransmitters and releases into the synapse the stimulated.
The way in which a nerve impulse can only move in one direction down a neurone.
The process through which neurotransmitters are released by the presynaptic neurone, cross the synaptic gap, and affect the post synaptic neurone/s

1) Electrical impulse arrives ar presynaptic neurone2) Vesicles stored in the end of the presynaptic neurone release neurotransmitters into the synapse3) Neurotransmitters diffuse across the synapse4) Neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the post synaptic membrane.5) The postsynaptic neurone is excited or inhibited.
The effect had on a postsynaptic neurone to increase chances of firing (when the effect of excitatory neurotransmitters is greater than the effect of inhibitory ones).
The effect had on a postsynaptic neurone to decrease chances of firing (when the effect of inhibitory neurotransmitters is greater than the effect of excitatory ones).
Comprised of the neurones which make up the Brain and Spinal Cord. Controls both simple reflexes and conscious awareness for higher-order thinking.
All the neurones outside of the CNS, divided into: Somatic NS and Autonomic NS
Regulates responses to our external environment. Consists of sensory nerves carrying information from the environment to CNS and motor nerves which carry instructions from CNS to skeletal muscles.
Regulates responses to our internal environment.Controls activities of our internal organs and is involved in homeostatic functions (homeostasis)Divided into: Sympathetic and Parasympathetic

SNS has sensory and motor pathways, whereas the autonomic nervous system only has motor pathways.SNS controls muscles and movement while the ANS controls internal organs and glands.SNS is associated with the voluntary control of body movements while the ANS controls visceral functions that occur below the level of consciousness.
Branch of ANS which is activated when doing anything requiring the expenditure of energy.Involved in freeze/flight/fight mechanisms when the body is exposed to a threat.
Ensures we conserve energy. Becomes less active when sympathetic NS is activated.
"Fight or flight" responses e.g....-Increased heart rate/ breathing, -Pupils dilate, -Saliva production inhibited,-Blood flow increases to muscles, away from internal organs.
"Rest and digest" responses e.g...-Decreased heart rate/ breathing, -Pupils constrict, -Saliva production stimulated, -Blood flow increases to internal organs.
Chemicals that diffuse across the synapse to the next neurone.
Drugs work at the synapses by blocking or stimulating receptors , mimicking the action of inhibitory or excitatory neurotransmitters
A physiological reaction that occurs in response to a perceived harmful event, attack, or threat to survival. Stimulated by the actions of the sympathetic nervous system/ adrenaline.
Collection of glands that produce hormones.
Chemical messengers, mostly those manufactured by the endocrine glands, that are produced in one tissue and affect another through travelling in the bloodstream
An organ that produces and releases hormones into the bloodstream.
A hormone released into the bloodstream in response to physical or mental stress.
A pair of endocrine glands that sit just above the kidneys and secrete adrenaline to arouse the body in times of stress.

cards.term: Example of glands, their hormones and functions
cards.definition: Adrenal gland- adrenaline- fight or flight responseOvary- oestrogen- stimulates female pubertyTestes- testosterone- stimulates male pubertyPineal gland- melatonin- stimulates sleepPituitary gland- oxytocin- lactation/ pair bonding

Specific areas of the cortex are associated with particular physical and psychological functions.Means that if a certain area becomes damaged through illness or injury, the function associated with that area will also be affected.
Controls voluntary movements
The part of the cortex that receives and processes sensory nerve impulses from the skin, allowing us to experience touch, temp., pressure and pain.
The part of the cortex that receives and processes sensory nerve impulses from the eyes, allowing us to experience vision.
The part of the cortex that receives and processes sensory nerve impulses from the ears, allowing us to experience hearing.
A region of the left hemisphere involved in the production of speech (damage = Broca\'s aphasia: lack of speech).
A region of the left hemisphere involved in the comprehension of speech (damage = Wernicke\'s aphasia: fluent but incoherent speech).

Broca carried out a PM on a patient who\'d been unable to speak during his life (aphasia). When his brain was examined, it was found that there was a lesion caused by syphilis in the left frontal lobe. THIS SUGGESTS that specific functions such as language are localised in specific areas of the brain.

X Lashley couldn\'t find a specific area of rats\' brains which affected their ability to run a maze = complex behaviour cannot be localised to a specific area of the brain, supporting an alternative, holistic theory of brain function...X The brain is plastic = not valid to assume that brain areas are specialised for specific functions i.e. there is an apparent capacity of any intact part of a functional brain to carry out the functions which are lost by the destruction of other parts (the theory of "equipotentiality").  e.g. 1) People with brain damage often recover a lot of the lost functions over timee.g. 2) Environmental influences change the layout of the brain (Braille readers have larger somatosensory cortex relating to their right forefinger)...-Findings are typical of males, RH participants = what we know about localisation of function may not be generalisable to the wider population e.g. women/ left handed people...-Much evidence on localisation of function is correlational = not valid to assume a cause and effect relationship between areas of the brain and behaviour e.g SEE ISSUES WITH ESTABLISHING CAUSE AND EFFECT USING PMs/EEG/FMRI.
Two symmetrical halves of the brain.
Activity on the left-side of the body is controlled by the...
Activity on the right-side of the body is controlled by the...

Plasticity is the brain\'s ability to physically and functionally adapt and change in response to trauma, new experiences and learning.Plasticity contradicts the previous theory there is a \'critical window\' for neural organisation during the first 3 years of life.The strength/ number of neuronal connections in our brains is determined by synaptic pruning, where extra neurons/ synaptic connections are eliminated to increase the efficiency of neuronal transmission.

cards.term: What are the neural mechanisms behind functional recovery?
cards.definition: \xc2\xb7 Axonal sprouting: undamaged axons grow new nerve endings to reconnect neurons whose links were severed.\xc2\xb7 Neuronal unmasking: dormant synapses open up connections to inactive regions of the brain to take over lost function.\xc2\xb7 Cross-modal reassignment: the brain uses an area that normally processes a certain type of sensory information for a different type.\xc2\xb7 Homologous area adaptation: the brain becomes active in the equivalent part on the opposite side of the brain from where it usually occurs.

When the brain transfers the functions of damaged areas to other healthy parts of the brain to allow normal functioning to carry on.This is possible because of the "equipotentiality" of the brain: all areas of the brain are equally able to perform a task.

Maguire et al used MRI scanning to calculate the amount of grey matter in the brains of London taxi-drivers vs controls. The posterior hippocampi of taxi drivers was significantly larger than that of controls, and overall, was positively correlated with the time spent as a driver.THIS SUGGESTS that the brain is plastic, as the structure of the brain changes in relation to environmental input (London taxi drivers rely extensively on their memories of routes).

Danelli et al: An Italian boy aged 2\xc2\xbd had most of his left hemisphere removed due to a tumour. All his linguistic ability initially disappeared, however aged 17, other than minor grammatical problems and slower naming of objects, his language was good.THIS SUGGESTS that the right hemisphere of the brain is able to demonstrate plasticity by taking on speech functions, allowing the recovery of lost speech functions.

cards.term: Evaluation of plasticity/functional recovery research: strengths
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x94 Evidence on plasticity/functional recovery can be used to refute the concept of localisation of function= evidence can show that it is not valid to assume that brain areas are specialised for specific functions i.e. there is an apparent capacity of any intact part of a functional brain to carry out the functions which are lost by the destruction of other parts (the theory of "equipotentiality")\xe2\x9c\x94 Findings on plasticity/functional recovery have practical applications. This means understanding the processes of plasticity and functional recovery has led to the development of neurorehabilitation e.g. motor therapy and electrical stimulation of the brain to counter the negative effects and deficits in motor and cognitive functions following accidents, injuries and/or strokes.

cards.term: Evaluation of plasticity/functional recovery research: limitations
cards.definition: X There are individual differences in the plasticity of the brain/ potential for functional recovery = conclusions on plasticity may not be applicable to a wider population i.e. many factors influence the degree of plasticity e.g. -older patients regain much less function than children-women may recover better as their functions are not as lateralised-patients that stayed in education for longer are less likely to be permanently disabled after a brain trauma. X There are limits to spontaneous functional recovery = functional recovery cannot be relied upon to reinstate normal function e.g. although after trauma the brain activates secondary neural circuits which contribute towards reinstating normal function, the brain can only \'repair\' itself up to a specific point, after which intervention is needed.

The two halves of the brain are functionally different and that each hemisphere has functional specialisations, E.g. specialized areas for language found in the left hemisphere, and for creativity, found in the right hemisphere.

Flash a stimulus to the left or right visual field of a patient that has had their corpus callosum severed, and then asking them to respond either verbally, OR though pointing/drawing/tactile test etc.

cards.term: Split brain patient: evidence for lateralisation I
cards.definition: Sperry + Gazzaniga: used a tachistoscope to present visual information to the R and L visual fields of split brain patients as they stared ahead. If a picture was flashed to the R of the dot, the P could answer verbally, but if the picture was flashed to the L of the dot, the person would say that nothing had been seen. However, when the same P was then asked to pick out an object using only the LEFT hand, this person could correctly answer.=the LH (receiving input from the RVF) alone has speech centres. However, the RH is able to produce a response not involving language i.e. by picking out the object via the left hand it controls.

cards.term: Split brain patient: evidence for lateralisation II
cards.definition: Sperry & Gazzanigaused chimeric figures e.g. half man, half woman. If the P focussed on the dot in the middle of the forehead, the visual information about the woman\'s face is visible in the patients L visual field and vice versa. When a split brain P is asked to point to a whole, normal picture of the face that was just seen, the P would usually pick out the woman\'s picture, however, if the patient is required to say whether the picture was a man or a woman, the patient will SAY that the picture was of a man.= LH (receiving input from the RVF) alone has speech centres. However, the RH is able to produce a response not involving language i.e. by pointing.

X Split brain surgery is a rare procedure = data on lateralisation may not be generalisable e.g. only 10-15 patients have been systematically studied after a split-brain operation...  X Data from the studies may lack ecological validity. This is because Sperry\'s methodology was artificial e.g. in real life a severed corpus callosum can be compensated for by unrestricted use of two eyes... X Split-brain P\'s had abnormal brain functioning before their surgery= the conclusions drawn about lateralisation may not represent normal brain functioning i.e. epileptics\' brains may not represent lateralisation in normal brains...X Conclusions on brain lateralisation may not be applicable across all age ranges bcus extent of lateralisation changes with age e.g. language becomes more lateralised as children grow up but then reduced after 25...X Process of split-brain patients\' surgery may have had additional effects other than severing the corpus callosum = conclusions on lateralisation may be confounded by extraneous damage e.g. the behaviour of the split-brain patients may be due to damage caused by severing smaller pathwaysX The brain is plasic= lateralisation isn\'t fixed e.g. Danelli plasticity study
Functional magnetic resonance imaging. A non-invasive technique used to produce images of the live, functioning brain whilst the participant completes a task.

Neurones that are most active during a task will used more energy, and therefore need more oxygen. When in the magnetic field of the scanner it possible to detect the changes which occur when RBCs release their oxygen, indicating which parts of the brain are using up the most oxygen.

A participant might be asked to alternate between looking at a stimulus and closing their eyes. The resulting fMRI data could be used to identify where there is a matching pattern of change, and thereby conclude which areas are involved in the task.

\xf0\x9f\x98\x8afMRI has good spatial resolution =it is able to differentiate between activity arising from different areas of the brain i.e. it can detect activity to the nearest 1-2mm, HOWEVER\xf0\x9f\x98\x8a The technique has no ethical issues = because unlike in some neuroimaging techniques, the brain isn\'t exposed to harmful radiation e.g. PET involves injecting the patient with radioactive sugar, which can be harmful.

\xe2\x98\xb9fMRI has poor temporal resolution = there is a delay in registering changes in neural processing of up to 4 seconds e.g. psychologists will be unable to predict with a high degree of accuracy the onset of brain activity. \xe2\x98\xb9 fMRI scans do not provide a direct measure of neural activity =because fMRI scans simply measure changes in blood flow and therefore it is impossible to infer causation (at a neural level). E.g. while any change in blood flow may indicate activity within a certain brain area, psychologists are unable to conclude whether this brain region causes a particular function.
Electroencephalogram. A non-invasive method used to measure the electrical activity of the brain.

The activity in different areas is measured through 24-32 electrodes placed on the scalp as participants carry out different tasks. Relationships between different tasks and the general activity of different areas of the cortex can be discovered in this way.
Sleep labs use electrodes to measure the activity of the brain during different phases of sleep.

\xf0\x9f\x98\x8a EEG has good temporal resolution = that it is sensitive to millisecond by millisecond changes in neural processing e.g. as precisely as to the nearest 1-10ms.\xf0\x9f\x98\x8a The technique has no ethical issues = unlike in some neuroimaging techniques, the brain isn\'t exposed to harmful radiation e.g. PET involves injecting the patient with radioactive sugar, which can be harmful.

\xe2\x98\xb9 EEG has poor spatial resolution = it is unable to differentiate precisely between activity arising from different areas of the brain, because electrodes can\'t measure the activity of individual neurones i.e. they detect the activity of a general area made up of millions of neurones.\xe2\x98\xb9 Electrical activity is often detected in several regions of the brain simultaneously. Consequently, it can be difficult pinpoint the exact area/region of activity i.e. making it difficult for researchers to draw valid conclusions about whether a brain region is associated with a particular function
A non-invasive technique that takes raw EEG data and uses it investigate processing of a particular event. "Event-related Potentials".

Electrodes are used to take hundreds of repeated readings of brain activity as a stimulus is presented. A computer is used to collate the data, so that any unrelated background activity cancels itself out. You should be left with the consistent activity elicited by the stimulus itself. This is called averaging.

Costa et al: recorded activation in the brain towards pictures of nude people of the same/opposite sex. Men verbally reported arousal towards the women, and women reported neutral feelings to both men and women. However ERPs demonstrated than both men and women were aroused by opposite sex images,

\xf0\x9f\x98\x8a ERP has good temporal resolution = it is sensitive to millisecond by millisecond changes in neural processing e.g. as precisely as to the nearest 1-10ms.\xf0\x9f\x98\x8a The technique has no ethical issues = because unlike in some neuroimaging techniques, the brain isn\'t exposed to harmful radiation e.g. PET involves injecting the patient with radioactive sugar, which can be harmful. \xf0\x9f\x98\x8a ERP can establish cause and effect: it enables the determination of how processing is affected by a specific events i.e. it can eliminate extraneous neural activity.

\xe2\x98\xb9 Poor spatial resolution = it is unable to differentiate precisely between activity arising from different areas of the brain, because electrodes can\'t measure the activity of individual neurones i.e. they detect the activity of a general area made up of millions of neurones.
An invasive procedure to examine the brain after death.

Carried out on individuals who have been studied during their lives because of a rare psychological condition that has occurred \'naturally\'. The aim is to explain their condition through finding an abnormality in the brain.

Broca carried out a PM on a patient who\'d been unable to speak during his life. When his brain was examined, it was found that there was a lesion caused by syphilis in the left frontal lobe. It was concluded that this area was responsible for speech (now known as "Broca\'s area").

\xf0\x9f\x98\x8a PM enables researchers to perform a more detailed examination of the anatomical structure of the brain = because it can reach areas not accessible using EEG/fMRI e.g. deeper regions like the hypothalamus and hippocampus.\xf0\x9f\x98\x8a Allows greater understanding of the subjects of rare cases = can provide a unique insight into conditions that couldn\'t be created artificially for ethical reasons e.g. SEE BROCA.

\xe2\x98\xb9 Damage has often occurred due to an accident or disease = any conclusions about the relationship between an area and its function may not be valid e.g. If the damage has been done by accident, there is no guarantee that the damage will be limited to a particular area.\xe2\x98\xb9Ps are often only studied after their behaviour became abnormal = it is not possible to conclude that the damage caused a symptom e.g. if the person was not studied before their damage it is not known when the damage developed.
Biological rhythm which takes more than 24hrs to complete e.g. menstrual cycle during which the old uterus lining is shed, and a new one thickens in preparation for a fertilised egg.

The menstrual cycle lasts an average of 28 days. This average is universal amongst women, and reliable for individual women.Conclusion: the menstrual cycle is likely to be controlled by endogenous pacemakers.HOWEVERMcClintock and Stern (98) 29 women wore cotton pads to under their armpits for 8 hours. The collected "pheromones" were transferred to other women\'s upper lips.If the donor women had been in the latter half of their menstrual cycles, the recipients\' menstrual cycles were shortened. If the donor women had been at the start of their cycle, the effect was to lengthen the cycle of the women who\'d received the compounds.Conclusion: The menstrual cycle can also be influenced by exogenous zeitgebers.

cards.term: Evaluation of evidence on infradian rhythms
cards.definition: \xf0\x9f\x98\x8a Synchronising of women\'s periods can be explained through evolutionary psychology = it may be understood as an adaptive strategy e.g. for our ancestors it may have been advantageous for females to fall pregnant at the same time so that new-borns can be cared for collectively, increasing their chance of survival...\xe2\x98\xb9 Other studies have failed to find any evidence of menstrual synchrony in all female samples = evidence isn\'t reliable e.g. McClintock\'s sample was very small, relied on Ps self reporting period onset, and there are many factors that may affect a woman\'s cycle (stress, exercise, diet) and so may have confounded McClintock\'s evidence of synchronisation...

Biological rhythm which takes less than 24hrs to complete e.g. Sleep has 5 stages that occur throughout the night: 4 stages of increasingly slowed brain and physiological activity, followed by a period of REM sleep characterised by increased brain activity and dreaming. The stages repeat every 90-100 minutes.

Dement & Kleitman: 7 adult males and 2 adult females were studied under controlled lab conditions, where they reported to the lab just before their usual bedtime. They had been asked to eat normally but to avoid caffeine or alcohol on the day of the study. The participants went to bed in a quiet, dark room.An EEG was used to amplify and record the signals of electrodes which were attached to the participants face and scalp.All Ps had periods of REM every night. It was found that if Ps were awoken during REM sleep there was a high incidence of dream recall, compared to very low incidence if woken at other stages.Conclusion: Dement and Kleitman had identified the stage at which most dreaming occurs during the stages of sleep.

cards.term: Evaluation of evidence on ultradian rhythms
cards.definition: \xf0\x9f\x98\x8a Much research on ultradian rhythms like sleep has been carried out in controlled conditions = increases the internal validity and reliability of findings e.g. minimising the effects of confounding variables on sleep, and using objective measurements such as EEG...\xe2\x98\xb9 Settings are artificial = evidence lacks ecological validity, where sleep in a lab may not reflect the nature of sleep e.g. in labs Ps are attached to electrodes and in lab setting. in a person\'s own bedroom, often with a partner etc...
Biological rhythm which takes 24hrs to complete e.g. sleep/wake cycle

Internal "body clocks" that regulate biological rhythms. The most important in humans is the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus which receives info. about light levels from the optic nerve to synchronise it with the outside world.
Light stimulates the SCN to send signals to the pineal gland to inhibit the secretion of melatonin and vice versa (in the dark melatonin is secreted which inhibits brain areas promoting wakefulness).

Ralph et al studied a strain of mutant hamsters with a 20 hour sleep/wake cycle. When researchers transplanted the SCN from immature mutant hamsters into normal adult hamsters who\'d had their own SCN removed, these hamsters regained their circadian rhythm, but it now lasted 20 hrs. The reverse experiment was also conducted, with the reverse results.THIS SUGGESTS that the SCN is the regulator of hamsters\' circadian rhythms.
External stimuli ("time-givers) that regulate biological rhythms e.g. natural/artificial light, alarms.

Shih-Yu Lee et al: A group of mothers of premature babies were found to have disrupted sleep as a result or being in a low light environment (intensive care). 15 women receiving light therapy over 3 weeks showed improvement in sleep compared to a control group.= EZs (artificial light) can both disrupt sleep when out of sync with the EPs, but also be used to regulate it.

\xf0\x9f\x98\x8a The research into biological rhythms has practical applications. T= the findings are of use in real life in highlighting the dangers of modern lifestyles, where the endogenous pacemaker and exogenous zeitgebers are out of sync.e.g. 1) Cho found experienced female aircrew performed worse on cognitive tests than less experienced crew, and had damage to the temporal lobes.e.g. 2) Shift work has been linked to lower productivity, depression as well as breast cancer and heart problems.e.g. 3) The Chernobyl nuclear disaster and Three Mile Island near-disaster were linked to workers making mistakes between 2am and 4am.\xe2\x98\xb9 Much research has been carried out in artificial conditions = evidence lacks ecological validity e.g. sleep in a lab may not reflect the nature of sleep in a person\'s own bedroom, often with a partner etc...\xe2\x98\xb9 The act of monitoring sleep patterns can itself affect sleep patterns = this is a potentially confounding variable i.e. it may be this factor which is determining the quality of sleep in studies such as that by Shih-Yu Lee et al (above)...\xe2\x98\xb9 There are individual differences in the sleep-wake cycle = research may have been confounded by failing to control for these e.g. Duffy et al found that \'morning people\' prefer to rise and go to bed early (about 6 am and 10 pm) whereas \'evening people\' prefer to wake and go to bed later (about 10 am and 1 am), showing there may be innate individual differences in circadian rhythm which have not been accounted for during investigations...\xe2\x98\xb9 The emphasis on biological mechanisms in regulating sleep/wake cycles is biologically reductionist = it only considers a singular biological mechanism and fails to consider the other widely divergent viewpoints. E.g. the behaviourist approach would suggest that bodily rhythms are conditioned to follow social norms (sleep occurs when it is dark because that is the social norm and it wouldn\'t be socially acceptable for a person to conduct their daily routines during the night)...
The genetic make up of an individual
The measurable characteristics of an individual, as determined by the interaction between GENOTYPE AND ENVIRONMENTAL INFLUENCES.

e.g. the disease PKU. Genotype: defective gene leaves person unable to breakdown phenylalanine, of which a build up causes brain damage HOWEVER, a diet modified to reduce phenylalanine means this isn\'t expressed, and the child develops to have a normal PHENOTYPE.

e.g.1: Aggression may have evolved in the form of fixed action patterns (e.g. sticklebacks\' territorial behaviour, attacking other males in mating seasons), as individuals who demonstrated aggressive behaviour in the species\' evolutionary history were more likely to survive and pass on genes for the aggressive behaviour.e.g.2: Innate releasing mechanisms (e.g. babies smiling etc) may have evolved as individuals in the species\' evolutionary history who demonstrated sociability were more likely to elicit caregiver attention, and therefore survive and pass on genes for the behaviour.
Strengths of the Biological approach

cards.term: \xc2\xb7 The methods used in the biological approach are highly scientific. This means they gather objective measurements of behaviour e.g. using ERP to measure the brains\' response to environmental stimuli rather than self report...There are many applications which have been derived from the approach. This means it has been highly influential e.g. revolutionising the treatment of mental illness using drug therapy...
cards.definition: Limitations of the Biological Approach

cards.term: The approach demonstrates biological reductionism. This means that it attempts to explain behaviour using the simplest component parts. e.g. explaining complex behaviour such as gender/mental illness as the result of genes/hormones/ neurotransmitter imbalances, and thus neglecting the influence of environmental factors... The approach demonstrates biological determinism. This means that it denies free will. e.g. denying we have any responsibility for behaviour such as aggression if certain alleles are resent (MAOA-L), suggesting that carriers should not be blamed

cards.definition: Behaviour is learned through observation and imitation. Reinforcement can be vicarious i.e. we can learn through observation of the consequences for others of their actions. We are most likely to imitate those who we can identify with.

cards.term: Evidence for Social Learning Theory: part 1
cards.definition: Bandura36 boys & 36 girls aged 3-6 either watched a same/opposite sex adult model kick/hit/sit on a Bobo doll for 9 minutes, accompanied by aggressive comments e.g. "pow", "kick him" (half watched a same-sex, half an opposite sex model) OR act non-aggressively towards the Bobo doll OR observed no model. The children were deliberately annoyed by being told that a range of toys were for other children, then were allowed to play in the room with the Bobo doll for 20 minutes whilst experimenters watched through a one-way mirror. Children in condition 1 were significantly more physically and verbally aggressive than those who in 2/3 and imitation was greatest when the model was of the same sex model.= supports identification/modelling/imitation...

cards.term: Evidence for Social Learning Theory: part 2
cards.definition: BanduraChildren saw the adult model being rewarded by a second adult OR a second adult telling off the adult model for the aggressive behaviour OR the adult model being neither rewarded or punished. Children behaved the most aggressively in condition 1 and least aggressively in condition 2 (= supports vicarious reinforcement...). However, when the children in condition 2 were later offered rewards to copy the behaviour they showed that they had learned as many aggressive acts as the children in condition 1 (=supports mediational processes...).
Copying/ simulating behaviour.
This happens "with" the model. An individual is influenced by the model because they are in some way similar and/or wish to be like them.
When a model provides an example of an attitude or behaviour, which another individual can observe & themselves.
The consequence that the observer sees the model receiving: the behaviour becomes associated with a positive or negative response.

According to SLT, cognitive factors that influence learning a behaviour and come between stimulus and response. For modelling to occur there must be attention, retention,motor reproduction, motivation.
Mediational cognitive process: noticing certain behaviours
Mediational cognitive process: remembering the behaviour
Mediational cognitive process: assessing whether the behaviour is physically possible to carry out. Depends on the individual\'s perception of their ability (self efficacy).
Mediational cognitive process: the individual assessing whether they want to imitate the behaviour based on the perceived consequences.

-The approach can account for cross cultural differences in behaviour= increases validity e.g. Mead\'s research of cross cultural differences in gender related behaviour demonstrated the environment to be influential rather than genes producing universal behaviour.-The approach has scientific status= predictions are tested in lab experiments, measuring observable behaviour e.g. Bandura using child\'s behaviour towards doll as objective evidence that learning had occurred.-The approach presents a more comprehensive view of human behaviour than the Behaviourist approach e.g. recognising importance of cognitive factors rather than just observable behaviour.

-The approach relies on evidence from lab studies= may lack validity e.g. in Bandura\'s study, performance of aggressive behaviour may have been a result of demand characteristics from the setting rather than true social learning.

The approach focuses on internal mental processes, and the influences of these on behaviour. It is assumed that internal mental processes can be studied scientifically. Human information processing is similar to the way a computer works, proceeding through a sequence of stages from input to output.

Murdock: Psychology students read 10-40 words & asked to write down as many as they could remember in 90 s. No matter the list length words at start of the list were well remembered ("The Primacy Effect"), + words at the end ("The Recency Effect").Used to support how STM and LTM are separate.= demonstrates observable behaviour being measured in order to infer unobservable mental processes/ create a cognitive model.
Unobservable behaviours e.g. memory, problem solving, which can be inferred (assumed) about from our observable behaviour in experiments.
A mental framework for storing and organising all the information we know/ believe about a concept.
+ Speeds up information processing by creating expectations- Creating expectations can lead to bias in information processing
A representation of mental processes, usually in the form of a diagram, which can be tested.
The analogy that the mind is like a computer in the way it processes information.
The process whereby cognitive psychologists draw conclusions/assumptions about the way mental processes operate on the basis of observed behaviour.

The combination of cognitive psychology with neuroscience, aiming to locate the areas of the brain in which cognitive processes are based e.g. by conducting brain scans as Ps complete cognitive tasks to identify which regions are active, or of Ps with mental disorders to identify neural correlates of their symptoms.

cards.term: Evidence to support the assumption of the cognitive approach
cards.definition: Murdock: Psychology students read 10-40 words & asked to write down as many as they could remember in 90s. No matter the list length words at start of the list were well remembered ("The Primacy Effect"), + words at the end ("The Recency Effect").=supports inferring internal mental processes from observed behaviour...

Scoville & Milner: After removal of his hippocampus HM suffered severe side effects on his memory. LTMs were still vivid and STM capacity was normal memories however he couldn\'t form any new permanent memories.= used to infer that the hippocampus is the area involved in formation of LTMs

-The approach has many practical applications = useful in solving problems e.g. CBT used to treat depression by targeting and changing negative thoughts believed to underlie symptoms of depression.-The approach has scientific status = predictions are tested in lab experiments, measuring observable behaviour e.g. Murdock using which words were remembered as objective evidence for unobservable memory processes.

-The approach relies on evidence from lab studies = research is often carried out using artificial stimuli which may not reflect everyday experience e.g. many memory experiments use lists of nonsense words to study the coding/ capacity/ duration of memory.-The approach presents a reductionist view of human behaviour= oversimplistic e.g. reduces complex behaviours such as depression/schizophrenia to the level of mental processes, without taking into account the social context of the P.

Much of our behaviour stems from unconscious drives. Early childhood experiences influence adult behaviour and personality, depending on how these drives are gratified as we move through the stages of psychosexual development.

The reservoir of feelings/ thoughts/ urges/ memories that are outside of our conscious awareness, esp. ones causing anxiety or conflict. Unpleasant memories repressed in the unconscious may still affect behaviour eg phobias.

cards.term: 3 parts of personality according to Freud
cards.definition: id, ego, superego
The primitive and instinctive component of personality operating according to the pleasure principle. Present from birth. An over-demanding id leads to greedy/selfish/aggressive behaviour.
The mediating part of the personality operating according to the reality principle. Develops at age 2-4. Partly un/conscious.

The part of the personality operating according to the morality principle. Develops at age 4-5. Partly un/conscious. Incorporates the values and morals of society which are learned from one\'s parents and others, Causes feelings of guilt.
Unconscious psychological mechanisms employed by the ego to reduce anxiety arising from unacceptable or potentially harmful stimuli e.g...
Defence mechanism employed by the ego to keep threatening or disturbing thoughts from becoming conscious.
Defence mechanism employed by the ego to refuse to see the unpleasant aspects of reality.
Defence mechanism employed by the ego transferring emotional impulses to a neutral target.

The stages of development which describes the way in which children receive sexual gratification from birth to puberty, during which their personalities are shaped e.g. if fixation occurs at a particular stage due to over/under-gratification.
Stage of psychosexual development age 0-2. Focus of pleasure is the mothers\'s breast.
Stage of psychosexual development age 2-3. Focus of pleasure is the anus/ withholding and expelling faeces.
Stage of psychosexual development age 3-6. Focus of pleasure is the genital area. Child experiences the Oedipus/Electra complex.
Stage of psychosexual development age 6-puberty. Earlier conflicts are repressed
Stage of psychosexual development age puberty+. Sexual desires become conscious.
-not about mental health-everyone can relate to it -looks at healthy individuals- we have free will

Freud: Little Hans was the 5 year old son of Freud\'s friend had developed a phobia of horses. The father wrote to him to tell him about his son\'s development, revealing Hans was particularly afraid of large white horses with black blinkers and black around the mouth. He was terrified to leave the house and believed that the horses might either bite him or fall down. =supports that unconscious (Oedipus complex) can manifest itself to affect observable behaviour.

-Many of Freud\'s concepts are unfalsifiable = concepts can\'t be proven wrong, which is a criteria of being scientific e.g. it can\'t be proven wrong that an event which can\'t currently be remembered has been repressed into the unconscious mind.-The approach is androcentric = Freud used male behaviour as the standard norm for all human behaviour, and described female behaviour as a deviation from this e.g. Freud stated that all females are jealous of males because they have a penis (penis envy), reflecting and maintaining the view in the early 1900s that women were second-class citizens compared to males. - The approach is deterministic = argues that unconscious forces and childhood experiences cause behaviour e.g. our personality traits are explained as the result of being fixated on a given psychosexual stage (under-gratification at the oral stage could lead to overeating as an adult etc)-Freud relied on the case study method, conducting indepth investigations several individuals with problematic behaviour to support his theories = theories based on unrepresentative sample e.g. may not be possible to develop theory of normal human development in individuals with anxiety disorders.
The concept that we are active agents, able to change and decide on the course of our own development.

Realising personal potential- a drive which everyone is assumed to have. The type of person that manages to self-actualise has accurate perceptions of the world, acceptance of others, creativity, a good sense of humour, detachment and a need for privacy.

A motivational theory comprising a five tier model of human needs, which motivate people when they are unmet (physiological needs, safety and security, love & belonging, self-esteem, self-actualisation)
When our concepts of self (self-image and ideal self) are very similar. This is more likely if we receive unconditional positive regard.

person-centered therapy was developed by Carl Rogers. This is non-directive and the client is encouraged to discover their own solutions within a warm, supportive and non-judgemental environment (given unconditional positive regard).
Criteria imposed upon us in that we have to meet in order to receive conditional positive regard.
-The approach presents a holistic view of human behaviour= anti-reductionist e.g. believes humans are greater than the sum of their parts.

\xc2\xb7 "The father of psychology."\xc2\xb7 Wundt founded the Institute of Experimental Psychology; the first psychology laboratory (Germany in 1870s).\xc2\xb7 Published one of the first books on psychology, helping to establish the subject as an independent branch of science.\xc2\xb7 His work paved the way for later controlled research and the study of mental processes e.g. by cognitive psychologists, through his use of introspection.

-The approach is ethnocentric = culture biasede.g. the notions of free will and choice reflect Western thinking, whereas in the third world individuals living in poverty have little choice in their actions.-The approach is overly optimistic = may be too positive about human nature e.g. it is unrealistically idealistic to assume that individuals are intrinsically good.-Some of the concepts are vague or poorly defined = difficult to test the validity of the concepts empirically. e.g. the notions of free will and self-actualisation refer to subjective experiences which can\'t be measured objectively.

\xc2\xb7 A method for studying mental processes: the systematic analysis of Ps\' conscious experience by asking them to report their sensations in response to controlled stimuli.The analysis used a "structuralist approach" i.e. reducing experience to its components part (sensations, emotional reactions etc.), aiming to establish general theories about mental processes.

cards.term: The emergence of psychology as a science: IN FAVOUR of Wundt
cards.definition: Wundt used highly controlled lab conditions= increases internal validity of work= use of identical stimuli & physical surroundings and instructions were given to each P.Wundt\'s focus on mental processes through introspection can be seen as a forerunner of the cognitive approach= influential = cognitive psychologist now attempt to study unobservable mental processes, although using more objective measurements

cards.term: he emergence of psychology as a science: AGAINST Wundt
cards.definition: Wundt\'s use of introspection may lack validity= Ps self reflection is subjective and van\'t be verified= likely that introspection only reveals a tiny proportion of mental activity.Greater contributions to the emergence of psychology as a science was made by early behaviourists= they rejected measurements of unobservable behaviour= only use empiricalmethods which can objectively verified
Learning a new voluntary behaviour through consequences: reinforcement (increasing a behaviour) and punishment (decreasing a behaviour).

All behaviour is LEARNED from our direct experiences. It can be understood in terms of stimulus-response links, or can be seen as a result of its consequences. Psychologists should only study observable behaviour as it can be measured objectively and scientifically. It is appropriate to generalise from animal research to human behaviour.

cards.term: 2 types of learning according to Behaviourist Psychologists
cards.definition: Classical conditioningOperant conditioning
When a behaviour is increased because it results in the removal of an stimulus.
When a behaviour is increased because it results in the acquisition of a desired outcome.
Learning to produce a reflexive behaviour to a new stimulus, through association.UCS \xe2\x86\x92UCRUCS+NS\xe2\x86\x92UCRCS\xe2\x86\x92CR

Skinner: In the "Skinner Box", if the accidental pressing of a lever resulted in the presentation of food, the rat would quickly learn to press the bar repeatedly to get more food (+ reinforcement). It would also learn to press the lever if it resulted in the cessation of a painful electric shock (- reinforcement).

Pavlov: By pairing food (UCS) with the sound of a bell (NS), a dog learned to associate the bell with food. After a number of pairings, the dog learned to salivate when hearing the bell alone (CS\xe2\x86\x92CR).

-The approach has many practical applications= useful contributions to the real world e.g. therapies to treat phobias, token economy for schizo.-The approach has scientific status= it emphasises control and objectivity within research e.g. behaviourists used lab experiments measuring observable behaviour to discover the laws of learning.

-The approach presents a reductionist view of human behaviour = reduces the complexity of human behaviour to what they argue are its simplest components e.g. through its belief in environmental reductionism, behaviour is reduced to a series of stimulus-response links.-The approach presents has relied largely on the use of animal studies = may not be generalisabe to humans e.g. learning theory for attachment lacks evidence- human behaviour is more complex
Any method in which a person is asked to state or explain their own feelings, opinions, behaviours and experiences related to a given topic.
A set of written questions (sometimes called items) used to access a persons\' thoughts/experiences
+ Cost effective+ Can gather large amounts of data quickly+ Can be completed without the researcher being present
- Answers may be affected by response bias e.g. social desirability bias- Ps may misunderstand the question or read it incorrectly
Questions with no fixed answer/ response and respondents can answer in any way they wish.
+ Get more valid, rich and qualitative data- Harder to analyse the data
Questions with a fixed answer/ the choice of response is determined by the question setter.
+ Quantitative data is easier to analyse- Lacking detailed or in depth answers, which may not reflect the Ps true meaning.
Made up of pre-determined questions and are asked in a fixed order, face to face.
There is a general aim that a certain topic will be discussed and interaction tends to be free flowing.
Measures whether a test "looks like" it tests what it is supposed to test.
The results from a test match those from an established test. There should be a high positive correlation between the 2 sets of results (+0.8).
+ Replicable+ Easier to compare P\'s answers/analyse+ Focussed data- Less valid data, as information is missed if questions/answers are too restricted

+ Can get more detailed answers as people can elaborate+ Allows the interviewer to follow up interesting answers- Not easy to replicate - Not easy to compare Ps responses/analyse data- Unfocussed data
A general statement that the researcher intends to investigate.
A detailed statement which is operationalised and testable that states the affect of the IV on the DV/ relationship between co-variables.
The researcher makes it clear what significant difference is anticipated between the 2 conditions/ what relationship is anticipated between co-variables (One tailed).
Simply states that there will be a significant difference between groups/ relationship between co-variables, but not what the difference/ relationship will be.
States that there will be no effect of the IV on the DV/ relationship between the 2 co-variables.
A particular form of research method that uses secondary data. Data from a large number of studies which have involved the same research question and method are combined.
Numerical data
+Rich and detailed-Difficult to analyse -Subjective
Descriptive data expressed in words.
+Easy to analyse+More objective-Less meaningful
Information that has been obtained first hand by the researcher from the Ps. It is also known as field
+High validity as it\'s collected with specific aim in mind-Time consuming to gather
Information that has already been collected by previous researchers. It is also known as \'desk research\' and can be found in journal articles, books or websites.
+Quick to gather- Bias in original interpretation can reduce validity
British Psychological Society

Part of the BPS\' code of ethics: when research is explained, it must be done in such a way that people are not misled to act in a way which is not in their best interest.If under 16 consent must be obtained from their parents.
When information is withheld from participants/ they misled about the purpose of the study.

Part of the BPS\' code of ethics: Ps should be told this at the start of the research that they can leave (or withdraw their data) when they wish. No attempt should be made to encourage them to remain.
Part of the BPS\' code of ethics: should leave studies in the same condition in which they arrived, without suffering any trauma.
Part of the BPS\' code of ethics: researchers should discuss the aims of the research with the Ps after they have completed the study.

\xe2\x80\xa2Thank you for taking part\xe2\x80\xa2Aim of the experiment (NOT results)\xe2\x80\xa2What happened in the other condition\xe2\x80\xa2Right to withdraw data\xe2\x80\xa2Any questions/ provide contact details for follow up questions?

\xe2\x80\xa2NOT the aim of the experiment\xe2\x80\xa2What the task will be\xe2\x80\xa2Right to withdraw\xe2\x80\xa2Ensure confidentiality\xe2\x80\xa2Ask for consent (check over 16), including a space to sign.

cards.term: Areas in which psychological knowledge could impact on the economy
cards.definition: \xe2\x80\xa2 The workforce \xe2\x80\xa2 Healthcare
An aspect of the experimental situation that is manipulated by the researcher or changes naturally.
The variable that is measured by the researcher.
The process of devising a way of measuring a variable. It is a clear statement of what the variable is.
An experiment that takes place in a controlled environment where the researcher manipulates the IV and records the effect on the DV while maintaining strict control of extraneous variables.
+ Can establish cause and effect+ Few if any extraneous variables+Easy to replicate to check reliability.+High internal validity
- Lacks ecological / external validity- Demand characteristics can occur- Experimenter effects can occur -May raise ethical issues e.g. deception
The researcher manipulates the IV and records the effect on the DV in the Ps own natural environment.
+ More ecologically/externally valid than lab+ Fewer demand characteristics and experimenter effects than lab if Ps unaware they are being tested.
- Extraneous variables more difficult to control- More difficult to replicate exactly- May raise ethical issues
An experiment where the change in the IV is not caused by the researcher- as it would have happened if the researcher wasn\'t there. The researcher records the effect on the DV.
+ Fewer demand characteristics or researcher effects if Ps unaware of being tested.+ Fewer ethical issues+ Allows Ps who wouldn\'t normally be tested to take part.
- Lack of control  over extraneous variables- No random allocation can create confounding variables- Impossible to replicate exactly
The IV is a characteristic of the Ps (themselves (usually takes place in a lab).
+ IF in a lab, high control over extraneous variables+Easy to replicate to check reliability.
-No random allocation can create confounding variables-IF in a lab, artificial conditions may reduce ecological validity
Any variable apart from the IV which has the potential to effect the DV if not controlled.
A variable apart from the IV which HAS effected the DV,meaning the effect of the IV can\'t be concluded validly.
Organising participants by chance so that each has an equal chance of ending up in each condition
How methods can be applied to real life settings.
Refers to how likely it is that the time period when a study was conducted has influenced the findings and whether they can be generalised to other periods in time,
Any cue from the research situation that can be interpreted by participants as revealing the purpose of the investigation, leading them to changing their behaviour.
Any (unintentional) influence of the researcher\'s behaviour/characteristics on participants/data/outcome.
The type of experiment you do.
How Ps are allocated to the conditions of an experiment
Each participant either takes part in condition A or B
+ Reduces demand characteristics+ Prevents order effects
- Individual differences could be confounding.- More Ps are required
Every P takes part in both conditions of the experiment.
+ Individual differences are controlled+Fewer Ps are required
- Increased likelihood of demand characteristics confounding results- Order effects can occur
Participants are matched on key characteristics. Each is randomly allocated to one of the conditions.
+ Reduces demand characteristics+ Prevents order effects+Participant variables are controlled
- Time consuming- More Ps are required- Hard to match Ps on all variables
An attempt to control order effects in a repeated measures design where one group takes part in condition A THEN B, and one group takes part in condition B THEN A.
Keeping variables the same as a method of control e.g. instructions to Ps, time of day of memory test.
A extraneous variable arising from the order which Ps take part in the different conditions, so their performance improves/worsens across conditions through practice/fatigue.
Deciding the order of variables by chance e.g. words on a memory test.
Take place in a setting where behaviour would usually occur.
+ High ecological validity- Hard to replicate- Extraneous variables can influence behaviour
Observing people under controlled conditions
+ Easy to replicate+ More control over extraneous variables- Findings may lack ecological validity
The researcher is involved in/with the observation.
+ Observer has greater understanding to be able to contextualise their observations.- The behaviour of the Ps may be affected by the observer, reducing validity of findings.
A researcher observes people without becoming part of the situation.
+ Allows researcher to remain objective.- Researcher is less able to contextualise the observed behaviour.
Ps are not aware of being observed.
+ Prevents the observer effect so more natural behaviour is observed.- Ethical issues.
Ps are aware that they are being observed
+ Fewer ethical issues- Behaviour can be influenced as Ps know they\'re being watched
When a target behaviour is broken up into components that are observable and measurable.
