Recording behaviour with a pre established time frame e.g. every 30 seconds, so observer has time to record what they have seen although some behaviour may be missed.
Counting the time a particular behaviour occurs in a group/individual, so behaviour isn\'t missed (although if too much happens at once, it may be difficult to record everything).
Two or more researchers observe the same behaviour separately at the same time then compare and amend results. A correlation of +0.8 indicates high reliability.
The process of interpreting secondary material as a way to understand behaviour. Involves coding material according to categories, counting frequency of certain categories.
A type of content analysis: materials (possibly converted into written transcripts first) are reviewed and coded to look for emerging THEMES. The data is qualitative.
+No ethical issues, as no people are directly involved.-Coding of materials is subjective.
The entire group a researcher is interested in.
When certain groups are over or under represented with in the sample selected. It limits the extent to which generalisations can be made to the target population.
When findings from a particular sample under investigation are broadly applied to the target population. This is possible if the sample of people is representative of the population.
The assessment of work by other specialists in the same field before it is published.
One or more experts in the field assess the work. It may be accepted outright; accepted with the condition that modifications are made; or rejected.
To verify- should research be published?-whether method used/statistics used were appropriate? -the implications of the research to the field? - whether the work the researchers\' own?
A research method that involves a detailed study of a signal individual, institution or event.

Based on "animal" (human and non-human) behaviour patterns in the natural environment, argues that instinctual behaviours such as aggression have evolved in the form of "fixed action patterns" produced by "innate releasing mechanisms"...
An innate "hardwired" neural mechanism, which is triggered by a specific sign stimulus to produce a motor action (FAP).
Motor actions which are stereotyped, universal, independent of individual experience, ballistic, and have specific triggers.

Provides a way to visualise how innate releasing mechanisms can trigger fixed action patterns: the sign stimulus acts like a weight which pulls a lever (IRM) which allows water to flow from a tank, symbolising the release of energy which occurs when a FAP is performed.

Tinbergen: Model male sticklebacks with red painted bellies are attacked by other males. If there was no spot there was no aggression.This suggests that red bellies (developed during mating season) act as sign stimuli, triggering an IRM in male sticklebacks to perform an attack FAP.Sackett: Rhesus monkeys were reared in isolation and were provided with pictures of monkeys playing/exploring/in threatening poses. As the baby monkeys matured they displayed disturbed behaviour to the pictures of threatening monkeys.This suggests that that aggressive poses are sign stimuli to rhesus monkeys, triggering a defensive FAP.

X It has been shown that performance of an aggressive act can be a further stimulus making further aggression more likely =contradicts the hydraulic model i.e. the hydraulic model predicts that the performance of an act would use up the energy specific energy, and reduce any further aggression....X There are subtle variations between members of the same species in the production of aggressive behaviours. = contradicts the idea that FAPs are universal, stereotypes and independent of individual experience e.g. the duration of each behaviour varies from one animal to another, and even in the same animal from one encounter to another...X There is evidence that aggressive behaviour is not necessarily adaptive. This means that doubt is cast on the assumption that animal aggression is made up of adaptive rituals e.g. Jane Goodall studied chips in Tanzania and observed a "4 year war", where chimps attempted to systematically slaughter those of another community in a coordinated, premeditated fashion e.g. holding individuals down and biting/hitting for up to 20 mins in spite of appeasement signals...X Evidence for the ethological explanation comes from animals = the evidence found may not generalise to more cognitively complex species such as humans. E.g. aggression in humans is less likely a result of IRMs and FAPs as shown in the wide ranging and subtle variations in situations which trigger human aggression such as by Nisbett who found a north-south divide in the US in homicide rates amongst white males, with southern males being more likely to kill another man if their "honour" had been insulted...

Humans have inherited their ancestors\' psychological mechanisms for improving their chances of passing on their genes. i.e. modern behaviours have evolved because they solved challenges faced by our ancestors...

Females lose more resources than men if they choose a sub-standard partner, so are pickier about who they select. Therefore to succeed males must compete with other males to present themselves as the most attractive mate, demonstrating an ability to protect both them and their offspring. Therefore aggression is likely between men competing for access to females.

Our male ancestors faced is that of paternity uncertainty. It would have been impossible for our male ancestors to know whether their partner was bearing their child, in comparison to females who always know. Therefore aggression is likely by men towards women as a strategy to guard them from access to other men.

cards.term: Evidence for evolutionary explanations of male:male aggression
cards.definition: Daly & Wilson: In a review of conflicts that resulted in murder in Detroit- the victims and offenders were most likely to be unemployed and unmarried young men.- In 58/214 cases, the reason for the murder was sexual jealousy involving 2 men contesting a female partner.= aggression is a strategy by which males increase their fitness i.e. low status males who have not yet secured a mate may attempt to increase their status, and therefore attract a female, by competing with other young men.

cards.term: Evidence for evolutionary explanations of male:female aggression
cards.definition: Daley & Wilson (96) Analysed data on violence of men towards women. They round that-murder rates were higher in estranged than cohabiting couples.-murder and assault by husbands was greatest on younger wives and decreased with age.-murder and assault by husbands was higher in non-marital than marital relationships.-the highest rate of violence was when a woman was cohabiting but had a child by another man.This suggests aggression towards Fs may be a M strategy for increasing fitness i.e. it is more likely in cases where there is more chance of the F mating with another M, which could potentially lead to paternity uncertainty/ becoming a cuckold. Therefore aggression towards Fs maybe seen as a form of sexual jealous/ mate retention/guarding

cards.term: Evaluation of evolutionary explanations of human aggression
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x94Historically and cross-culturally, women were/are treated more harshly for adultery than men =the universality of this kind of behaviour suggests may have evolved as a strategy to increase male fitness by preventing cuckoldry e.g. Neck rings are worn by the women of the Myanmar tribe to stretch the neck (weakening the neck muscles) as an aid to beauty. If a woman commits adultery, he is allowed to remove them, with painful, if not fatal, results...XExplanations are based on conjecture rather than evidence. This means the explanations are supposition based on correlational data as the explanation is impossible to test empirically e.g. murder statistics...XThe explanation has ethical implications. This is because the predictions it makes are socially sensitive e.g. it could be seen to justify/ excuse domestic violence towards women by their partners...XEvidence on human aggression demonstrates androcentrism = it explains aggression from a male perspective, emphasising the differences between men and women (this is alpha bias) e.g. The evolutionary argument states that men must prevent women from being unfaithful, and does not really acknowledge the fact that men also be unfaithful, provoking female aggression...X There are alternative explanations, with more empirical evidence, which can provide an explanation for aggression =the murder statistics used to support the evolutionary explanation can be accounted for by other mechanisms such as social learning e.g. Smetana found that parents were more likely to physically punish boys for bad conduct whereas they were more likely to explain to girls why their behaviour was wrong...

Argues that aggressive behaviour is inherited through genes. Older evidence looks at data from twin and adoption studies, whereas newer evidence has looked for specific candidates genes thought to contribute to an increased risk of engaging in antisocial behaviour e.g. MAOA: \xe2\x80\xa2 The MAOA gene codes for the body\'s production of the MAOA enzyme.\xe2\x80\xa2 The enzyme controls the breakdown of mood-related neurotransmitters e.g. serotonin, noradrenaline, dopamine \xe2\x80\xa2 One allele codes for the high activity version (MAOA-H) and one controls for the low activity version of the enzyme (MAOA-L). The LOW activity version has been lined to aggression.

cards.term: Evidence for genetic factors in aggression
cards.definition: Christiansen: analysed the concordance for criminal behaviour for 3586 pairs of twins in Denmark. From this sample, 926 individuals had been registered by the police for a criminal conviction. Male MZ twins showed 35% concordance compared to 12% concordance between DZ twins (21% vs. 8% in females).= aggression has a genetic component, as MZ twins share 100% of their genes whilst DZ only share 50%.Brunner et al (93) studied a large Dutch family where many of the men had a history of extreme violence e.g. one man had tried to rape his sister, one tried to run his boss down with his car. It was found that the all the violent men in the family had the low activity allele of the MAOA gene, meaning that excess neurotransmitters would accumulate in their bodies instead of being broken down. = the MAOA-L allele is associated with the demonstration of aggressive behaviour.

cards.term: Evaluation of genetic factors in aggression
cards.definition: X 1/3 of men are found to have the MAOA-L allele = it isn\'t always expressed in direct overt demonstrations of aggression. e.g. as well as aggression, it is also associated with risk taking behaviour (needed in certain occupations such as stockbroking)...X For ethical reasons, data on aggression in humans comes from crime statistics, or self-report data = data for the genetic explanation on human aggression may be unreliable e.g. not all crime is aggressive/not all aggression is reported as a crime/ social desirability bias may prevent Ps from admitting to aggressive behaviour...X It is difficult to separate the influence of genetics on aggression from those of the environment =data on the influence of genes by be confounded in some cases by environmental variables e.g. MZ twins often share more environmental influences than DZ twins which may be the real cause for MZ concordance for criminal convictions being higher than DZ...X Women don\'t often express the MAOA-L allele = the genetic explanation or aggression demonstrates androcentrism i.e. the research shows beta bias, ignoring the fact that female aggression may have a different cause... X The explanation is reductionist = it oversimplifies what is likely to be a complex behaviour like aggression down to the level of genetics e.g. Caspi et al showed male children with MAOA-L were more likely to grow up to exhibit antisocial behaviour, BUT ONLY if they had also been maltreated as children, whereas those who MAOA-H didn\'t display antisocial behaviour even if they had, showing that genes and environment interact to influence aggressive behaviour...
Brain mechanisms:1)The limbic system2) Serotonin

Includes the brain structures of the hypothalamus and amygdala. Activation is associated with aggression. (HOWEVER and stimulation of some parts of the amygdala decreases aggression, so the mechanism is not yet clear)

cards.term: Evidence for the role of the limbic system in aggression
cards.definition: Many animal studies have shown that if certain areas of the amygdala are electrically stimulated, an animal responds with aggression, for example snarling and adopting an aggressive posture. If the areas are surgically removed the animal no longer responds to stimuli that would previously have led to rage. =the amygdala is involved in producing aggressive behaviour.Wong et al. undertook MRI scans of 19 violent male criminals in Broadmoor hospital and compared the size of the amygdala with 20 \'normal\' control subjects. He found that the volume of the amygdala was significantly smaller in the 19 violent criminals, thus supporting the role of the amygdala and limbic system in aggression.

A neurotransmitter which works in the frontal areas of the brain to inhibit the firing of the amygdala. Low levels are associated with aggression and impulsive behaviour (HOWEVER high serotonin have also been linked to aggression in some studies, so the mechanism is not yet clear)

cards.term: Evidence for the role of serotonin in aggression
cards.definition: Rosado et al: 80 dogs referred to the vets for aggressive behaviour towards humans were compared to controls for levels of serotonin. Aggressive dogs showed an average of 278 units compared to 387 units.= low serotonin levels are associated with aggression in dogs.Mann et al gave 5 healthy participants dexfenfluramine, which reduces serotonin levels. Using a questionnaire to assess aggression levels they found the treatment was associated with an increase in aggression scores in males (but not females).= low serotonin levels are associated with high levels of aggression.

cards.term: Evaluation of neural mechanisms in aggression
cards.definition: X Much evidence on neural mechanisms is on animals = it may not generalise to human behaviour e.g. human aggression may be more complex than animal aggression as humans have more complex cognitive processes and social environments that animals...\xe2\x9c\x94However, this resolves ethical issues = it would breach guidelines for protecting Ps to carry out experiments e.g. involving electrical stimulation/removal of brain areas...X But, where there is experimental evidence on human aggression, it may lack validity. This means the "aggression" demonstrated may not be like aggression in a more natural environment e.g. the increase in self reported aggression in Mann\'s study may not be reflective of genuine aggression, but merely a response to demand characteristics to change their answers on the 2nd time of being asked...XThe neural explanation is deterministic =it is denied that we have free will in our aggression behaviour i.e. suggesting that individuals with low serotonin/ overactive amygdala are unable to control and therefore can\'t be blamed for our aggression...XThe neural explanation is reductionist = it oversimplifies what is likely to be a complex behaviour like aggression down to the level of neural mechanisms, not taking into account of cognitive and social factors which may be involved in aggression too...

Differing levels of testosterone between men and women may be a factor to explain why, cross-culturally, males are typically more aggressive than females. Testosterone is a steroid hormone from the androgen group i.e. stimulates or controls the development and maintenance of male characteristics. Adult males produce 10x more testosterone than females, with levels escalating at puberty. It is though that testosterone may reduce activity of the orbitofronal cortex or reduce serotonergic activity in the brain.

cards.term: Animal based evidence for the role of testosterone in aggression
cards.definition: Connor & Levine: rats castrated at birth show much decreased levels of aggression, even if given huge doses of testosterone as adults. Rats castrated after puberty could be made aggressive with testosterone injections. = exposure to testosterone at a critical period is necessary for the potential for aggression to develop. After this critical period, further exposure to testosterone is associated with stimulating aggressive behaviour.

cards.term: Correlational evidence for the role of testosterone in aggression
cards.definition: Dabbs et al: the level of testosterone in saliva samples from 692 male prisoners was related to the type of crime they had committed. High testosterone men were more likely to have committed crimes involving sex and violence than men with lower testosterone levels (who were more likely to have committed burglaries, drug offences). = increased testosterone levels are associated with aggressive behaviour.

cards.term: Human experimental evidence on the role of testosterone in aggression
cards.definition: Van Goozen et al: 35 male-to-female and 15 female-to-male transsexuals completed questionnaires to assess their proneness to aggression before and after sex change treatment (anti-androgen drugs vs. testosterone). There was a relative decrease and increase in aggression respectively. = there is an association between testosterone levels and aggressive behaviour.

cards.term: Evaluation for hormonal mechanisms in aggression
cards.definition: X Much evidence on hormonal mechanisms is on animals = it may not generalise to human behaviour e.g. human aggression may be more complex than animal aggression as humans have more complex cognitive processes and social environments that animals...\xe2\x9c\x94 However, this resolves ethical issues = it would breach guidelines for protecting Ps to carry out experiments e.g. involving castration/ hormone injections...X Therefore evidence available on humans is often correlational. However, this cannot establish cause and effect i.e. it may be that aggressive behaviour causes testosterone levels to increase rather than the other way around...X But, even where there is experimental evidence on human aggression, it may lack validity = "aggression" demonstrated may not be like aggression in a more natural environment e.g. the answers on Van Goozen\'s questionnaire may reflect what the transitioning GID patients believe they should say to fulfil their new role rather than a true measure of aggression...X The hormonal explanation is deterministic = it is denied that we have free will in our aggression behaviour i.e. suggesting that individuals with high testosterone are unable to control and therefore can\'t be blamed for our aggression...
Frustration-hypothesis modelSLTDeindividuation

Dollard (1939) - All aggression is the result of frustration. Frustration= "any event or stimulus that prevents an individual from attaining some goal and its accompanying reinforcing quality".When an obstacle blocks a goal, the frustration created leads to an aggressive drive, which once released allows the individual to experience CATHARSIS.

Proximity to goal:Confederates were instructed to push their way in front of people queuing. If they were closer to the front of the queue (in front of the 2nd person) the other people were more likely to react with verbal aggression than if they were at the back of the queue (in front of the 12th person).Environmental cues:Ps were given electric shocks in a lab situation to create frustration. The individual who gave the shocks was a confederate to the researchers. The Ps then had the opportunity to give electric shocks to the confederate. In one condition, 2 guns were present on the table next to the shock generator; in the second condition there were no guns present. With guns present, the no. of shocks given to the P was 6.07 vs 4.67 (presence environmental stimuli related to aggressive behaviour can cognitively prime aggressive behaviour following frustration.)Expectation of success:Kulick and Brown led participants involved in telephoning for charity donations to believe they could expect a high or low degree of success. They then received no donations. Ps with the greatest expectations showed more aggression than those with lower expectations e.g. slamming the phone down.Perceived justification of frustration:Pastore asked participants how they would react to a number of situations e.g. a bus driving by them vs a bus driving by them with an "out of service" message displayed. When the frustration was "justified" vs "unjustified", participants expressed much lower levels of anger.

X The explanation has real world applications in explaining cases of aggression = increased validity of the explanation e.g. after WWI, many ordinary Germans were led to believe that the Jews were to blame for the loss and the dire economic situation of the country. This frustration was followed by aggression towards Jews...X Aggression is only one possible response to frustration = the FAH is over-simplistic, as F isn\'t SUFFICIENT to produce aggression e.g. some respond to frustration with despair or depression...X Not all aggression is related to frustration = the FAH is over-simplistic, as F is not NECESSARY to produce aggression e.g. e.g. pain, extreme temperature and noxious stimuli have all been shown to stimulate aggression...X Some research has found that aggression is likely to lead to MORE aggression in the future = contradicts the explanation i.e. the catharsis following an aggressive act should reduce the aggressive drive...X Much of the research is based on hypothetical situations = the research many lack ecological validity i.e. Ps predictions of how they would act may not be representative of how they would at in a situation, due to social desirability bias etc...

A psychological state in which an individual loses their personal identity and takes on the identity of a social group. It can explain why people may act in an uncharacteristically aggressive way in a group/ when placed in a particular role (esp. when wearing a uniform).

In western society we have strong norms against aggression and in our individuated states people in public places generally carry out continual self-assessment of their behaviour to ensure compliance with social norms.However in particular conditions (e.g. darkness, drugs, alcohol, uniforms, masks, disguises), the sense of anonymity leads to a shift to the de-individuated state. In this state we lose self-awareness and so stop monitoring and regulating our own behaviour. Social norms are ignored, and as a result behaviour may become anti-normative and disinhibited, increasing the likelihood of aggression.

cards.term: Evidence for the role of deindividuation in aggression
cards.definition: Diener: A natural experiment. On the night of Halloween, concealed raters observed 1300 child trick or treaters under different conditions: one condition of anonymity, one of non-anonymity, and then conditions of being alone or in a group. The children were given the opportunity to steal sweets and money. Those children who were in a group and anonymous were the group who stole the most at 57%, compared to 21% in the group that were identifiable/ alone but anonymous. 8% stole when identified and alone. =in a group, children are more likely to behave in a socially deviant way, therefore supporting deindividuation theory as a social psychological theory of aggression.Zimbardo: Female undergrads divided into 2 groups. Group 1 with large name tags to wear and could see each other during the study. Group 2 in loose fitting lab coats, hoods over faces and were kept away from other Ps during the study. All Ps were asked to observe a woman (a confederate) being interviewed, and to evaluate her performance. Half the time, the interviewee was a mild mannered pleasant woman, and half the time she was rude and obnoxious. "Evaluation"= administering (fake) electric shocks. Group 1 shocked the rude interviewee more than the pleasant interviewee. Group 2 shocked both interviewees equally. = the Ps aggressive behaviour to the interviewees in group 2 may have been triggered by their anonymous state (hood), and in turn, a reduction of self-awareness which would normally prevent aggressive behaviour as a result of this deindividuation.

cards.term: Evaluation of the deindividuation explanation of aggression
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x94 The research has practical applications =it can be used to reduce the risk of aggression through the suggestion that reducing individual\'s anonymity, and in turn, increasing their self awareness, could prevent deindividuation e.g. \xc2\xa3300,000 a year is spent on installing and maintaining CCTV systems in Britain...\xe2\x9c\x94The association between deindividuation and aggression appear to cross-culturally = the theory is not ethnocentric e.g. Watson studied 23 cultures for the nature of warfare practices .It was found that in cultures where warriors concealed their identity by wearing face and body paints, they were more aggressive than those who were more identifiable . In particular, they were significantly more likely to engage in the mutilation/torture of prisoners, and were more likely to kill those they captured...X Experimental evidence on de-individuation may have been affected by extraneous variables. This is because the nature of the guards/KKK type hoods used may have led to demand characteristics that Ps were responding to, as these garments have associations with aggression. e.g. this was supported in a replication of Zimbardo\'s electric shock experiment, but rather than the KKK style hoods the Ps had to wear, Johnson and Downing\'s Ps wore surgical masks and gowns to deliver electric shocks. In this variation, the Ps gave significantly less shocks than those who wore the name badges, despite being relatively anonymous...X It is not true that deindividuation always leads to aggressive behaviour. This disputes the theory e.g. in Gergen et al\'s "black room" experiment, participants spent an hour together in either a completely dark or normally lit room. In the former condition, participants began to discuss serious matters, 90% deliberately touched each other, 50% hugged, and 80% admitted to experiencing sexual arousal...
Aggression is acquired through a process of observational learning in social contexts.

cards.term: The process of SLT in aggression
cards.definition: Identification: This happens with the model, involving taking on a range of their observed behaviours, values, beliefs & attitudes. Particularly likely to happen with a model who is attractive, similar, high status etc.Modelling: Aggressive behaviour which is observed, and having been observed can be imitated. One person is the model (who provides the example), the other individual (e.g. the child) interprets the behaviour.Imitation: Copying aggressive behaviour of the model.Reinforcement: When aggressive behaviour becomes associated with a positive or negative response. If the response to the behaviour is positively reinforces, it is more likely to be repeated (can occur vicariously).
Attention, retention, motivation, and motor reproduction affect learning, coming between observation of aggressive behaviour and demonstration of that behaviour (SLT).

Bandura: 72 children aged 3-6 (36 boys, 36 girls) put in 3 groups: 1: watched adult model kick/hit/sit on a Bobo doll for 9 minutes, accompanied by aggressive comments e.g. "pow", "kick him" (half watched a same-sex, half an opposite sex model) vs 2: watched an adult model act non-aggressively vs 3: no model.The children were annoyed then allowed to play in the room with the Bobo doll for 20 minutes whilst experimenters watched through a one-way mirror. Ps in condition 1 were significantly more physically and verbally aggressive than those who didn\'t receive aggressive modelling, and imitation was greatest of a same sex model.= children can learn aggressive behaviour through observation of a model and this is more likely if they identify with the model.2nd part1: Children saw an aggressive adult model being rewarded by a second adult vs 2: Children saw a second adult telling off the adult model for the aggressive behaviour vs 3: Adult model was neither rewarded or punished.Children behaved the most aggressively in condition 1 and least in condition 2.= children are most likely to demonstrate aggressive behaviour they have learned if they observe vicarious positive reinforcement, and least if they observe vicarious punishment.

X The SLT can explain cross cultural differences in aggression = it is not ethnocentric, as the theory can explain how the same processes can lead to the specific forms of aggression seen in different cultures to develop e.g. Mead found The Arapesh is an example of a non-aggressive culture in which aggression is not modelled or reinforced by adults, whereas for The Mundugumor violence is the norm and status is determined by the amount of aggression shown. XThe research that the SLT explanation of aggression is based on was a snapshot study = demonstrating the short term impact of observing an aggressive model, but not the long term effects e.g. there is no evidence that the aggressive behaviour continued... X Early evidence for SLT of aggression comes from experimental studies and so may have been affected by demand characteristics = the children behaved as they believe they were expected to rather than experiencing true aggressive drives e.g. the children may have believed they were supposed to copy the adults, particularly as the Bobo dolls were designed to be hit.XEarly evidence for SLT of aggression comes from experimental studies and so may lack ecological validity. This means that the artificial nature of the set up may have led to the children not demonstrating natural behaviour e.g. e.g. a doll is not a living person and does not retaliate...HOWEVER \xe2\x9c\x94 When Bandura had children watch a film about an adult model hitting a live clown, and found that when allowed into a room with the same clown, the aggression WAS imitated.

Aggressive behaviour that exists within certain institutions/ groups e.g. educational and healthcare settings, prisons. It can also refer to other forms of collective aggression between social groups, based on the racial/national/religious characteristics of members of one group e.g. warfare, terrorist activities.

e.g. Deprivation Model stating the characteristics of the prison itself, rather than the population which accounts for aggression in prison. It is argued that it is the deprivations of imprisonment that causes extreme stress and frustration, and in turn, aggression against other inmates/ prison staff e.g. Deprivation of liberty, autonomy, goods and services, heterosexual relationships and of security.

cards.term: Evidence for the situation model of institutional aggression
cards.definition: Wilson argued that most violence occurs in environments that are hot, noise-polluted and overcrowded. By changing these factors (cooler, music to drown out prison noises and an outside view), there was a dramatic decrease in violence in 2 special units he designed for the most violent prisoners in the UK.= situational factors can be used to control the occurrence of institutional aggression.Zimbardo\'s prison study: all the "guards" assessed as being psychologically sound before entering the prison. However, who then went on to show extremely aggressive behaviour towards the inmates = it was the situation the guards were in rather than the disposition of those guards that led to their aggression.

e.g. The Importation Model:People who enter prison do so already possessing certain \xc2\xac\xc2\xactraits (i.e. values, attitudes and experiences) that predispose them towards interpersonal violence within prison, so any interpersonal violence is a product of the characteristics they import into the institution, rather than the institution itself. This aggressive behaviour is the same as they will have demonstrated in normal society.

cards.term: Evidence for the dispositional model of institutional aggression
cards.definition: Poole and Regoli: in 4 juvenile offender institutes, pre-institutional violence was the best predictor of inmate aggression, regardless of particular features of the institution e.g. overcrowding.= the dispositional characteristics of the prisoners are more influential in institutional aggression than situational factors.Baskin et al: controlling for background, certain psychiatric impairments increased the probability of aggressive behaviour in inmates e.g. depression= self-harm, confusion=towards in mates and staff, depression & confusion= towards property. = specific dispositional factors are associated with specific forms of aggression.

cards.term: Evaluation of research on institutional aggression
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x94 The situational model has practical applications = it could be used to control institutional aggression e.g. In Nottingham\'s Lowdham Grange Prison, landlines have been installed to allow calls to be made to a select few numbers. Stats show the prison has been safer since suggesting that reducing deprivations can reduce likelihood of aggression...\xe2\x9c\x94 The dispositional model also has practical applications = it could be used to control institutional aggression e.g. Aggression could be dealt with by programmes such as anger management...X Institutional aggression may not be universal in nature between different prison populations = different types of prisoner may be affected differently by situational/dispositional factors e.g. Poole & Regoli\'s finding of pre-institutional violence predicting violence in a juvenile institution was not replicated in adult prisons in other studies...X Institutional aggression may not be a homogeneous phenomenon = different forms may have different causes e.g. Jiang & Fisher-Giorlando found that aggression towards fellow inmates was best explained by the importation model whereas aggression towards staff was influenced to a greater extent by situational factors...X The research on institutional aggression is androcentric = it is biased towards understanding the behaviour of male inmates. However, e.g. although there are still incidences of aggression, female offenders often develop strong bonds with other prisoners...

TV, video games etc. It is thought that computer games may have greater potential to influence behaviour than other forms of media because of their interactive nature, and some have blamed violent video games for specific crimes (e.g. the Columbine High School massacre). However, others argue against this point (SLT can be used as a theory to explain these results, as well as cognitive mechanisms on the next page).

cards.term: Evidence for media influences on aggression
cards.definition: LEARN 2Experimental evidence: Bartholemew and Anderson: students played either a violent computer game or a non-violent video game (for 10 minutes. Ps then were allowed to deliver blasts of white noise to punish a (non-existent) competitor. They were able to select the duration and intensity of blast. Those who played the violent game selected significantly higher noise levels than the non-violent game players (6.97 vs 4.6dBs) =playing violent computer games results in aggressive behaviour.Correlational evidenceDeLisi et al: 227 juvenile offenders with histories of serious aggression interviewed to gather data on their video game habits and measures of aggression. There was a significant relationship between their aggressive behaviour and frequency of violent game playing/ how much they enjoyed violent games = that playing violent computer games regularly is associated with higher levels of aggression.Longitudinal evidence Huesmann et al: 557 children aged 6-10 growing up in Chicago in 1977, and then revisited again in 1992. Habitual early exposure to TV violence was predictive of adult physical aggression later in life for both boys and girls, even when SES, IQ and parenting styles were controlled for = exposure to media violence in childhood increases the chance of aggressive behaviour in adulthood.Meta-analyses Anderson et al performed a meta- analysis of 136 studies using different methodology. They found that exposure to violent computer games was associated with increases in aggressive behaviours, thoughts and feelings. This was true in males and females, in collectivist and individualistic cultures. The effect was stronger in higher quality research = exposure to media violence universally increases the chance of aggressive behaviour.

cards.term: Evidence for research on media influences on aggression
cards.definition: X Data may be skewed by "publication bias" which means that significant results are more likely to get published i.e. this is sometimes called the "file drawer problem" as non-significant results often get left in the filing cabinet, thus reducing the validity of the argument that exposure to violent computer games leads to aggression is reduced.X Some critics argue that the published research "overstates the case" for the influence of computer game violence = the argument that media violence increases aggression may be exaggeratede.g. Ferguson and Kilburn (09) noted that when aggression towards another person of violent crime is the measurement of aggression, the relationship between exposure to media and violent behaviour is close to zero. Therefore, the relationship may be less important in real life than originally thought.X The research may have been confounded by extraneous variables e.g. Ferguson et al\'s meta analysis showed that the effects of aggressive media disappear when other potential influences such as trait aggression, family violence and mental health are taken into account = the validity of the argument that exposure to violent computer games is reduced.X It may be the frustration caused by the game rather than the violence portrayed per se which is the root of the aggressive behaviour linked to playing violent computer games e.g. even non-violent video games leave Ps feeling aggressive if they are poorly designed or too difficult = the results of studies on media violence may not have been testing what they set out to test.

cards.term: The role of desensitisation, disinhibition and cognitive priming
cards.definition: Most studies have focussed on establishing merely whether or not there is a link between exposure to media violence and aggressive behaviour. However, it is also important to examine possible reasons for why there does seem to be a link i.e. desensitisation, disinhibition and cognitive priming.

Carnegey et al: Ps were randomly allocated to play a violent or non-violent game for 20 mins. They then watched a 10 min film depicting real life violence whilst their physiological responses were measured. Those who\'d played a violent game demonstrated lower arousal = exposure to aggression reduces the body\'s response to it.

\xe2\x9c\x94 There is evidence that the decreased in arousal from repeated exposure to violence does impact on behaviour e.g. Bushman and Anderson showed that exposure to violence results in decreased helping behaviour to others in distress, giving the explanation ecological validity.X The outcome of desensitisation has been challenged: some argue that it would have the opposite effect i.e. if someone has a diminished response to a violent stimulus it could be argued that they be less inclined to act violently. Therefore the effects of this mechanism are unclear.X The effects of desensitisation may not be universal, meaning it may affect individuals differently i.e. media exposure is widespread, yet we are not all affected equally. Therefore results of research cannot necessarily be generalised to all individuals.
Normal social constraints against certain behaviours can be weakened by environmental triggers. These behaviours then appear temporarily socially acceptable and therefore more likely.

Berkowitz and Alioto: Carried out a laboratory experiment where participants who saw a film that depicted aggression as vengeance (revenge) gave more (fake) electric shocks of longer duration to a confederate.= seeing violence portrayed as acceptable increases the likelihood of it being performed.

X The effects of disinhibition may have a limited impact on real life behaviour as it may be restricted to the very short term i.e. effects of disinhibition seemed to be contained in the time period when the game is being played = the results of studies may not have much relevance in the real world..X The effects of disinhibition are subject to individual differences, and so cannot be generalised e.g. effects of disinhibition may only occur in people who are fully engaged in playing without being easily distracted (e.g. introverts)= disinhibition may not be an important mechanism in determining most individuals\' behaviour.

Violent images provide us with ready-made "scripts" about aggression which are stored in memory and are triggered when we perceive aggressive cues in a situation, making aggressive behaviour more likely.

Fischer and Greitemeyer: Male participants who had been exposed to aggressive song lyrics about women recalled more negative attributes of women and reporting higher levels of aggression towards women. This procedure was replicated with female participants and \'men hating\' song lyrics with similar results = exposure to aggressive stimuli can prime individuals be aggression themselves.

cards.term: Evaluation of research on cognitive priming
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x94 The evidence on cognitive priming has practical applications as it can be utilised in real life e.g. Holloway et al (77) found that Ps who overheard a prosocial message on the radio before entering a studying involving bargaining were more cooperative. This demonstrates that cognitive priming can be used to encourage positive behaviour.\xe2\x9c\x94 There is biological evidence to support the cognitive priming mechanism e.g. brain scanning has confirmed areas of the brain involved in emotion and those for storing episodic memories are activated when exposed to violent films. This strengthens the explanation.
A) 2 or more symptoms.B) One or more major areas of functioning are below what they were before.C) Continuous signs of the disturbance persist for 6 months, including at least 1 month of symptoms.
Positive and negative
Symptoms not present in people in the normal population.
Hallucinations, delusions, disorganised speech, disorganisied behaviour
Perceptions that have no basis in reality e.g. hearing voices, seeing things.
False beliefs that are firmly held despite being completely illogical e.g. delusions of persecution, delusions of grandeur.
Irregular speech patterns e.g. Rambling monologues, choosing words for rhyme rather than meaning.
Motor disturbance e.g. catatonic excitement/ stupor
Thoughts, feelings, or behaviors normally present that are absent or diminished in a person with a mental disorder.
AvolitionSpeech poverty
Decreased speech production/ fluency
The reduction, difficulty, or inability to start and continue with goal-directed behaviour e.g. no longer being interested in going out and meeting with friends.

-Paranoid: hallucinations & delusions -Hebephrenic : disorganised speech and behaviour.-Catatonic Schizophrenia: disorganised behaviour.-Undifferentiated: general positive symptoms.-Residual Schizophrenia-people who have once suffered from severe positive symptoms which have now reduced. Negative symptoms remain.

Do the same clinicians making the same diagnosis on different occasions from the same information?e.g. Read et al (04) showed when a person is diagnosed with schizophrenia, there is only a 38% chance of them being diagnosed again on a re-test at a later time.This suggests there is some subjectivity in applying the diagnostic criteria to identifying schizophrenia.

cards.term: Factors affecting the reliability/ validity of diagnosis
cards.definition: -Symptom overlap*-Co-morbidity*-Gender bias*-Culture bias*-Test-retest reliability-Self report methods-Ps taking medication

cards.term: The implications of invalid diagnosis of sz
cards.definition: -recommendation of unsuitable treatment inc. institutionalisation (which can lead to (loss of rights/responsibility); -stigmatisation; -loss of self-esteem; -creation of a self-fulfilling prophecy.

The presence of one of ore additional disorders or diseases simultaneously occurring with sz.= the reliability and therefore validity of diagnosis is reduced as there is potential to confuse symptoms of schizophrenia with another. e.g. Buckleyreported an estimated 50% of Ss had co-morbid depression, 15% panic disorder, 29% PTSD, 23% OCD and 47% substance abuse.

Over diagnosing members of other cultures as suffering for sz, suggesting psychiatrists may base their diagnosis on their culture based expectations rather than the objective symptoms, leading to an invalid diagnosis. e.g. McGovern and Cope (87) found two-thirds of psychotic patients held in hospitals in Birmingham were African-Caribbean, compared with only one-third who were white and Asian.

The tendency for diagnosis criteria to be applied differently to males and females, suggesting that psychiatrists may base their diagnosis on their gender based expectations rather than the objective symptoms. e.g. Loring and Powell randomly selected 290 psychiatrists to assess 2 case studies. When the patient was described as M, or no information was given about gender, the description resulted in a diagnosis of S 56% of the time, however if the patient was labelled F they received this diagnosis 20% of the time. The bias was not so prevalent amongst female psychiatrists.

None of the symptoms of schizophrenia are exclusive to this disorder = reliability and therefore validity of diagnosis of sz is reduced as the same symptom could be an indicator of more than one disorder. e.g. Konstantareas & Hewitt compared 14 autistic Ps with 14 schizophrenic Ps. Although no schizophrenic Ps demonstrated autistic symptoms, 7 autistic Ps demonstrated symptoms of schizophrenia.
Schizophrenia can be inherited.

-GottesmanReview of 40 studies over 60 years. Rate of concordance for schizophrenia= 48% in MZ vs. 17% in DZ twins.= biological component to developing S as MZ twins who share 100% of their genes have a higher concordance for S than DZ, who only share 50%.-Kety et al (68)Looking at schizophrenics who\'d been given up for adoption as children-Rate of schizo. in their adopted parents was \'normal\' (2%)-Rate of schizo. in their biological parents was \'high\' (13%)= biological component to developing S as there is greater concordance for S between the P and their bio fam with whom they share genes than their adopted fam with whom they share environmental influences.

X MZs are often reared in a more similar environment than DZs. = an extraneous variable, the effect of which would weaken support for the genetic explanation e.g. it may be this variable which has overinflated MZ concordance...X MZ concordance is not 100% = genetics are not the sole cause of S, i.e. if it were, MZ concordance for S should be 100%...XIn early studies, classification of zygosity was based on appearance = data may be invalid e.g. if DZ twins were mistakenly classified as MZ, this could reduce the apparent "MZ" concordance...X In discordant MZs about half go on to develop a schizophrenia-like disorder = the genetic explanation may be more valid than it appears e.g. if a broader definition of S was used, MZ concordance ...
Suggests the development of sz is related to structural and functional brain abnormalities e.g. the dopamine hypothesis.

Suggests the development of sz is related to an increased rate of neural communication because of -excess levels of dopamine in the brain, -more/extra sensitive dopamine receptors OR,-slower re-uptake of dopamine from synapses.

cards.term: Evidence for neural correlates/ dopamine hypothesis
cards.definition: Drugs which have been developed to treat the positive symptoms of schizophrenia are dopamine antagonists (block dopamine receptors)= high levels of dopamine are associated with sz symptoms, before treatment begins.-L-Dopa for Parkinson\'s (caused by too little dopamine) acts by stimulating dopamine synthesis. A side effect is schizophrenic- like positive symptoms.= high levels of dopamine are associated with S symptoms, and so S Ps may already naturally have increased levels.

cards.term: Evaluation of the neural correlates/ dopamine hypothesis
cards.definition: X Much evidence is correlational = it cannot establish cause and effect e.g. it may be that increased dopamine causes S, OR that S dopamine levels to increase..X Dopamine has only been linked to the positive symptoms of schizophrenia = the dopamine hypothesis is not a comprehensive explanation of S i.e. it leaves the negative symptoms unaccounted for...XAbout 30% of schizophrenics are not helped by traditional dopamine antagonists = the dopamine hypothesis is not a comprehensive explanation of S i.e. if all S Ps had increased dopamine, they should all be helped by the drugs...X Other nts have more recently been linked to schizophrenia. This suggests that the dopamine hypothesis is reductionist by ignoring other influences e.g. newer drugs also bind to serotonin receptors...

cards.term: Overall evaluation of biological explanations of sz
cards.definition: X Biological explanations are reductionist = they reduce a complex disorder to the underlying biological components, alone, which may be over simplistic e.g. there is also evidence that family dysfunction plays a role in the disorder...X Biological explanations are deterministic = they don\'t allow that we have free will e.g. if a person has a gene for schizophrenia, it suggests that it inevitable that they will develop it...

cards.term: Psychological explanations - 2 examples of family dysfunction
cards.definition: -Schizophrenogenic mother-Expressed emotion

Based on the Psychodynamic approach to psychology, early theories assumed that disruption to early family relationships affects the way a child perceives reality and interacts with the world e.g. Fromm-Reichmann suggested that a particular mothering style causes S: a "schizophrenogenic mother" is domineering, cold, rejecting and guilt producing. Together with a passive and ineffectual father, these mothers "drive" their children to sz. THE EXCESSIVE STRESS TRIGGERS THEIR PSYCHOTIC THINKING AS THEY WITHDRAW FROM REALITY.

cards.term: Evidence for the schizophrenogenic mother explanation
cards.definition: Schofield and Balian:178 Ps with and 150 matched controls without schizophrenia, interviewed abouta) the quality of relationships between their parents: no significant difference found.b) childhood traumas: S patients significantly LESS likely to have experienced a trauma c) maternal characteristics: S patients reported their mothers as being less affectionate, more domineering and overprotective.= schizophrenogenic traits in a mother are associated with sz in their children.

cards.term: Evaluation of the schizophrenogenic mother explanation
cards.definition: X The data the theory is based on is unreliable =it is based on retrospectively gathered self report data i.e. S patients may not remember past event accurately, and may have a biased recollection of past events as a result of events which proceeded those recalled...XThe evidence cannot establish a cause and effect relationship = the evidence merely shows an association i.e. it may be a schizophrenogenic mother that triggers sz in their child OR it could be the early sz symptoms which lead the mother to become cold and rejecting...X Overall, attempts find evidence that mothers cause schizophrenia have not been successful. This then evidence has moved focus to communication styles of the family as a whole, and how they determine the course of schizophrenia e.g. expressed emotion...

The attitudes expressed by family members when talking about the schizophrenic family member. High levels of negative EE have been linked to schizophrenia.It is measured along 5 scales using the Camberwell Family Interview when a S patient is admitted to hospital. Families high in EE get high scores on:-Critical comments about family members-Hostility-Emotional over-involvementAnd low scores on warmth and positive remarks.IT IS LINKED TO RELAPSE OF SZ

cards.term: Evidence for the expressed emotion explanation
cards.definition: Vaughn and Leff : 128 patients followed up after being discharged to their families after a period of hospitalisation. Those who returned had a relapse rate of 12/15% (on vs not on medication). Those who had less than 35h contact with their high EE families had a relapse rate of 15/42%, and those with more than 35hr contact had 53/92% relapse.= there is an association between spending a lot of time with a family high in EE and relapsing.

cards.term: Evaluation of the expressed emotion explanation
cards.definition: X nEE is usually only measured once, when the patient has just been admitted to hospital = it may be an unrepresentative measurement i.e. EE may be uncharacteristically high at that point, due to the stress caused by the S patient being admitted to hospital...X The EE explanation s based on correlational evidence = it can\'t establish a cause an effect relationship between high EE and schizophrenia e.g. there is evidence that levels of EE drop during periods when the S patient is displaying fewer symptoms, suggesting that EE is a result rather than a cause of EE...X The explanation doesn\'t explain the onset of the disorder, only the relapse = it is not a complete explanation in itself i.e. there may be biological factors which cause the original symptoms...

cards.term: Evaluation of the family dysfunction explanation overall
cards.definition: X The explanation blames families = raising ethical issues e.g. if families are made to experience guilt, this may only lead to raised EE, worsening the issue (this is particularly unethical, is for example, biological factors are the real underlying cause of sz)...X The explanation aims to attempt to understand the sz patient in the context of their family environment = the explanations are not reductionist i.e. unlike the cognitive and biological explanations, the whole person/family system is studies...\xe2\x9c\x94The explanations have practical implications = it has some use in the real world i.e. suggesting that therapy for sz should be given to the family as a whole rather than the sz patient in isolation...

Sz Ps demonstrate dysfunctional information processing in comparison to those without the disorder, giving rise to their positive symptoms e.g. deficits in attention, theory of mind and source monitoring.

cards.term: Attention deficits and evidence of these in sz Ps
cards.definition: Ss have a faulty attention filter so preconscious thoughts that are usually filtered out as unimportant are interpreted in conscious awareness as more significante.g.Carter et al used fMRI scanning to analyse the performance of szs during a visual selective attention task. They made many more incorrect responses and displayed a slower mean response time than controls.= could explain why Ss experience delusions and hallucinations, as they are overloaded with sensory information.

cards.term: Theory of mind deficits and evidence of these in sz Ps
cards.definition: Reduced ablility to infer other\'s beliefs/intentionse.g.Corcoran et al: a series of visual cartoon jokes were presented to patients with sz. Some of these were based around physical humour, and some necessitated the understanding of the mental state of the protagonist. szs found the mental state cartoons more difficult to understand than the non-ToM cartoon vs healthy controls/ patients in remission who understood both forms of cartoon equally well.= could explain why S patients hold delusions about the intentions of others.

cards.term: Source monitoring deficits and evidence of these in sz Ps
cards.definition: S patients are impaired in monitoring the source of actions/thoughts as "being done by me"/"mine"e.g. Bentall et al: Ps had to read out category items (e.g. animals beginning with B) or generate them themselves. One week later, Ps had to decide which words they\'d read/ generated/ which were new. S patients with hallucinations were worse than those without, and both were worse than controls. = could be used to explain why S patients experience hallucinations e.g. misattributing their inner speech to external sources.

\xe2\x9c\x94 Doesn\'t preclude biological explanations = doesn\'t rule out the possible influence of biological factors e.g. increased dopamine levels may give rise to the dysfunctional information processing...\xe2\x9c\x94 Practical applications = it is practically useful i.e. CBT has been developed, based on the assumption that changing dysfunctional information processing will reduce Ss symptoms...\xe2\x9c\x94 CBT has been shown to be effective in the treatment of S = the cognitive explanation has support i.e. if changing information processing improves symptoms, it suggests dysfunctional information processing was the cause of the S...

X Cognitive deficits correlate with schizophrenic symptoms = it is not possible to establish the direction of cause and effect e.g. it could be that S causes dysfunctional information processing rather than the other way round...X The cognitive explanation is reductionist = it oversimplifies the disorder of schizophrenia i.e. it reduces the condition to the simplest component of thought processes, neglecting social factors such as the role of family dysfunction...X In cognitive experiments, the S group have usually been treated with medication, unlike the control groups = the effects of being medication may be an extraneous variable i.e. it maybe this rather than sz itself which leads to dysfunctional information processing...
Drug therapy:-Typical antipsychotics-Atypical antisychotics

"Conventional" antipsychotics (e.g. chlorpromazine, haloperidol) work by binding to dopamine receptors (without stimulating them), thereby reducing the effect of dopamine at the receptors. They are "dopamine antagonists". They block dopamine receptors in all areas of the brain. These drugs lead to hallucinations and delusions subsiding within a few days.

cards.term: Evidence on the effectiveness of typical antipsychotics
cards.definition: Cole et al compared the symptoms of schizos. taking chlorpromazine for 6 weeks to a control/placebo group. 75% of patients were "much improved" vs. 25%.= typical antipsychotics were effective, causing greater improvement that the "placebo effect" alone.

X Severe side effects = patients may be more likely to not adhere to treatment e.g. blocking dopamine receptors in the "extrapyramidal areas" of the brain, which control movement, can result in Parkinsonism (over 50% of patients), and later, tardive dyskinesia (in 10% of long term users)...X The drugs only treat positive symptoms = antipsychotics alone are not likely to offer a complete treatment, with other treatments needed in conjunction i.e. negative symptoms, affecting functioning in everyday life, are likely to persist...X The drugs fail to improve the symptoms of around 25% of szs = the effectiveness of typical antipsychotics are subject to individual differences i.e. a range of treatments beyond these drugs is required to offer help to the broad range of S patients...
Second generation antipsychotics (e.g. clozapine, olanzapine) bind to dopamine receptors. They dissociate much more rapidly than typical antipsychotics. They also bind to serotonin receptors.

cards.term: Evidence for the effectiveness of atypical antipsychotics
cards.definition: Meltzer found that up to 66% of patients with symptoms which had not been helped by typical drugs, DID respond to atypical drugs within 12 months= atypical antipsychotics can be a useful treatment where typical antipsychotics have not reduced symptoms.

X More expensive than typical antipsychotics = less widely available e.g. esp. in the UK where the funding of the NHS is very limited...\xe2\x9c\x94 Offer a broader range of improvements than typical antipsychotics = more likely to be adequate as a sole treatment i.e. the drugs treat positive and negative symptoms. This \xe2\x9c\x94 Less severe side effects than typical antipsychotics but are still serious = sz patients may be less likely to adhere to medication e.g. Clozapine can cause a decrease in white blood cells, sedation, hypersalivation and weight gain...
CBTpFamily therapy

A form of CBT modified to treat psychotic disorders like sz. Helps the patient to identify and correct their dysfunctional interpretations of events, in order to change their behaviour, and therefore improve their functioning. 16 sessions are recommended.

Assessment- patient expresses their thoughts about their experiences. Realistic goals are discussed, using the patient\'s current distress as motivation for change.Engagement- therapist empathises with the patient\'s perspective and distress.ABC Model: The patient is taught that it is their beliefs (B) that are the real cause of what they have been experiencing (C), rather than the activating events (A) which have seemed to be the cause.Normalisation: The patient is taught that many people can have psychotic-like experiences in a range of different circumstances (stressful events, torture, hunger, when asleep, etc). This reduces anxiety and the sense of isolation by "decatastrophising" the psychotic experiences. The therapist uses gentle questioning to help the patient dispute (D) illogical deductions and conclusions. The therapist remains empathetic and non-judgmental.The patient develops their own alternative explanations (E) for their previously distressing assumptions.

Morrison et al:A single blind, randomised control trial on 74 patients, not taking medication. 37 had the "treatment as usual" offered, and 37 given CBT alongside the "treatment as usual" (Ps came from different areas, so "treatment as usual" varied, but control for this, the same number of Ps from each area were assigned to each condition). Therapy lasted 26 sessions/9m. At this point, x2 as many CBT patients had positive clinical outcomes. This was maintained 18 months later. In addition, CBT had improved personal and social functioning.= there is highly reliable evidence that the addition of CBT to treatment programmes would be useful in helping to treat the symptoms of S, both immediately and in the long term.Morrison et al "At risk" adolescents were given CBT. It CBT didn\'t reduce the number of Ps who went on to develop their first psychotic episode, but severity of that episode was reduced (by reducing the depression/anxiety usually experienced during a first episode).This suggests that CBT can be used pre-emptively to reduce the impact of S on young sufferers before they develop the condition.

\xe2\x9c\x94CBT allows patient to take some responsibility for own treatment = they are empowered e.g. by learning about the origins of their disorder and how they can reduce their symptoms...\xe2\x9c\x94Research supports the effectiveness of CBT alongside drug therapy = it is appropriate to combine the treatments e.g. once drugs allow the P to gain insight into their condition it is then possible to engage with CBT...\xe2\x9c\x94Effectiveness can be long term/ongoing = the nature of the treatment prevent relapse e.g. by teaching Ps to take control over the dysfunctional thoughts which trigger their symptoms...

X Most evidence on the effectiveness has been carried out on patients who have also been prescribed medication = it is difficult to conclude how effective CBT is e.g. it is difficult to separate out the effects of CBT vs the medication...X CBT requires self-awareness and willingness to engage with process = CBT may not be suitable for all sz patients/at every stage of the illness e.g. not all Ps have these traits/ positive symptoms can lead to lack of awareness & negative symptoms lead to reluctance/inability to engage...X Not all clients are suited to vigorous confrontation = CBT may not persevere with the therapy e.g. they drop out due to dislike of the methods used...

As dysfunctional communication patterns in families such as high expressed emotion have been found to be linked to relapse, family therapy has been developed to reduce re-hospitalisation of sz patientsLasts for at least 10 sessions over a period of 3-12 months. Recommended for all sz patients in contact with their families, but it\'s prioritised for those with a high risk of relapse.

Psychoeducation: Family members are taught about the symptoms of sz in order to help them understand the patient\'s experiences.Reducing emotional climate: Family members are put in touch with social support networks in order to control stress levels and create a more tolerant environment for the sz.Skills training Therapy : concentrates on teaching problem solving techniques and communication skills such as how to reduce criticism and over-involvement.
Behaviorist theory, reinforces target behavior by rewarding tokens which can be exchanged for material goods. uses operant conditioning.

Pharoah et al: 53 randomised control studies conducted between 2002 and 2010 over 3 different continents were reviewed. All the studies compared outcomes for family therapy as opposed to "standard care".The following results were found:-Family therapy increased compliance.-Family therapy increased general functioning but not living independently/employment. -Family therapy reduced relapse during and in the 24months afterwards.= family therapy is an effective treatment on a range of measures.Garety et al:Estimated the rate of relapse to be 50% with standard care as opposed to 25% with family therapy.= can be used to halve relapse rates of sz by reducing the factors which usually trigger relapse such as high EE.

\xe2\x9c\x94Family therapy is cost effective = in the long term it reduces the impact of S on the economy i.e. by reducing relapse rates, patients don\'t have to be readmitted...\xe2\x9c\x94Family therapy has a wider positive impact on other family members = it is likely to have benefits to other family members e.g. improving relationships; reducing the likelihood of other family members becoming affected by mental illness...

X The evidence on the effectiveness of family therapy is methodologically flawed:--In Pharoah\'s study, it is not clear allocation was random in the Chinese studies = the type of family may be an EV e.g. if only the most nurturing families chose to have family therapy, it may be this trait rather than the therapy which led to improvements... --Not all 53 studies used blind raters = the data may be affected by researcher bias e.g. they may have perceived improvements to be greater than they were due to their expectations...X Effectiveness of family therapy may be related to increased compliance with medication = the data may be confounded i.e. famiy therapy may only be indirectly effective, and not actually improve the S symptoms itself...X Family therapy may only have short term effects = it may need to continue beyond initial improvements of the patient e.g. Hogarty et al (86) followed up patients into a second year after family therapy had ceased and found higher levels of relapse...
May be used whilst in the hospital to MANAGE sz patients\' symptoms. They are based on Skinnerian operant conditioning principles.\xe2\x80\xa2
Combine biological and environmentale. Anti psychotics + CBT.

Tokens are paired with rewarding stimuli (e.g. food, movie time) and so become secondary reinforcers. Patient engages in target desirable behaviour e.g. dressing themselves, tidying up after a meal. Patient is given tokens for engaging in these behaviours. Patient trades tokens for desirable items/ privileges. The more choice in rewards, the more powerful the tokens become.

Allyon and Azrin : A token economy was introduced to a psych ward to 45 sz women in hospital. Beforehand undesirable behaviours such as screaming, being mute and not using cutlery were exhibited. Tokens embossed with "one gift" were rewarded for positive behaviours such as completing chores, and could be exchanged for benefits like listening to music. Within 20 days, patients were on average showing an average of 40 improved behaviours.=TEcan be used to teach sz patients behaviour to counteract negative symptoms, making their behaviour more manageable in in a short space of time.-Paul and Lentz- 28 szs (half men, half women) who had been hospitalised for an average of 17 years, all receiving drug treatment, were given tokens as rewards for socially desirable behaviour such as bed-making, joining in with social events etc. in their free time. There could be exchanged for meals, cigarettes etc. This was maintained over 6 years.Behaviour observations, structured interviews and assessment scales were carried out regular intervals to measure social behaviour and level of functioning. By the end of the study 10% had been released from the unit to live independently, and 82.5% had been released into community care. =TE can be used to counteract the effects of institutionalisation, allowing S patients to return to the community.

X Token economies have only been shown to work in a hospital setting =the effects may not generalise to the real world i.e. without consistent reinforcement in a more natural environment, behaviour could revert to its prior state...X Involves clinicians exercising control over basic reinforcers such as food and stimulating activities = it raises ethical implications i.e. it could be argued that vulnerable Ps are being deprived of their freedoms for not conforming to expectations...X Targets observable behaviours = the therapy could be argued to be merely a superficial treatment i.e. cognitive and emotional symptoms of schizophrenia are not addressed ...X It has fallen out of favour =it has reduced in popularity, with alternative therapies taking its place e.g. social skills therapy has now superseded token economies inc conversation skills, medication self- management and employment skills...

cards.term: The importance of an interactionist approach in explaining and treating schizophrenia
cards.definition: They suggest that the best explanations combine biological, psychological and environmental elements, and therefore the best therapeutic outcomes will be obtained by a combination of drug therapies and psychotherapies.

cards.term: The interactionist approach to explaining sz
cards.definition: the Diathesis-Stress model: mental disorders are the result of an interaction between biological and environmental influences. -"Diathesis"=biological vulnerability (e.g. genetic factors, brain differences, excess dopamine); -"Stress" =environmental triggers (e.g. urban environment, childhood trauma, family dysfunction, drug use).
There are also interactionist approaches to treatment, with research suggesting that individuals who receive a combination of treatments tailored to their circumstances gain the best outcomes.

cards.term: Evidence for the interactionist approach to explaining sz
cards.definition: Tienari et al: Hospital records reviewed for nearly 20,000 women admitted to Finnish psych hospitals 1960-79 to identify those diagnosed S. The women\'s records examined to find those that had had one or more offspring adopted away (high risk children).145 of these high-risk adopted children matched with 158 low-risk adopted controls. Adoptive families of these children were assessed for functioning e.g. parent-offspring conflict. The interviewing psychiatrists were blind in this process. After 21 years...-Of all the children 11 high risk vs 3 low risk children developed S.. -High risk children raised in a well-functioning family significantly less likely to develop sz than high risk children in dysfunctional families. = genetic vulnerability increases risk of sz, but this risk can be minimised through being raised in a well-functioning family.van Os et al studied fingerprints of discordant MZ twins and found that szs have fingerprint abnormalities e.g. more ridges than their non-schizophrenic twin. Fingerprints develop in the second trimester of pregnancy when the baby is most at risk from viruses. =suggests that exposure to a virus can trigger a biological vulnerability to be expressed.

\xe2\x9c\x94 The approach is comprehensive = they take into account the breadth of risk factors/ target the broad range of the symptoms experiences by S patients e.g. genetic and environmental/positive and negative symptoms...\xe2\x9c\x94 Can explain why concordance rates between MZ twins are not 100% for schizophrenia = it shows a risk for S may be present into the genotype but not show in the phenotype i.e. one twin may be exposed to an environmental trigger that the other is not...

cards.term: Evidence for the interactionist approach to treating sz
cards.definition: Hogarty et al: Ps with S received either medication only, medication plus social skills training, medication plus family therapy or medication plus social skills training and family therapy.After 1 year 40% of medication only group relapsed vs. 20% of the medication + social skills/family therapy group vs. 0% of the group with all 3. (In a follow up after the 2nd year after family therapy/social skills training had ended, relapse rates had increased).= a combination of treatments produces the best outcomes for sz patients.Sudak found that antipsychotic drugs combined with CBT strengthens adherence to drug treatment.= an interactionist to treatment is more effective than using treatments in isolation.

X The original diathesis stress model assumed that the diathesis had to be genetic. However this overlooked other possible vulnerabilities e.g. it is now believed that vulnerability can be can be neurodevelopmental, due to birth trauma or early psychological trauma...  X In Tienari\'s study, interaction between the adoptee and the adoptive family may have been reciprocal = the direction of cause and effect cannot be established e.g. "dysfunctional" family relations may have been exacerbated by the S patients innate tendencies, rather than being the trigger for the S itself...X Combining therapies increase their cost in the short term =there are practical issues with administering interactionist treatment i.e. the NHS has limited funding...
The biological aspects of being male or female including chromosomes, hormones and anatomy.
The psychological and cultural aspects of being male or female including attitudes, behaviours and social roles.
Sex can\'t change but gender can.
Displaying a both typically masculine AND feminine characteristics in one\'s personality.
Bem\'s sex role inventory (BSRI)
Measure androgyny using a rating scale of 60 traits (20 masculine, 20 feminine and 20 neutral) to produce a masculinity and femininity score which are compared.
High femininity, low masculinity scores.
High masculininty, low feminininity scores.
High masculinity, high femininity scores.

-Good test retest reliability = individual\'s scores remain consistent when compared between repeated testing sessions i.e. there\'s a correlation between 0.76-0.94 between test scores over a 4 week period...-Biased results= data may lack validity e.g. most of the adjectives used in the test are socially desirable, and so Ps may show bias in rating themselves...\xe2\x80\xa2 Outdated = lacks temporal validity e.g. the characteristics used are based on what students judged to be desirable in the 70s...-Demonstrates a reductionist view of gender =oversimplifies gender related behaviours e.g. a person\'s masculinity & femininity are reduced to a single score...\xc2\xb7 There is evidence to that androgyny may not have a positive effect on wellbeing. This refutes Bem\'s assumption e.g. it has been associated with negative traits such as competitiveness...
A set of beliefs and preconceived ideas about what is expected or appropriate for males and females in a given society.

cards.term: How are sex role stereotypes formed?
cards.definition: Sex-role stereotypes may developed through observation, imitation and reinforcement (SLT); through development of cognitive awareness of gender, eg through the development of gender constancy (Kohlberg);or as part of the process of internalisation (Freud)
Seavey\'s baby X study

\xe2\x80\xa2Ps left to interact with a baby for 3 minutes after being told it was male/female/not told.\xe2\x80\xa2When the baby was labelled female, Ps were more likely to use the doll to play with child; when baby was labelled male, Ps used plastic ring toy etc.= Adults interact differently with infants depending on whether they believe they are male or female.:\xe2\x80\xa2The findings have real life implications = because the behavior of the adults did not match up with how the adults described the baby i.e. their stereotypes affected their behavior unconsciously.\xe2\x80\xa2The actual baby was kept constant in all the conditions. This controlled for the behavior of the baby, making conclusions more valid i.e. it can be concluded that it was the adult\'s that guided the interaction rather than the baby\'s behaviour.

cards.term: AO3 points for sex role stereotypes
cards.definition: \xf0\x9f\x98\x8a Sex role stereotypes guide expectations. This means that they provide a cognitive short-cut e.g. by providing a basis to predict what behaviour may be expected from males and females...\xe2\x98\xb9 Sex role stereotypes have socially sensitive implications. Tis is because they impact the treatment of people in everyday life e.g. shaping/limiting academic/career expectations\xe2\x98\xb9 Research on sex role stereotypes may lack temporal validity. This is because they are changing as a result of changing norms e.g. norms have shifted towards less stereotypical child-rearing and gender neutrality, eg clothing, toys, d\xc3\xa9cor etc ...\xe2\x98\xb9 Emphasising the role of sex role stereotypes on behaviour ignores the role od biology. This means the impact of hormones and genetics are not considered e.g. males\' increased levels of testosterone may be more important in typical male aggression than sex role stereotypes..
Differences in sex chromosomes (Males XY, females XX) cause gender differences.
Any sex chromosome pattern that deviates from the usual XX/XY formation and which tends to be associated with a distinct pattern of physical and psychological symptoms.

cards.term: Evidence for genetic explanation of gender
cards.definition: -Atypical chromosome patterns: suggests that atypical sex chromosomes can cause changes in gender-related behaviour, as despite receiving typical fe/male upbringing, Ps demonstrate differences when compared to people with typical chromosomes.-Money & Ehrhardt: advised the parents to raise accidentally the penectomised Bruce as a girl with the help of plastic surgery.Despite initially being reported as a success, Bruce eventually went public & revealed that he had become a man again = biological sex causes gender to develop, as despite being raised as female, Bruce strongly identified with his birth sex.
XO individual raised as female
In comparison to a typical female, demonstrate higher verbal ability, lower spatial ability, visual memory/maths skills, hypersensitivity & poor peer relations.
