XXY individual raised as male
in comparison to a typical male, have an extra X chromosome, genotype: XXY) demonstrate poor language skills in childhood, low reading ability, passive, shy & co-operative temperaments.

cards.term: Evaluation of evidence for genetic explanation of gender
cards.definition: Evidence on the effect of genes tends to come from case studies =what is revealed can\'t necessarily be generalised to normal gender development i.e. sample sizes are small, and often arise from unusual circumstances (for example Bruce had a twin brother, and did not have full female genital reconstruction, which may have led to the identification with the male gender)...
Sex hormones cause gender related behaviour: TESTOSTERONE, OESTROGEN, OXYTOCIN.

cards.term: Evidence for effect of testosterone on gender
cards.definition: Dabbs et al (95) measured the amount of testosterone in 992 prisoners\' saliva measured. Men with higher testosterone were more likely to have committed crimes involving sex and violence than men with low testosterone levels, & prison rule breaking was higher in high testosterone men.= sex influences gender, in this case, there is a positive correlation between testosterone levels and aggressive behaviour.

cards.term: Evidence for effect of oestrogen on gender
cards.definition: Easteal reported some cases in which PMS has been accepted as a defence for court for crimes including shoplifting and even murder as it has been linked to increased emotionality, irritability and aggression.=that sex influences gender, in this case, fluctuations in oestrogen in during the course of the menstrual cycle correlates with uncharacteristically emotional behaviour in women.

cards.term: Evidence for effect of oxytocin on gender
cards.definition: Van Leengoed et al injected an oxytocin antagonist into female rats shortly after giving birth. Mothers showed a reduction in maternal behaviours, however normal behaviour was seen when the drug wore off.= sex influences gender, in this case, oxytocin seems to be responsible for triggering maternal behaviour.

cards.term: Evaluation of evidence for hormonal influence on gender
cards.definition: -Experimental evidence on hormones comes from animal studies. = may not be appropriate to generalise the influence of hormones on animal behaviour to human behaviour e.g. human gender related behaviours may be subject to a wider range of influences from the more complex social environments we inhabit.HOWEVER.-It is unethical to perform hormone manipulation experiments on humans. = human evidence is correlational and therefore cannot establish cause and effect e.g. it could be the case that men with a body type indicating increased levels of testosterone may be expected to be more aggressive, and this could lead to a self-fulfilling prophecy.

cards.term: Evaluation of the biological explanation of gender
cards.definition: -Deterministic= deny that we have any free will e.g. "anatomy is destiny", and therefore our behaviour is assumed to be directed by our biological sex, meaning that females are destined to be caregivers, and males to be competitive/aggressive, regardless of our personal preferences/goals...-Reductionist= simplify a complex behaviour such as gender to the simplest underlying biological mechanisms, may leading to the complexity of gender being ignored e.g. the role of cultural and media influences.-Mead showed cross cultural diversity in gender roles = refutes the biological explanation of gender i.e. sex differences are universal, and if these are the causes of gender differences, gender differences should be universal too.-Gender roles have changed over time =refutes the biological explanation of gender i.e. sex differences are constant over time, so if these are the causes of gender differences, gender differences should be universal too.

cards.term: Assumption of the cognitive explanation of gender development
cards.definition: A child\'s understanding of gender develops as part of an innate process, which is the same for every person. The specifics of the gender concepts children develop depend on family/cultural experiences.
Kohlberg\'s cognitive developmental theoryGender schema theory

cards.term: Assumption of Kohlberg\'s cognitive developmental theory
cards.definition: Children\'s understanding of gender develops with age in stages which are universal. This occurs as a function of general cognitive development.

cards.term: 3 stages of Kohlberg\'s cognitive developmental theory
cards.definition: Gender identityGender stabilityGender constancy
Acquired around age 2-3. The child recognises that they are a boy or a girl and possesses the ability to label others as such.
Happens at around age 3-4. The child understands that their own gender is fixed and they will be male or female when they are older over TIME, but can still be fooled by appearance.

Usually reached by age 4-7. Knows a person\'s gender is stable over time and in different situations, despite superficial changes in appearance. Only at this point will children will actively seek out information about their gender e.g. by identifying with adult models.

cards.term: Evidence supporting Kohlber\'gs cognitive developmental theory
cards.definition: 1) Slaby and Frey asked children...\xe2\x80\xa2 Gender identity qus e.g. is this a girl or a by doll? \xe2\x80\xa2 Gender stability qus e.g. will you be a mummy or a daddy when you grow up?\xe2\x80\xa2 Gender constancy qus e.g. would you be a boy or girl if you played with (opposite sex toy)?Results: Children aged 4-9 answered the questions in line with the age predictions made by Kohlberg.= understanding of gender develops in stages, according to their age, as children mature cognitively.2) Slaby and Frey divided children into those showing low/high gender constancy. Each child was shown a silent film of a M/F adult model carrying out a stereotypical activity simultaneously on a split screen. Eye tracking monitored which model the child preferred. Those high in gender constancy spent longer looking at the same sex model than the low gender constancy children.= in accordance with Kohlberg\'s stages, children only seek out adult models once gender constancy has been reached.

cards.term: Strengths of Kohlberg\'s cognitive developmental theory
cards.definition: -Stages have been shown cross-culturally = theory is not ethnocentric i.e. the stages are biologically determined and therefore universal.

cards.term: Limitations of Kohlberg\'s gender schema theory
cards.definition: -Very descriptive = it outlines the process of gender development rather that explaining how development occurs i.e. it lacks depth of explanation.-Developed using interviews of children as young as 2/3 = validity of the data may have been affected e.g. young children may lack communication skills to express their understanding or may misunderstand questions...-Evidence shows that children will play with same sex peers before age 2 = Kohlberg may have underestimated the age at children have some understanding of gender i.e. it suggests children have already gained an understanding of gender identity if they can identify same sex peers...-Evidence shows that children demonstrate stereotypical behaviours before they have reached gender constancy = refutes Kohlberg\'s theory i.e. children should only begin to learn the specifics of what is associated with their gender once they have reached constancy...(This supports gender schema theory...)

AS SOON AS a child can identify their own sex, they actively seek out information to increase their understanding of gender. In the process they develop gender schemas: mental structures which hold our ideas about what is appropriate behaviour for males and females (e.g. behaviour, hobbies, personality traits, occupations). These influence the individual\'s behaviour.

1. Child 1st learns what things are associated with each sex (toys, activities and behaviour), and focuses on these.2. Child makes links within the schema, to allow them to make predictions e.g. playing with dolls= person likely to have long hair and wear dresses. They can only do this for their own sex.3. The child makes links for both sexes.

1) Martin & Halverson showed 5/6 y.o.s pictures of people carrying out schema in/consistent activities. Children\'s recall of the pictures was tested a week later.Recall for gender consistent images was good. When gender inconsistent images were recalled, they were often distorted e.g. a boy playing with the gun.=supports GST as it demonstrates that children\'s perception/ memory is biased in accordance with stereotypes, suggesting gender schemas exist.-Campbell et al 56 children were studies at 27 m and then at 39m in the children\'s homes. Being shown a picture album whilst sitting on their parent\'s lap they were asked to point to the girl/boy, the girl/boy\'s toy and the girl/boy\'s activity. They were then given a selection of the toys shown, and were filmed playing, whilst parents were preventing from influencing their choices. During this time performance on gender labelling increased from 53 to 94%; stereotyping of toys from 20 to 51% and of activities from 0 to 17%=supports the theory that children can begin to build up gender schemas once they are able to identify males and females, as the more children that could do this, the more that began to show stereotypes as a result.

-GST explains why children often remain very rigid in their views concerning gender = gender schemas may bias them to focus only on things that confirm their schemas, and consequently, ignore examples that are contradictory.

-There is some evidence that once a child performs a non-stereotypical behaviour, they adjust their views on it = contradicts GST as it suggests that schemas are affected by behavior, whereas GST predicts the opposite i.e. gender schemas should guide behavior.-GST is very descriptive =outlines the process of gender development rather that explaining how development occurs i.e. it lacks depth of explanation.-GST is a reductionist theory = it reduces the complex concept of gender to the level of thought processes (this illustrates machine reductionism). e.g. it ignores the influence of biological factors.

cards.term: Assumption of psychodynamic explanation of gender
cards.definition: 2 factors are important in explaining gender development:\xe2\x80\xa2 Innate unconscious forces and\xe2\x80\xa2 Childhood experiences

cards.term: How did Freud describe children before the phallic stage?
cards.definition: Bisexual

In the phallic stage, a boy develops sexual interest in his mother. This leads to the fear that his father might castrate him if he discovered the boy\'s desire for his mother i.e. castration anxiety. To resolve the conflict, the boy represses his desire & IDENTIFIES with his father ("identification with the aggressor"), and thus INTERNALISES gender-related behaviours and attitudes of the same sex-parent .

In the phallic stage, a girl experiences penis envy. It leads to the girl desiring her father, as he has what she desires. As the girl cannot have a penis of her own, she converts this desire into a desire for a baby: the "penis-baby project". She desires that her father provide this baby (preferably a male baby). As she is anxious that her mother will find out she represses her desire & IDENTIFIES with her mother, and thus INTERNALISES gender-related behaviours and attitudes of the same sex-parent .
The first step in a child resolving their conflict at the phallic stage, wanting to be like their same-sex parent.
The second step in a child resolving their conflict at the phallic stage, when they take on the gender identity of their same-sex parent.

cards.term: Evidence for the psychodynamic explanation of gender
cards.definition: Freud: Case study of "Little Hans" who had a phobia of horses. Freud asked the father to write and tell him about his son\'s development in order that he could interpret it. Hans was particularly afraid of large white horses with black blinkers and black around the mouth. He was terrified to leave the house in case a horse might either bite him or fall down. =His anxiety represents unconscious castration anxiety which Hans was experiencing, especially as his father had black glasses and a black beard. The fear of the horse falling was the unconscious desire for his father to drop down dead.

cards.term: Evidence against the psychodynamic explanation of gender
cards.definition: Green: gender roles studied of 3-20 year olds being brought up by homo/transsexual e.g. preferred games/toys/clothes/jobs. With the possible exception of one participant, all 34 had developed heterosexual preferences and conformed to cultural gender roles. =Appropriate gender development still takes place when there is no same-sex parent in the family, or when the family varies in some other way from a nuclear family. This contradicts Freud\'s predictions.

cards.term: Strengths of psychodynamic explanation of gender
cards.definition: -Freud\'s evidence came from case studies. This means he was basing his theories on rich qualitative data e.g. detailed correspondence with Little Hans\' father.

-It may not be appropriate to generalise findings in the form of a theory to explain typical human gender development i.e. Little Hans\' unusual behaviour is unlikely to be representative of all boys.-The mechanisms described, such as penis envy/ castration anxiety, are all unconscious = the explanation is unfalsifiable i.e. it is impossible to prove the theories wrong as they are not available for testing, and are therefore lacking in scientific status.-Evidence suggests that children show a preference for same sex playmates before the phallic stage = contradicts the explanation i.e. children should not identify as male or female until the conflict at the phallic stage has been resolved.-The account of female development is less developed than that of males\' = theory is androcentric, demonstrating alpha bias e.g. For example, the notion of penis envy implies that women are inferior to men, which is not an idea with which many people would now agree.

cards.term: Assumption of SLT explanation of gender
cards.definition: Children learn by observing what types of attitudes & behaviours are associated with their gender.
Identification ModellingImitiation Vicarious Reinforcement
When an observer associates themselves with a same sex model and wants to be like the model.
A same sex model provides an example for the child for gender related behaviour.
Copying the gender related behaviour of another person
When behaviour becomes associated with a positive or negative response. If the response to the behaviour is positively reinforces, it is more likely to be repeated (can occur vicariously).
Thought processes between observing model and imitation e.g. children more likely to imitate models who are perceived to be attractive, similar (esp gender), high status etc.

1) Fagot observed parents with a child under 2, including their use of praise & "telling off" for different behaviours. Girls were praised when for dressing up/ staying close to their parent and asked for help & discouraged from rough and tumble play. Boys were praised for playing with bricks and transportation toys, and discouraged from playing with dolls. = Children learn to behave according to stereotypes through being reinforced for typical behaviour and punished for behaviour which is atypical.2) Perry & Bussey: Children saw 4 same & opp. sex models choosing between 2 items, when asked to choose the one thy liked best.Children clearly preferred the item that had been chosen by all the adults of their own sex.=Children will imitate models which they identify most closely with, which may lead to the learning of gender specific behaviours.

cards.term: Strength of SLT explanation of gender
cards.definition: - Mead showed cross cultural differences in gender related behavior = strengthens the theory i.e. the fact that gender related behavior isn\'t universal (see cultural influences for specifics) supports the notion that it is learned from models rather than being biological,

-Reductionist= biological factors are not considered to be important e.g. there is a wealth of scientific evidence on the influence of biological factors such as sex chromosomes and hormones on gender which is not taken into account.-Many cultures have similar traditional gender stereotypes =theory can\'t explain how traditional gender stereotypes originate e.g. it is likely that biological factors are the origin for behaviours such as nurturing behaviour in women, and social learning processes act to reinforce these behaviours.-Many people display gender "inappropriate" behaviours despite lack of reinforcement =contradicts the theory i.e. boys who receive bullying for displaying feminine traits would be predicted to cease demonstrating this behaviour, when in fact they often don\'t, suggesting biological factors override the effects of reinforcement.-Many studies of modelling involve children imitating the model immediately after observing them, in the same context = results many be confounded by the effects of demand characteristics i.e. in such studies, it may be obvious what the experimenter expects, which children may conform to.

cards.term: What theory can you use to explain how media/culture influences gender roles?
cards.definition: Social Learning Theory
Beliefs, customs, and traditions of a specific group of people.

cards.term: What can cross cultural research demonstrate about gender roles
cards.definition: It reveals differences whether there between cultures there are differences in gender related behaviour suggesting the role of nurture can override nature.

cards.term: Evidence for cultural influences on gender roles
cards.definition: 1) Mead lived with & observed behaviour of M&F in 3 tribes in New Guinea for 6m: Arapesh: both M&F showed stereotypically (western) feminine traits e.g. caring behaviour. Mundugamor: both M&G showed stereotypically male behaviour e.g. aggression.Tchambuli: M&F demonstrated distinctive gender roles but the reverse of western expectations (F practical, M flirtatious and decorating bodies to  attractiveness.=cultural influences shape the expression of gender, overriding biological influences which would be universal. 2) In several cultures, "3rd gender" is used to acknowledge individuals who identify neither as M or Fe.g. hijras in India/ Pakistan/ Bangladesh are biological M who wear F clothes, but are recognised as a separate group, with E (for eunuch) on their passports instead of M or F; "Two spirits" considered by Native American tribes to be individuals with both a M&F spirit. The wear both M&F clothes and have distinct roles e.g. story tellers, fortune tellers and matchmakers.= concept of gender is influenced by cultural factors i.e. the notion of gender being binary is not universal.

cards.term: Evaluation of research on cultural influences on gender roles
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x94Increasing globalization is likely to reduce x-cult differences. This is because models are becoming universal e.g. celebrities who are famous all around the world.x Mead had a strong belief that gender roles were socially constructed = her interpretations of the tribes hay have been biased, limiting the validity of her conclusions e.g. later researchers have disagreed with her interpretations.x Cross cultural research may exaggerate x-cult. differences= research demonstrates there are more similarities than differences in in the way it is viewed e.g. Williams and Best found high agreement between 27 cultures on which of 300 words were associated with being masc./fem. x An interactionist approach to explaining the influence of culture may be more valid = there may be bio factors which provide the basis of gender related behaviour, but specifics are down to the individual\'s culture e.g. reinforced through a social learning.
The expression of culture on a large scale e.g. through TV/social media platforms.

cards.term: Evidence for media influences on gender roles
cards.definition: 1) Furnham and Farragher: in a study of TV adverts it was shown that M were more likely to be shown in autonomous roles within professional contexts, whereas F were more often seen occupying familial roles within domestic settings.=media typically presents males and females in stereotypical roles.2) McGee and Frueh: in longitudinal study over 15 months it was found that children 6-12 who watched more than 25 hours of TV a week held more sex-stereotype perceptions than those who watched 10 or less hours.=the presentation of stereotypical gender roles may lead to children holding more rigid stereotypes.

cards.term: Evaluation of evidence on media influences on gender roles
cards.definition: \xe2\x9c\x94Research has practical applications, suggesting that it is possible to produce an intervention to reduce effects of stereotyping e.g. Johnson and Ettema showed 12 year olds a tv programme designed to counter traditional stereotypes, and both boys and girls showed reduced gender stereotyping afterwards.x Much gender development occurs before a child is 4 = the influence of the media may have been exaggerated i.e. before age 4, a child\'s family are more likely to be a source of influence than the media.x Research doesn\'t establish the direction of cause and effect = media may just reflect prevailing stereotypes rather than shaping them.

cards.term: What is the disorder characterised by ATYPICAL gender development
cards.definition: Gender Dysphoria

Atypical gender development: people experience a conflict between their biological sex and their gender identity. For a diagnosis, this must persist for 6m+ and cause the individual distress or impaired functioning. Most dysphoria occurs in childhood (2-4yrs) and doesn\'t persist beyond puberty.

There are neurobiological differences in people with GD which lead to their dysphoria perhaps caused by overexposure to androgens in the uterus, causing masculinization of bio Fs and vice versa, or genetics.

cards.term: Evidence for a biological explanation of GD
cards.definition: 1) Heylen et al reviewed case studies where at least one twin had been diagnosed with GD:3/8 female MZ twins were concordant for GD vs 0/5 DZ.6/15 male MZ twins concordant for GD vs 0/16 DZ.= GD has a genetic component to it as MZ twins who share 100% of their genes have higher concordance for GD than DZ who only share 50% of genes.2) Ning Zhou et al studied the "bed nucleus of the striate terminalis" (BSTc- an area of the thalamus which is 40% bigger in males than females by age 5). In dead MtF transgender individuals, the BSTc was a similar size to that in a female brain.= there are neural correlates with GD, with males appearing to have a brain more typical of a biological female, which may be associated with their gender dysphoria.

cards.term: Evaluation of the biological explanation of GD
cards.definition: -Practical applications = it lends itself to methods of reducing gender dysphoria e.g. Green and Fleming found that the treatment of individuals with GD by hormone therapy was successful in 87% of FtM cases and 97% of MtF in reducing feelings of dysphoria.-There is a lack of continuity between childhood and adulthood GD. This refutes the biological explanation i.e. if GD is genetic, it should persist, as genetics remains constant.-Evidence can\'t establish cause and effect = much of the evidence is correlational e.g. differences in brains may have developed as a result of environmental influences from seeking out experiences more typical of the opposite sex.-Deterministic = GD patients are seen to be at the mercy of their biology i.e. denying any choice they may have in becoming accepting of their biological sex.
There are factors in the social environment of the individual during their early development which leads to gender dysphoria.

cards.term: Evidence for a social explanation of GD
cards.definition: 1) Zucker et al: 115 boys with concerns about their gender identity and their mothers: of the boys who were eventually diagnosed with GD, 64% were also diagnosed with separation anxiety disorder. Of the boys whose symptoms were subclinical, 38% were diagnosed with separation anxiety disorder.=the child may fantasise about a "symbiotic fusion" with his mother to relieve his anxiety about separation, and therefore "becomes" his mother. This occurs at a subconscious level.2) Gehring and Knutsen: In a sample of 23/42 transsexuals (34 MtF and 8 FtM), reported some form of unwanted sexual event at an average age of 13, generally involved another adolescent satisfying their curiosity about the gender of the sufferer rather. The sample also reported being: verbally abused (77%), insulted (81%), embarrassed in front of others (55%), made to feel guilty by their parents (58%) before their 15th birthday.= trauma is associated with the development of GID.

cards.term: Evaluation of social explanation of GD
cards.definition: X The explanation has only been applied to MtF transsexuals = social explanations demonstrate gender bias i.e. beta bias, by ignoring the possibility that FtM transsexuals are subject to different factors.

X GD affects relatively few individuals = the data set is limited i.e. are potentially very few Ps to include in samples, meaning any sample may be unrepresentative of the GD population as a whole.X The explanations of GD seek to explain "GD" as a homogenous disorder. This may be oversimplistic e.g. Blanchard proposed that some GD MtF patients wish to change sex because they are homosexual and some who wish to change because they are autogynephilic (aroused by thinking about themselves as a woman), demonstrating there may be sub-types of GD.X The findings of GD research are socially sensitive. This means that understanding the cause of GD has implications for the way that GD is treated e.g. increasing understanding may reduce the stigma around the condition.
\xe2\x80\xa2They agree that there are innate aspects to gender.\xe2\x80\xa2However, P argues that childhood experiences are important too.\xe2\x80\xa2B has theories that are testable; P doesn\'t.

\xe2\x80\xa2Nature (B) vs. nurture (SLT)\xe2\x80\xa2SLT can explain cross cultural differences and changes over time in gender behaviour; B can\'t.\xe2\x80\xa2B can explain why Bruce couldn\'t be socialised as a girl; SLT can\'t.

\xe2\x80\xa2C would argue that B is reductionist by ignoring the role of thought processes.\xe2\x80\xa2C argues that B is too deterministic as they say children have an active role in their own gender development.

\xe2\x80\xa2Agree that gender develops in age related stages.\xe2\x80\xa2C argues that gender development occurs later than P..C argues that gender develops over time whereas P argues it develops in one fell swoop.

\xe2\x80\xa2P argues that SLT is too reductionist by focusing entirely on behaviour and ignoring unconscious processes.\xe2\x80\xa2SLT argues that children identify with any number of models at any time, whereas P argues that they only identify with the same sex parent at the phallic stage.\xe2\x80\xa2SLT can explain why gender development occurs normally in single parent families; P can\'t.

\xe2\x80\xa2C argues that gender develops in stages whereas SLT says it can develop at any age, depending on experiences.\xe2\x80\xa2SLT argues that role models are needed for gender development, whereas C argues that children only seek out role models after gender has been established.
The quality something has e.g. a behaviour, if it is found to exist across time and cultures.
The effect if a preconceived assumption affects the interpretation of findings/collection of data etc., reducing its validity.
When psychological research or theory offers a view which does not represent the experiences or behaviour of men and women.
There are a lack of women appointed at senior research level.
Male bias i.e. men\'s behaviour provides the standard against which women\'s behaviour is compared.
Exaggerates the differences between women and men
Tendency to ignore differences between genders.

cards.term: Examples of research showing alpha bias
cards.definition: -Bowlby\'s monotropic theory-Freud\'s theory of gender development

cards.term: Examples of research showing beta bias
cards.definition: -Asch\'s conformity experiment-Fight or flight research on male animals

- Real world implications= that men, and particularly women, may be negatively affected by research which demonstrates alpha bias e.g. reinforcing stereotypes such as women being submissive homemakers.

-Research has been exploited by Feminist Psychologists = redressing the balance for women in society e.g. Eagly acknowledged that women may be less effective leaders but argued this should be used to develop training programmes.-Feminist Psychologists have promoted male and female differences whn women appear more favourably = redressing the balance for women in society e.g. research shows that women are better at learning because they are more organised, attentive and flexible...
-Real life consequences = promoting gender equality e.g. the law has been changed to ensure that women have greater occupational and educational opportunities.

-Ignores that women have some special needs= research fails to take into account that women DO have some biological differences which it is important to acknowledge e.g. equal parental leave ignores the demands of pregnancy, childbirth and breastfeeding.

-Both forms of bias lull us into believing that all men and all women are the same as each other= talking about men and women as homogenous groups leads us to ignore individual differences i.e. individual men and women are different to each other...
Identifying common aspects e.g. across cultures
-Ainsworth\'s strange situation applied world wide-Deviation from ideal mental health as a universally applied definition of abnormality
Using techniques that are only relevant to one culture to study and/or draw conclusions about another. This is INAPPROPRIATE and may lead to invalid conclusions being made.
When psychological research or theory offers a view which does not justifiably represent the experiences or behaviour of different cultures e.g. because an etic was imposed.

-don\'t extrapolate findings/theories to cultures that aren\'t represented in the sample\xe2\x80\xa2 use researchers who are native to the culture being investigated\xe2\x80\xa2 carry out cross-cultural research rather than research on a sole culture\xe2\x80\xa2 do not assume universal norms across different cultures\xe2\x80\xa2 be sensitive to cultural norms when designing research/ reporting findings\xe2\x80\xa2 study single culture to understand that culture (emic approach)
A type of culture bias: the assumption that the behaviour in own ethnic group is the norm, and using that norm to evaluate other groups of people.
\xe2\x80\xa2 2/3 of published psychology research is from the US\xe2\x80\xa295% of western research is done on white Ps\xe2\x80\xa2Lab studies represent the Western view of Science
The belief that it is essential to consider cultural context when examining behaviour in that culture: there is no global norm. This view is supported by the emic approach.
Identifying specific aspects of a culture e.g. culture specific behaviours.

-Mead studied the tribes of Papua New Guinea and found that different tribes had different expressions of gender.-Culture bound syndromes are mental disorders which are only diagnosed in specific cultures e.g. "Kayak angst" is in the Inuit people of Greenland and includes anxiety about getting lost at sea or drowning.

-May lead to reinforcement of racial stereotypes = could be used to justify discrimination of certain groups e.g. the US Army IQ test to rank different races -It\'s difficult to avoid = practical difficulties in carrying out cross cultural research e.g. cost involved, language barriers, differences in customs-With all the focus on avoiding bias, it shouldn\'t be neglected that there are behaviours which are universal e.g. some behaviour such as imitation and interactional synchrony in infants appears to be innate...

cards.term: Counterarguments to negative implications of culture bias
cards.definition: -It may begin to decrease= the world is becoming more interconnected e.g. Academics now hold international research conferences to share findings...-May be counteracted by promoting indigenous psychology= psychologists from around the world conducting research in their own countrye.g. Afrocentrism idisputes the view that European descriptions apply equally to black people.
Studies in which there are potential social consequences or implications, either directly for the participants in research or the class of individuals represented by the research.

cards.term: 4 ways to assess the social sensitivity of research
cards.definition: 1) What are the implications of studying x?2) To what uses will/could the research findings be put?3) Could the research possibly have a wider influence on public policy?4) Are the findings from potentially controversial topics even valid?

Yerkes investigated the relationship between race and IQ. It was found that the average mental age of White American adults was 13- the highest of all the races, followed by Northern and Western Europeans, then Slavs/ Eastern Europeans, then Southern Europeans and lastly, African Americans.

cards.term: What were the implications of Yerkes\' study?
cards.definition: It was used to validate racism by providing evidence that IQ is genetic.

cards.term: To what were Yerkes\' findings put?
cards.definition: Therefore the results were used to actively discriminate against particular groups: Yerkes graded each recruit from A+ to E- and used it as a basis to make suggestions as to suitable army placements.

cards.term: What impact did Yerkes\' have on public policy?
cards.definition: Based on Yerkes\' results and lobbying from scientists who supported the eugenics argument, the Immigration Restriction Act (1924) was passed by the US Congress which set immigration quotas for particular groups.

cards.term: Are the findings from Yerkes\' study even valid?
cards.definition: Yerkes\' tests were biased against white US participants by having questions relying largely of white American culture-based knowledge.

cards.term: Negative implications of socially sensitive research
cards.definition: -Socially sensitive research has been used to validate discrimination by certain ethnic groups as inferior e.g. the US Army IQ rest used before WWI led to different races being ranked as superior to others i.e. white Americans at the top, African-Americans at the bottom= socially sensitive research should be avoided.- Potential social implications are often ignored. This is because current ethical guidelines mainly protect the immediate needs of research Ps. e.g. the focus of guidelines is regarding immediate issues such as informed consent and right to withdraw.

cards.term: Counterarguments to negative implications of socially sensitive research
cards.definition: -Potentially socially sensitive research on under-represented groups may promote a greater sensitivity and understanding e.g. Humphreys acted as a gay man and talked to his Ps in a toilet where gay men commonly met for casual sex. He took their car number plates to check their backgrounds and used a contact in the police force to find their addresses. He concluded that gay stereotypes were false, demonstrating that this SS research was worthwhile.-Even seemingly harmless research can be exploited in ways which are unpredictable e.g. research into operant conditioning of animals has been used to train animals to deliver explosive weapons e.g. Project Pigeon =it it isn\'t always possible to foresee social implications of research.
Are we free to choose how to think and behave, or is our behaviour caused by factors outside an individual\'s control?
The assumption of science that to be scientific, it should be possible to generate laws about cause and effect relationships which allow predictions to be made i.e. determinism is assumed.
Behaviour is without externally imposed forces, so we are free to choose how to behave in a given situation because we have consciousness and self-awareness.
Behaviour is caused by events outside an individual\'s control, so free-will is an illusion, and behaviour is totally predictable.
Biological, environmental, psychic
Behaviour is under the control of environmental stimuli and external forces of reward and punishment.
Behaviour is caused by unconscious forces associated with instincts of sex, aggression and repressed conflicts, childhood experiences, and memories.
Behaviour is caused by the action of the nervous/ hormonal systems and genetic factors.
"Free behaviour", is not random: it is caused, but by a person\'s own character, wishes or consciously desired goals, but we can call it free as it\'s rational, voluntary and purposeful.

cards.term: Conclusion to the free will-determinism debate
cards.definition: Both the hard determinism and free will position are too extreme. It is most likely that the compromise position that both free will & determinism influence behaviour, depending on the situation, comes closest to the truth. This is described by the soft determinism position.

-Rogers: client centred therapy which aimed to increase client\'s psychological well being by aiding the process of clients CHOOSING to see themselves and their circumstances differently and to react to their experiences differently= effective with mild psychological disorders.-Penfield et al stimulated the primary motor cortex of patients about to undergo brain surgery. Even though the area being stimulated was that involved in voluntary limb movement, patients reported feeling that their arms were moving passively. This suggests that free will exists, at least in the form of a subjective feeling.

Gottesman compared concordance between MZ (100% related) & DZ twins (50% related) for schizophrenia. Rate of concordance = 48% vs. 17%.= biological determinism, as genes contribute to the development of schizophrenia.-Skinner showed that an animal\'s behaviour could be shaped as a result of reinforcement and punishment; principles put to use with humans in different settings e.g. psychiatric wards with schizophrenic patients, in order to elicit more desirable behaviour= environmental determinism.

-An optimistic perspective= it suggests it\'s possible for individuals to change their lives through the choices they make e.g. someone with genes/ environmental influences associated with low academic achievement could make the choice to work hard to become successful.-Individuals feel as though they have free will = individuals are willing to praise/blame people for the choices they make e.g. as seen in then criminal justice system, which is able to punish people, assumed to have chosen to commit criminal acts.

-Supports a scientific approach = science emphasises causal explanations, and deterministic theories provide testable hypotheses about cause and effect relationships e.g. in a lab experiment, by controlling EVs, it is possible to establish that an IV does cause changes in a DV, thereby providing support for theories based on determinism.
-Inconsistent with the assumptions of science = impossible to test the existence of free will i.e. it lacks an operationalised definition meaning it can\'t be measured using empirical methods.

-Supports fatalism = individuals have no ability to escape their "fate", as determined by forces outside of their control e.g. this may lead someone who believes they will fail due to their family\'s lack of success or lack of opportunities to give up on changing their lives for the better. -Assumes that we have no moral responsibility for our actions = not possible to praise/blame people e.g. it could be argued that someone with the MAOA-L allele can\'t be blamed if they commit an aggressive crime.
To what extent are particular aspects of a behaviour a product of inherited or acquired influences?
Heredity, or the genetic influence i.e. DNA inherited from parents.
Environmental influences ranging from the pre-natal biological environment to the social and historical environments we are brought up in.
The viewpoint that nature and nurture are necessary to understand and explain behaviour.

-Gottesman compared concordance between MZ (100% related) & DZ twins (50% related) for schizophrenia. Rate of concordance = 48% vs. 17%. = influence of nature is important in the development of schizophrenia. -Money & Ehrhardt Bruce study: Bruce eventually went public & revealed that he had become a man again = the influence of nature is important in gender development as receiving the upbringing typical of a girl wasn\'t enough to override the influences of Bruce\'s sex chromosomes/ brain sex.

-Pavlov showed that repeated pairing a bell (NS) with the presentation of food (UCS) meant that dogs would associate the bell with the food= This would result in the bell becoming a conditioned stimulus for the conditioned salivation response. This suggests behaviour can be learned through experiencing associations in the environment.-Skinner showed that an animal\'s behaviour could be shaped as a result of reinforcement and punishment. This suggests behaviour can be learned through consequences in the environment.

cards.term: Conclusion to nature vs nurture debate
cards.definition: It is most likely that nature and nurture are necessary to understand and explain human behaviour. The challenge is to show the relative contributions of each influence.

cards.term: Evaluation of N vs N debate: political implications
cards.definition: Both viewpoints have been used to manipulate the populations under specific regimes e.g. the Nazis, believing in the role of nature practised eugenics to wipe out "undesirable" characteristics in the population, whereas the communist regimes believing in the influence of nurture have used "re-education camps" to indoctrinate the population with their views.

cards.term: Evaluation of N vs N debate: too extreme
cards.definition: An extreme nature or nurture is reductionist i.e. a compromise position, understanding the influence of nature and nurture interact is more appropriate for most behaviours.

cards.term: Evaluation of N vs N debate: complex interactions
cards.definition: There are many frms in which N and N interactions exist:-Reaction ranges: nature sets upper and lower limit for an individuals\' potential on a trait such as IQ, but nurture determines whereabouts on the scale the resulting phenotype lay. -Diathesis stress models: a biological vulnerability (nature) and environmental stressor (nurture) need to both be in place for a trait to be displayed e.g. schizophrenia -Factors overriding each other: a change in the environment (nurture) can prevent a biological vulnerability (nature) from becoming expressed e.g. PKU.

cards.term: Evaluation of N vs N debate: influences can\'t be separated
cards.definition: The 2 influences often correlate...-Passive correlations: it is common for those who share genes (nature) to share environment (nurture) so if a trait "runs in the family", it\'s difficult to determine the reason.-Active correlations: individuals with particular genetic traits (nature) to seek out particular environments (nurture), e.g. committing a violent act.-Reactive correlations: individuals with particular genetic traits (nature) may be treated in particular ways (nurture) e.g. if someone predisposed to delusions is labelled as "odd", the way in which they are then treated may exacerbate their symptoms, making it unclear why they went on to develop schizophrenia.
To which level should psychologists reduce explanations in order to produce the "best" explanation of behaviour.

The way in which explanations vary from those at a lower/fundamental level focusing on basic components or units to those at a higher/ more holistic e.g. from biological to cognitive to socio-cultural.
To understand human beings, the whole person must be considered as "greater than the sum of the parts".

To understand human beings, psychologists must analyse and reduce the whole person into the simplest component parts. Behaviour can be "reduced" to different levels of explanation e.g. biological reductionism (genes/neurotransmitters), environmental reductionism (S-R links).
Explains human behaviour in terms of links/interactions between different levels of explanation.

-Investigating localisation of brain function e.g. Broca carried out a PM on a patient who\'d been unable to speak during his life (aphasia). When his brain was examined, it was found that there was a lesion caused by syphilis in the left frontal lobe. This illustrates a reductionist approach to understanding the brain i.e. suggesting functions of the brain can be isolated in specific areas of the brain.-Watson and Rayner Studied 9 month old "Little Albert". Observing that he showed fear when a hammer struck a metal bar behind his back, they placed a white rat (to which he showed no fear) in front of him at the same time as striking the bar. After a few pairings, Little Albert began to show towards the rat, and developed a general phobia towards white furry objects. This illustrates that simple examples of learning can be explained in a reductionist way, by breaking it down to it\'s simplest component parts e.g. UCS + NS = UCR, followed by the NS becoming a CS, where CS= CR.

cards.term: The biological approach in relation to the debates
cards.definition: -Biological determinism-Biological reductionism-Nature-Nomothetic laws

-Investigating localisation of brain function e.g. Lashley conducted experiments spanning over 25 years, methodically damaging areas of rats\' brains to find out which areas they use to help them learn their way round a maze. There was no area which uniquely hindered their ability to run the maze. This illustrates a holistic approach to understanding the brain.-Kohler placed hungry chimp Sultan in a cage with a bunch of bananas out of reach outside. Two hollow bamboo sticks were inside the cage: neither stick alone could reach them but joined, they could. cage. After a while Sultan started playing with the sticks and accidentally one of the sticks went into the hollow end of the other. He then used the two sticks to form a longer stick, and with its help pulled the banana inside the cage. This illustrates a holistic view of learning ="insight learning" has occurred when the chimp solved the problem viewing all of the components of the problem together, allowing their emergent properties to become apparent.

-Consistent with a scientific approach and so can be investigated. This is because the experimental method relies on researchers reducing complex behaviour into the simplest component variables e.g. an independent variable will be changed whilst possible EVs are controlled, to measure the effect on an observable operationalised DV.

-May lead to complexity of behaviour being missed= meaning of a behaviour is neglected e.g. reducing schizophrenia to the biological level as the result of high levels of dopamine means that the subjective experience of what it feels like to have schizophrenia, or the significance in our society of such a label is ignored...-May lead to neglect of other levels of explanation. This means that by focussing on one level of component part, other important aspects of a behaviour are not taken into account e.g. a biologically reductionist explanation of schizophrenia may lead to a lack of appreciation of how the family context can play a role in the development of a disorder

-Provides more complete picture of behaviour and experience = no aspect of a behaviour will be overlooked by focussing solely on one component part i.e. the whole person/ behaviour/ experience is emphasised.-Explanations are more meaningful. This means that by studying the whole person, an insight into their subjective experience is gained e.g. using unstructured interviews to gain rich qualitative data on an individual\'s point of view...

-Difficulty investigating holistic = there are too many variables considered to investigate any specific variable scientifically i.e. this makes experimental testing inappropriate, so more subjective methods such as unstructured interviews must be used instead which provide insight into the person\'s experience as a whole.

cards.term: Conclusion to holism vs reductionism debate
cards.definition: The interactionist approach: explains human behaviour in terms of links/interactions between different levels of explanation e.g. attempts by psychologists to explain schizophrenia: it is only by taking into account biological, psychological and social factors that psychologists can achieve a better understanding of the problem from sociocultural factors such as family dysfunction, faulty information processing and increased dopamine levels.
How much attention should be paid to the individual in psychology?
Research in psychology which understands people through studying individual cases because everyone is unique. Case studies may be used.

Research in psychology which understands people through developing general laws which apply to all e.g. classifying people into groups, establishing principles of behaviour or establishing dimensions on which people can be compared. Experiments may be used.

-HM had brain surgery to reduce the symptoms of epilepsy. As a side effect he suffered memory loss. His STM was normal, but he could not transfer any new information to LTM, so he could not retain any information about family (e.g. moving house, his father dying) or world events, or remember new people he met. However, he could remember everything from before the surgery, which had already passed into LTM = it is possible to gain understanding of memory using an idiographic method such as a case study.-Koluchova investigated the long term development of twin boys who had experienced privation until they were 7 years old. In a longitudinal study the twins were assessed at intervals over 22 years for intellectual and social ability. Despite having no speech and a lack of social ability at age 7, by 10, they attended mainstream school and normal attachments. They went on to have normal adult lives = it is possible to gain understanding of deprivation using an idiographic method such as a case study.

-Murdock: Ps learning a list of words will tend to remember the first and last few, and forget those in the middle (The "primacy" and "recency" effects). This has been used as evidence that there exists a separate long term and short term memory store (with a limited capacity) = it is possible to gain understanding of memory using nomothetic methods such as lab experiment, with findings generalised from the sample studied to form a model of human memory.-Bowlby compared 44 juvenile thieves with a law-abiding control group. The two groups were interviewed about themselves, their behaviour & their childhood experiences. Members of family were interviewed about family history. Approx. 39% of the delinquent group had experienced up to 6 months of maternal separation in their first five years (only 5% for non-delinquent group) = it is possible to gain understanding of the effects of deprivation using nomothetic methods, with findings generalised from the sample studied to support the maternal deprivation hypothesis.

-Provides a holistic view of human nature. This means that by studying the individual, an insight into their subjective experience is gained e.g. using unstructured interviews to gain rich qualitative data on an individual\'s point of view...

-Practical applications = general laws can be generated to predict and therefore control behaviour e.g. understanding the general laws of learning has been implemented into the development of Behavioural therapies for disorders from phobias to schizophrenia...-Uses empirical methods = it places an emphasis on behaviour that be measured objectively e.g. words remembered in a memory test, the number of times a rat presses a lever...

- Lacks practical applications = it is inappropriate to extend findings of idiographic studies to form general laws, so you cannot predict the behaviour of individuals (other than the subject of a case study) from a single case study e.g. it wasn\'t possible to make an accurate prognosis for Genie Wiley\'s progress after a period of privation based on the outcomes of the Czech twins- they ended up with very different outcomes...-Relies on methods of self-report as the main way of gathering data. = data gathered by lack validity e.g. subjective reports of experience may be affected by social desirability bias.

-Reductionist = it ignores the differences between individuals by placing them into generalised categories e.g. the Myers Briggs personality test may categories 2 individuals with the same personality type, but hey many have achieved this "type" by answering the questions differently.

cards.term: I=Conclusion to the idiographic vs nomothetic debate
cards.definition: Both the idiographic and nomothetic approaches have a role in psychology, as they are complementary e.g. most case studies are sources of hypotheses, which can then be tested empirically using nomothetic methods e.g. the HM case study suggested that there were separate long term and short term stores to memory. Also, sometimes a case study is used to falsify a nomothetic theory e.g. the Koluchova twin case study suggested that Bowlby\'s theory of a critical period was incorrect.

cards.term: The Behaviourist in relation to the debates
cards.definition: -Environmental determinism-Environmental reductionism-Nurture -Nomothetic laws

cards.term: Social Learning Theory in relation to the debates
cards.definition: -Soft determinism-Interacting levels of explanation-Nurture (mainly)-Nomothetic laws

cards.term: The Cognitive approach in relation to the debates
cards.definition: -Soft determinism-Machine reductionism-Nature and nurture interact-Nomothetic laws

cards.term: The Psychodynamic approach in relation to the debates
cards.definition: -Psychic determinism-Interacting levels of explanation-Nature and nurture interact-Idiographic methods/ nomothetic laws

cards.term: The Humanistic approach in relation to the debates
cards.definition: -Free will-Holistic-Nature and nurture interact-Idiographic methods
Data gathered by the researcher/ researchers conducting the research
Data conducted by other researchers
Non-numerical data that required interpretation
Numerical data, not requiring interpretation
Method of gathering participants for the research
Participants have an equal chance of being selected
Participants who are available at the time are used in the sample
Participants volunteer to take part in the study, gathered via newspaper adverts for example.
The sample takes into account the proportion of groups in a population which is then used when gathering participants for the study.
How the participants experience the experiment in their groups
Participants are different in each group
The same participants do the different conditions of the experiment
Participants are matched within groups based on characteristics that may affect the study
A specific testable prediction of results
No difference/ relationship will be found, any differences are due to chance.
A statement that lays out what a researcher predicts will be found
Predicts the direction of difference or relationship that the result is likely to take
No prediction of the direction of difference or relationship it is likely to take
In a repeated measures design, the order of the conditions the participants do it in is alternated e.g. ABBA
The order in which the participants conduct the experiment can cause fatigue and practice
Participants do not always answer correctly as they do not want to appear in a negative light to social views and norms.
Participants behave in a way they think they should to fit what they perceive to be the aim of the experiment.
The differences between participants
Differences in the situation/ environment that could affect the study. e.g. time of day
A variable that may have affected the dependent variable but that was not the independent variable
A variable that affects the findings of a study directly, so much that you are no longer measuring what was intended
Ensuring that all aspects of a test/ research are specific so they can be tested
The extent to which the outcome of the study is the direct result of the IV
Whether the results of the study can be used to predict future behaviour
The extent to which the findings still explain the behaviour in different situations
The extent to which findings can be applied to other people and contexts, other than ones directly involved in research itself
The data being scientific, using quantitative data that is non-numerical
Findings requiring interpretation from the researchers, often gathering qualitative data
The trustworthiness of the research findings
1. Debrief2. Informed consent3. Right to withdraw4. Competent researcher5. Deception
1. Respect2. Competence3. Responsibility4. Integrity
A specific testable prediction containing variables, and will state either a difference or relationship.
States the direction the results will go in (more, less, positive, fewer)
Does not state the direction of the results, leaving it open

cards.term: What is the aim of sampling methods?
cards.definition: To ensure a representative sample of participants is used, so can be successfully generalised.
Sample of those who are available at the time of the study
Every member of the population has an equal chance of being chosen.
Involves classifying the population into categories and then choosing a sample which consists of participants from each category in the same proportions as they are in the population.
Volunteering when asked or in a response to an advert.
- No bias- Clear how the sample is chosen, process can be explained

- Difficult to ensure everyone is available- Some people might not want to take part in the study- There can be bias in that there may be more of one group than the other, such as more male soldiers than female
- Each group is represented, so conclusions can be drawn- Efficient to ensure representation from each group
- Difficult to know how many of each group to choose - Some groups may not be important fro the study
- More ethical as they chose to take part- Volunteers are likely to be interested so less likely to give biased information, less likely to have social desirability or demand characteristic.
- Takes long time to get sufficient numbers- Participants may be similar, so there may not be representation
-More ethical because the researcher can judge if the participant is likely to be upset by the study- Researcher has more control over choosing, more quick and efficient
- More chance of bias - choosing people you know, people of own age, friendly looking people etc.- Self selected, so would rule out anyone not available or not willing
Closed ended or open ended

1. Fixed choice questions, with yes/no response2. Likert scale questions, selecting from a fixed set of choices to rate agreement to statements3. Ranked scale question, ranking choice relative to other options
- Quick and easy to answer- Researchers can easily analyse data, percentages and averages can be worked out- Questions are all the same so is more reliable

- Limited amount of information- Answers may not match what the participants would like express- Choice answers could mean different things to different respondents, such as \'unsure\' could mean \'don\'t know\', so lacks validity
- Respondents can answer freely- Allows them to elaborate on their answers and justify opinions-More detailed and valid, true to real life
- More time and effort for respondents- Qualitative analysis which can lead to subjective interpretation that is difficult to analyse- Respondents often fail to complete their answers
When a respondent gives an answer that puts them in a more favourable light, desirable to social norms.
1. Structured2. Semi-structured3. Unstructured
Standardised so all respondents are asked same questions
- Easy to administer- Do not need to establish a rapport between researcher and respondent
- Data can be superficial and lack depth- Respondent may not be able to express opinions fully
More conversational and dynamic. Researcher has a set of questions they want to be answered but do not have a standardised format to follow.
- Conversation can flow better- More comfortable having a relaxed atmosphere
- Flexibility of interviews may lessen reliability
The interviewer needs to be analytical. No set of questions or format, just asking questions and making direct reference to quotes from respondents.
- More flexible as questions can be changed- Increased validity - Usually in depth and detailed answers
- Time consuming- Employing and training interviewers is expensive
If the respondents answer a certain way for a list of questions, they may continue to answer in that way out of habit.
Qualitative data is made numerical by counting the instances certain themes and categories appear in the data
To analyse data without losing its meaningfulness, but making it more manageable by reducing it into patterns, trends and themes.
1. INDUCTIVE- Researcher would read and re read data and themes would emerge without imposing ideas or expectations.2. DEDUCTIVE- Specify themes that they will look for before analysis of data.
1. Gather2. Journal3. Prepare data4. Appoint coders5. Familiarise 6. Ideas7. Identifying themes8. Naming themes9. Reliability/ validity check10. Report of the results
- Encourages researcher to derive themes, so achieves better validity- Large data sets, many researchers can apply their interpretation to the data
- Highly subjective data as it requires interpretation, so unscientific- Open to researcher bias, not very reliable
Mean, median and mode
Adding up all values and dividing them by number of scores. Interval/ ratio level data is obtained. Most sensitive and can be affected by extreme values or when there is skewed distribution.
Most frequent score. Nominal data is obtained. Easy to calculate, not affected by extreme scores, but is not a useful measure on small datasets with frequently occurring same values.

Placed in rank order and is the middle score. Ordinal level data is obtained. Simple calculation and not affected by skewed distribution, but is less sensitive than the mean and not useful on small datasets.
The range and standard deviation

Difference between highest and lowest value. Affected by extreme scores and may not be useful if there are outliers. Does not indicate the distribution around the mean. If there are extreme scores, interquartile range can be used.

Useful for investigating spread of scores. Shows distance of each value from the mean. Standard deviation represents how the scores are spread around the mean, the higher the value, the greater the spread of scores around the mean value.

cards.term: Which graphs can be used to illustrate summary data or data frequencies?
cards.definition: Bar charts and histograms
Present data from a categorical variable, such as mean, mode and median. Categorical variable on x-axis and height represents value.
Present distribution of scores by illustrating the frequency. Bars are joined to represent continuous data. Possible values on x-axis and y-axis represents frequency.
Symmetry around the midpoint. Mean, mode and median aligned around the midpoint.
Obedience

cards.term: Obeying direct orders from someone in authority
cards.definition: Compliance

cards.term: Going along with what someone says, while not necessarily agreeing with it, often with peers rather than those in authority
cards.definition: Conforming

cards.term: Doing something against the individual\'s own inclinations, but not doing with the intention of matching the behaviour of the majority.
cards.definition: Internalising
What was the percentage obedience in self-administered variation?
What was the percentage obedience in remote-feedback variation?
What was the percentage obedience in verbal feedback variation?
What was the percentage obedience in rundown office block variation?
What was the percentage obedience in proximity variation?
What was the percentage obedience in touch proximity variation?
What was the percentage obedience in telephonic instructions variation?
What was the percentage obedience in ordinary man gives orders variation?
Where did Milgram conduct his study?
What was the background of Milgram\'s research?

cards.term: Focused on conflict between obedience to authority and personal conscience. Justifications for acts of genocide during WWII.
cards.definition: Milgram\'s aim

cards.term: Whether ordinary people will follow orders and give an innocent person an electric shock, and what conditions would increase or decrease the level of obedience.
cards.definition: What sampling method did Milgram use?

cards.term: Volunteer sampling - advert in a local newspaper
cards.definition: What participants did Milgram ask for?
What did Milgram say his study was about?
How much money were the participants paid?
How many participants were in Milgram\'s study?
How many confederates in Milgram\'s study?
What were the roles?

cards.term: Rigged - participant was always the teacher and Mr Wallace was the learner.
cards.definition: What was the voltage of the sample shock?
How many switches sin the shock generator?

cards.term: 30 switches increasing in 15 volts from 15V to 450V
cards.definition: What did the participant have to do?

cards.term: Teach the learner a list of word pairs and shocks were administered if an incorrect pair was given.
cards.definition: What were the 4 verbal prods?

cards.term: 1. Please continue2. The experiment requires you to continue3. It is absolutely essential that you continue4. You have no other choice but to continue, you must go on
cards.definition: How many variations are there in Milgram\'s study?
Remote-feedback condition

cards.term: Learner banged on wall at 300V and refused to answer after 315V
cards.definition: Verbal feedback condition

cards.term: At 75V, learner grunts. 120V shouts that it is painful. 135V painful groans. 150V shouts "Experimenter get me out of here". 270V agonising screams. 300V refusal to continue.
cards.definition: Proximity condition

cards.term: Learner could be seen and heard as the learner and teacher are in the same room
cards.definition: Touch proximity condition

cards.term: Learner has to place his own hand on the shock plate to receive the shock. At 150V refuses to continue and experimenter orders teacher to force the learner\'s hand on the shock plate.
cards.definition: What was given to the participants in the end of Milgram\'s study?
What did Milgram conclude?

cards.term: When learner could not be seen or heard, participant was more likely to follow orders. Provides evidence that people will obey orders given to somebody in a role of authority, even to the extent of killing an innocent human being.
cards.definition: Strengths in Milgram\'s original study

cards.term: - Right to withdraw given- Deception was a necessity because the research was studying obedience, so prevents demand characteristic- Lab experiment - standardised procedure, scripted, quantitative and qualitative data gathered. Good controls, so replicable and reliable- Debriefed
cards.definition: Weaknesses in Milgram\'s original study

cards.term: - Verbal prods and incentive prevents withdrawal from study- Stress was deliberately caused to the participants- Lacks ecological validity- Androcentric, ethnocentric, sampling method affects generalisability- Deception 4 times - shocks not real, Mr Wallace, not a study on memory and learning, allocation of roles
cards.definition: Telephonic instructions

cards.term: Initial instructions given face to face, then experimenter would leave the room and continue to give instructions via telephone. Shows presence of authority figure impacts obedience.
cards.definition: Rundown office block

cards.term: A rundown office building in Bridgeport was used. Shows that location impacts level of obedience.
cards.definition: Ordinary man gives orders

cards.term: Experimenter was an ordinary man. 1st confederate was the learner, 2nd confederate was the experimenter. Experimenter takes a phone call, and teacher is told to continue. Learner suggests that they should increase the shock level each time he makes a mistake.
cards.definition: Self-administered shocks

cards.term: Learner has to administer shocks to himself. If participant refuses, the teacher witnesses self-administered shocks.
cards.definition: Sampling method used by Meeus and Raaijmakers
How many participants in M + R

cards.term: 39 Dutch participants - 24 in experimental condition and 15 in control
cards.definition: What did the participants have to do in M + R?

cards.term: Make a series of 15 increasingly distressing remarks to the interviewees
cards.definition: What was the experimental and control condition? (M+R)

cards.term: Experimental - experimenter who gave the orders sat in the interviewControl - experimenter was not present
cards.definition: What classed as obedient? (M+R)

cards.term: The participant who made all the stress remarks was obedient and those who refused was disobedient
cards.definition: What were the results in M+R?

cards.term: Experimental condition - 92% made all 15 stressful commentsControl condition - 0% did
cards.definition: What did M+R conclude?

cards.term: People in everyday situations like a job interview will generally obey orders to abuse a stranger psychologically.

cards.definition: Allows data gathered to be in-depth and detailed. Gathers data from many different sources and different research methods

cards.term: What type of data do case studies gather?
cards.definition: Qualitative, but can also give quantitative (e.g. IQ tests)
Gathering data using different research methods and developing themes.
Henry Molaison
Suffered brain injury as a result of surgical procedure to relieve him from seizures caused by epilepsy.

cards.term: Which part of HM\'s brain was removed?
cards.definition: William Scoville removed HM\'s hippocampus, which was associated with consolidating memories.
He was assessed of having anterograde (loss of ability to make NEW memories) and retrograde (loss of ability to recall events PRIOR to the injury) amnesia.

cards.term: How did HM contribute to understanding memory?
cards.definition: Shows that there is short term and long term memory storage. Informs us that short term memories need to be transferred to long term storage to be able to be retrieved again.

cards.term: What 3 main standards should a good study adhere to?
cards.definition: 1. Possible to generalise2. Replicable3. Valid
If findings are consistent, and considered reliable, it can be trusted that findings will happen again.
Need to be impartial and judgement free
How well the procedure establishes a causal relationship between manipulated IV and measured DV.
The extent to which the performance on the measure can predict future performance on a similar criterion.
The extent to which the research can be generalised to other situations (real life or everyday situations).
Defining precisely how you intend to measure the DV and alter the conditions of the IV
Independent measures, repeated measures and matched pairs
Using DIFFERENT participants in each condition of the experiment
Using the SAME participants in each condition of the experiment
Using different but similar participants in each condition. An effort is made to match the participants in any important characteristics that might be important to the study.
Occurs when repeated measures design is used. Practice effect - become practised at the test and improve their performanceFatigue effect - become tired or bored so performance deteriorates
Each condition is tested first or second in equal amounts. Divided equally between the conditions and experiment them in different order.e.g. one group tested in A then B, other group do B then A.
Each participant is assigned either Condition A or B first randomly
Extraneous variable

cards.term: Variable that may have affected the DV but that was not the IV
cards.definition: Confounding variable

cards.term: Variable that affects the findings of a study directly, so much that you are no longer measuring what was intended
cards.definition: Situational variables

cards.term: An extraneous variable found in the environment, such as noise, time of day, temperature, disturbances etc.
cards.definition: Participant variables

cards.term: Participants themselves may affect results as they have different characteristics, such as intelligence, level of motivation, age, personality, skills.
cards.definition: Experimenter/ researcher effect

cards.term: The way the experimenter may influence the outcome of an experiment by their actions or presence.
cards.definition: Hawthorne effect

cards.term: Presence of the experimenter can affect performance
cards.definition: Demand characteristics

cards.term: Participants have certain expectations concerning the experiment. Actual communication, what the participant may have heard about the experiment, effect of the experimenter causes the participant to alter their behaviour to meet the expectations.
cards.definition: Standardisation

cards.term: Making an experiment the same experience for all participants. Standardised instructions and standardised procedures.
cards.definition: Single-blind procedure

cards.term: Participants are unaware of the study aim so it does not influence how they perform
cards.definition: Double-blind procedure

cards.term: Neither the participant nor the researcher knows the aim of the study. Eliminate experimenter effects.
cards.definition: Inferential test shows...

cards.term: how strong a difference between variables is
cards.definition: Type 1 error

cards.term: Accepting the alternative hypothesis when results were not significant and null hypothesis should have actually been retained. Level of significance was too lenient
cards.definition: Type II error

cards.term: Retaining the null hypothesis when there was actually a real effect. The level of significance was too stringent.
cards.definition: Nominal data
Ordinal data

cards.term: Ordered in some way, e.g. ranking
cards.definition: Interval data

cards.term: Real measurements are involved, e.g temperature
cards.definition: Ratio data

cards.term: Same as interval, but there is a true zero point, e.g. cm or seconds
cards.definition: Observed value

cards.term: Number at the end of the calculation
cards.definition: Critical value

cards.term: To decide if the observed value is significant, it is compared with a critical value in a critical values table
cards.definition: Inferential test decision tree

cards.term: 1. Difference or relationship2. Nominal or ordinal data3. Independent groups or repeated measures
cards.definition: Difference/ relationship and nominal data
Relationship and ordinal data
Difference, ordinal data and independent groups
Difference, ordinal data and repeated measures
Mann-Whitney U test

cards.term: 1. Rank all scores as a whole group2. Find sum of ranks for both groups, so each group will need to be divided back into their original sets3. Use the formula to calculate Ua and Ub
cards.definition: The observed value in Mann-Whitney is significant if...

cards.term: it is equal to or LESS than the critical value
cards.definition: Wilcoxon test

cards.term: 1. Calculate the difference between pairs of scores by each participant (A-B)2. Rank the score differences3. Calculate sum total of ranks for positive differences and negative differences4. Smaller score is the T value
cards.definition: Who proposed the Multi-store model of memory?
What are the 3 basic memory stores?

cards.term: Sensory register, short-term memory and long-term memory
cards.definition: Multi store model of memory

cards.term: Attended information from sensory register is transferred to STM, from STM information can be transferred to LTM
cards.definition: Sensory register research

cards.term: Sperling used a visual array of letters - participants recalled on average 4.32 letters of the whole array. Shows it can only hold limited amount of information.
cards.definition: Sensory register summary

cards.term: - One register for each sensory modality e.g. visual, auditory- Limited, approx. 50 milliseconds duration- Capacity 3-4 items- Forgetting by decay- Retrieval by scanning
cards.definition: STM duration research

cards.term: Peterson and Peterson - using an interference task to prevent rehearsal. Required to remember a single trigram for intervals of 3, 6, 9, 12, 15 and 18 secs. Correct recall of trigram was likely after a short interval but performance dropped after 15-18 secs.
cards.definition: STM capacity research

cards.term: Miller - STM limited to around 7 items. \'Magic number seven, plus or minus two\'
cards.definition: Primacy-recency effect

cards.term: Glanzer and Cunitz - first and last words in the list were recalled well, but middle words were not remembered well. First (primacy effect) had gone into LTM through rehearsal and end (recency effect) is still in rehearsal loop. Middle is not well recalled as it was displaced by new material.
cards.definition: STM encoding

cards.term: Memory trace was held in an auditory or verbal form because of phonological similarity effect. Suggests STM encoding is primarily acoustic.
cards.definition: STM retrieval

cards.term: Based on rapid scanning of stored information. Rehearsal is important for maintaining information in the STM, increasing strength of memory trace.
cards.definition: Transfer of information between STM and LTM

cards.term: Transfer can be a result of rehearsal - leave a weak memory trace. Stronger memory trace by using a medical operation such as a mnemonic.
cards.definition: STM summary

cards.term: - Acoustic and verbal encoding- Duration 15 - 30 seconds- Storage capacity 5 - 9 items- Forgetting by decay through displacement- Retrieval by sequential search
cards.definition: Retrieval from LTM

cards.term: LTM exists for all sensory modalities, multiple copies of a memory were retained. Tip-of-the-tongue phenomenon (Brown and McNeill 1968) showed that people were able to accurately predict that they could recognise a correct answer even if they could not recall the answer at that moment in time.
cards.definition: Encoding in LTM

cards.term: Depend on rehearsal process or association between new and pre-existing knowledge. Encoding is semantic.
cards.definition: Duration of LTM

cards.term: Potentially a lifetime. Bahrick (1975) found that identification of names and faces in High School Yearbook was between 70-80% accurate 48 years after leaving school.
cards.definition: Capacity of LTM

cards.term: Potentially infinite. Brady (2008) showed 2500 objects over 5.5 hours. Participants were shown the original object paired with a different object, identification was 92% and if different object was similar 88%
cards.definition: LTM summary

cards.term: - Semantic encoding- Potentially a lifetime of duration- Limitless capacity- Forgetting through decay and interference- Semantic retrieval
cards.definition: Strengths of MSM
