cards.term: - Supporting evidence- HM case study gives physiological support- Shows they have separate stores - Baddeley conducted an experiment and found that semantic words were more difficult to recall, suggests encoding in STM and LTM were different
cards.definition: Weaknesses of MSM

cards.term: - Experiments use artificial tasks, so might not be valid- Alternative explanations- Too simplistic an explanation. - Emphasis given to rehearsal in transfer of information from STM to LTM
cards.definition: Clive Wearing

cards.term: Could not recall past events, but could only remember how to play the piano. Suggests the LTM is not a single store but could be because of something more complex
cards.definition: Who proposed the Working Memory Model?
Working memory model

cards.term: Why did Baddeley and Hitch propose the WMM?
cards.definition: They noted problems with the MSM because it was overly simplistic and it emphasised the role of rehearsal as being critical to learning.

cards.term: What are the 3 components of the WMM?
cards.definition: Central executive, phonological loop and visuospatial sketchpad

cards.term: What is the role of the working memory?
cards.definition: To temporarily store and manipulate information being used. It is fragile and susceptible to distraction, overload and overwork

Deal with the running of the memory system and two slave systems. Has limited capacity but can deal with different types of sensory information. The attentional controller with capacity to focus, divide and switch attention.
Able to process different forms of information e.g. acoustic, visual
Holds speech based information for about 2 seconds before decay. Deals with temporary storage of VERBAL information.

cards.term: What are the two components in the phonological loop?
cards.definition: Articulatory loop (inner voice) and Primary Acoustic Store (inner ear)
Holds auditory traces which decay rapidly after a few seconds.
It is more difficult to remember similar sounding words and letters compared to different sounding words. Not the case for semantic similarity, shows that it relies on acoustic encoding for storage.
Revives memory traces by rehearsing them, subvocal speech.

Short monosyllabic words were recalled more successfully than longer polysyllabic words. Longer words filled up the limited capacity resulting in decay. The LONGER the word, the more capacity was used up and forgetting more likely.
Can temporarily hold and manipulate visual and spatial information, such as shapes, colours. Limited in capacity to around 3 - 4 objects.
Some people have better STM than others. Poor WM has been associated with dyslexia and Specific language impairment.
- Expands on MSM, more information- Neurophysiological evidence - case study of KF- Valid, credible as it fits with everyday situations

Suffered STM impairment following a motorbike accident. Problem with immediate recall of words being presented verbally, but not with visual information. KF has impaired articulatory loop but intact VSSP

- Artificial task, lack ecological and task validity- Only explains STM, not transfer to LTM- Central Executive is simplistic and vague, doesn\'t explain what it does, difficult to design tasks to test it
Bartlett (1932)

cards.term: What did Bartlett believe about memory?
cards.definition: It should not be divided into its parts and treated as independent from other functioning, but should be studied to capture the relationship between memory
Conducted experiments to test memory for shapes and objects and found that participants often assign verbal labels. Perception of the shape or object influenced how it was remembered.
Showed ink blots and asked what they saw. Participants searched their own stored images to find the best match.
Participants connect a stimulus with knowledge or experience they already possessed. Once the stimulus gains meaning, it can be more readily stored.
Perception is an active construction of what we think we see using our prior knowledge.

- 20 participants read the story twice - Tested recall after several minutes, weeks, months and years- Story became SHORTENED, phrases reflected modern concepts and the story became more COHERENT- Transformations were reported to make the story more familiar

cards.term: What did Bartlett conclude about memory?
cards.definition: - It is a reconstruction each time it is recalled- Rarely accurate and prone to rationalisation (shortening)- Confabulation (making up bits and filling in gaps)- Remembering is constructive and influenced by inferences made by an individual
Schemas are parcels of stored knowledge or mental representations of information about a specific object or event. Used in recognition and interpretation of unfamiliar objects and events.
Attitudes and responses to events change our memory for those events. Recall involves retrieving knowledge that has been altered to fit with stereotypes the person already has.
How we perceive an object or event is based on individual interpretation, influences by past experiences, knowledge learned and beliefs we possess.
- Evidence - War of Ghosts and Loftus+Palmer- Can be tested experimentally, makes it scientific- Good application to real life, police and courts with eyewitnesses
Identical, share 100% of their genes as they come from one fertilised egg.

cards.term: What should be considered about MZ twins?
cards.definition: - Do not share the same environment- There are some physical differences, such as fingerprints- Can become less identical over time- Some characteristics, such as IQ and personality might become more alike as twins age
Different environmental influences affect which genes are switched on and off. Younger MZ twins have few epigenetic differences.
Not identical, come from two separate eggs fertilised at the same time. Share 50% of genes.

If a characteristic comes from genes, MZ twins should be more likely to share it. Psychologists can compare behaviour between a group of identical twins and fraternal twins to see which group shared the most similarity.
The extent to which the same behaviour is the same between twins. An agreement rate when both twins have got a characteristic.
- Twin studies are the main way of finding out if genes have any influence on behaviour.- Both twins share their environment, so there should not be many environmental differences between the twins.

- MZ twins will be treated more like twins than DZ twins, so environments are not the same.- Epigenetic modification, there are differences between twins. Difficult to say if a characteristic is caused by genes conclusively

- 16 year period (longitudinal) using 5 twin studies- To see if there was a relationship between genetic make up and development of schizophrenia by looking at concordance rate- 57 twin pairs (24 MZ and 33 DZ)- Hospital notes and semi-structured interviews
- MZ twins - 42%- DZ twin - 17%
Genes do play a role in the development of schizophrenia, but can\'t conclusively say it is solely due to genes.
It is the only direct way to isolate the influence of genes and the environment.

cards.term: In what circumstances in adoption studies suggest the roles of genes?
cards.definition: Similarities between child and their biological parents

cards.term: In what circumstances in adoption studies suggest the roles of environment?
cards.definition: Similarities between child and their adoptive parents
- Research in Finland- Sample of 155- 9 adopted children, 8 had biological mothers with schizophrenia or a form of psychoses

- Developmental trends (patterns) can be studied because studies are longitudinal. Same children can be studied at different times during development.- Control for environment, separates genes from environment.
- Adopted children are often placed into families very similar to their biological families- They are matched, so the environments might not be as different as thought

cards.term: What are the 3 main brain scanning techniques?
cards.definition: PET scans, CAT scans and fMRI scans
- inject patient with FDG (radioactive)- task is given to stimulate the brain- glucose is used up, radioactive atoms break down, gamma rays produced- high activity (red)- low activity (blue)

cards.term: What are PET scans useful for?
cards.definition: Investigating areas of the brain that are not functioning normally, indicate damage or tumours.
- Reasonably non-invasive, less dangerous than surgery- Valid measure- Reliable because it can be repeated and same results found again

- Invasive - Ethical implications, need informed consent and a good reason to carry it out- Can cause panic if claustrophobic- Difficult to isolate different brain functioning precisely, as they will be using other parts of the brain as well. Hard to claim exactly what part of the brain is performing which function
- uses blood flow of brain to indicate level of activity- head placed in large electromagnet
- No danger from radiation- Detection of blood flow is very precise so slight changes can be detected- Medical use, looking at brain structure and functioning

- Cannot look at receptors of neurotransmitters unlike PET scans- Too much head movement can distort imaging- The brain is never at rest, so it is not easy to gather a baseline measure- Risks, such as those with pacemakers and those who are claustrophobic.
- Multiple X-ray beams passed around the head at different angles- Detailed 3D image

cards.term: What are CAT scans useful for?
cards.definition: Detecting areas of brain damage after an accident or position of tumours
- Less harmful than PET scans- Can detect changes in physical structures, so good for detecting tumours or haemorrhages- Not painful, non-invasive
- MRI gives a clearer picture- Involves X-raying which can cause damage, notably cancers.
Raine (1997)- investigate whether people charged with murder and pleading NGRI have brain differences that might link to their aggression.

Dimoka (2010)- if brain function and structure linked to trust and distrust. Found that credibility and discredibility linked to cognitive brain areas in the prefrontal cortex. Benevolence and malevolence linked to emotion area (limbic system)

Betts (2009)- case of Herbert Weinstein, 64 year old man who strangled his wife. Defence was that a cyst had caused pressure on his prefrontal cortex, affecting understanding. CAT scan evidence of differences in his brain relating to schizophrenia.
A way of looking at relationships between two variables, not causes. If two variables are correlated, you can predict one from the other.

cards.term: In a correlation, the SAME person produces the two scores. True or false?
cards.definition: True

cards.term: What type of data is used in correlations?
cards.definition: Numerical data

cards.term: What are the three important features of correlation design?
cards.definition: 1. There is no IV or DV, only two variables of equal importance2. Hypothesis will be about a relationship between two variables (not a difference)3. Hypothesis could be directional as it could predict a positive or negative correlation.

cards.term: Name an example of co-variables in biological psychology
cards.definition: Measuring the number of genes a person shares (closeness of family relationship) and a behavioural charactersitic such as the amount of aggression they show.

cards.term: What type of graph do you use to show correlations?
cards.definition: Scatter diagrams
- Positive correlation- Negative correlation- Uncorrelated

cards.term: Which inferential statistic test do you use for correlations?
cards.definition: Spearman Rank Correlation Coefficient

cards.term: How do you carry out a Spearman\'s rho?
cards.definition: 1. Rank starting from the lowest score (rank 1) 2. If there are two or more scores the same, allocate those scores the same rank by finding the middle rank
1. Spearman\'s rho2. Draw a scatter graph then look at the line of best fit

cards.term: How do you interpret the results of the Spearman\'s test?
cards.definition: - If both scores rise, there is a positive correlation. A result of +1 means a perfect positive correlation- A result of 0 means no correlation- If one score rises and the other falls there is a negative correlation.
Both co-variables increase
When one variable increases and the other variable decreases.

cards.term: What are the two main parts in the nervous system?
cards.definition: Central nervous system and Peripheral nervous system

cards.term: What does the CNS consist of?
cards.definition: Brain and spinal cord

cards.term: What is the role of the CNS?
cards.definition: Central processing and control point for all human behaviour. Processes all information from the senses and is responsible for controlling behaviour.

cards.term: What is the role of the spinal cord in the CNS?
cards.definition: Connects the brain to the rest of the body, and allows messages to be passed from body to brain and from brain to other parts of the body.
Nerves in the CNS that communicate with other cells at the same time
A chemical involved in passing information from one neurone to another in synaptic transmission
What are the parts of the neurone?

cards.term: 1. Cell body2. Nucleus3. Myelin sheath4. Nodes of Ranvier5. Axon terminal6. Terminal buttons7. Dendrites8. Axon9. Schwann\'s cells
cards.definition: How is a message carried by the neurone?

cards.term: - Ions such as sodium, potassium, chlorine and calcium arise in certain quantities- When voltage outside and inside differ, the action potential is sent- AP travels into the axons - Releases the neurotransmitter
cards.definition: Synaptic transmission

cards.term: How a message is carried by a neurone by action potential
cards.definition: How is a synaptic transmission generated?

cards.term: 1. Electrical impulse down the axon triggers release of neurotransmitters from axon terminals. 2. Released into synaptic gap to be picked up by the receptors on dendrites or to be taken up again for re-use
cards.definition: Pre-synaptic neurone
Post-synaptic neurone
Neurotransmitters in synaptic transmission

cards.term: - When AP reaches axon terminal, calcium channels open, flooding terminal button with calcium ions- Vesicles release neurotransmitter - Vesicles fuse with the membrane
cards.definition: Receptors in synaptic transmission

cards.term: - Designed to bind to a specific neurotransmitter- When detecting the neurotransmitter, it will be absorbed by the post-synaptic neurone- Any not absorbed will be destroyed or reabsorbed by pre-synaptic neurone
cards.definition: Function of neurotransmitters

cards.term: Chemical messengers that act between neurones in the brain. Allows the brain to process thoughts and memories.
cards.definition: 4 common neurotransmitters
Acetylcholine

cards.term: Stimulates muscle contractions, key function in motor control and movement. Memory, attention and alertness. Expressions of anger and sexuality.
cards.definition: Noradrenaline

cards.term: Mood control, sleeping, dreaming and learning.
cards.definition: Dopamine

cards.term: Posture and control of movement. Reinforcement in learning, and dependency such as addictions. Hormonal regulation, such as menstrual cycle.
cards.definition: Serotonin

cards.term: Mood control, particularly limbic system. Feeling pain, sleep, regulating body temperature and hunger.
cards.definition: The brain is in two halves, called...
Corpus callosum

cards.term: Section that joins the two hemispheres
cards.definition: Cortex
Pre-frontal cortex

cards.term: - Has connections with parts of the brain relating to neurotransmitters, such as dopamine and serotonin- Regulating emotions, so aggression comes from LACK of regulation or control over behaviour
cards.definition: Orbitofrontal cortex

cards.term: Accepting delayed gratification and deferring rewards
cards.definition: Ventromedial cortex
Lateral prefrontal cortex

cards.term: Making choices in behaviour by letting us see options.
cards.definition: What are the differences between the left and right hemisphere pre frontal cortex?

cards.term: Left hemisphere involved in positive emotions and right hemisphere with negative emotions.
cards.definition: Prefrontal cortex role in aggression

cards.term: Damage to prefrontal cortex:- Focus on the present- Not be able to plan long term- Wanting immediate rewards- Unable to control aggressive reactions- Raine et al (1998) emotional impulsive aggression had low prefrontal cortex functioning
cards.definition: Amygdala

cards.term: - Limbic system- Self-preservation, flight/fight response- Centre for emotions and motivation- Combines all sensory modality to give an instinctive feeling or reaction- Identifying threat
cards.definition: Animal studies involving amygdala

cards.term: If amygdala is stimulated using electrical current, the animal shows aggression. If amygdala is removed, animal becomes passive and unresponsive and doesn\'t respond to fear.
cards.definition: Hypothalamus

cards.term: - Limbic system- Maintain homeostasis - regulating hunger, thirst and response to anger, agression- Regulating hormones used to signal between organs and tissue- Hormones regulating sexual function, testosterone production
cards.definition: Recreational drug
Examples of recreational drugs
Psychoactive drug

cards.term: Drugs that have an effect on the CNS
cards.definition: Specific mode of action

cards.term: Act in a specific way in the synapse
cards.definition: Reward pathway in the brain

cards.term: Pleasure centre, where pleasure seems to be so desired that the animal will continue to behave in such a manner that the pleasure received. The desire for pleasure over-rides other drives
cards.definition: Effects of nicotine in the synapse

cards.term: - Release more neurotransmitter in response to an impulse- Increases number of impulses- More dopamine in the reward system
cards.definition: What is the long term effect of nicotine in the synapse?

cards.term: - Binding over time affects receptors, decreases dopamine receptors- Change in the shape of the cell- Without nicotine, more dopamine is required to stimulate the post-synaptic neurone to a \'normal\' level
cards.definition: Desensitisation

cards.term: When more of a substance is required to achieve the same response, leading to addiction.
cards.definition: Effects of cocaine in the synapse

cards.term: - Blocks reuptake- More neurotransmitter (dopamine) in the synapse- Over-stimulation at the post-synaptic receptors
cards.definition: What are the long-term effects of cocaine in the synapse?

cards.term: - Dopamine receptors become damaged- Become fewer- Desensitisation- Addiction
cards.definition: Effects of cannabis in the synapse

cards.term: - Binds to cannabinoid (CB1) receptors- Blocks their activity- Can affect GABAergic neurones and stop them from inhibiting dopamine production in the reward system- Excess dopamine, gives \'high\'
cards.definition: How can cannabis affect memory function?

cards.term: - Binds to cannabinoid receptors, blocking them- Less activity in neurones in the hippocampus- Making memories can be affected
cards.definition: What is a hormone?

cards.term: A chemical produced by the body that sends messaged to organs of the body via the bloodstream.
cards.definition: How is testosterone production controlled?

cards.term: Hypothalamus and pituitary gland control how much testosterone the testes produce and secrete. Hypothalamus sends a signal to pituitary gland to release gonadotrophic substances.
cards.definition: How does testosterone lead to aggression?

cards.term: Anti-natal exposure to testosterone has an effect on the developing brain, leading to increased spatial ability and (possibly) competitive aggression
cards.definition: Beeman (1947)

cards.term: Castrated male mice had reduced aggression. Later, injected the mice with testosterone which re-established aggression.
cards.definition: Dabbs (1987)

cards.term: - Measured levels of testosterone in the saliva of 89 male prisoners involved in violent/ non-violent crime- Level of testosterone was higher in those who had been involved in violent crimes- Higher levels of testosterone were also rated by peers as being tough (correlational)
cards.definition: Serotonin explanation for aggression

cards.term: - Low levels of serotonin being indicated by low levels of metabolites- People who engage in aggressive behaviour and have poor levels of control have low levels of metabolites
cards.definition: Mann (1990)

cards.term: People given a drug that lowers levels of serotonin were more aggressive (measured by questionnaire)
cards.definition: Evolution

cards.term: How inherited characteristics in organisms evolve from generation to generation.
cards.definition: Survival of the fittest

cards.term: Those who are more adapted to the environment survive, and they pass on those genes to their offspring to aid survival
cards.definition: Natural selection

cards.term: The way some characteristics may aid survival over other characterisitcs

cards.definition: - Can be used alongside other research methods such as case studies and lab experiments- Can be used on their own- No IV to manipulate- All data gathered by observing

cards.term: What types of data can be gathered using observations?
cards.definition: Quantitative data e.g. observing how many times people actQualitative data e.g. describing how people acted aggressively

cards.term: What are the ways to collect data in observations?
cards.definition: Tallying, event sampling and time sampling
Identify the type of data to record, then record each instance of something happening on a piece of paper.
Choosing which events are to be observed and then noting down each time that event occurs.
Observing for certain periods of time. Makes the observation more manageable.

cards.term: What are the types of observations?
cards.definition: - Structured/ naturalistic- Participant/ non-participant- Overt/ covert
The situation is set up and then what happens is observed

\'Strange situation\': observed interactions between mothers and their children to examine attachment patterns. Watched through a one-way mirror. Observations to see what the child did when the mother was both in and out of the room, with or without the stranger.
- Can be repeated, so results can be compared between observations, reliable- Ensures the behaviour takes place, it can take a long time for some behaviour to occur naturally
- Situation is artificial, lack ecological validity- The situation might be interpreted differently by different participants, so may not be as controlled as thought
Takes place in the participants\' natural setting

Looked at parents dropping off children at preschool to look at parental behaviour, the length of time the separation between the child and parents took and how the child interacted with peers. Aim to see effects of parental lingering - the longer the parents took to leave, the less time children spent playing with peers.
- Natural environment, so ecologically valid- Gather in depth data and detail, data often qualitative and rich

- Subjectivity because the observer has to choose what to observe and what to record- An observation of one group/ individual at one moment in time, data not generalisable to other people at different times
Observers are part of what they are observing, involved in the situation, activity or group
- Ecological validity, observation in a natural setting- Observer likely to gather valid data because the behaviour is naturally occurring
- Difficult to replicate because it is difficult to find an observer who is also a member of the group- Observer too involved to record all the data, cannot step back from it
Observers are not a part of what is being observed, they sit away from the activity
- Objective, the observer can stand back from the situation - Can record data easily because they have time to concentrate- Tally systematically
- Likely to affect the situation just by their presence- May miss relevant information and interactions or misunderstand something as they are not part of the observation
Participants do not know the observation is taking place

- Behaviour of participants likely to be natural because they are unaware that they are being observed, validity- Easier to carry out as the participants are not watching the observer carry out the observation
- Often not ethical because there is no informed consent, if not carried out in a public place it goes against ethical guidelines- Observer cannot be helped by participants
The participants know the observation is taking place and they are aware of all aspects of the study

- Ethical because informed consent can be gained and the right to withdraw can be given- Observers can ask for help to set up the study (where to observe from) or they might want a further explanation
When there is more than one observer, observations can be compared. Separate sets of data are recorded and tested to see if there is a correlation between them.

- Flexibility it allows researchers- Well suited to large data sets- Allows researchers to expand range of study past individual experiences- Great for multiple researchers- Interpretation of themes- Allows categories to emerge from the data

- Reliability is a concern due to wide variety of interpretations- May miss nuanced data- Flexibility makes it difficult to concentrate on what aspect of the data to focus on- Discovery and verification of themes and codes mesh together- Limited interpretive power- Difficult to maintain sense of continuity of data- Does not allow researchers to make claims about language usage
Gathering data using content of articles, newspapers, media programmes and books (auditory or visual material). Exploring articles to find key terms or instances, generating categories.

cards.term: What are the three types of content analysis?
cards.definition: Conventional content analysis, directive content analysis and summative content analysis
Picking categories out from the data
Theories drive the categories
Searching for key words and then counting them before interpreting the data

cards.term: How are qualitative and quantitative data gathered from content analysis?
cards.definition: Qualitative data gathered if the data are formed into a story/ text about categories/ issues.Quantitative data gathered by tallying of categories/ issues

- Readily understood, inexpensive research method. Unobtrusive and doesn\'t require contact with people- Powerful tool when combined with other research methods. Useful for analysing historical material and trends over time- Establishing reliability is easy and straightforward, scores highest with regard to ease of replication.

- Purely descriptive method, may not reveal the underlying motives for the observed pattern- Analysis is limited by availability of material, observed trends in media may not be an accurate reflection of reality.

- IV and DV- Strong controls, such as the environment, duration of study, biochemical factors, gender, age, type of animal and other variables- Can show a cause-and-effect relationship- Scientific and draw hypothesis from theory

cards.term: What is different with human and animal studies?
cards.definition: - They have to be fed, housed, looked after and handled differently- Studies cannot last too long- Must be suitable for the species- Animal needs to have the right features, such as biochemistry or brain structure- More controls with animals

cards.term: Ethical guidelines for use of animals in lab experiments, BPS Guideline (2012)
cards.definition: - Caging must be suitable, avoid overcrowding- Some food deprivation, only minimal distress- Anaesthetic used to alleviate suffering- Post-operative care to minimise stress, humane killing- Regulated procedure must hold a personal licence, be a scientific procedure establishment- Animals used only if alternatives have been considered and rejected- Species must be appropriate, bred in captivity - Smallest number possible- Responsible care for animals- suitable accommodation and environment, foods and water- After experiment, animals should be used for breeding or as companion animals

- Rats have a short gestation period, 22 days- Can investigate behaviours across generations- Internal validity as behaviour is unlikely to change due to demand characteristic- High control, can isolate variables from animals- Pain and distress can be permitted if necessary- Humans share common ancestry with other animals- Useful for medical research

cards.term: Utilitarian argument for use of animals
cards.definition: Suffering of a small number of animals is justified because it helps a significant number of people. We have a moral obligation to our own species to advance knowledge. (Gray 1991)

cards.term: Singer\'s (1975) argument for use of animals
cards.definition: Research should take place if for the greater good of the greater number

- Lack credibility and ecological validity- Too many differences between humans and animals- Differences in human and animal evolution and genetic make-up. Act differently, behaviour and thought processes. - Physiologically, our brains differ from animals. - Utilitarian argument - research gives human suffering priority over animal suffering. Singer (1975) viewed this as speciesism, animals have same rights as humans.
Animals attributed with human qualities

cards.term: Cost-benefit argument for not using animals
cards.definition: It does not work as the cost to animals might not be known at the start and neither might the benefits of the findings

- Relatively small and easy to handle, so procedures can be more feasible - Short gestation periods and reproductive cycles, so generations can be studied- Similar brain structures to humans, can be related to humans
- Brains are not exactly the same, so generalising might not be valuable- Using animal findings to draw conclusions about humans does not address complexity of human processing and behaviour.
- Hypothesis testing and falsification- Objectivity and controls- Empiricism- Replicability- Reliability- Validity- Reductionism
The view that all knowledge is based on experience.
Theory of learning that examines how a response is associated with a stimulus to cause conditioning. Learning by association
Something within the environment that produces a response
Something that happens after the stimulus is received, either a reflex or automatic behaviour

cards.term: What year did Pavlov conduct his experiment?

cards.definition: How the cerebral cortex works. He wanted to look at reflex behaviours to see if he could work out pathways in the brain

- Salivation measured by volume in a glass tube- Special chamber where the dogs could not even hear footsteps- Salivation to the meat was a reflex, when association was made between metronome and salivation, new paths made in the cortex. - Pairing had to take place about 20 times
After several pairings, salivation starts after 9 seconds and by 45 seconds, 11 drops of saliva had been collected (metronome study)
Dogs could learn through association
- Lab experiment, controls, scientific, cause-and-effect conclusions could be drawn- Carried out many experiments and found the same results, stimulus could be conditioned to produce reflex.
- Dogs are difficult to generalise to humans because human brains are more complex, lack credibility- Lack ecological validity, lab experiment

cards.term: Using the terminology, NS, UCS, UCR, CS, CR, explain classical conditioning
cards.definition: Extinction

cards.term: When the conditioned stimulus no longer leads to a conditioned response.
cards.definition: How did Pavlov study extinction?

cards.term: - No longer given food at the sound of the bell- Bell alone was presented many times- Dogs stopped salivating at the sound of the bell
cards.definition: Spontaneous recovery

cards.term: Spontaneous reappearance of a conditioned response after it has been extinguished.
cards.definition: Stimulus generalisation

cards.term: When the neutral stimulus, which becomes the conditioned stimulus, is not used exactly but still gains the response.
cards.definition: Operant conditioning

cards.term: Learning through the consequences of actions. The learning of voluntary behaviour. An association is made between a behaviour and consequences for that behaviour.
cards.definition: Skinner\'s pigeons

cards.term: - When a lab pigeon taps a blue button, it receives a food pellet as a reward- When the pigeon taps a red button, it receives a mild electric shock- The pigeon learns to press the blue button and avoid the red button
cards.definition: Thorndike (1911)

cards.term: - Cat in a cage with a latch on the door and salmon outside the cage- The cat hits the latch on the door and opens- Amount of time and effort spent on escaping became less over time
cards.definition: Instrumental learning (Thorndike)

cards.term: Behaviour that produced the desired effect became dominant, occurred faster the more the experiment took place
cards.definition: Skinner\'s ABC model of operant conditioning

cards.term: Antecedent - present stimulus that triggers behaviourBehaviour - response that could be observed or measuredConsequence - reward or punishment
cards.definition: Reinforcement

cards.term: Encourage the repetition of desired behaviour
cards.definition: Positive reinforcement

cards.term: Something desired is given in response to a behaviour
cards.definition: Negative reinforcement

cards.term: Something undesired is taken away in response to a behaviour
cards.definition: Punishment

cards.term: Discouraging behaviour, doing something to stop the behaviour
cards.definition: Positive punishment

cards.term: When something undesired is given as a punishment for bad or unwanted behaviour
cards.definition: Negative punishment

cards.term: Removal of something nice as punishment in order to reduce the bad/ undesired behaviour
cards.definition: Primary reinforcement

cards.term: The reward meets a basic need, such as foodf
cards.definition: Secondary reinforcement

cards.term: Reward is something that can buy or get a basic need, such as money
cards.definition: Schedules of reinforcement

cards.term: A rule that dictates the situations in which a behaviour will be reinforced.
cards.definition: Fixed interval

cards.term: The rewarding of a first correct response only after a present amount of time has passed. There is a scalloping effect. e.g. rat gets food pellet after pressing the lever after a 30-second time delay
cards.definition: Variable interval

cards.term: The rewarding of the first correct response after a set amount of time has passed, after which a new time period is set.
cards.definition: Fixed ratio

cards.term: Where a response is reinforced after a specified number of responses. e.g. providing the food pellet after the rat presses the lever 8 times
cards.definition: Variable ratio

cards.term: Where a response is reinforced after a set number of correct responses is given. After this has been achieved, the number of correct responses in order for reinforcement to be given changes.
cards.definition: Behaviour modification

cards.term: If rewards or punishments are planned, so that certain behaviours are produced and others are dropped, this is modifying the individual\'s behaviour
cards.definition: Shaping

cards.term: Gradually working towards the required behaviour by rewards or punishments
cards.definition: Token economy

cards.term: Tokens are secondary reinforcers as they can be exchangeable for primary reinforcers. Tokens are given in return for showing the desired behaviour. Through selective reinforcement, desirable behaviours are encouraged and undesirable behaviours extinguished
cards.definition: Strengths of operant conditioning

cards.term: - Can explain wide assortment of behaviours. Has practical applications- Scientific: concepts can be defined, measured, controlled, objective, replicable- Skinner viewed determinism as positive as behaviourist principles could be used to create a better world- Thorndike and Skinner supporting studies
cards.definition: Weaknesses of operant conditioning

cards.term: - Controlled environment is not natural, artificial nature, lack ecological validity- Reductionism - underestimates the role of biological factors- Animal research is not generalisable to humans as they have different anatomy and physiology- Ethical issues - needs to be weighed against the benefits of research- Deterministic - behaviours largely governed by environmental forces. Individuals cannot control their own actions and cannot be responsible for them. Has sinister implications in controlling behaviour
cards.definition: Social Learning Theory

cards.term: People learn through observing and imitating role models.
cards.definition: Observational learning

cards.term: People watch what others do and imitate their actions, therefore learning new behaviours
cards.definition: Modelling

cards.term: A way of learning by imitating the behaviour of others
cards.definition: Role models

cards.term: Significant individuals in a person\'s life.
cards.definition: Vicarious reinforcement

cards.term: Learning through the consequences of another person\'s behaviour
cards.definition: Self-efficacy

cards.term: A person knowing their own ability to do something and being confident with it. Self-confidence and belief to imitate the behaviour.
cards.definition: Bandura (1977) 4 criteria to be met for imitation to occur:

cards.term: 1. Attention to role model2. Retention of the observed behaviour3. Reproduction of target behaviour4. Motivation to imitate the observed behaviour
cards.definition: Intrinsic motivation

cards.term: Inherent satisfaction rather than a physical outcome
cards.definition: Extrinsic motivation

cards.term: Motivator that is not so much a feeling or a view, but something tangible
cards.definition: Strengths of SLT

cards.term: - Supporting studies - Bandura, Ross and Ross- Lab experiment, standardised procedures, controls, replicable, credible, objective- Inter rater reliability- Treatment for phobias
cards.definition: Weaknesses of SLT

cards.term: - Low ecological validity, artificial setting- Individual differences would affect response- Classical and Operant conditioning
cards.definition: Bandura, Ross and Ross (1961) aim

cards.term: To investigate whether young children will imitate behaviour they observe

cards.definition: Patient has an insight in their disorder
Patient thinks that what happens to them is real - in a pyschotic episode
Health and Care Professions Council
Became governing body of psychologists in 2008. Keeps a register of psychologists and social work professionals who meet their standards and they regulate these professions.

cards.term: Who must register with the HCPC?
cards.definition: Clinical psychologists, health psychologists, counselling psychologists, educational psychologists, occupational psychologists, sport and exercise psychologists and forensic psychologists.

cards.term: How does the HCPC protect the public?
cards.definition: - Set standards in terms of education and training, professional skills, conduct, performance and ethics- Keeps a register of professionals- Approve programmes where professionals must complete to register- Take action when professionals do not meet standards

cards.term: What are the 7 standards of HCPC?
cards.definition: 1. Character2. Health3. Standards of proficiency4. Conduct, performance and ethics5. Continuing professional development6. Education and training7. Standards for prescribing
Have to provide credible character references to give an idea of the character traits to make them suitable. Considers criminal convictions.
Provide information about their general health every two years. If their health impairs ability to practise, they must limit or stop their work
Professional autonomy and accountability, and formulation and delivery of plans and strategies for meeting health and social care needs. Must demonstrate these skills.

cards.term: HCPC standard of conduct, performance and ethics
cards.definition: 14 guidelines they must adhere to, including confidentiality and acting within the limits of their own knowledge and skills.

cards.term: HCPC standard of continuing professional development
cards.definition: Take part in and document regular training they undertake to develop their own practice. Attend training events, keep up to date with current trends.

cards.term: HCPC standard of education and training
cards.definition: Set of minimum levels of qualification specified before they can register. Must have at least a master\'s degree with BPS qualifications.
Safe practice for prescribing medication, includes knowledge and training to prescribe professionally.

cards.term: 2 stages to register with the HCPC
cards.definition: 1. Checks the trainee has passed all elements of a programme, all academic, clinical and research elements must be passed2. Trainee can apply. Will require character reference, health reference and information about the applicant
Standardised so all respondents are asked the same questions in the same way, often using closed questions. Easy to administer, no need to establish rapport. Data is superficial and lacks depth.

Conversational and dynamic. Researcher has a set of questions they aim to be answered but no standardised format. Conversation can flow while achieving research aim and getting relevant information. Both quantitative and qualitative.

Loose research aim and qualitative information. Interviewer is analytical and can seek meaning from respondents. Achieves good rapport with respondents and responsive to information offered. Good at listening and use non-judgemental language.
Data which relates to a living individual who can be identified from the data and includes any expression of opinion about the individual.
A list of instructions for all participants that is the same for all people
Age, gender and ethnicity of interviewer and style of interviewing can affect the answer of the individual.
How someone\'s judgement is shaped by particular feelings, beliefs and desires.
All sources of bias are minimised and subjectivity is eliminated.
- Unstructured interviews gather qualitative data because issues can be explored, gives in depth and detailed - More valid than questionnaires
- Interviewer bias- Subjectivity when analysing data- Social desirability as interviewees may respond in a socially acceptable way

cards.term: 2 examples of interview studies in clinical psychology
cards.definition: 1. Vallentine et al (2010)2. Goldstein (1988)
To study the usefulness of psych-education within group work for offender patients in high-security forensic hospital setting

cards.term: What type of interview did Vallentine use?
cards.definition: Semi-structured

cards.term: What was the aim of the interviews in Vallentine\'s study?
cards.definition: To understand the experiences of the patient group as part of a psycho-educational group treatment programme and how the group could be improved in the future

cards.term: How many participants were in Vallentine\'s study?
cards.definition: 42 males

cards.term: Which hospital were the participants in Vallentine\'s study from?
cards.definition: Broadmoor high-security hospital, most received a diagnosis of schizophrenia or a similar disorder

cards.term: What was the programme in Vallentine\'s study for?
cards.definition: To help them understand and cope with their illness and to assess the impact of this on their symptoms

cards.term: How did Vallentine et al analyse the interview data?
cards.definition: Content analysis was carried out in the data to see what key themes could be found in their responses.

cards.term: What 4 core themes were identified in Vallentine\'s study?
cards.definition: 1. What the participants valued and why2. What was helpful about the group3. Clinical implications4. What was difficult/ unhelpful

cards.term: Example of \'What the participants valued and why\' in Vallentine\'s study
cards.definition: Knowing the basic stuff gives you piece of mind that you can get out, it gives you hope

cards.term: Example of \'What was helpful about the group\' in Vallentine\'s study
cards.definition: It helped me understand the symptoms I\'ve got and how different treatments help

cards.term: Example of \'Clinical implications\' in Vallentine\'s study
cards.definition: It gives you piece of mind

cards.term: Example of \'What was difficult/ unhelpful\' in Vallentine\'s study
cards.definition: It made me feel guilty about my past

cards.term: What did the results show in Vallentine\'s study?
cards.definition: Patients valued knowing and understanding their illness, and the group sessions allowed them to understand their own symptoms, but how other people\'s experiences were similar. Many reported increased confidence in dealing with their illness, made them positive about the future.

cards.term: What did Vallentine et al conclude?
cards.definition: Results showed positive and negative changes in the various measures taken after the psycho-education group took place.

- Interviews allow patients to fully explain their own point of view- Semi-structured allows more detail - Interviews were recorded, so interviews could be played back to check for accuracy, reliability checks by having another researcher code the data
- Lack of reliability due to the way data is gathered, questions are not standardised, difficult to repeat
To compare the course of schizophrenia in men and women for the first ten years of the condition, in particular hospitalisation.

cards.term: What were the interviews in Goldstein\'s study used to gather?
cards.definition: Data about symptoms of the patient

cards.term: What were the questionnaires in Goldstein\'s study used to gather?
cards.definition: Information about their premorbid functioning (functioning before the onset of illness) e.g. dealing with isolation, peer relationships and interests form ages of 6-13 and 14-20
90 patients, 32 women and 58 men. Mean age 24. Majority were white and middle class

cards.term: Hospital conditions of the participants in Goldstein\'s study
cards.definition: Most were receiving treatment at a private psychiatric hospital in New York.

cards.term: What diagnosis did the participants in Goldstein\'s study have?
cards.definition: All were hospitalised with a diagnosis of schizophrenia for the first or second time at the start of the study. Diagnosis confirmed by two independent psychiatrists.

cards.term: In Goldstein\'s study, the course of schizophrenia was measured by...
cards.definition: Number of hospitalisations and length of hospitalisations over a ten year period
There were significant differences between men and women. Differences were sharper in the first five years of the disorder.

cards.term: What association was found in Goldstein\'s study?
cards.definition: Strong association between level of functioning in childhood and adolescence and the course of the condition.

cards.term: Differences between number of hospitalisations of men and women in Goldstein\'s study
cards.definition: Men were hospitalised an average of 2.24 times over ten years. Women: 1.12 times.

cards.term: Differences between length of hospitalisations of men and women in Goldstein\'s study
cards.definition: Mean number of days spent in hospital was 417.83 for men and 206.81 for women.
- Men and women were well matched in terms of marital status, age and socio-economic background- Data is objective and unbiased in terms of number of hospital stays and length of the stay

- Although they were matched, women mostly had clerical or sales jobs or were housewives whilst men had more blue collar jobs. More unemployed men than women- Age limit was 45 years. 9% of schizophrenic women had their first schizophrenic episode after 45, very few men do, so biased sample
Information the researcher gathers themselves directly from a group of participants
Researcher can be certain it is reliable and valid as the research was carried out themselves, conclusions are certain
More time-consuming because they have to collect it themselves and researchers may face many ethical considerations in working directly with patient groups.
Relies on evidence that has been gathered by other researchers by accessing other peer-reviewed articles of public access statistics
Saves time having to carry out the research
Takes place over a long period of time, often involves comparing a single sample group with their own performance over time.

cards.term: Advantages of longitudinal research when studying mental health
cards.definition: Patients often have different symptoms and experiences when suffering the same illness. It is the only way to measure the effect of time on the behaviour, so is important when considering treatments.

- Research has to go on for a long period of time. Many issues - patients drop out, die or not be able to be contacted. This reduces sample size and makes the final outcome less valid.- By the time meaningful data can be used to draw a conclusion in the study, the data may be irrelevant. Could be outdated.
Use a large group of people in the sample to get a good \'cross-section\' of the whole target population, and then draw conclusions from the data gathered. Same time.

- Data is drawn together more quickly, conclusions drawn can be used and acted on more rapidly- Results more valid as they will be reported at the time when they have most application rather than several years later.
Comparisons made will be between different groups of people, so individual differences are likely to have a significant effect on conclusions.
Results of the research could be attributed to the effects of being raised in a particular time and place.
Researchers look at a particular behaviour or pattern of thinking between different cultures. Same procedure but in different cultural groups, to compare similarities and differences between them.
It is found in all cultures, suggesting it is in our nature and comes from biology

- Researchers gain an understanding of how culture plays a role in validity and reliability of diagnoses in clinical psychology.- Identify elements of abnormal behaviour that can be attributed to purely biological factors- Can reduce ehtnocentrism and improve generalisability- Clinicians\' understanding of cultural factors improves when diagnosing and treating patients of different cultural groups

Likely to be conflict between cultural values of some or all participants. Conclusions drawn may lack validity if interpretation of behaviour does not take into account their own cultural backgrounds.

Looking at secondary data from multiple studies conducted by other researchers and drawing findings together to make overall conclusions. Seek out studies from a variety of places, cultures and times, all tested the same area with the aim of bringing findings together.

- Conclusions can be drawn from a vast array of different areas and a huge overall sample, very quickly and at much less cost - Easily consider a large amount of information gathered from a huge overall sample size rather than having to gather primary data

- Do not have involvement in gathering of data directly, so may have issues of reliability and validity in methods of data gathering- Publication bias could impact validity. Research producing null effects may not be published and would be ignored by meta-analytic research. Often biased against research where no effect has been found.
Look at one individual or a small group in depth to gather detailed data, usually from a number of sources
Focusing in detail on a topic and on individuals

cards.term: What are case studies used for?
cards.definition: Finding out detail about something rather than for building cause and effect understanding.
Taking data from different sources and checking whether the data agree. If same data are gathered, data are reliable and likely to be valid. Adds credibility to results.

- Triangulation (test for reliability, validity and credibility)- Find out detail and depth about an individual or small group, rich data to draw conclusions from. - Look at rare situations and individuals where samples are difficult to find.

cards.term: Example of a case study in clinical psychology
cards.definition: Lavarenne et al (2013)

cards.term: What was Lavarenne et al\'s study about?
cards.definition: Containing psychotic patients with fragile ego boundaries

cards.term: Background information in Lavarenne et al\'s study
cards.definition: Group was for out-patients suffering varying types of schizophrenia.

cards.term: How many patients were in Lavarenne et al\'s study?
cards.definition: The session usually had 10 members, but only 6 attended the 45 minute session. \'Thursday group\' running since 1985, made up of members who had been attending for between 3 weeks and 22 years.

cards.term: How many researchers were in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: 3 researchers led and coded immediately after the session as the sessions were not recorded or video-taped.

cards.term: What did the researchers record after every session?
cards.definition: - Whether members express psychotic, manic or depressed thoughts and behaviours.- Emotions observed- Verbal expression of loneliness, loss, dreams, current or past relationships, humour, etc. - If members make supporting or insightful comments- If members engaged or participated in the group
Someone does not have a clear sense of \'I\' inside themselves and they find it hard to separate themselves from the outside world.

cards.term: What is the purpose of the group in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: To support the patients by giving them some structure to help them cope with their illness, and encourage a sense of connection with others.

cards.term: What is the context behind the session in Lavarenne\'s case study?
cards.definition: A specific session just before Christmas, where he group members were facing a break of more than seven days before their next meeting. Suggested the group may be reacting to the potential change in routine.

cards.term: Who were the group members in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: Brett, Earl, Deena, Dan, Dillon and Andy

cards.term: What behaviour did Brett carry out in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: Gave out a Christmas card and calendar. Also gave tapes (with recordings on them) so that members passed them around between them.

cards.term: What was Brett\'s behaviour interpreted as?
cards.definition: Wants the group to be linked together and connected to reinforce the group boundary, to help solidify his ego boundary.

cards.term: What behaviour did Earl carry out in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: 1. Reject gifts from Brett. 2. Earl had grandiose, delusional ideas that he was working on running an oil pipeline around the world. 3. Claimed to be \'Falasha\' (Ethiopian Jew) after being treated in a Jewish hospital

cards.term: What was Earl\'s behaviour interpreted as?
cards.definition: 1. Has an underlying fear or being defeated and accepting the gift may have triggered fragmentation fears. 2. Delusion related to his identity merging with his father\'s (he was an engineer and had been employed in the oil industry)3. Had a fragile ego boundary as he absorbed a false identity

cards.term: What behaviour did Deena carry out in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: Reported having nightmares, her psychiatrist suggested to be treated for sleep apnoea. Refused and said she preferred her sleep issues treated psychologically (thinking good thoughts before bedtime)

cards.term: What was Deena\'s behaviour interpreted as?
cards.definition: Her focus between awake and asleep is blurred so has a fragile ego boundary

cards.term: What behaviour did Dan carry out in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: Talked about having an out-of-body experience when he could not get his spirit back into his body

cards.term: What was Dan\'s behaviour interpreted as?
cards.definition: He felt his ego boundary to be fragile during this frightening experience

cards.term: What behaviour did Dillon carry out in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: Talked about having a lot of people in the house over Christmas and how he would not like it, He suggested he would cope by going for a walk or shovelling snow.

cards.term: What was Dillon\'s behaviour interpreted as?
cards.definition: The ability to be aware of how much closeness he could tolerate shows insight. Limited tolerance to personal space and closeness indicates fragile ego boundary.

cards.term: What behaviour did Andy carry out in Lavarenne\'s study?
cards.definition: Talked about limiting her food intake, mothering her daughter, swimming rigorously each day and helping young relatives with homework each day after school
Cells with a membrane-bound nucleus and organelles; found in plants and animals.
Cells lacking a membrane-bound nucleus and organelles; found in bacteria.

cards.term: Differences between eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells
cards.definition: Prokaryotic cells are smaller; eukaryotic cells have membrane-bound organelles and a nucleus containing genetic material.

cards.term: Difference in magnitude between human hair (100 um) and HIV virus (100 nm)
cards.definition: Human hair: 100 um = 10^-4 m; HIV virus: 100 nm = 10^-7 m; Difference = 10^(-4 - (-7)) = 10^3 = 1000.

cards.term: Components of both plant and animal cells
cards.definition: Nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria, ribosomes.

cards.term: Additional cell components found in plant cells
cards.definition: Chloroplasts, permanent vacuole, cell wall.
Aside from storing genetic information, it controls cellular activities.
Fluid component of the cell containing organelles, enzymes, and dissolved ions and nutrients.
It serves as the site of cellular reactions (e.g., first stage of respiration) and as a transport medium.
Controls the entry and exit of materials into and out of the cell.
Site of later stages of aerobic respiration, producing ATP.
Joins amino acids in a specific order during translation for protein synthesis.
Made of cellulose.

cards.term: Function of the plant cell wall
cards.definition: Provides strength and prevents the cell from bursting when water enters by osmosis.
Contains cell sap (a solution of salts, sugars, and organic acids).
Supports the cell, maintaining its turgidity.
Site of photosynthesis.

cards.term: Adaptations of sperm cells in animals
cards.definition: Haploid nucleus, tail for movement, mitochondria for energy, acrosome containing enzymes to digest egg cell membrane.

cards.term: Adaptations of nerve cells in animals
cards.definition: Long axon for transmission, dendrites for receiving impulses, myelin sheath for insulation and faster transmission.
Protein filament arrangement for contraction, mitochondria for energy, merged cells for synchronous contraction.

cards.term: Adaptations of root hair cells in plants
cards.definition: Large surface area, thin walls.

cards.term: Adaptations of xylem cells in plants
cards.definition: No upper or lower margins, thick woody side walls.

cards.term: Adaptations of phloem cells in plants
cards.definition: Sieve plates for transport, companion cells for energy provision.

cards.term: Storage of genetic information in prokaryotic cells
cards.definition: Chromosomal DNA and plasmid DNA found free within the cytoplasm.
The process by which cells become specialized.
Allows for the production of different tissues and organs, performing various vital functions in the body.

cards.term: Stage in life cycle when most animal cells differentiate
cards.definition: Early in their life cycle.

cards.term: Duration of ability to differentiate in plant cells
cards.definition: Throughout their entire life cycle.

cards.term: Purpose of cell division in mature animals
cards.definition: Repair and replacement of cells.
Cells acquire different sub-cellular structures to enable specific functions.
The number of times an image appears larger than the real object.
The smallest distance between two distinguishable objects.
Passes light through a specimen, allowing observation.
Inexpensive, easy to use, portable, can observe both dead and living specimens.
Limited resolution.
Uses a beam of electrons focused by magnets to produce an image.
Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM).
Greater magnification and resolution.

cards.term: Reason electron microscopes have greater magnification and resolution
cards.definition: They use electrons with shorter wavelengths than light.

cards.term: Impact of electron microscopes on understanding cells
cards.definition: Allows observation of sub-cellular structures and enhances understanding of structure-function relationships.
Expensive, less portable, require training, observe only dead specimens.
Magnification = size of image / size of real object.
A way of expressing numbers as a figure between 1 and 10 multiplied by a power of 10.
A power of 10 used to quantify and compare size.
Binary fission (simple cell division).
Once every 20 minutes if enough nutrients and suitable temperature are available.
Nutrient broth solution and colonies on an agar gel plate.

cards.term: Nutrients in a nutrient broth solution
cards.definition: Includes nitrogen for protein synthesis, carbohydrates for energy, and other minerals.

cards.term: Purpose of uncontaminated cultures of microorganisms
cards.definition: For investigating disinfectant and antibiotic action.

cards.term: Preparation of uncontaminated culture using aseptic technique
cards.definition: Includes using sterilized Petri dishes, sterilizing inoculating loops, and storing cultures upside down to prevent contamination.

cards.term: Reason for sterilizing Petri dishes and culture media
cards.definition: To kill any bacteria already present.
To kill any bacteria present on the loop.

cards.term: Reason for securing Petri dish lids with adhesive tape and storing them upside down
cards.definition: To prevent airborne bacteria contamination and to prevent condensation from dripping onto colonies.
1 x 10^-2 meters.

cards.term: Reason for incubating cultures at 25C in school laboratories
cards.definition: To inhibit the growth of harmful pathogens.

cards.term: Formula for calculating cross-sectional area of a bacterial colony
cards.definition: Area = r^2.

cards.term: Calculation of number of bacteria after a certain time period
cards.definition: Number of bacteria = Initial bacteria count x 2^(time period/mean division time).

cards.term: Number of bacteria after 3 hours for a population dividing every 15 minutes and starting with 5 bacteria

cards.definition: 1 x 10^-3 meters.
1 x 10^-6 meters.
1 x 10^-9 meters.
Consist of DNA molecules combined with proteins, containing genes for protein synthesis.
A section of DNA that codes for a protein.
An unspecialized cell capable of differentiating into other cell types and self-renewal.

cards.term: Function of stem cells in embryos
cards.definition: Embryonic stem cells can differentiate into various cell types, potentially treating conditions like paralysis and diabetes.

cards.term: Function of stem cells in adult bone marrow
cards.definition: Adult stem cells can differentiate into different cell types, replenishing dead or damaged tissues.

cards.term: Function of stem cells in plant meristems
cards.definition: Meristem stem cells can differentiate into any plant cell type, ensuring continuous growth and repair.
Producing an embryo with the same genetic makeup as the patient for potential treatment using stem cells.

cards.term: Advantages of cloning plants using meristem stem cells
cards.definition: Prevents extinction of rare plants, produces large numbers of desirable plants, and creates identical plants for research.

cards.term: Issues associated with the use of stem cells
cards.definition: Ethical concerns, slow and costly therapy development, risk of viral infections, and potential immune rejection.

cards.term: Number of chromosomes in human body cells
cards.definition: 46 chromosomes.
23 chromosomes.

cards.term: Arrangement of chromosomes in the nucleus of a body cell
cards.definition: Arranged in pairs, forming 23 pairs.

cards.term: Main stages of the cell cycle
cards.definition: Replication of DNA and organelle synthesis, mitosis, and cell division.
Produces genetically identical cells for growth and repair.

cards.term: Description of the first stage of the cell cycle
cards.definition: Cells grow, replicate DNA, and synthesize organelles.

cards.term: Description of the second stage of the cell cycle
cards.definition: Chromosomes separate, and the nucleus divides.

cards.term: Description of the third stage of the cell cycle
cards.definition: Cytoplasm and cell membrane divide, producing two identical daughter cells.
Net movement of particles from higher to lower concentration.

cards.term: Factors affecting the rate of diffusion
cards.definition: Concentration gradient, temperature, and surface area.

cards.term: Possible outcome when an animal cell is placed in a hypotonic solution
cards.definition: Cell may burst due to water intake.

cards.term: Possible outcome when an animal cell is placed in a hypertonic solution
cards.definition: Cell may shrivel up due to water loss.

cards.term: Mechanism of maintaining rigidity in plant leaves and stems
cards.definition: Turgor pressure from water intake, pressing cytoplasm against cell wall.

cards.term: Possible outcome when a plant cell is placed in a hypertonic solution
cards.definition: Water moves out, causing cell to shrink and membrane to detach from cell wall.
Movement of molecules against concentration gradient, requiring energy.

cards.term: Use of active transport in plant root hair cells
cards.definition: Absorbing mineral ions from dilute soil solutions.

cards.term: Use of active transport in absorbing digestion products
cards.definition: Moving glucose from gut to blood, aiding its transport to tissues for energy.

cards.term: Examples of substances transported by diffusion in lungs and kidneys
cards.definition: Oxygen and carbon dioxide in lungs, urea in kidneys.

cards.term: Adaptations of single-celled organisms for diffusion
cards.definition: Large surface area to volume ratio.

cards.term: Calculation of surface area to volume ratio
cards.definition: Surface Area: Volume = Number of Sides x (Side Length x Side Width) / (Length x Width x Depth).

cards.term: Factors increasing the effectiveness of gas exchange surfaces
cards.definition: Large surface area, thin membrane, efficient blood supply, and ventilation.
Movement of water from dilute to concentrated solution through a semi-permeable membrane.

cards.term: Meaning of a solution being isotonic to a cell
cards.definition: Concentration of external solution equals that of internal solution.

cards.term: Meaning of a solution being hypertonic to a cell
cards.definition: Concentration of external solution is higher than internal solution.

cards.term: Meaning of a solution being hypotonic to a cell
cards.definition: Concentration of external solution is lower than internal solution.
The basic building block of a living organism.
A group of cells with a similar structure and function working together. For example, muscular tissue contracts to bring about movement.
A collection of tissues working together to perform a specific function. For example, the stomach contains glandular, muscular, and epithelial tissues.
A group of organs working together to perform specific functions. For example, the digestive system contains organs such as the stomach, the small intestine, and the large intestine.

cards.term: Main Function of the Digestive System
cards.definition: To digest food and absorb the nutrients obtained from digestion.

cards.term: Role of the Pancreas and the Salivary Gland in the Digestive System
cards.definition: The pancreas and the salivary gland are glands which produce digestive juices containing enzymes.

cards.term: Lock and Key Hypothesis of Enzyme Function
cards.definition: The shape of the enzyme active site and the substrate are complementary, so they can bind together to form an enzyme-substrate complex.

cards.term: Effect of Temperature on Enzyme Action
cards.definition: Up to a certain point, increasing temperature increases enzyme action, as molecules have a higher kinetic energy. Above a certain temperature, the shape of the active site is altered, and the enzyme becomes denatured, so it can no longer catalyze the reaction. The optimum temperature is around 37C.

cards.term: Effect of pH on Enzyme Function
cards.definition: The optimum pH for most enzymes is 7 (apart from proteases in the stomach). If the pH is too extreme, the shape of the active site may be altered, and the enzyme may no longer work.

cards.term: Locations of Carbohydrases, Proteases, and Lipases Production in the Body
cards.definition: Carbohydrases: amylase - salivary gland and pancreas; maltase - small intestine. Proteases: pepsin - stomach; others - pancreas and small intestine. Lipases: pancreas and small intestine.

cards.term: Role of Carbohydrases in the Digestive System
cards.definition: Carbohydrases break down carbohydrates into monosaccharides and disaccharides. Amylase breaks down starch into maltose, and maltase breaks down maltose into glucose.

cards.term: Role of Proteases in the Digestive System
cards.definition: Proteases break down proteins into amino acids.

cards.term: Role of Lipases in the Digestive System
cards.definition: Lipases break down lipids into fatty acids and glycerol.
They are used to build bigger molecules such as carbohydrates and proteins. Glucose is used as a substrate in respiration.

cards.term: Location of Bile Production and Storage in the Body
cards.definition: Bile is made by the liver and stored in the gallbladder.

cards.term: Role of Bile in the Digestive System
cards.definition: Bile is an alkaline substance which neutralizes the hydrochloric acid secreted by the stomach. Bile emulsifies lipids to form droplets, increasing the surface area for the lipase enzyme to work on.

cards.term: Role of the Stomach in the Digestive System
cards.definition: The stomach produces hydrochloric acid, which kills any bacteria present and provides the optimum acidic pH for the protease enzyme to function.
An organ that pumps blood around the body.
Carries oxygen and other useful substances to bodily tissues, and removes waste substances.

cards.term: Function of the Double Circulatory System
cards.definition: One pathway carries blood from the heart to the lungs - where the gaseous exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide takes place. Another pathway carries blood from the heart to the tissues.

cards.term: Destination of Blood Pumped by the Right Ventricle
cards.definition: The lungs.

cards.term: Destination of Blood Pumped by the Left Ventricle
cards.definition: Body tissues.

cards.term: Importance of the Double Circulatory System
cards.definition: It makes the circulatory system more efficient - for example, oxygenated blood can be pumped around the body at a higher pressure by the left ventricle.

cards.term: Number of Chambers in the Heart and Their Names
cards.definition: 4 - right atrium, right ventricle, left atrium, left ventricle.

cards.term: Reason for the Thicker Wall of the Left Ventricle
cards.definition: The left ventricle has to pump blood at a higher pressure around the whole body.

cards.term: Four Main Blood Vessels Associated with the Heart
cards.definition: Aorta (left) - carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the body. Pulmonary vein (left) - carries oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart. Vena cava (right) - carries deoxygenated blood from the body to the heart. Pulmonary artery (right) - carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.

cards.term: Purpose of Valves in the Heart
cards.definition: Prevent the backflow of blood.

cards.term: Role of the Small Intestine in the Digestive System
cards.definition: The small intestine is the site where soluble food molecules are absorbed into the bloodstream.
Coronary arteries supply the heart muscle with oxygenated blood.

cards.term: Process of Blood Flow Through the Heart
cards.definition: Blood enters the right atrium via the vena cava, and the left atrium via the pulmonary vein. The atria contract, forcing blood into the ventricles and causing valves to shut. After the ventricles contract, blood in the right ventricle enters the pulmonary artery (to the lungs) and blood in the left ventricle enters the aorta (to the body).

cards.term: Approximate Value of the Natural Resting Heart Rate
cards.definition: 70 beats per minute.
Heart rate is controlled by a group of cells in the right atrium which act as a pacemaker. They release waves of electrical activity which cause the heart muscle to contract.
Irregular heart rhythms can be treated using an artificial pacemaker, which sends out electrical signals to correct the heart's rhythm.

cards.term: Three Types of Blood Vessel in the Body
cards.definition: Arteries, Veins, Capillaries.
Thick muscle layer adds strength to resist high pressure. Thick elastic layer allows arteries to stretch and recoil - to withstand high pressure.
Wide lumen enables low pressure. Valves prevent backflow of blood.
Walls are one cell thick - short diffusion path. Permeable walls - substances can diffuse across. Narrow lumen - blood moves slowly - more time for diffusion.
Volume of blood / number of minutes.

cards.term: Role of the Liver in the Digestive System
cards.definition: Produces bile (stored in the gallbladder) which emulsifies lipids and allows the lipase enzyme to work more efficiently.

cards.term: Location of the Lungs in the Body
cards.definition: The lungs are located in the thorax (within the chest). They are protected by the ribcage and separated from the rest of the abdomen by the diaphragm.

cards.term: Tissues Making up the Gas Exchange System
cards.definition: Trachea, Intercostal muscles, Bronchi, Bronchioles, Alveoli, Diaphragm.

cards.term: Ventilation of Lungs by Intercostal Muscles
cards.definition: Intercostal muscles contract, ribcage moves upwards and outwards, diaphragm flattens and volume of the chest increases, increased volume results in decreased pressure, air is drawn into lungs down pressure gradient. The inverse occurs when air moves out of the lungs.
Oxygen diffuses from the alveoli into the capillary bloodstream down its concentration gradient. Carbon dioxide diffuses from the capillary into the alveoli down its concentration gradient.

cards.term: Adaptations of Alveoli for Gas Exchange
cards.definition: Small and arranged in clusters - larger surface area. Rich blood supply - maintains concentration gradient. Thin alveolar wall - short diffusion pathway.
Number of breaths / number of minutes.
Plasma.
Red blood cells, White blood cells, Platelets, Carbon dioxide, Urea, Products of digestion.
A yellow liquid within blood that transports substances around the body.

cards.term: Purpose of Red Blood Cells in Blood
cards.definition: Transport of oxygen around the body.

cards.term: Role of the Large Intestine in the Digestive System
cards.definition: Absorbs water from undigested food, producing faeces.

cards.term: Adaptations of Red Blood Cells for Their Function
cards.definition: Biconcave shape - increased surface area to volume ratio. No nucleus - more room for haemoglobin to bind to oxygen. Contain haemoglobin - binds to oxygen.

cards.term: Purpose of White Blood Cells in Blood
cards.definition: They form part of the immune system, which protects the body from invading pathogens.

cards.term: Adaptations of White Blood Cells for Their Function
cards.definition: Have a nucleus - contains DNA which codes for proteins. Can produce antibodies. Can produce antitoxins. Can engulf and digest pathogens (phagocytosis).
Platelets are small cell fragments which aid the clotting of blood at the site of a wound.

Platelets aid in the process of blood clotting (conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin). As a result, red blood cells are trapped in the fibrin network, forming a clot which prevents excessive bleeding. Scab formation (after the clot has dried) prevents bacteria from entering the wound.

Coronary heart disease occurs when the coronary arteries that supply the heart muscle become blocked with a buildup of fatty material. This restricts the supply of oxygen to the heart, possibly leading to a heart attack or death.
A metal mesh tube inserted into a blocked artery to keep it open, typically inflated using a balloon and later removed to allow blood flow.
Insertion can be carried out without general anesthesia, quick recovery time, lower risk of a heart attack.
Risk of postoperative infection, risk of blood clots at the site of the stent.
Drugs that reduce LDL (bad) cholesterol levels, thus lowering the risk of coronary heart disease.
Reduce risk of strokes, coronary heart disease, and heart attacks, increase level of HDL (good) cholesterol.
Need to be taken continuously, may have side effects, effect may not be immediate.
Biological catalysts that speed up the breakdown of food without being used up.
Surgery where blocked coronary arteries are replaced with sections of veins taken from other parts of the body.
Blood flows in the wrong direction, causing the heart to become less efficient, leading to breathlessness and potential fatality.

cards.term: Types of Valves to Replace Leaky Valves
cards.definition: Mechanical valves (made of metal or polymers) and biological valves (taken from animals or humans).
Last for a very long time.
Need to take medication to prevent blood clotting around the valve.
Work very well without the need for medication.
Only last 12-15 years.
To support a patient's heart while they await a suitable donor heart.
Less likely to be rejected by the immune system, allows damaged heart to rest and recover.
Risk of infection due to surgery, risk of blood clots, need to take blood-thinning drugs.
The state of physical and mental wellbeing.
A disease caused by a pathogen that can be transmitted from one person to another, e.g., the flu.
A disease that cannot be transmitted from person to person, e.g., cancer.
Enzymes catalyze metabolic reactions such as building larger molecules, changing one molecule to another, and breaking down larger molecules into smaller ones.
Epidermal tissue covers the plant with a waxy cuticle to reduce water loss from the leaf surface.
Contains many chloroplasts to facilitate rapid photosynthesis.
The movement of dissolved sugars from the leaves to other parts of the plant.
The evaporation of water vapor from the surface of a plant.
Water evaporates from the leaf surface via stomata, then cohesion and tension pull water up the xylem, creating a continuous transpiration stream.
Increasing temperature increases the rate of transpiration due to higher evaporation and diffusion of water.
Increasing humidity decreases the rate of transpiration due to reduced water vapor concentration gradient.

cards.term: Effect of Wind Speed on Transpiration
cards.definition: Increasing wind speed increases the rate of transpiration by lowering the water vapor concentration outside the leaf.

cards.term: Effect of Light Intensity on Transpiration
cards.definition: Increasing light intensity increases the rate of transpiration by opening more stomata, allowing for increased evaporation.
Contains many air spaces for gas exchange.
Made of dead cells forming a hollow tube, strengthened by lignin, with bordered pits for specific mineral transport.
