cards.definition: The empirical formula is the smallest whole number ratio of the atoms of each element in a compound. Reacting masses or percentage composition can be used to calculate the empirical formula.
Fe2O3
Actual number of atoms of each element in a compound.

cards.term: Experiment to work out the empirical formula of magnesium oxide
cards.definition: Weigh a sample of magnesium. Heat the sample in a crucible. Weigh the mass of magnesium oxide at the end. Calculate the mass of oxygen (this is the increase of mass). Calculate the moles of magnesium and oxygen using the experimental mass and relative atomic mass. Work out the whole number ratio of the number of moles of magnesium to oxygen.
No matter is lost or gained during a chemical reaction.

cards.term: Total mass of a reaction in a closed system throughout the experiment
cards.definition: Mass stays constant.

cards.term: Total mass of a reaction in an open flask throughout the experiment
cards.definition: Mass decreases as the gas escapes.

cards.term: Mass of oxygen needed in the reaction: Ca + O2 -> CaO, if 52g of calcium reacts with oxygen to form 79g of calcium oxide
cards.definition: Mass of oxygen = 79 - 52 = 27g.

cards.term: Equation linking mass, moles, and relative atomic mass
cards.definition: Mass (g) = Moles x Relative atomic mass (Mr)
Concentration(g/dm^3) = Mass(g)/Volume(dm^3)
The number of atoms, molecules, or ions in one mole of a given substance. The value of the constant is 6.02 x 10^23.

cards.term: Mass of 20 moles of calcium carbonate, CaCO3
cards.definition: Mass (g) = Moles x Relative atomic mass (Mr). Mr = 100. 20 x 100 = 2000 g.

cards.term: Formula linking the Avogadro constant, moles, and number of particles
cards.definition: Number of particles = Avogadro constant x Moles

cards.term: Number of atoms in 3 moles of copper
cards.definition: Number of atoms = Avogadro's constant x Moles = 6.02 x 10^23 x 3 = 1.81 x 10^24

cards.term: Limiting reagent in a chemical reaction
cards.definition: The chemical that is used up first in a reaction, preventing the formation of more product. Typically, an excess of one of the reactants is used to ensure that the other reactant is completely used up.

cards.term: Arrangement and movement of particles in solids
cards.definition: Tightly packed together in a regular arrangement. Vibrate in fixed positions.

cards.term: Arrangement and movement of particles in liquids
cards.definition: Close together but able to move past each other. Vibrate and move around each other.

cards.term: Arrangement and movement of particles in gases
cards.definition: Well separated with no regular arrangement. Vibrate and move freely at high speeds.

cards.term: Relative energies of particles in solids, liquids, and gases
cards.definition: Particles in a solid have the least amount of energy, and particles in a gas have the most energy.
When matter changes from one state to another due to changes in temperature or pressure.

cards.term: State changes from solid to liquid and vice versa
cards.definition: Solid to liquid: Melting; Liquid to solid: Freezing

cards.term: State changes from liquid to gas and vice versa
cards.definition: Liquid to gas: Evaporation; Gas to liquid: Condensation

cards.term: Forces between particles in solids, liquids, and gases
cards.definition: Solids - Strong forces of attraction between particles which keeps them in their fixed positions. Liquids - Weaker attractive forces than in solids. Gases - Weakest intermolecular forces so particles are in random movement.

A physical change involves changes in the forces between particles. The particles themselves remain the same and the chemical properties remain the same. A chemical change affects the chemical properties of the substance.

cards.term: Physical changes are relatively easy to reverse
cards.definition: TRUE. Relatively easy to reverse since no new product is formed during the changes of state.
The term describing when a solid changes straight into a gas.

cards.term: Particles when a solid melts into a liquid
cards.definition: When heated, the particles absorb thermal energy which is converted into kinetic energy. The particles in the solid vibrate more, causing the solid to expand until the structure breaks and becomes a liquid.

cards.term: Particles when a liquid evaporates into a gas
cards.definition: When heated, the particles in a liquid expand, and some particles on the surface gain sufficient energy to overcome the intermolecular forces and evaporate. At the boiling point, all of the liquid particles gain enough energy to evaporate.
Liquid
Contains 2 or more elements or compounds that are not chemically combined together. The chemical properties of each substance in the mixture are unchanged.
A single element or compound, not mixed with any other substance.

cards.term: Using melting point data to distinguish between pure substances and mixtures
cards.definition: Pure substances have a sharp exact melting point whereas mixtures melt over a range of temperatures since they consist of several elements / compounds.
Used to separate a solvent from a solution. It is useful for producing water from salt solution.

cards.term: When is fractional distillation used to separate mixtures?
cards.definition: Fractional distillation is used to separate a pure liquid from a mixture of liquids. These liquids must have different boiling points to be separated.

cards.term: Difference between fractional and simple distillation
cards.definition: Simple distillation is used to separate a solvent from a solution. Fractional distillation is used to separate different liquids from a mixture of liquids, using their different boiling points.

- Oil is heated until it evaporates into the fractionating column. Vapours rise up the fractionating column and condense at the different fractions, depending on the relative boiling point of each substance.

cards.term: Mixtures that can be separated using filtration
cards.definition: Filtration is used to separate an insoluble substance from a solution.

cards.term: How to separate an insoluble substance from a solution using filtration
cards.definition: Place filter paper in a funnel. Pour the solution containing an insoluble substance through the funnel into a conical flask. The insoluble substance will collect on the filter paper and the solution will collect in the conical flask.

cards.term: When is crystallisation used to separate a mixture?
cards.definition: To separate a soluble solid from a solution if the solid decomposes when heated.

cards.term: How to separate a soluble solid from a solution using crystallisation
cards.definition: Pour the solution into an evaporating dish and heat gently. When the crystals start to form, remove the dish from the heat and leave to cool. Once cold, filter the crystals out of the solution and leave them in a warm place to dry.

cards.term: Process used to identify soluble substances in a mixture
cards.definition: Chromatography

cards.term: How does paper chromatography work to separate a mixture?
cards.definition: The mobile phase (solvent) moves through the stationary phase (paper) so anything dissolved in the mobile phase will move with up the paper. Compounds interact differently with each phase so will move different distances through the stationary phase meaning they will be separated.

cards.term: How chromatography shows the composition of a mixture
cards.definition: Different colored substances in the mixture will separate as they have different solubilities in the solvent and will travel at different rates.

cards.term: Why pencil should be used to draw the line along the bottom of the chromatography paper
cards.definition: It will not affect the experiment as it is insoluble in the solvent.

cards.term: Reason for keeping the water (solvent) in the beaker for paper chromatography no deeper than 1 cm
cards.definition: If it is deeper it will wash away the substances placed on the line on the chromatography paper.

cards.term: Reason for using a lid when carrying out paper chromatography
cards.definition: To prevent the solvent from evaporating.

cards.term: Number of spots produced by a pure substance on a chromatogram and difference for an impure substance
cards.definition: Pure substances produce one spot. An impure substance contains more than one compound so will produce more spots (one spot for each chemical).
The Rf value is the ratio between the distance traveled by the dissolved substance (the solute) and the distance traveled by the solvent.
Rf = Distance traveled by substance / Distance traveled by solvent

cards.term: Where to measure the distance moved by a substance on the chromatography paper
cards.definition: Measure from the pencil baseline to the middle of the spot of the substance.

cards.term: How to use chromatography to see if a certain substance is present in a mixture
cards.definition: Run a pure sample of this substance alongside the unknown mixture. If the Rf value of the pure substance matches the value of one of the spots from the mixture, it is likely to be present.

cards.term: Substances with a higher solubility in the solvent will travel further up the chromatography paper
cards.definition: TRUE. They will stay dissolved in the solvent (mobile phase) for longer.

cards.term: Process to separate salt from a mixture of salt and sand
cards.definition: Salt is soluble in water, sand isn't. Add water to the mixture. Filter the solution to remove the insoluble sand. Evaporate the water to collect the salt crystals.

cards.term: How liquids can be separated if they have different densities
cards.definition: If liquids have different densities they will naturally separate into two layers. To separate these layers, use a flask with a tap on the bottom. Open the tap to collect the bottom liquid (has the highest density).
Safe to drink.

cards.term: Process to make waste and groundwater potable
cards.definition: 1. Sedimentation: Large insoluble particles sink to the bottom after the water is left still for a while. 2. Filtration: Removes small insoluble particles by passing the water through layers of sand and filters. 3. Chlorination: Kills bacteria and microorganisms which are too small to be removed by filtration.
Distillation: 1. Filter to remove insoluble particles. 2. Boil. 3. Cool and condense the water vapor.
Extremely expensive as it requires a lot of energy to boil large volumes of water. Wastewater is toxic due to the high concentration of salt so must be disposed of carefully.
Water that has had metallic ions (such as copper or calcium ions) removed.

cards.term: Use of deionised water in experimental analysis
cards.definition: Deionised water is used to prevent ions in the water interacting with the substances under analysis. If water wasn't deionised, false positive results may be produced.

cards.term: Which ions make aqueous solutions acidic?
cards.definition: Hydrogen ions (H+)

cards.term: Which ions make aqueous solutions alkaline?
cards.definition: Hydroxide ions (OH-)
The pH scale ranges from pH 0 to pH 14 and measures the acidity or alkalinity of a solution.

cards.term: What are pH ranges for acids and alkalis? What the OH of a neutral solution?
cards.definition: Acid - Less than pH 7 (pH 1 is strongest). Neutral - pH 7. Alkali - Greater than pH 7 (pH 14 is strongest).

cards.term: What can be used to measure pH?
cards.definition: Universal indicator, pH probe

cards.term: What colour is phenolphthalein in acid and alkali?
cards.definition: Acid - Colourless, Alkali - Pink

cards.term: What colour is methyl orange in an acid and an alkali?
cards.definition: Acid - Red, Alkali - Yellow

cards.term: What colour is blue litmus paper in an acid and an alkali?
cards.definition: Acid - Turns red, Alkali - Stays blue

cards.term: What colour is blue litmus paper in an acid and an alkali?
cards.definition: Acid - Stays red, Alkali - Turns blue

cards.term: Suggest a problem with using universal indicator to test the pH of a solution
cards.definition: The colour of the solution is matched to a pH colour chart. This is quite subjective as people may disagree with which colour the solution matches. It doesn't provide an exact pH value.

cards.term: Acid X has a pH of 1. What can you say about the concentration of hydrogen ions in acid X? (higher only)
cards.definition: There is a high concentration of hydrogen ions in the acid, making it a strong acid. The lower the pH of the acid, the higher the concentration of H+ ions.

cards.term: Alkali Y has a pH of 8.5. What can you say about the concentration of hydroxide ions in alkali Y? (higher only)
cards.definition: There is a low concentration of hydroxide ions in the alkali, making it a weak alkali. The lower the pH of the alkali, the lower the concentration of OH- ions.

cards.term: If pH decreases by one unit, what happens to the concentration hydrogen ions? (higher only)
cards.definition: The hydrogen ion concentration increases by a factor of 10.

cards.term: What is a neutralisation reaction? During an acid-alkali neutralisation reaction, what happens?
cards.definition: A neutralisation reaction is a reaction between an acid and a base. In an acid-alkali neutralisation reaction, H+ ions from the acid react with OH- ions from the alkali to form water.

cards.term: What is the ionic equation for a neutralisation reaction?
cards.definition: H+(aq) + OH-(aq) > H2O(l)

cards.term: What do the terms concentrated and dilute mean when talking about acid? Is this the same as strong/ weak acids? (higher only)
cards.definition: Concentrated acids have more moles of acid per unit volume of water than dilute acids. The concentration of an acid is not the same as strength. Strength refers to whether the acid has completely dissociated in water or not.

cards.term: An acid only partially dissociates in water. What can be said about the strength of the acid? (higher only)
cards.definition: Weak acid
Any substance that reacts with an acid to form salt and water only.

cards.term: True or false? Alkalis are insoluble bases
cards.definition: FALSE. Alkalis are soluble bases.

cards.term: What are the products when an acid reacts with a metal?
cards.definition: Salt and hydrogen. acid + metal  salt + hydrogen

cards.term: What are the products when an acid reacts with a metal oxide?
cards.definition: Salt and water. acid + metal oxide  salt + water

cards.term: What are the products when an acid reacts with a metal hydroxide?
cards.definition: Salt and water. acid + metal hydroxide  salt + water

cards.term: What are the products when an acid reacts with a metal carbonate?
cards.definition: Salt, water and carbon dioxide. Acid + metal carbonate salt + water + carbon dioxide

cards.term: Why are metal oxides normally bases rather than alkalis?
cards.definition: Metal oxides are normally insoluble. Alkalis are soluble.

cards.term: What is the name of the salt formed from magnesium and sulfuric acid?
cards.definition: Magnesium sulfate

cards.term: What is the name of the salt formed from zinc oxide and nitric acid?
cards.definition: Zinc nitrate

cards.term: What is the name of the salt formed from calcium carbonate and hydrochloric acid?
cards.definition: Calcium chloride

cards.term: Describe the chemical test for hydrogen
cards.definition: Insert a lit splint into a test tube of gas. A squeaky pop will be heard if hydrogen is present.

cards.term: Describe the chemical test for carbon dioxide
cards.definition: Bubble the gas through limewater (calcium hydroxide). Limewater turns cloudy if carbon dioxide is present.

cards.term: When a soluble salt is prepared from an acid and an insoluble reactant, why is excess of the insoluble reactant added?
cards.definition: To ensure all the acid reacts.

cards.term: When a soluble salt is prepared from an acid and an insoluble reactant, how and why is the excess reactant removed?
cards.definition: By filtration. It is removed to leave a pure solution of the salt.

cards.term: What method must be used to prepare a salt from an acid and a soluble reactant? Why?
cards.definition: Titration. Since both the reactants are soluble, a titration allows you to combine the reactants exactly and avoid adding an excess of either reactant as this would be hard to remove.

cards.term: Name the method that could be used to prepare a sample of soluble copper sulfate from insoluble copper oxide and sulfuric acid?
cards.definition: Filtration

cards.term: What 3 steps are required when producing a pure dry salt from an acid and alkali?
cards.definition: Complete a titration to find the volume of acid that reacts exactly with a set volume of alkali. Use the results from the titration to mix the acid and alkali in the correct proportions. Evaporate the water from the solution, leaving pure dry salt crystals.

cards.term: Describe how to carry out an acid-alkali titration
cards.definition: 1. Use a pipette to add a measured volume of acid to the conical flask then add a few drops of indicator. Place on a white tile. 2. Fill the burette with the alkali, noting the initial volume. 3. Add the alkali to the conical flask. First complete a rough trial to find the end point (the point at which the indicator first changes colour). 4. Repeat, adding the alkali drop by drop near the end point and swirling the flask constantly to mix. 5. Record the final volume in the burette. Repeat until you have concordant results.

cards.term: Most common chlorides are soluble. What are the two exceptions?
cards.definition: Silver chloride and lead chloride are insoluble.

cards.term: True or false? All nitrates are soluble
cards.definition: TRUE

cards.term: Fill in the gap: All common sodium, potassium and ammonium salts are
cards.definition: Soluble

cards.term: Most common sulfates are soluble. What are the three exceptions?
cards.definition: Lead sulfate, calcium sulfate and barium sulfate are insoluble.

cards.term: Most common carbonates and hydroxides are insoluble. What are the three exceptions?
cards.definition: The carbonates / hydroxides of sodium potassium and ammonium are soluble.

cards.term: What salt is produced when lead reacts with sulfuric acid? Will a precipitate form?
cards.definition: Lead sulfate. A precipitate will form because lead sulfate is insoluble.

cards.term: How could you prepare a pure, dry sample of an insoluble salt?
cards.definition: 1. Mix the two solutions required to form the salt. 2. Filter the mixture using filter paper. 3. The residue on the filter paper is the insoluble salt. 4. Wash the salt with distilled water and leave to dry.
An ionic compound in its molten or aqueous State. Aqueous - dissolved in water.

cards.term: Why can an electrolyte carry charge?
cards.definition: An ionic compound in is molten or aqueous state has mobile ions which can carry charge.
A process which uses electrical energy (from a direct current supply) to decompose electrolytes.

cards.term: What is the cathode and anode?
cards.definition: Cathode - negative electrode. Anode - positive electrode

cards.term: Where do charged ions in the electrolyte move to during electrolysis?
cards.definition: Cations (positive ions) move towards the cathode (negative electrode). Anions (negative ions) move towards the anode (positive electrode).

cards.term: What happens at the anode during electrolysis?
cards.definition: The anions (negatively charged ions) lose electrons to form their elements.

cards.term: What happens at the cathode during electrolysis?
cards.definition: Cations (positively charged ions) gain electrons to form their elements.

cards.term: Name the processes that occur at each electrode during electrolysis (higher only)
cards.definition: Anode (positive) - oxidation. Cathode (negative) - reduction.

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode in electrolysis?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Non metal. Negative electrode: Metal or hydrogen.

cards.term: How can you predict whether a metal or hydrogen will form at the negative electrode?
cards.definition: If hydrogen is above the metal in the reactivity series then the metal will form. If the metal is more reactive than hydrogen then hydrogen will form.

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of copper chloride solution?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Chlorine. Negative electrode: Copper

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of sodium sulfate solution?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Oxygen. Negative electrode: Hydrogen

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of molten lead bromide?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Bromine. Negative electrode: Hydrogen

cards.term: Predict what will be formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of molten zinc chloride
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Chlorine. Negative electrode: Zinc

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of sodium chloride solution?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Chlorine. Negative electrode: Hydrogen

cards.term: What is formed at each electrode during the electrolysis of water acidified with sulfuric acid?
cards.definition: Positive electrode: Oxygen. Negative electrode: Hydrogen

cards.term: What are the half equations for the reactions occurring at the cathode and anode during the electrolysis of copper chloride? (higher only)
cards.definition: Anode: 2Cl-  Cl2 + 2e-. Cathode: Cu2+ + 2e-  Cu

cards.term: What does oxidation mean in terms of electrons? (higher only)
cards.definition: Loss of electrons

cards.term: What does reduction mean in terms of electrons? (higher only)
cards.definition: Gain of electrons

cards.term: Describe how electrolysis of copper sulfate can be used to purify copper
cards.definition: Place 2 copper electrodes into copper sulfate solution. The anode should be impure copper and cathode should be pure copper. Connect to a power supply. The copper in the impure anode is pulled towards the cathode to form pure copper. Impurities form as sludge below the anode. Cu2+ ions from copper sulfate remain in solution.

cards.term: What are the products when a metal reacts with cold water?
cards.definition: Metal hydroxide and hydrogen gas.

cards.term: What are the products when a metal reacts with steam?
cards.definition: Metal oxide and hydrogen gas.

cards.term: Write the chemical equation for the reaction that occurs when calcium reacts with cold water
cards.definition: Ca + 2H2O  Ca(OH)2 + H2

cards.term: Write the chemical equation for the reaction that occurs when zinc reacts with steam
cards.definition: Zn + H2O  ZnO + H2

cards.term: What are the products when a metal reacts with dilute acids?
cards.definition: Salt and hydrogen.

cards.term: If a metal reacts with cold water, what does it suggest about the reactivity of this metal?
cards.definition: It suggests the metal is very reactive as only the most reactive metals can react with cold water.

cards.term: A metal reacts with oxygen but not acid or cold water. What does this suggest about the reactivity of this metal?
cards.definition: Not very reactive, most metals react with oxygen.

cards.term: Name a metal which will not react with water, acid or oxygen
cards.definition: Gold

cards.term: Describe an experiment that uses displacement to compare the reactivity of two metals
cards.definition:
Add a solid metal to a salt solution (the salt must contain a different metal).

If the solid metal is more reactive, it will gradually disappear, displacing the metal that was in the salt solution.

If nothing happens, the metal in the salt is more reactive and can't be displaced.

cards.term: What would you expect to observe when magnesium is added to copper sulfate solution?
cards.definition:
The copper sulfate solution is blue.
Magnesium is more reactive than copper so when magnesium is added the blue solution decolourises and copper coats the surface of the magnesium.

cards.term: Why can a displacement reaction be called a redox reaction? Explain in terms of electron transfer (higher only)
cards.definition:
A redox reaction occurs when reduction and oxidation are taking place in the same reaction.

In a displacement reaction, the more reactive metal atoms lose electrons to form ions (oxidation) and the less reactive metal ions gain electrons to form the element (reduction).

cards.term: Fill in the gap: 'The reactivity of a metal is related to its tendency to form'
cards.definition: Cations (positive ions)

cards.term: Which metals are most easily oxidised?
cards.definition: The metals highest in the reactivity series. More reactive metals are more likely to react with water and dilute acids to form cations.

cards.term: Where are most metals extracted from?
cards.definition: From ores found in the Earth's crust.
A rock which contains metals often chemically combined with other substances.

cards.term: Which metals are found in the earth's crust as uncombined elements?
cards.definition: Unreactive metals

cards.term: Explain what oxidation means in terms of oxygen
cards.definition: Gain of oxygen

cards.term: Explain what reduction means in terms of oxygen
cards.definition: Loss of oxygen

cards.term: Most ores contain metals chemically combined with oxygen. What process must be carried out to extract the metal?
cards.definition: Reduction

cards.term: How can metals be extracted from their ores?
cards.definition:
Reduction with carbon: Can only be done if the metal is less reactive than carbon (links to reactivity series).

Electrolysis: Can be done with all metals, but requires a large amount of energy (high cost).

cards.term: How would you extract iron from its ore?
cards.definition:
Iron is less reactive than carbon so can be extracted by reduction with carbon.

Electrolysis could also be used, but this would use a lot of unnecessary energy (high cost).

cards.term: What is the chemical equation for the reduction of iron with carbon?
cards.definition: 2Fe2O3 + 3C  4Fe + 3CO2

cards.term: How can aluminium be extracted from its ore?
cards.definition:
Aluminium is more reactive than carbon so electrolysis must be used.

When the molten ore undergoes electrolysis, the metal forms at the cathode.

cards.term: When aluminium is extracted from aluminium oxide, why is it first dissolved in molten cryolite?
cards.definition: Aluminium oxide has a very high melting point. It is dissolved in molten cryolite to produce an electrolyte with a lower melting point, reducing energy usage and cost.

cards.term: How can plants be used as an alternative metal extraction method? How does it work? (higher only)
cards.definition:
Phytoextraction:

Plants are grown in areas with metals in the soil. The plants take up metals through their roots and concentrate them in their shoots and leaves. These plants are burned and the metals are removed from the ash.

cards.term: How can bacteria be used as an alternative metal extraction method? How does it work? (higher only)
cards.definition:
Bacterial extraction:

Some bacteria absorb metal compounds. These bacteria produce solutions called leachates containing the metals. Scrap iron can be used to remove the metal from the leachate.

cards.term: What are the limitations of biological methods of extraction? (higher only)
cards.definition:
- Only suitable for low grade ores with smaller quantities of metals.

- Slow processes.

- Require displacement or electrolysis for the final step.

cards.term: How is a metal's relative resistance to oxidation related to its position in the reactivity series?
cards.definition: Oxidation is the loss of electrons. Metals lower in the reactivity series are less reactive. This means they are less likely to form their cations so are more resistant to oxidation.

cards.term: What are the advantages of recycling metals?
cards.definition:
- Economically beneficial because electrolysis is expensive.

- Prevents the detrimental environmental impact of mining and extraction of new metals.

- Less waste produced so less landfill.

- Less energy required compared to electrolysis.

- More sustainable - not using up the finite resources.

- Recycling process provides employment.

cards.term: What is a life cycle assessment?
cards.definition: Analysis of the overall environmental impact that a product may have throughout its lifetime.

cards.term: What different factors does a life cycle assessment of a product consider?
cards.definition:
- Extraction and processing of raw materials.
- Manufacturing.

- Packaging and transportation.

- Use of the product.

- Disposal.

A reaction in which the products can react to form the original reactants.

Denoted by the symbol:

cards.term: How can the direction of a reversible reaction be altered?
cards.definition:
Changing the reaction conditions.

E.g. Temperature, pressure, concentration.

cards.term: What is meant by the term dynamic equilibrium?
cards.definition: Dynamic equilibrium is when the rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the backwards reaction. This means the concentration of reactants and products are constant even though compounds are continually reacting.
A system where nothing is added or removed. All reactants and products remain in the reaction vessel.

cards.term: Why is equilibrium only reached if the reaction takes place in a closed system?
cards.definition: The closed system prevents any reactants and products escaping so that they are able to react continuously.
An industrial process used to produce ammonia (for making fertilisers).

cards.term: Write the chemical equation for the reversible reaction between nitrogen and hydrogen, forming ammonia
cards.definition: N2 + 3H2  2NH3

cards.term: Where are the sources of nitrogen and hydrogen for the Haber process?
cards.definition:
Nitrogen: Extracted from the air.

Hydrogen: Obtained from natural gas.

cards.term: True or false? 'The process used to form ammonia is a reversible reaction that will never reach dynamic equilibrium'
cards.definition:
FALSE

The formation of ammonia is a reversible reaction that will reach dynamic equilibrium in a closed system.

cards.term: What conditions are used for the Haber process?
cards.definition:
- 450C temperature
- 200 atm pressure
- Iron catalyst

cards.term: Explain the effect of increasing the temperature of a reversible reaction if the forward reaction is endothermic (higher only)
cards.definition: The forward reaction is endothermic so increasing the temperature favours the forward reaction. The equilibrium will shift towards the forward reaction and the yield of the products will increase.

cards.term: Explain the effect of increasing the pressure of a reversible gaseous reaction
cards.definition: An increase in pressure will favour the reaction that produces the least number of molecules. The equilibrium position will shift towards the side that produces the fewest gaseous molecules.

cards.term: The equation for the Haber process is N2 + 3H2  2NH3. Explain the effect of increasing the pressure on the yield of ammonia (higher only)
cards.definition: Increasing the pressure will shift equilibrium to the right as there are fewer molecules of gas. The yield of ammonia will increase.

cards.term: The concentration of the reactants are increased during a reversible reaction. What effect will this have on the equilibrium position? (higher only)
cards.definition: The equilibrium will shift to the right so the product yield will increase. This will reduce the effect of the increased concentration of the reactants.

cards.term: If there are equal gaseous molecules of the reactant and product in a reversible reaction, what effect will changing the pressure have on the equilibrium position? (higher only)
cards.definition: No effect

- High melting point.
- High density.
- Form coloured compounds
- Transition metals and their compounds can be used as catalysts.

cards.term: Transition metal used as a catalyst in the Haber process
cards.definition: Iron
Oxygen reacts with the metal to form a metal oxide

cards.term: Why metal corrosion is a redox reaction
cards.definition: The metal loses electrons so is oxidised. Oxygen gains electrons so is reduced.
Rusting is the name specifically given to the corrosion of iron when it reacts to oxygen and water in the air.

cards.term: Substances needed to be excluded to prevent rusting
cards.definition:
Oxygen (O2)
Water (H2O)

cards.term: Methods to exclude oxygen and water to prevent iron rusting
cards.definition:
- Paint the metal.
- Coat the metal in oil/grease.
- Cover the metal in plastic.
- Keep the metal in a vacuum container.

cards.term: Definition of sacrificial protection and how it prevents corrosion
cards.definition: Sacrificial protection is when the metal being protected from rusting is galvanized with a more reactive metal. The outer metal will corrode first and will prevent the corrosion of the inner metal.

cards.term: Metal used in the sacrificial protection of iron
cards.definition: Zinc
A process in which a metal is coated with a layer of another metal.

- To make a metal more resistant to corrosion.
- To improve the appearance of a metal (e.g. silver plated cutlery).

Similar setup to electrolysis: The metal being coated is the cathode. The metal that will form the exterior layer is the anode. The electrolyte solution must contain ions of the metal which will form the outer coating. A power supply is connected to both electrodes.

cards.term: Reason why pure metals are generally very malleable
cards.definition: The atoms lie in uniform rows which are able to slide over one another.
An alloy is a mixture of two or more metals or a metal and another element.

cards.term: How converting a pure metal into an alloy increases its strength
cards.definition: Alloys contain several metals which will have different sized atoms. This distorts the regular arrangement of the atoms so the layers are unable to slide over one another very easily.

cards.term: Reasons why iron is alloyed with other metals to produce alloy steels
cards.definition:
Iron is relatively brittle so it is combined with other elements such as carbon produces a material with more desirable qualities.
- Low carbon steel: Malleable so used for sheeting.
- High carbon steel: Hard so used for cutting tools.
- Stainless steel: Corrosion resistant so used for cutlery.

cards.term: Key property of copper making it suitable for use in electrical cables
cards.definition: Very good electrical conductor.

cards.term: Property of aluminium making it suitable for use in aircraft
cards.definition: Low density

cards.term: Key property of gold making it suitable for use in jewellery
cards.definition: Very unreactive so resistant to corrosion. Jewellery appearance will not be affected over time.

cards.term: Definition of magnalium and its use
cards.definition: Magnalium is an alloy of magnesium and aluminium. It is lighter and stronger than aluminium and more resistant to corrosion. It is used for cars and aircraft.

cards.term: Definition of brass and its use
cards.definition: Brass is an alloy of copper and zinc. Brass is hard and resistant to corrosion. It is used for decorative hardware such as plumbing fittings.

cards.term: Calculation of concentration of a solution in mol dm^-3
cards.definition: Concentration (mol dm^-3) = moles / volume (dm^3)

cards.term: Conversion of concentration in g dm^-3 to mol dm^-3
cards.definition: Concentration (mol dm^-3) = concentration (g dm^-3) / Mr (molecular mass)

cards.term: Description of carrying out an acid-alkali titration to find the concentration of alkali
cards.definition:
1. Rinse the pipette with the solution of unknown concentration (alkali). Use this pipette to add a known volume of alkali to a conical flask.
2. Add a few drops of indicator.
3. Rinse and fill the burette with acid.
4. Gradually add the acid to the conical flask.
5. Record the volume in the burette when the indicator changes color. Repeat the experiment until you have concordant results.
6. Use results to calculate a mean titre and the concentration of alkali.

cards.term: Calculation of the concentration of acid given the alkali concentration and volume of acid used for neutralization
cards.definition:
- Calculate the number of moles of the alkali using the known volume and concentration (moles = concentration x volume).
- Use the chemical equation to work out the ratio of acid and alkali that react and hence work out how many moles of acid have reacted.
- Divide the moles of acid by the volume used in neutralization to find concentration.
The amount of product that would be collected under perfect reaction conditions.
Percentage yield = (Actual yield / Theoretical yield) x 100

cards.term: Percentage yield of NH3 if 40.5 g of NH3 is produced from 20.0 mol H2 and excess N2
cards.definition: Percentage yield = (40.5/227) x 100 = 17.8%

cards.term: Reasons why actual yield of product might be less than expected
cards.definition:
- Incomplete reaction.
- Competing, unwanted side reactions.
- Practical losses, for example, some solid may get lost when being transferred between beakers.
Atom economy is a measure of the efficiency of the reaction. It looks at the amount of reactants that get turned into useful products.
Atom economy = (Mr of desired product / Mr of reactants) x 100
The higher the atom economy, the more sustainable and efficient the process.

cards.term: Reasons why one reaction pathway might be chosen over another
cards.definition:
- Higher atom economy.
- Higher yield.
- Faster rate.
- Equilibrium position favors products more.
- By-products are more useful / less harmful.
At the same temperature and pressure, equal amounts of gas will occupy the same volume.

cards.term: Definition of molar volume of a gas
cards.definition: The volume occupied by one mole of molecules of any gas at room temperature and pressure.
Room temperature and pressure: 20C, 1 atmosphere

cards.term: Calculation of molar volume of a gas
cards.definition: Molar volume = volume (dm^3) / moles of gas. Units: dm^3 mol^-1
A reversible reaction that forms ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen.

cards.term: Steps carried out during the Haber process
cards.definition:
1. Reactants are obtained (hydrogen from natural gas, nitrogen from air).
2. The gases are compressed to 200 atm and heated to 450C before being pumped into a tank containing layers of catalytic iron beads.
3. Ammonia forms.
4. Ammonia and unreacted hydrogen and nitrogen pass into a cooling tank where the ammonia is collected as a liquid.
5. The unreacted hydrogen and nitrogen are recycled back into the tank.
The rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the backward reaction. The concentration of reactants and products are constant.

cards.term: Chemical equation for the formation of ammonia from hydrogen and nitrogen
cards.definition: N2 + 3H2  2NH3

cards.term: Ideal conditions for the Haber process
cards.definition:
- 450C temperature
- 200 atm pressure
- Iron catalyst

cards.term: Effect of temperature on the rate of attainment of equilibrium
cards.definition: A higher temperature means equilibrium is reached quicker. This is because the reacting particles have more kinetic energy so there are more frequent successful collisions.

cards.term: Effect of a catalyst on the rate of attainment of equilibrium
cards.definition: Equilibrium is reached faster when a catalyst is used because the catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy.

cards.term: Effect of pressure on the rate of attainment of equilibrium
cards.definition: Equilibrium is reached faster with a higher pressure. This is because there are more particles in the same volume (or the same number of particles in a smaller volume) so more collisions between reacting particles.

cards.term: Effect of concentration on the rate of attainment of equilibrium
cards.definition: Equilibrium is reached faster at a higher concentration. This is because there are more particles in the same volume so more collisions between the reacting particles.

cards.term: Reasons why the conditions used in the Haber process are a compromise
cards.definition:
- A high temperature increases the rate of reaction however, it will favor the reverse reaction, decreasing the yield. A compromise of 450C is used to obtain a sufficient rate and yield.
- A high pressure speeds up the rate and favors the forward reaction (increasing the yield). High pressures can be dangerous and require expensive machinery so a compromise of 200 atm is used.
To promote plant growth.
Nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium compounds.
A combination of all three fertilizer compounds: nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium compounds.

cards.term: Parts of plant growth affected by nitrogen, potassium, and phosphorus
cards.definition:
Nitrogen: Healthy leaves.
Phosphorus: Healthy roots.
Potassium: Growth and healthy fruit/flowers.

cards.term: Most commonly used ammonium salt in fertilizers
cards.definition: Ammonium nitrate
React ammonia with nitric acid: NH3 + HNO3  NH4NO3

cards.term: Formation of ammonium sulfate from ammonia and sulfuric acid
cards.definition: 2NH3 + H2SO4  (NH4)2SO4

cards.term: Laboratory method of preparing ammonium sulfate
cards.definition:
Titration between ammonia and sulfuric acid:
- Exact volume of NH3 added to a conical flask using a pipette.
- Add a few drops of indicator.
- Add H2SO4 from the burette drop by drop. Stop when the indicator changes color.
- Repeat, adding the exact volumes of reactants without the indicator (as it is an impurity).
- Remove the water by evaporation and crystallization, leaving pure crystals.

cards.term: Industrial method of producing ammonium sulfate
cards.definition: Raw materials obtained from the Haber process (ammonia) and the contact process (sulfuric acid). A large reactor chamber is filled with ammonia gas. Sulfuric acid is sprayed into the chamber from above. Ammonium sulfate crystals are produced.

cards.term: Comparison between laboratory method and industrial process of producing ammonium sulfate
cards.definition:
Laboratory method:
- Faster rate of reaction.
- Small reactant quantities can easily be bought.
- Room temperature and pressure.
- Simple equipment required.
- Very small yield.

Industrial process:
- Continuous process so continuous yield.
- Large volumes of product.
- Slow rate of reaction.
- High energy requirement.
- Other industrial processes required to obtain the reactants.

cards.term: Setup of a chemical cell and production of voltage
cards.definition: Two metals of different reactivities are placed in an electrolyte. The more reactive metal releases electrons, becoming positively charged. The electrons flow to the other electrode which becomes negatively charged. The difference in the ability of each electrode to release electrons causes a voltage to be produced.

cards.term: When a chemical cell stops producing voltage
cards.definition: When one of the reactants has been used up.
A cell that continually produces a voltage as long as it is supplied with oxygen and a fuel (like hydrogen).

cards.term: Only product of a hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell
cards.definition: Water

cards.term: Operation of a hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell
cards.definition: Hydrogen and oxygen are pumped through porous electrodes. The electrolyte is often an acid such as phosphoric acid. Hydrogen and oxygen react, producing electricity and water.

cards.term: Overall reaction in a hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell
cards.definition: 2H2 + O2  2H2O

- No pollution produced.
- Produce more energy than an alternative fuel like petrol.
- Continuous process as long as fuel is supplied.

- Materials used to make them are expensive.
- High pressure tanks required to store oxygen and fuels like hydrogen.
- Hydrogen is expensive and hard to store.
- Efficiency is affected by temperature.

cards.term:
How are elements arranged in the periodic table?

Ordered by increasing atomic number.

Elements in the same group (column) have the
same number of outer shell electrons.

Elements in the same period (row) have the
same number of electron shells.
cards.definition: Ordered by increasing atomic number. Elements in the same group (column) have the same number of outer shell electrons. Elements in the same period (row) have the same number of electron shells.

cards.term:
How many electrons are in the outer shell of a group
1 element?

One
cards.definition: One

cards.term:
Why do elements in the same group have similar
chemical properties?

They have the same number of electrons
in the outer shell.
cards.definition: They have the same number of electrons in the outer shell.

cards.term:
What group of the periodic table are the alkali
metals?

Group 1
cards.definition: Group 1

cards.term:
List two properties of alkali metals

- Relatively low melting points
- Soft
cards.definition:
- Relatively low melting points
- Soft

cards.term:
Why are group 1 elements called the alkali metals?

They react with water to form alkaline
solutions (9H greater than 7).
cards.definition: They react with water to form alkaline solutions (pH greater than 7).

cards.term:
What are the products of the reaction between
lithium and water?

Lithium hydroxide and hydrogen.
cards.definition: Lithium hydroxide and hydrogen.

cards.term:
Write a balanced symbol equation for the reaction of
sodium with water

2Na + 2H2O  2NaOH + H2
cards.definition: 2Na + 2H2O  2NaOH + H2

cards.term:
Why should alkali metals be stored in oil?

To prevent them reacting with water
vapour and oxygen in the air.
cards.definition: To prevent them reacting with water vapor and oxygen in the air.

cards.term:
What would be observed when lithium reacts with
water?

- Slowest reaction of the alkali metals.

- Bubbles of hydrogen are produced.

- Doesn't melt (highest melting point of
alkali metals).
cards.definition:
- Slowest reaction of the alkali metals.
- Bubbles of hydrogen are produced.
- Doesn't melt (highest melting point of alkali metals).

cards.term:
What would be observed when sodium reacts with
water?

Faster reaction than lithium.

Floats on the surface of water (less dense than water).
Bubbles of hydrogen are produced which cause the
sodium to whizz around the surface of the water.

Melts as enough energy is given out to meet sodiums
melting point.
cards.definition: Faster reaction than lithium. Floats on the surface of water (less dense than water). Bubbles of hydrogen are produced which cause the sodium to whizz around the surface of the water. Melts as enough energy is given out to meet sodiums melting point.

cards.term:
What would be observed when potassium reacts
with water?

More violent reaction than sodium.

Bubbles of hydrogen are produced which cause the
potassium to whizz around the surface of the water.
Melts into a shiny ball.

Burns with a lilac flame.
cards.definition: More violent reaction than sodium. Bubbles of hydrogen are produced which cause the potassium to whizz around the surface of the water. Melts into a shiny ball. Burns with a lilac flame.

cards.term:
What is the order of reactivity of the first 3 alkali
metals with water?

Lithium reacts least violent reaction,
potassium reacts most violently:

Lithium < Sodium < Potassium
cards.definition: Lithium reacts least violently, sodium reacts more violently than lithium, and potassium reacts most violently.

cards.term:
Using the reactions of the first 3 alkali metals with
water, predict the reactivity trend down group 1

Reactivity increases down group 1.
cards.definition: Reactivity increases down group 1.

cards.term:
Why does reactivity increase down group 1?

The number of electron shells increases down
the group so there is more electron shielding. As
a result, there is weaker attraction between the
positive nucleus and outer shell electron. This
means it is easier to remove an outer shell
electron to form a positive metal ion.
cards.definition: The number of electron shells increases down the group so there is more electron shielding. As a result, there is weaker attraction between the positive nucleus and outer shell electron. This means it is easier to remove an outer shell electron to form a positive metal ion.

cards.term:
Which group 1 element would you expect to react
most violently with water?

Reactivity increases down the group so
francium will react most violently with
water.
cards.definition: Reactivity increases down the group so francium will react most violently with water.

cards.term:
What group are the halogens in? Why?

Group 7 because they have 7 outer shell electrons.
cards.definition: Group 7 because they have 7 outer shell electrons.

cards.term:
What is the colour and state of chlorine at room
temperature?

Pale green gas
cards.definition: Pale green gas

cards.term:
What is the colour and state of bromine at room
temperature?

Red-brown liquid
cards.definition: Red-brown liquid

cards.term:
What is the colour and state of iodine at room
temperature?

Black solid
cards.definition: Black solid

cards.term:
Why are the halogens at different states at room
temperature? What is the trend down the group?

At room temperature, chlorine is gaseous,
bromine is liquid and iodine is solid because they
have different melting and boiling points. As you

go down the group, melting and boiling point
increases.
cards.definition: At room temperature, chlorine is gaseous, bromine is liquid, and iodine is solid because they have different melting and boiling points. As you go down the group, melting and boiling point increases.

cards.term:
What state would you expect the halogens fluorine
and astatine to be at room temperature?

Fluorine is above chlorine so should have a boiling point
lower than chlorine. This means it would be a gas at room
temperature.

Astatine is below iodine in group 7 so should have a higher
melting point than iodine. Therefore you can predict that it
would be a solid at room temperature.
cards.definition: Fluorine is above chlorine so should have a boiling point lower than chlorine. This means it would be a gas at room temperature. Astatine is below iodine in group 7 so should have a higher melting point than iodine. Therefore you can predict that it would be a solid at room temperature.

cards.term:
Why does melting and boiling point increase down
Group 7?

The molecules get bigger down the group
so there are more intermolecular forces to
overcome during melting / boiling so more
energy is required.
cards.definition: The molecules get bigger down the group so there are more intermolecular forces to overcome during melting / boiling so more energy is required.

cards.term:
What is the chemical test for chlorine?

Damp litmus paper placed into a test
tube of gas. If chlorine is present, the
litmus paper will turn red then white due
to the bleaching effect of chlorine.
cards.definition: Damp litmus paper placed into a test tube of gas. If chlorine is present, the litmus paper will turn red then white due to the bleaching effect of chlorine.

cards.term:
Halogens are diatomic. What does this mean?

They form molecules consisting of 2
atoms

E.g: Cl2, Br2, -
cards.definition: They form molecules consisting of 2 atoms. E.g: Cl2, Br2, -

cards.term:
What charge does a halide ion carry? Why?
-1
e.g. Cl-, Br-...

They gain one electron to have a stable
electron configuration.
cards.definition: They gain one electron to have a stable electron configuration.

cards.term:
What is produced when a halogen reacts with a
metal?

Metal halide salt
cards.definition: Metal halide salt

cards.term:
Write a balanced symbol equation for the reaction
between bromine and sodium

Br2 + 2Na  2NaBr
cards.definition: Br2 + 2Na  2NaBr

cards.term:
Write a balanced symbol equation for the reaction
between chlorine and calcium

Cl2 + Ca  CaCl2
cards.definition: Cl2 + Ca  CaCl2

cards.term:
Predict the product of the reaction between
magnesium and fluorine

Magnesium fluoride (MgF2)
cards.definition: Magnesium fluoride (MgF2)

cards.term:
Write a word equation for the reaction between
iodine and potassium

Iodine + potassium  Potassium iodide.

Remember: the ion of a halogen ends
with -ide.
cards.definition: Iodine + potassium  Potassium iodide. Remember: the ion of a halogen ends with -ide.

cards.term:
Describe the trend in reactivity of the halogens. How
does this affect the rate of reaction?

Reactivity decreases down group 7.

Rate of reaction decreases down group 7.
cards.definition: Reactivity decreases down group 7. Rate of reaction decreases down group 7.

cards.term:
What is formed when hydrogen reacts with a
halogen?

Hydrogen halides
(e.g. HCl, HBr...)
cards.definition: Hydrogen halides (e.g. HCl, HBr...)

cards.term:
Chlorine reacts with hydrogen in the presence of
sunlight but bromine requires a flame. Why?

Reactivity decreases down the group so

bromine requires more energy for the
reaction to occur.
cards.definition: Reactivity decreases down the group so bromine requires more energy for the reaction to occur.

cards.term:
What is formed when a hydrogen halide dissolves in
water?

An acidic solution. Hydrogen ions
dissociate, making the solution acidic.
cards.definition: An acidic solution. Hydrogen ions dissociate, making the solution acidic.

cards.term:
Write a balanced symbol equation for the reaction
between hydrogen and chlorine

H2 + Cl2  2HCl
cards.definition: H2 + Cl2  2HCl

cards.term:
Predict the product of the reaction between
hydrogen and fluorine

Hydrogen fluoride (HF)
cards.definition: Hydrogen fluoride (HF)

cards.term:
When does a halogen displacement reaction occur?

When a more reactive halogen displaces
a less reactive halogen from an aqueous
solution of its halide.
cards.definition: When a more reactive halogen displaces a less reactive halogen from an aqueous solution of its halide.

cards.term:
Why will halide ions A only be displaced by halogen

B if B is above A in group 7?

The most reactive halogen (B) will displace the

less reactive halogen (A) to become part of the

ionic compound. Reactivity increases as you go
up the group so B must be higher in group 7 to

be more reactive than A.
cards.definition: The most reactive halogen (B) will displace the less reactive halogen (A) to become part of the ionic compound. Reactivity increases as you go up the group so B must be higher in group 7 to be more reactive than A.

cards.term:
Which halogens can chlorine displace from an
aqueous Ionic solution?

Chlorine can displace any halogens
below it in group 7. It will displace iodine
and bromine.
cards.definition: Chlorine can displace any halogens below it in group 7. It will displace iodine and bromine.

cards.term:
Which halogens can't be displaced from an aqueous
ionic solution by bromine?

Bromine cant displace any halogens
above it in group 7. These are chlorine
and fluorine.
cards.definition: Bromine cant displace any halogens above it in group 7. These are chlorine and fluorine.

cards.term:
Why can iodine not displace chlorine or bromine
from an aqueous ionic solution?

Because reactivity decreases down the group
and iodine is below chlorine and bromine
group 7. Displacement will only occur if iodine
is more reactive than the halogen in the ionic
compound.
cards.definition: Because reactivity decreases down the group and iodine is below chlorine and bromine group 7. Displacement will only occur if iodine is more reactive than the halogen in the ionic compound.

cards.term:
Write the word equation for the reaction between
chlorine and potassium bromide

Chlorine + potassium bromide  potassium chloride + bromine
cards.definition: Chlorine + potassium bromide  potassium chloride + bromine

cards.term:
Write the word equation for the reaction between
bromine and calcium chloride

No reaction will occur because bromine
Is less reactive than chlorine so chlorine
won't be displaced.
cards.definition: No reaction will occur because bromine is less reactive than chlorine so chlorine won't be displaced.

cards.term:
Write the balanced symbol equation for the reaction
that takes place between bromine and potassium
iodide
Br2 + 2KI  I2 + 2KBr
cards.definition: Br2 + 2KI  I2 + 2KBr

cards.term:
Which halogens would you expect astatine to be
able to displace?

None of them. It is at the bottom of group
7 so has the lowest reactivity.
cards.definition: None of them. It is at the bottom of group 7 so has the lowest reactivity.

cards.term:
Why does reactivity decrease down group 7?

As you go down group 7, the outer shell is further
from the nucleus and electron shielding increases.
Attraction between the nucleus and outer electrons
decreases so it is harder for the atom to gain an
electron meaning reactivity decreases.
cards.definition: As you go down group 7, the outer shell is further from the nucleus and electron shielding increases. Attraction between the nucleus and outer electrons decreases so it is harder for the atom to gain an electron meaning reactivity decreases.

cards.term:
What colours are solutions of chlorine, bromine and
iodine?

Chlorine water - colourless

Bromine water - orange

Iodine solution - brown
cards.definition: Chlorine water - colourless. Bromine water - orange. Iodine solution - brown.

cards.term:
What would you observe when chlorine is added to
potassium bromide?

Cl2 + 2KBr  Br2 + 2KCl. Colour change from colourless (due to Cl2) to orange (due to Br2).
cards.definition: Colour change from colourless (due to Cl2) to orange (due to Br2).

cards.term:
What is a redox reaction?
(higher only)

A reaction where oxidation and reduction
take place at the same time.
cards.definition: A reaction where oxidation and reduction take place at the same time.

cards.term:
Are halogen displacement reactions redox
reactions? Explain your answer (higher only)

Yes because the halide ion is oxidised (loses an
electron) to form a halogen atom and the
halogen is reduced (gains an electron) to form a
halide ion.
cards.definition: Yes because the halide ion is oxidised (loses an electron) to form a halogen atom and the halogen is reduced (gains an electron) to form a halide ion.

cards.term:
Write the two half equations for the reaction between
chlorine and potassium bromide, stating which is
reduction and which is oxidation (higher only)

Overall equation: Cl2 + 2KBr  Br2 + 2KCl. Reduction: Cl2 + 2e^-  2Cl^-. Oxidation: 2Br^-  Br2 + 2e^-
cards.definition: Overall equation: Cl2 + 2KBr  Br2 + 2KCl. Reduction: Cl2 + 2e^-  2Cl^-. Oxidation: 2Br^-  Br2 + 2e^-

cards.term:
Bromine reacts with potassium iodide. What is
reduced and what is oxidised? (higher only)

Bromine is reduced to bromide ions.

Iodide ions are oxidised to iodine.
cards.definition: Bromine is reduced to bromide ions. Iodide ions are oxidised to iodine.

cards.term:
What name is used to describe the elements in
group 0 of the periodic table?

Noble gases
cards.definition: Noble gases

cards.term:
How many electrons do the noble gases have in
their outer shell?

0

They have no incomplete shells of
electrons.
cards.definition: 0. They have no incomplete shells of electrons.

cards.term:
What does chemically inert mean?

Not chemically active.
cards.definition: Not chemically active.

cards.term:
Why are the noble gases chemically inert?

They have full outer electron shells. This
is a very stable electron configuration
and means the elements are very
unreactive.
cards.definition: They have full outer electron shells. This is a very stable electron configuration and means the elements are very unreactive.

cards.term:
What properties of helium makes it suitable for use
in balloons?

It is less dense than air and does not
burn.
cards.definition: It is less dense than air and does not burn.

cards.term:
Why is argon used to fill electric light bulbs?

lt is very chemically inert so will not react
when the light bulb gets hot. It is
non-flammable.
cards.definition: It is very chemically inert so will not react when the light bulb gets hot. It is non-flammable.

cards.term:
Why is argon used for welding?

It provides an inert welding atmosphere.
Argon is more dense than air so keeps
air away from the metal.
cards.definition: It provides an inert welding atmosphere. Argon is more dense than air so keeps air away from the metal.

cards.term:
What is the trend in boiling points down group 0?

Boiling point increases down group 0 because
the relative atomic mass increases so there
are more intermolecular forces between
atoms.
cards.definition: Boiling point increases down group 0 because the relative atomic mass increases so there are more intermolecular forces between atoms.

cards.term:
What is the trend in boiling points across period 3?

Boiling point increases across period 3
because the number of electrons increases
so there are more intermolecular forces.
cards.definition: Boiling point increases across period 3 because the number of electrons increases so there are more intermolecular forces.

cards.term:
What is the boiling point of helium? Why?

-269C. It is the only element in group 0
with a boiling point below -200C.
cards.definition: -269C. It is the only element in group 0 with a boiling point below -200C.

cards.term:
What is the boiling point of xenon? Why?

-108C. It has the highest relative atomic mass in
the group so has the most intermolecular forces.
cards.definition: -108C. It has the highest relative atomic mass in the group so has the most intermolecular forces.

cards.term:
Why are the boiling points of the noble gases low?

They are simple covalently bonded molecules
with weak intermolecular forces so do not
require much energy to overcome these forces.
cards.definition: They are simple covalently bonded molecules with weak intermolecular forces so do not require much energy to overcome these forces.

cards.term:
What is the name of group 7 of the periodic table?

Halogens
cards.definition: Halogens

cards.term:
What is the name of group 0 of the periodic table?

Noble gases
cards.definition: Noble gases

cards.term:
What are the three most common noble gases?

Helium, neon, argon
cards.definition: Helium, neon, argon

topics.title: Rates of Reaction and Energy Changes (paper2)

cards.definition: Rate of reaction = Amount of reactant used or product formed / Time (s)
g/s, cm/s, mol/s

cards.term: Measurement of rate of reaction when gas is given off
cards.definition:
- Measure time and collect gas in an upside down measuring cylinder in a trough of water or in a gas syringe to measure the volume of gas produced.
- Measure time and the change in mass.

cards.term: Measurement of rate of reaction when precipitate is formed
cards.definition: Put a black cross below a beaker containing one reactant. Time how long it takes for the cross to disappear after the second reactant is added.

cards.term: Limitation of using the precipitation method to investigate rate of reaction
cards.definition: It's subjective so people are likely to disagree over the exact point at which the cross is no longer visible.

cards.term: Measurement of rate of reaction using a digital balance
cards.definition: When a gas is produced as this will cause mass to decrease. The experiment can be carried out on a digital balance and the rate of reaction can be calculated by recording the mass at regular time intervals.
The minimum amount of energy required for a reaction to occur between two reacting particles.

cards.term: Requirement for a reaction to occur
cards.definition: Particles must collide at the correct orientation with sufficient energy to react.

cards.term: Two things that could happen when the rate of reaction increases in terms of particles
cards.definition:
- More frequent collisions.
- Energy of collisions increases.

cards.term: Ways to increase the rate of a reaction
cards.definition:
- Increase the temperature.
- Increase the concentration.
- Increase surface area to volume ratio.
- Add a catalyst.
- Increase the pressure (for gases).

cards.term: Effect of temperature on rate of reaction
cards.definition: Increasing temperature increases the rate of reaction. This is because the reactants have more energy so more particles have energy above the activation energy meaning more collisions will be successful. Collisions also occur more frequently because the particles have more kinetic energy.

cards.term: Effect of surface area on rate of reaction
cards.definition: Increasing the surface area of reactants increases the rate of reaction. This is because a greater surface area means there are more exposed particles so more frequent successful collisions.

cards.term: Effect of a catalyst on rate of reaction
cards.definition: A catalyst increases the rate of reaction by providing an alternate reaction pathway with a lower activation energy. More particles will have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy and react so more successful collisions occur in the same time.

cards.term: Effect of concentration on rate of reaction
cards.definition: Increasing concentration increases the rate of reaction. This is because there are more reacting particles in the same volume so there are more frequent successful collisions.

cards.term: Effect of pressure on rate of a gaseous reaction
cards.definition: Increasing the pressure of a gaseous reaction increases the rate of reaction. This is because there are more reacting particles in the same volume of gas (or the same number of particles in a smaller volume) so more frequent successful collisions occur.

cards.term: Measurement of rate of reaction for marble chips reacting with hydrochloric acid
cards.definition: Since gaseous carbon dioxide is released, the rate can be measured by using a digital balance to measure the change in mass over a period of time.

cards.term: Ways to increase the rate of marble chips reacting with hydrochloric acid
cards.definition:
- Increase the surface area of the marble chips by turning them into a powder.
- Increase concentration of acid.
- Increase temperature.

cards.term: Method to find rate of reaction from a graph
cards.definition: Plot: X axis - time, Y axis - amount of reactant used or product formed. Draw a tangent to a point on the graph and find the gradient of this line to find the rate of reaction at that time.

cards.term: Interpretation of a steep gradient in a graph showing gas production over time
cards.definition: Fast rate of reaction.

cards.term: Description of the shape of a graph showing gas production over time
cards.definition: Initially the curve is very steep as the rate of reaction is relatively fast at the start. The curve becomes less steep as the reactants get used up because there are fewer successful collisions occurring. At the end, the graph is a flat line because all the reactants have been turned into products.
A substance which speeds up the rate of a reaction without being chemically changed at the end.

cards.term: Mechanism by which a catalyst speeds up a reaction
cards.definition: It provides an alternate reaction pathway with a lower activation energy.
Enzymes act as biological catalysts that increase the rate of reactions in living cells.

cards.term: Enzyme used to produce ethanol from glucose
cards.definition: Yeast

cards.term: Meaning of exothermic and endothermic reactions
cards.definition:
Endothermic - a reaction that takes in heat energy from the surroundings.
Exothermic - a reaction that gives out energy to the surroundings.
Exothermic
Either exothermic or endothermic.

cards.term: Nature of salt dissolving in water
cards.definition: Either exothermic or endothermic.
Exothermic

cards.term: Measurement of temperature change in a neutralisation reaction
cards.definition:
1. Measure initial temperature of the solutions.
2. Mix both reactants in a polystyrene cup.
3. Record the highest temperature reached.
4. Calculate the temperature change.

cards.term: Methods to minimize heat loss during an experiment measuring temperature change
cards.definition:
- Use polystyrene cup.
- Place reaction cup in a beaker full with cotton wool for extra insulation.
- Lid on the reaction cup.

cards.term: Explanation of bond energies in chemical reactions
cards.definition: Energy is needed to break bonds and is released when bonds are made. Exothermic reactions release more energy from breaking bonds than they use to make bonds, while endothermic reactions absorb more energy in forming new bonds than they use to break old bonds.

Combustion
Neutralisation

Thermal decomposition
Photosynthesis

cards.term: Calculation of energy change from bond energies
cards.definition: Energy change (kJ/mol) = Total energy of bonds broken - total energy of bonds made.

cards.term: Interpretation of negative energy change in a reaction
cards.definition: Exothermic, as energy has been lost to the surroundings.
A graph showing the relative energies of reactants and products, as well as the activation energy of a reaction.
Compounds that contain hydrogen and carbon atoms only.

A complex mixture of hydrocarbons. Contains molecules with rings or chains of carbon atoms. An important source of useful substances like fuels and feedstocks for the petrochemical industry. A finite resource.

cards.term: Where can crude oil be found?
cards.definition: Under the sea and ground.
It will run out.

cards.term: How can crude oil be separated?
cards.definition: Fractional distillation.

cards.term: How does the process of fractional distillation work to separate crude oil?
cards.definition: Crude oil is vaporised before it enters a fractionating column. The fractionating column is hotter at the bottom than at the top. The vapours rise up and condense at different fractions depending on their boiling points. Hydrocarbons with low boiling points will be tapped off the top of the column and hydrocarbons with high boiling points will be tapped off the bottom of the column.
Unseparated crude oil isn't very useful but the separated products (such as petrol) are very useful.
Heating and cooking.

cards.term: Which fraction of crude oil is used as fuel in cars?
cards.definition: Petrol (gasoline). Diesel is also less commonly used.
Aircraft fuel
Fuel for some cars and trains.
Fraction of crude oil used for road surfacing and roofs.
Fuel for large ships and in some power stations.

cards.term: How do the hydrocarbons at each faction differ?
cards.definition: Boiling points, ease of ignition, viscosity, the number of hydrogen and carbon atoms their molecules have.

cards.term: Where in the fractionating column do hydrocarbons with the highest viscosity condense?
cards.definition: The hydrocarbons with the highest viscosity (like bitumen) are collected at the bottom of the fractionating column.

cards.term: Properties of hydrocarbons from the top of the fractionating column
cards.definition: Low boiling point, highly volatile, easily ignited, shorter carbon chains (small molecules).
Series of compounds which have the same general formula, have similar chemical properties, differ by CH in molecular formula form neighbouring molecules, slight variation in physical properties.

cards.term: Products from crude oil mostly belong to which homologous series?
cards.definition: Alkane homologous series.

cards.term: Products of complete combustion of hydrocarbon fuels
cards.definition: Water (HO) and carbon dioxide (CO).

cards.term: True or false? Energy is given out when a fuel undergoes complete combustion
cards.definition: TRUE. The reaction is exothermic.

cards.term: Balanced symbol equation for the complete combustion of ethane
cards.definition: 2CH + 7O  4CO + 6HO

cards.term: When does incomplete combustion occur? How to ensure complete combustion occurs?
cards.definition: Incomplete combustion occurs when there is an insufficient supply of oxygen. To ensure complete combustion occurs, the reaction should be carried out with excess oxygen.
Carbon particulates (soot), carbon monoxide (CO), water (HO).

cards.term: Balanced symbol equation for the incomplete combustion of methane to form carbon monoxide
cards.definition: 2CH + 3O  2CO + 4HO

cards.term: Balanced symbol equation for the incomplete combustion of methane to form carbon particulates
cards.definition: CH + O  C + 2HO
Carbon monoxide is a toxic gas. It is colorless and odorless and if breathed in can cause death by preventing the red blood cells from carrying oxygen around the body.
Produces carbon monoxide which is toxic and can be fatal if breathed in. Produces carbon particulates (soot) which cause global dimming and respiratory problems.

cards.term: Why is sulfur dioxide sometimes produced when burning hydrocarbon fuels?
cards.definition: Some hydrocarbon fuels contain sulfur impurities. When the fuel is burned, the sulfur reacts with oxygen to form sulfur dioxide.
Sulfur dioxide (produced when combusting impure hydrocarbon fuels) evaporates into the air. It reacts with water in the clouds to form sulfuric acid. This is 'acid rain'.
Corrodes buildings and statues made of limestone. Kills/damages the vegetation. Lowers the pH of large bodies of water, killing the wildlife.

cards.term: How are oxides of nitrogen produced from car engines?
cards.definition: The high temperature and pressure of a car engine cause nitrogen and oxygen from the air to react together.

cards.term: Problems associated with oxides of nitrogen
cards.definition: Pollutants. Produce acid rain with similar effects as sulfur dioxide. Cause respiratory problems.

cards.term: Advantages of using hydrogen as a fuel in cars
cards.definition: Releases more energy per kg compared to most other fuels. Water is the only product so no pollutants. Renewable source as hydrogen can be extracted from water.

cards.term: Disadvantages of using hydrogen as a fuel in cars
cards.definition: Expensive to produce and a lot of energy is required for the electrolysis of water to acquire the hydrogen. Difficult and dangerous to store hydrogen because it is very volatile and easily ignites.

cards.term: Non-renewable fossil fuel found in natural gas
cards.definition: Methane

cards.term: Are petrol, kerosene and diesel renewable fuels?
cards.definition: No, they are non-renewable. They are finite resources which are not being readily replaced.
Breaking down large hydrocarbons into smaller more useful ones. Saturated alkanes are cracked into shorter chain alkanes and short chain unsaturated alkenes.
Saturated - only contains single bonds. Unsaturated - contains some C=C double bonds.
Thermal decomposition.
The demand for shorter chain alkenes and alkanes is much greater than the demand for long chain alkanes.

cards.term: What produced the gases that formed Earth's early atmosphere?
cards.definition: Volcanic activity
Initially, the Earths surface was molten with no atmosphere. Cooling caused land masses to solidify. Volcanoes formed on the land masses and released gases which formed the early atmosphere.
Little or no oxygen. Large amount of carbon dioxide. Water vapor. Small amounts of other gases.
Condensation of water vapor.

cards.term: How the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere decreased after oceans formed
cards.definition: Carbon dioxide dissolved into the oceans so the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere decreased.

cards.term: How the amount of oxygen in the early Earths atmosphere increased
cards.definition: The growth of early plants used carbon dioxide for photosynthesis and released oxygen. This increased the amount of oxygen and decreased the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
Insert a glowing splint into a test tube of gas. If oxygen is present, the splint will ignite.
Various gases in the atmosphere (such as carbon dioxide, methane and water vapor) that absorb the heat radiated from Earth.

Electromagnetic radiation from the sun passes through the Earths atmosphere. The Earth absorbs some radiation and warms up. Heat is radiated from the Earth as infrared radiation. Some of the infrared radiation is absorbed by greenhouse gases in the atmosphere which warms the atmosphere.

cards.term: How human activity increased atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration
cards.definition: Burning fossil fuels for energy releases carbon dioxide. Deforestation reduces the amount of photosynthesis occurring so less carbon dioxide is converted to oxygen.

cards.term: Evidence that human activity is causing climate change
cards.definition: There is a correlation between carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere, fossil fuel consumption and temperature change. Correlation doesnt mean causation. There may be uncertainties in the data (e.g. location of the measurements and historical accuracy).
Nitrogen - 78%, Oxygen - 21%, Argon - 0.93%, Carbon - 0.04%
Melting of polar ice caps. Difficulties acquiring drinking water. Flooding. Forest fires. Destruction of ecosystems.

cards.term: How human activity increased the amount of methane in the atmosphere
cards.definition: Raising livestock such as cows. Decay of organic waste in landfill sites.

cards.term: Ways to mitigate the effects of global warming
cards.definition: Construct flood defenses in areas of low lying land. Use of irrigation systems to provide water in drought. Produce alternative crops which are better adapted to the new environment.
A charged atom, molecule or particle.

cards.term: Why must a test for a specific ion be unique?
cards.definition: Tests are used to identify ions and must be unique so that the test gives an easily observed result which is specific to the ion that is present.

cards.term: Describe how you would carry out a flame test to test for ions
cards.definition:
- Clean a nichrome wire using hydrochloric acid.
- Turn the Bunsen burner onto the blue flame.
- Dip the wire in a solution of the substance being tested.
- Place the wire in the flame and record the colour.

cards.term: What is the result of the flame test on lithium ions?
cards.definition: Crimson flame

cards.term: What is the result of the flame test on sodium ions?
cards.definition: Yellow flame

cards.term: What is the result of the flame test on potassium ions?
cards.definition: Lilac flame

cards.term: What is the result of the flame test on calcium ions?
cards.definition: Orange-red flame

cards.term: What is the result of the flame test on copper ions?
cards.definition: Blue-green flame

cards.term: Why must the wire be cleaned before carrying out a flame test?
cards.definition: To remove any unwanted ions that might obscure the colour of the flame.

cards.term: Why can a flame test not be used when a compound contains a mixture of metal ions?
cards.definition: The flame colours of the ions will blend together so the individual flame colours won't be seen meaning the ions cant be identified.
An insoluble solid suspended in a liquid.

cards.term: Without using the flame test, how can you test for aqueous metal ions?
cards.definition: Add sodium hydroxide solution to the metal ions. Observe the colour of the precipitate.

cards.term: What colour precipitate forms when sodium hydroxide reacts with calcium ions?
cards.definition: White

cards.term: What colour precipitate forms when sodium hydroxide reacts with copper(II) ions?
cards.definition: Blue

cards.term: What colour precipitate forms when sodium hydroxide reacts with iron(II) ions?
cards.definition: Green

cards.term: What colour precipitate forms when sodium hydroxide reacts with iron(III) ions?
cards.definition: Brown

cards.term: What colour precipitate forms when sodium hydroxide reacts with aluminium ions?
cards.definition:
White (initially)

With excess NaOH, the precipitate re-dissolves to form a colourless solution.

cards.term: What is observed when sodium hydroxide reacts with ammonium ions?
cards.definition: A pungent smelling gas is produced (NH3) which will turn damp red litmus paper blue.
